row.Body: No offense to the 1.0 site owner, I know they put in time and money to get their sites going, but does this mean that the 2.0 site is basically just onstartups moved to the 2.0 platform? Are we stuck with this domain name, logo, etc?
row.Title: So are we stuck with onstartups as the name and logo?

row.Body: I like it because its easy for me to find. Obviously the site is not stuck though because it can be moved to another URL.

Is it ok for users to answer a question with their own services? An example in the question below.

Video for demonstrating concept

If not allowed, how should the community handle these?
row.Title: Are users allowed to suggest their own services?

row.Body:
IMVHO, it should be allowed providing:

  1. The suggestion adds value to the answer, rather than a shameless plug. There must be enough additional information to earn the plug.
  2. Users should state they are plugging their own service, so the asker can assess it in an objective way as they expect

As it is a business, and a startup-based QA site, we can't slap anyone too hard for acting in the best interest of their own business ... providing they balance that with the interests of the community too!

Answers.onstartups.com is 100% a Stack Exchange Network site. The owners have agreed to turn over ownership of the site and to keep the same domain name to provide a seamless experience for the existing users. But it is operating on our servers and it is a fully-fledged product of Stack Exchange just like any other SE site.

A similar agreement was reached with Basically Money. Wherever possible, we are working with the Stack Exchange 1.0 sites that have created successful communities. Generally, it is better to bring them into the Stack Exchange Network rather than shutting them down or creating competing sites. The more people we get together in one place, the better the site will be.

The logo and URL/Google ranking is a windfall to this community. I don't know how much you want to call that "being stuck" with thousands of posts and users it brings into the fold.

Right now the list of sites at stackexchange.com/sites has this for answers.onstartups.com:

Q&A for startups

So, please suggest a better description here and I'll make sure it gets updated!

Note: to fit with all the other descriptions, it should be in the form of "Q&A for..."
row.Title: Suggest a better description for this site!

row.Body:
How about if we base it on the description from the original proposal:

Q&A for entrepreneurs looking to start or run a new business.

As Aiden pointed out, I think it is perfectly acceptable as long as it adds value.

Before answers.onstartups officially became part of the SE network, we didn't have a meta site, so meta questions were asked on the site itself. A similar question was previously asked (on the site itself, probably why you didn't find it). Please see Meta: Is advertising / updates allowed here? to get a better understanding of what the community has agreed upon.

You may also find these other questions helpful/useful:

  • Meta: What is considered Spam
  • Meta: Voting Down

As a side note: As a long time answers.onstartups member, I'm happy to see that moving to SE has brought us new members. But I really hope that new members respect the existing community culture. We have very relaxed guidelines on what questions can be asked (and self promotion in questions/answers). I would hate to see that welcoming feeling the site has go away. Wil, thanks so much for asking!
I'm just curious what is startups.com and will it continue to operate in parallel with onstartups or will be merged?
row.Title: How onstartups relate to startups.com?

row.Body:
startups.com is a completely different community, and I really hope they don't merge them with us.

Several months back I created a profile on startups.com, and began participating. But I was quickly turned off by the site, and after about a week I stopped going to the site. The quality of the questions and answers on startups.com is terrible. I was amazed at some of the questions that were being asked and even more so that they were getting upvoted. A majority of the questions were either really amateurish, or really badly phrased and required more details to answer properly. For example two questions I still remember are: Where can I buy books? and How can I beat the competition?. I expect to see some questions like that on all sites (including answers.onstartups.com), but it says a lot about the quality of the site when most of the questions are of that caliber.

The quality of the answers was just as bad. There were a lot of answers that were getting upvotes that were completely wrong. And I'm not talking about subjective answers where I had a different opinion, I'm talking about indisputable facts that were stated incorrectly!

It appears as though startups.com has more users than answers.onstartups.com, but I'm not so sure that is really the case. There is some suspicion that startups.com users create various accounts to populate their site and vote each other up.

Like I said, I haven't been to startups.com in several months, so it's totally possible that things have changed over there. But if the quality is still the same, I think merging them with us is a big mistake, and will only bring down the quality of our site. I vote to keep them as a separate community.

That's just my opinion/experience, others may feel differently.

Update: startups.com is finally shutting down.

I agree that the description, and maybe even the name itself is unclear.

Does "startups" even apply to small business Q&A; or does small business deserve a separate site?

I equate the term "startup" with high-growth Silicon Valley dot-com bubble venture capital-seeking businesses and their ilk... I'm a freelance developer and I feel like what I do is the opposite of "startup": it's about steady and sustainable business, not investment, high growth, acquisition, and the other things associated with startups.

So, mostly because of the "startup" name, I wonder if this is even the right place for my questions. Who is the focus of this site?

I have a biased opinion here (since I'm the guy behind OnStartups.com), but I think that having an existing, active set of great users is good for the community overall. Small price to pay for reusing an existing domain and branding.

Not sure if people have been following WebApps site, but some big controversy over there about the decision to name all 2.0 sites xxx.stackexchange.com vs individual names. Since we've got a name already, how does that effect this site? Have they talked to dharmesh already?

Reference meta thread on WebApps

http://meta.webapps.stackexchange.com/questions/624/webapps-stackexchange-com-versus-nothingtoinstall-com
row.Title: How will the new decision on StackExchange 2.0 site naming effect onstartups?

row.Body:
Tagline displayed at top of every page:

Welcome to the new answers.onstartups.com! This site is a part of OnStartups.com, a blog on entrepeneurship by Dharmesh Shah.

Community-driven or self-promoting?

With all due respect to Mr Shah's efforts in promoting this community, does this tagline contribute to Answers.OnStartups.com and its perceived value as a community-driven website or does it detract legitimacy by coming across as self-promoting?

If it does add value, is it necessary to display it on every page? And should newcomers looking for answers to their questions be interested in Dharmesh Shah as one of the most prominent links shown on every page?

To be honest, I would be less impessed with StackOverflow if every question page started with something like:

Welcome to StackOverflow.com, the most popular programming website in the world! This site is a community-driven questions & answers site for programmers, an independent Fog Creek spin-off with hosting sponsored by Peak Internet.

Since the logo clearly says "Answers.OnStartups.com", is it really necessary to put in the tagline again, on every page?
row.Title: Perception of tagline on every page

row.Body:
At the end of the day, I don't think it will affect the community of Answers.OnStartups.com. Much.

Depending on where that ugly discussion goes, it could stay the way it is (which I think is most likely) or it could revert to startups.stackexchange.com or something like startups.se.com, depending on the branding of the network.

Would like to hear Dharmesh's thoughts on this, too.

No offense to Dharmesh, but I would like to see the site go to startups.stackexchange.com. I think it would gain more exposure and trust from users, so that they know for sure it a stackexchange site.

I still wonder if my information can be seen by onstartups.com.

Joel will be blogging about the elevator pitch approach to naming. This site did not go through the domain naming and voting, but we still need an elevator pitch. So this is to get you started:

We need a killer "elevator pitch!"

The Elevator Pitch

This isn't as easy as it sounds. Imagine the user who will never read your FAQ and you have two seconds to grab their attention. It should be catchy but descriptive. It should be thoroughly clear but painfully concise. Make every... word... count.

Here are some creative examples:

  • Gawker: Daily Manhattan media news and gossip. Reporting live from the center of the universe.
  • Gizmodo: The gadget guide. So much in love with shiny new toys, it’s unnatural.
  • Autoblog: We obsessively cover the auto industry.
  • DumbLittleMan: So what do we do here? Well, it’s simple. 15 to 20 times per week we provide tips that will save you money, increase your productivity, or simply keep you sane.
  • Needcoffee.com: We are the Internet equivalent of a triple espresso with whipped cream. Mmmm…whipped cream.

Use it as a Tagline

A shorter elevator pitch can be used as a tagline — something you can display in the header at the top of the page. If it doesn't fit, consider shortening it or creating a separate tagline. Here are some great examples:

  • Slashdot: News for nerds. Stuff that matters.
  • Lifehacker: Don’t live to geek, geek to live!
  • The Simple Dollar: Financial talk for the rest of us.

The Motto (don't forget your logo)

A logo begs for its own little, short tagline — like a motto. Maybe the tagline inspires the logo; Maybe it's the other way around. Mottos make good t-shirt, bumper stickers, and other marketing material. Either way, you'll recognize a good motto when you see it:

  • Just do it.
  • Think Different.
  • The Uncola.
  • Intel inside.
  • Like a rock.
  • The king of beers.

…and perhaps all this leads to a proper name and domain for your site… eventually. So let's start from the basics. Come up with a killer elevator pitch, tagline, and/or motto!
row.Title: Write an Elevator Pitch / Tagline

row.Body: Isn't that the super tag of everything?
row.Title: why is there a startups tag?

row.Body:
I recently asked a question about tax implications for buying my partner out. Seeing as this is specific to

  1. My startup
  2. U.S. Tax law

it seems that I should add a United-States tag.
row.Title: Why aren't there country tags?

row.Body:
I'm looking at this proposal: Area 51: Business Buzzwords and Lingo.

Would potential questions on that site be welcomed here?

If so, please vote to close. Please discuss.
row.Title: Are "Business Buzzwords and Lingo" inquiries on topic?

row.Body:
There are some country tags, although not a lot of them. There is a United States tag, but it's labeled usa.

The country tags that I am aware of are:

  • usa
  • uk
  • canada
  • india
  • foreign (I think this tag was created in the very beginning when most users were from the US.)

However, most people include the country information in the question itself if it is relevant. Honestly, I wouldn't rely on just the tag because tags are easy to overlook. My recommendation would be to always include your country in any question that is tax or country related, in addition to the tag.

If you feel other country tags should be created, add it here (with a link to the relevant question) and I (or someone else) will add it.

Good question.

There is also a startup tag. When I first came to this site both tags already existed. This is how I interpreted them:

The startup tag: Is specific to a particular startup. For example, if I'm associated with ABC startup, and I post a question related to ABC startup, then I would use the startup tag.

The startups tag: General to all startups. Although this is a "startups" Q&A site, not all questions have to be directly tied to startups.

Edit: I've since come to believe that these tags were created without any thought being given to them. I don't think there was an intended purpose for them.

You might not be aware of it but the domain name, the logo and brand in general was the property of Dharmesh Shah. He "donated it" to Stack Exchange, I think it is OK to have a link to his blog in every page when you consider he is the one who created this community. I don't think any of the members of the original Answers.OnStartups community will disagree with me.

I don't think those questions would be a good fit for this site. It would be okay to get those type of questions every now and then, but I don't think it would be a good idea to fill this site with those type of questions.

The questions on this site are mostly focused on the execution of startups, not the terminology. In fact, I'm guessing very few of us are qualified to answer questions like "what is the origin of X?", unless they are recently coined terms.

I think the proposed English Language and Usage SE site is a better fit.

Throughout the beta, we need members from the site whose focus is to engage the community, both in community-building issues and site management. That's why we select a few members from each community to act as temporary, provisional Moderators. You can read about the program here: Moderators Pro Tempore.

I am pleased to announce that these members have stepped up and generously volunteered their time to help us assure that each community’s issues are properly addressed:


We want to make this site a huge success, and these members are great examples of exactly the type of people we need to make this site succeed. Please welcome them for the hard work and time they contribute.

Did I overlook anyone?

Almost certainly. There are members who are actively involved and very deserving of recognition. My failure to account for everyone this early on is in no way a slight against them. Ideally, Moderators are elected by the community and that's why you'll have your elections after the Beta period.

Most of all, be respectful and understanding of the Moderators Pro Tem. Members of your community are volunteering their time and learning on the job. It’s a learning experience for everyone.

EDIT: Please welcome your two newest mods!
row.Title: Moderator Pro Tem Announcement

row.Body:
I am new to onstartups, but I do like seeing thoughtful, genuinely helpful vendor responses on Twitter, LinkedIn answers, and social networks; so long as they are engaged with the community more on non-promotional topics than self-promotional topics. If someone just trolls for leads and posts plugs, that would be rude, and it does happen in any social forum online, but regulars notice and spammers get identified because they are so eager to over-promote themselves.

What I think is a more likely form of spam (and harder to single out and take down) is when the spammer is the question asker. They might never develop the repeat pattern of behavior to get flagged as spam, so their advertisement for their site/product will remain for a long time and continue to get views. Webmaster and seo forums get that type of spam often.

I'm surprised people aren't clever enough to wrap their plug in a more specific question like (check out my login/sign-up process, does it seem difficult to you? We have had complaints and wish to improve the process, etc.). It's not hard to do, but the annoying mark of a spammer is how little effort they put into blending their message into anything the audience cares about. :/
I'm researching the feasibility of a product I'm building. I would like the feedback of people on here, but I'm not sure if it's appropriate to ask. Is it?
row.Title: I have a question, but it's related to some research I'm doing - is it OK to ask?

row.Body:
Currently we have a tax tag and a taxes tag.

  1. What is the difference between the two?
  2. Should we merge these tags?

Update: Based on the response, I made the tax tag and the taxes tag synomyns, and merged them.
row.Title: What is the difference between the 'tax' tag and the 'taxes' tag?

row.Body:
Hi Matt,

What people suggest on some of the other Stack Exchange sites I've visited is you should just ask anyway and be thick skinned about what happens.

The worst thing that could happen is people vote it down, but usually the community only do that if you are deliberately spamming or being argumentative.

So ask away. The more specific you are the better. If you have lots of ideas / questions try and break them down into several more definitive questions that can be answered.

Many people have already asked for feedback on ideas and usually receive good honest answers.

Zuly,

The difference between the two tags is confusing enough that the question had to be asked. For a regular user they are not likely to bother to think twice. I would suggest making taxes a synonym of tax.

You might already know this, but...

With Stack Exchange sites once you reach 2500 reputation you can suggest and vote on tag synonyms.

See http://meta.answers.onstartups.com/tags/tags/synonyms

and http://meta.answers.onstartups.com/tags/synonyms

Having synonyms means that the extraneous tag won't be recreated and it's answer will automatically be associated with the remaining tag. Also the correct version will be presented to the user in the tag autosearch if they try to enter the synonym.

Let's say a user is spamming by answering every question with a link to his site. What is the proper action for the moderators? An e-mail warning? Suspend the account for a day? We probably need some consistency among moderators. This must be addressed somewhere already. Are we aligning with stackoverflow, for instance?

Let's discuss.
row.Title: How do moderators decide punishment based on the user behavior?

row.Body:
We've had a few posts related to people looking for business partners or co-founders. Examples:

  • Looking for co-founder: Brisbane, Australia
  • We are passionate about building tech startup
  • Looking for a co-founder

How should we treat these posts? Are they on topic, or off topic?

My personal take is that they are off topic. This is a Q&A site, and so I think the minimum requirement for any question is that it actually be a question. I see these posts more like "wanted" ads. I wouldn't consider these posts to be spam. And I think the posters have a genuine need. But I don't consider this site to be the right place for these posts.

It would be great to get a community consensus on this. Please share your thoughts.
row.Title: Are "Co-founders wanted" posts on topic?

row.Body:
The meta site gave me a great idea. I think that this software for asking questions regarding the back end of the site is great. It's great for providing feedback and fostering a healthy discussion for the net benefit of all that use the site.

Don't you think that this would be great if developers were able to use this Q&A system as a method of collecting feedback on their own site?

Just a thought...
row.Title: Can this meta software be used on other sites?

row.Body:
I think it's off-topic if it says "I'm looking for a co-founder".

But if it's a question such as "where do I find a co-founder in Brisbane", it sounds legit: a correct answer could include local meetups and other events.

Unfortunately, we no longer offer a subscription service or license the software to host private Stack Exchange sites. The only way to create a Stack Exchange site is to go through the democratic, community-driven process at Area 51. You can read more about that process here: Area 51: FAQ.

Direct solicitations for any sort of business relationship is definitely off topic for this site. The top off-topic questions from the original charter/proposal:

  • What do you think about my idea to start [ an online copyright venture ] ?
  • Is anyone interested in investing in my startup?
  • Employees <of any given type> wanted for <any given startup>. Will you work for us?

... they all define the same basic issue: direct solicitations for business relationships are not on topic for this site. This site is about start-ups. Not a resource to solicit business or partnerships.

There is no hard and fast "guidelines to punishment" on these sites. The problem is so statistically rare, that we prefer to take a more hands-on, human approach to dealing with other members of the site.

The first line of defense — if that's what you want to call it — lies within the community-self moderation working alongside the system behaviors. Unwelcomed or ill-advised content is most often dealt with through down-voting and flagging. That typically takes care of the vast, vast majority of problems.

Failing that, I prefer moderators to handle the "human exception" on their individual merits (or demerits). Was the intention of the user malicious or is it a simple misunderstanding? First, Moderators (and users) should point out the problems through comments on the site, so everyone benefits from the advice. Next, perhaps, a personal email message to discuss the issue followed by warnings. If it the problems continue, then a short suspension might be warranted. If the situation persists, suspension periods can be increased. Permanent suspensions and IP bans have happened but are exceedingly rare.

In the past 24 hours there were two questions that were just requests for feedback on someones site.

http://answers.onstartups.com/questions/15904/looking-for-feedback-on-our-website

http://answers.onstartups.com/questions/15900/provide-feedback-on-playtictacphoto-com

Both users who asked the question only have one rep point, based on other SE sites this means they are less likely to return to the site (based on them logging on, asking a single question and not participating in any other activity).

Although the two questions above will likely receive some response from the great people that use this site, but ultimately I feel that these sorts of questions will become repetitive and just filler content amongst better questions. Which is ultimately harmful to the community.

This site has a couple of specific issues that are unique to a startups site: feedback and advertising.

Many people who come to this site have a project that they would like feedback on. Also, many people have services or products that they would like to advertise.

It would be good if the nice folks running this site could come up with a solution for these types of questions. I would suggest a separate part of this site to post these kinds of feedback or advertisement type questions (similar to careers).

I then suggest that these questions be closed as noise as they distract from the main point of this and other SE sites, to build a top quality, searchable repository of knowledge.
row.Title: Should we allow "Please give me feedback on my site | business plan | startup idea" questions?

row.Body: My suggestion is to keep it as it is - "Q&A for startups" it is simple and clear, do not try to make it better by adding more words (noise) to it.

I have found many questions and some answers that were clearly SPAM, and every time I do I get points deducted from my reputation score... why?

I understand we don't want people to go around voting down questions and answers as they wish but wouldn't be better to just make it required to add a comment every time you vote down a question or answer?
row.Title: Why do people get "punished" when they vote down a question or answer?

row.Body:
This is to put the emphasis on up-voting. Good content should be voted up; the rest, no vote at all. Down-voting should be reasonably rare and should give you pause.

Down-voting doesn't cost much (to the voter nor the recipient) but it is still taken personally. We didn't want a system where the user felt it was correct to issue a +1 or a -1 on each question they voted on.

The -1 rep to down-vote is a tiny disincentive, but just enough to send out the message that over-use of down-voting is discouraged.

If you see something that is obviously spam, my suggestion is to flag it as spam instead of down-voting.

When you flag something as spam, three things happen:

  1. The question (or answer) gets an automatic down vote, but it does not cost the flagger any rep.
  2. The flagged item shows up in the moderators dashboard, so it is handled much quicker by the moderators.
  3. A countdown begins on that item. If enough people downvote that item, it is automatically closed by the software, without the need for moderator intervention.

As a side note: I do think people should leave a comment if they downvote something. It helps everyone.
What is a "tumbleweed" badge? Is that an equivalent to Charlie Brown getting a rock on Halloween?
row.Title: What is the tumbleweed badge?

row.Body: The tumbleweed badge is awarded when a question is asked with no answers, no comments, and low views for a week. Basically, it's for a question with very little action/interest.

This site is in beta, but I see no one with the beta badge... Is it never assigned to this site or do they get assigned after it comes out of beta?

Just revisiting this - the tag above the title of the site says 'beta' - so, again, why no beta badges?
row.Title: When are the beta badges awarded?

row.Body:
The Beta badges are only awarded for participation in the private beta, that is, those people who joined during the commit phase of an Area 51 site.

I wasn't around when they switched this site over from SE 1.0 to SE 2.0, so I don't know if there was a private beta.

I doubt it as nobody here has a Beta badge.

Just a bit of background on why the badge exists.

To quote Jeff (who helped found / build / write) these sites:

Tumbleweed — a consolation prize for asking a question that gets almost no attention (no answers, no comments, low pageviews for a week). It says “sorry, we failed you — but keep trying”

Here are some links:

http://meta.stackoverflow.com/questions/1576/what-is-the-purpose-of-the-tumbleweed-badge

http://meta.stackoverflow.com/questions/47369/is-the-tumbleweed-badge-good-or-bad

Yeah I think you maybe right though the site seems to me to be more about small business rather then just the starting of the business. If it was just starting up, then everyone at the site would be new and listening to someone who started a company 7 years ago and about to sell it might be missed.

I think your overall correct though because any startup activity should be so named from planning, getting capital, marketing etc... its all a part of the start up.

So +1 on the elimination of the tag.

You will also notice a few things once you have a reasonable amount of rep:

  1. You can vote to close those questions (3000 rep required), so you don't need to worry about downvoting them see http://answers.onstartups.com/privileges for more info about this privilege.

  2. You won't really care about the small loss of rep because you will be earning considerable amounts of rep from your existing answers (even from people discovering and voting up past answers this will be worth some rep gain each day).

The system has been well thought through and well discussed. It favors those who are active and work to promote the site.

If you have more rep it is easier for you to get rid of those annoying or obvious spam questions.

For now flag the posts as spam, or requires mod. attention. I'm doing the same thing with these questions. The better the quality of questions and answers, the better the system, the more we can attract good quality people.

In the early days of a site it's frustrating, but give it a couple of months and we can have 20 or so regulars with enough rep to start closing questions.

So here is my go at it. Thanks.

Name:
Business Startup

Elevator
Get and provide experienced insight on forming a business from reputable scored sources.

Tagline
Build business from 2.0 experience.

Motto
Ask, answer and know.

I'm hoping someone from Stack Exchange can comment on how things will work when deciding the final look of the site.

I wasn't around when this was a SE 1.0 site. Are the orange/blue color of the onstartups logo set in stone?

Will the tagline be staying?

Is there anything the community will be involved in since the logo and domain have already been picked?
row.Title: What are the current plans for site design and timing

row.Body:
Over the past few days there have been several (too many) questions of the type:

"How much money should I pay X to come on board."

Examples are:

How much equity to give a developer for a MVP

How much equity should I give an advisor

How much equity should I give a CEO

How much salary should a founder get

I suggest the moderators close these types of questions. Because they have no sensible answer and provide no benefit to the community.
row.Title: Should we close questions about equity / salary as noise or pointless?

row.Body:
I request moderators remove the ask-onstartups tag and retag any questions that have this tag. It's a meta tag that doesn't mean anything.

It would be a good idea to remove this tag and lock it while the site is still small.
row.Title: Remove / tidy ask-onstartups tag from all questions and delete

row.Body:
Near the end of the beta period (When will my site graduate?), Jin will start presenting designs for the site to solicit ideas and feedback. I don't know what he has in mind for the design but nothing is set in stone.

The placement and content of the tagline is temporary. The final design will have a better integration of that information into the design of the site. Using the system message is a temporary measure.

I would like to see more involvement in the development and governance of this site, but OnStartups consistently has the lowest participation (by far) of any of the meta sites.

I respectfully disagree though I follow your thoughts. Compensation and equity calculations are in academic settings, they are a legitmate question and a topic that a startup often need to address. This is one of the few places where collecting that type of information is possible.

We happen to research quite a bit, fortunately we have some bookworms in our group. We have some articles and such that maybe of help, excerpts and blog posts that we found particularly useful. Where would be an appropriate area to post some of this data? We are sure it would be of use to some start ups. I tried to log into META but couldn't??? maybe someone can relocate this as needed. :)

example http://venturesocially.tumblr.com/post/1235792139/creatinganeffectiveelevatorpitch

http://www.bothsidesofthetable.com/2010/10/06/the-four-main-things-that-investors-look-for-in-a-startup/
row.Title: Resources to share but where?

row.Body:
Hi XS,

This type of question has been asked previously on other Stack Exchange sites.

If you have some really good resources you would like to share the best way to get this out is to think of a really good title for you question and post it as a question.

Examples of a good question of this type:

Do you have any helpful links that assist in creating an elevator pitch?

Do you have any links to material that for creating a startup?

etc.

If you post it as a question it allows others to provide their helpful materials.

Try not to make the question to general. If your materials aren't related then create multiple questions. The community can then decide which question(s) to support.

This will also help for Google searches. With a clear, concise question people will see this in search results and will be directed to a page full of good links to quality articles.
"Q&As on building / growing startups - because your mom won't tell you the truth"

I like "Get Answers To Your Startup Questions"

(From the original idea/website)
I am not sure closing them will be useful unless the close comes with a pointer to a FAQ/community wiki that basically says "It depends" and then provides all sorts of references.

Great question. I've been meaning to ask this myself.

I agree with you that the "feedback on my site/idea" questions are doing more harm to the community than good. They provide very little benefit to the community. I think these questions are off-topic and should be closed, but since the community hasn't come to a consensus on that I've been hesitant to close them. I would like to hear what others think about this as well.

That said, I do think it's fine to include a link to your site if it provides value to the community. It can be in a question to provide more background, so that the community can provide a better answer, or in an answer to suggest a tool that can solve a problem or a detailed blog post on a particular subject. Sometimes it's hard to tell if it's spam, but for the most part you can tell the difference. I'm a lot more accepting if the link comes from someone who actively participates on the site, than if it comes from "Mr. 1 rep" who answers 5 questions, all with links to his site.

I like your suggestion of having a different section of the site dedicated to website feedback type questions, but I'm not sure if that's possible. Maybe Robert can answer that for us?

I agree with John and Tim. I don't think closing them is the answer - although I do see your point. I think Tim's "sort of on topic" comment is right.

The truth is that it is almost impossible for anyone here to answer those questions accurately because we don't have all the information. However, we can give suggestions and discuss basic rule of thumb guidelines. This type of question will require professional advice, that no one here can possibly provide online, but a lot of the questions asked on this site are like that as well. Any accounting or legal question should always be followed up by the OP with professional advice. We are merely getting them started.

We have a lot of meta questions on the main portion of the site (see here) as a result of the 1.0 site not having a separate meta section. I would like to move all of those questions over here, and then delete the old meta tag.

Any thoughts?
row.Title: Moving Old 1.0 Meta Questions To Here

row.Body: It looks like it would be more beneficial to the community if we had one thread giving the best resources available to answer most of those questions. I agree with the fear that otherwise, we'll never see the end of it.

So far we have a good number of questions and answers coming in and a reasonable sized user base. The OnStartups site is one of the healthiest Stack Exchange sites that is currently in Beta, looking at our stats.

I would like to put a call out to encourage everyone to vote more. Each person can cast 30 up or down votes each day, so get out there and start voting.

Why is voting beneficial to this site and why should you bother:

  • Up-voting increases the visibility for those questions / answers that are good quality
  • Down-voting indicates to the community the type of questions that should not be asked
  • Up-voting encourages users to ask better questions because there is a larger reward for better quality questions
  • Up-voting encourages users to put more effort into answers
  • Up-voting increases participation in the site. If you are getting positive feedback you are likely to ask and answer more questions. This also is good for new user engagement.

Up-voting is a win-win situation for the community and for the asker/answerer. While down-voting is useful for discouraging certain types of questions and behaviors.

So please go out there and cast your votes often. I also suggest you read this post on voting at Stack Exchange sites.
row.Title: Please, please, please vote more

row.Body:
Hello

as if there were enough "action" on the startups website,
perfectly ok questions get closed down by administrators.

The site is already lacking members that are willing to pay
a visit or participate on the questions here.

Why the hell, did this question get closed by this member?

You know what, it is disturbing enough that messages get closed,
but this is really disgusting.

People could have been ASKED before something get's closed down,
with a single girls vote.

This is no game. We are all trying to achieve something here.
Not reputation or badges, we try to achieve success.

What in the world, does closing a question, just because of someone
wants to earn 2 point reputation, bring to this community?

If you treat people like this, this can have huuge negative impact on the
rules and the site itself.

Sad sad sad.

EDIT:

My question is not startup related? This question is startup related?
Why not close such questions too? People advertise their own business on
a stackexchange site, and when it comes to asking something, it get's
closed?

SAD, SAD, SAD.
row.Title: As if there was enough participation

row.Body:
I have to 100% disagree with your assertion that this is about reputation or the inappropriate action of one person.

The questions was completely off topic and should have been closed. This site is for questions about start-up businesses, not to make travel arrangements. If your question was "an affordable place to stay for a dog show", would we even be having this conversation? Of course not.

The whole point of these sites is to form a community around specific topics. There’s nothing more toxic to a community than not being able to set boundaries around it; To define what it is, and is not. This is not a travel site. Your question was asking about making travel arrangements. The Moderator had every right and the responsibility to close that question.

I'm sorry your first experience on this site was not a positive one. That's okay. It happens. You are free to ask questions but all we ask is that it be on topic for the site. That did not happen in this case, and it was handled appropriately. Maintaining the quality and scope of the questions far outweighs the quantity of questions needed to make this site a success… by far.

As for your "EDIT:" That post was intended as an announcement to the community, long before this site had its own meta section. Now that we have a place for such meta posts, announcements of that nature would typically take place here.
+1 for the action.

Your question got my vote. Snicker.

Oh and your point has merit as well.
Second the request.
Great selection and looking forward to the site improving and growing.
Sometimes I can't answer a question but I want to keep track of it so I can read the responses. Is there a way I can do this on here?
row.Title: Is there a way to "Watch a Question" on here?

row.Body: Yes, mark it as favorite by clicking on the little star located below the question's points. Then you can view all of your favorite questions under the tab "Favorites" in your profile.

There is an RSS feed for each question. You can find the link in the bottom right corner (the link is named question feed). The feed for this question is http://answers.onstartups.com/feeds/question/8372

I've noticed that highly-voted down questions, which I'm sure are correspondingly flagged as spam, are still left around. The problem seems to be getting worse, in part (I think) because it's not being corrected.

  • Example 1
  • Example 2
  • Example 3
  • Example 4

Those four are all within the past month. As OnStartups continues to grow, it'd be great to avoid the newest questions page get cluttered with things the community has clearly indicated they don't think are appropriate.

P.S. Thanks for all the things you have done to make OnStartups an awesome community.
row.Title: Ask Dharmesh / Jason: Why are spam questions not deleted?

row.Body:
No good reason. But, as was said by Tim, we're happy for any offers of help. :)

Meanwhile, we'll try to do better. Overall, I think the community's been doing great and most of the discussions are non-spammy. But, point well taken.

Edit - I'd like to revisit this question: After I posted this question I migrated a lot of questions over. I was expecting to see the previously accepted answers that were "unaccepted" during the migration to be automatically awarded again once both the asker and the person whose answer was accepted visited the meta site. But it looks like that is not happening. One example is the Ask Dharmesh/Jason question I linked to below. Do the answers have to be manually awarded again?

After getting positive feedback from this question, I started moving the old 1.0 site meta questions to this site. However, the questions are not migrating correctly. So far I've only moved these two questions:

  • Is there a way to “Watch a Question” on here?
  • Ask Dharmesh / Jason: Why are spam questions not deleted?

I've noticed two issues so far:

  1. Both of these questions had accepted answers, but after the migration, the answers are no longer checked as accepted.
  2. Some of the user profiles got messed up after the migration.

Does anyone know what the problem is? I'm going to hold off on moving the rest of the meta questions until I can get this resolved.
row.Title: Moving meta questions - not working perfectly

row.Body:
The answer to both of your questions is: the user doesn't exist on this site.

The answer to question 1:

See http://meta.stackoverflow.com/questions/15275/migrated-questions-losing-their-accepted-answers/48492#48492

Because the user whose answer you are "accepting" may not exist on the target site at the time of migration.

Votes is a close enough proxy to this, and you can accept answers on the target site all day long once you associate your account and own the migrated question.

In short, there are severe technical issues involved doing this "automatically", and the workaround is trivial (associate, own the question, and accept an answer).

The answer to question 2:

If a user exists in the parent site it doesn't mean they automatically exist in the meta site. Once you merge a question, if they don't have an account in the meta site there will be a disconnect and the question won't appear as belonging to that user, however...

If a user signs into the meta site at some point in the future and then links their meta account to their account from the parent site the question will automatically be claimed without them needing to do anything.

Herr, questions on the site, including yours, are closed for various reasons.

Your question was closed as off-topic, I would probably see this question sitting in the "too localized" category, which is another reason that moderators can close questions.

Too localized: This question would only be relevant to a small geographic area, a specific moment in time, or an extraordinarily narrow situation that is not generally applicable to the worldwide audience of the internet.

Closing of questions is not a personal attack and the aim is to improve the site overall by providing a site that has a good quality pool of questions where there is a definite answer to those questions.

I suggest anyone reading this question check out both the FAQ and this section of the FAQ the six guidelines for great subjective questions.

If you believe that your question was closed unreasonably then you can flag it for moderator attention and explain why you think it should be reopened.

Hi, I'm the one who closed your question. I'm sorry that you took it like that.

I closed it because it seemed off-topic, and was against a guideline which says questions shouldn't be too local in scope.

I know we have to strike the right balance between keeping an open platform where everyone feels welcome, and keeping discussions on-topic.

If we manage this balance properly, traffic will remain fine. Thanks for helping us find he right balance.

I was one of the early users of Stack Overflow (the granddaddy of the software that runs this site) and one of the things I notice here is that many people are contributing answers (which is good) but people don't seem to be voting for them (which is bad).

Let's encourage more participation by rewarding people who take the time to write good answers. Click that vote button!
row.Title: Why is there so little voting on this site?

row.Body: You need 15 rep to upvote. It took me a little while to get that... but I upvoted your question, so you'll be that much closer :-)
I am trying to upvote, but yeah we need more rep points ;)

Sorry folks. I don't agree with the 15 rep points to vote on things, but that's the default in the software and there's no way to change it.

So, it'll take a little while for enough people to accrue sufficient rep points (and thereby cause others to get the needed points too). The site's only two days old -- so hopefully within a few days, we'll be at a decent level of momentum.

OK, good point. I'll do more of that. This posting was useful in that I wasn't sure what the voting was about or why I should bother, so thanks for that.

Scott
I realized that you needed knew that you needed a certain amount of reputation to upvote so was worried that I could only upvote a limited number of times.

In addition to up-voting good questions and answers, I've also been a little more generous here up-voting people with only 1 or 11 reputation so they could get to the threshold of 15 that would enable them, in turn, to vote for others. You can find these people by looking at the user list, which is sorted by reputation.

So folks, please vote! The OP is right, the voting improves the experience with this platform.

UPDATE: I just used up my daily vote allotment again up-voting users with less than 15 rep who demonstrated at least a clue in asking/answering a question.

The reason why there is less vote here I reckon because some of the question is really subjective. This is quite different compared to stackoverflow where you can get one definite answer.

I think to make new users to be able to vote is to up-vote a question. That way new user will have some point in the bank.

I'm learning a lot from this site and would love to vote on some of the really excellent posts here, but I'm at a reputation of 1. If anybody would be so inclined to give me an upvote here I would be happy to start voting.

You can review my rep and voting on my SO page:

http://stackoverflow.com/users/116/mark-harrison
You also need a certain number of points to add new tags I see (is that 15 points as well?) which was slightly annoying as a question I just posted required a new tag.

Perhaps they need a way to get the point economy started. It is hard to value questions an answers when they all have 0 votes. Perhaps they could allow people to vote on question until a total of, say, 1000 point of rep are awarded.

I have been doing some poking around some of the StackExchange sites, as a long time StackOverflow user, I am not used to not being able to vote.

This site appears to have enough rep around to start to function like it is supposed to work. I know of a site where there is a net of 10 points earned and where the "Tumbleweed" is the most popular badge.

This question is old and for some (like me) the voting concept is new. Think about how many are not enmeshed in web2.0 like I guess you guys are - LOL. Plus At this point apparently I have a teacher badge and it says I should check my profile... um - some day I might. Plus to vote I have to login... again - some day :)

Great site though, Dharmesh - which is why I don't mind answering.

I would add that it's very useful for people to get many perspectives - not necessarily to have other people vote on previous answers for them (yet?). If the voting is truly helpful to you, you might want to communicate to everyone (say in a LinkedIn discussion - or even via a new question/answer here) why it's important to [go through the trouble and] vote.

Cheers
I also suffered the "couldn't create new tags" problem, so if anyone wishes to upvote this answer to give me new powers, feel free.

hahaha this is a great question. Congratulations Dennis!

Now more seriously. I know that it would be nice to have more positive votes, but scarcity sometimes is what makes good stuff more valuable. So my answer is about moderation. I do want people to vote, but at the same time, I want people to vote ONLY for what they HONESTLY believe is a good answer. Otherwise, everybody´s reputation will be artificially inflated and therefore useless (pretty much like grades in grad school).

There are a number of posts about this on meta.stackexchange.com - see, for instance, this one. I would post links to others but as a newbie I'm limited to one/message. Hmm...

Interestingly, another StackExchange-based startup-oriented site I just started poking around in (startups.com) has exactly the same problem. Worse yet, some people have given me great answers for my questions there, and I can't vote for them!

Does anyone have experience with other Q&A sites? Is this particular to the ones focused on start-ups (perhaps because the questions asked tend to be more subjective and have no right answer), or is it just a function of age? Terribly ironic if communities of people distinguished by their ability to get new companies off the ground are not getting, well, the community off the ground...

I am in the same boat with only 1 point. I posted a few answers already. And I feel they deserve at least a point each :)

See here: http://answers.onstartups.com/users/2694/bill-paetzke

Apologies to Dharmesh and Jason if this question is inappropriate and should get kaboshed. If it disappears I guess I'll know. But I'm curious about future enhancements to this site. Both what's planned and what us users would like to see. I don't know how development is done with this site but figured I'd ask.

Personally, I'd love to see:

  • Ability to email individual users privately. At times there are people I'd love to contact but don't want to put my email address or theirs in an answer.

  • Would love the ability to post example files so we could all benefit. Sample marketing plan, business plan, project schedule...whatever.

There are others I can think of but I'll just toss those two out because I've thought of them many times.
row.Title: Future enhancements for Answers.OnStartups.com? What would you like to see?

row.Body:
There are enhancements that would make using the site a little easier. A couple that come to mind include:

  • An edited references page that has the common questions and answers (highest votes) so users can look through it before posted a question or expanding upon one.
  • A templates section, similar to the references page, for files, etc. (as Chris mentioned)
  • A private message queue to send notes/comments to individual users.
  • Ability to promote comments into the main question or response.

Every now and then I see questions from people who either don't bother to register [unknown (google)] or with something like gggaaaaaaa as their name. They're asking the community to give up their time and knowledge and don't have the courtesy to share a little about themselves.

I realize that some questions are a bit sensitive like "How do I quit my job and start a company" but you should at least put in your first name and give some general information about yourself. For non-sensitive questions, the more information you can give, the better the answers are likely to be.

Personally, I'm much more likely to answer a question asked by a properly registered user...
row.Title: Why do people expect good answers when they don't register properly?

row.Body:
The option of anonymity is a good thing in my opinion.

Forced registration killed one of the best forums on the web in my opinion - Joel on Software.

Plus here, we have the requirement for OpenID, which is also a barrier to signing up. (Why do I need to go Wordpress.com to log in to this site anyway?)

New registers often dont know how to use the OpenID system. Instead of complaining, why not teach them how to use the system and input their information? I dont think their not registering properly is because they dont care, obviously they care enough to be here, register, and post a question. Lets help new users out...

For new users: if you use your google account or OpenID, go back to your profile page and input your information so that all of us can get to know you better. that is the point of this website is it not :P.

I'm glad you post this topic :)
I really want to use my real pic, not some green fractal, but my gravatar doesn't work here :( It's OK with other forums though.
May be other people just have the same problems with open-id system and gravatar?

I have the gravatar problem for a long time. But registered another gravatar account and this seems to resolve the problem. I am very technically proficient, but all this OpenID and gravatar technology puzzled me from time to time and I can imagine how it is incomprehensible for most people.

The concept was started on StackOverflow.com which is geared toward computer programmers. Their goal is to judge questions and answers on their merit. If I find the solution to a problem, I'm not that concerned with who asked and/or answered. Also, I can run your code to see if it works.

That works well with programming related questions. Sometimes we don't get enough information about the business, market, idea, etc., so we can't provide good answers. If there is an area I don't understand, the credibility of the person answering the question may be important since it can be difficult/costly to try out all the answers.

1. OpenID sucks, it's too complicated for average Joe and even for techies who use it for the first time
  2. People wants to give it a shot before revealing everything
  3. Anonymity and half-anonymity (not obvious that who you are) is a good thing, especially if your competitors googling you (yeah I'm a paranoid)

Question Matters

Personally, I'm much more likely to answer a question asked by a properly registered user...

I totally agree on this but generally from the question itself you can understand how much time that person spent before asking the question, If it's

Plz, gimme the code

or

Tell me the magic so I can be rich in 21 days

Then personally I wouldn't bother to answer, but even if the person is not registered properly from their question you can understand if they spent time to craft a good question. Explained their situation well, given enough background information (at as much as they can disclose) etc.

To sum it up:

I don't mind bad registrations but I mind bad questions.

Sorry guys, buy I checked out the FAQ but it didn't answer my question. Let you imagine, next month I'll launch a new webapp. Asking for review/comments or just advertise ('hey, look this app I'm launching') is allowed here or it's a deprecated habit?

I just ask before breaking some netiquette behavior.

TIA Paolo
row.Title: Is advertising / updates allowed here?

row.Body:
I think generally it's ok to ask for feedback on your site/app because you honestly want to hear others' comments. Just trying to advertise on the site or be spammy wouldn't be received well. One way you can show you are genuine is to become an active user of the site.

Good luck with your launch!

Ask some specific questions about your site or tag clouds (That seems to be what your site does/is going to do.). Like, "What do you use to build tag clouds?" or "Do you think tag clouds are useful?" or "Would you include a tag cloud on your site if it was easy to build?" or "How much would you pay for a tag cloud generator?"

I think that's a fine and fair question to ask -- and I guess the community here doesn't have a clear consensus on this yet.

My own personal take is that:

  • Pure notifications of new startups launching are clearly unwanted. There are already many sites out there that meet this need -- Feed My App, CrunchBase and many others. (A side note, Bob Walsh's StartupToDo.com has a good list of such sites.)

  • (I think several people will disagree with me on the following) request for "please review my webapp" are unwanted. Let me explain my motivation: I, as most other readers of these posts, quickly notice if the startup works in a field which I have a special interest in. In 99% of the cases it does not. So I just ignore the request, and most other readers do the same. The request is effectively noise for us. Such requests should rather be made as customized emails to people who are already interested in the field; or to blogs and communities more vertically specialized in the field in question.

  • While "please review my webapp" requests are generally unwanted, they can be made interesting if they focus on something that is universal and educational. For example "please review my webapp and tell me basic things I should have thought of" is unwanted. But "please review my webapp's signup form with emphasis on how to interpret this A/B testing data" is interesting to a wider audience and welcome.
I noticed someone added a disclaimer to an answer he gave on this site. Is that necessary or advisable?
row.Title: Do I need to add a disclaimer when I answer a question on this site?

row.Body: Depends on the nature of the answer. If you provide "legal advice" then you probably want to point out that you're not a lawyer, or if you provide tax advice that you're not an accountant. If someone's asking about how to locate competitors for a particular product, though, there's likely no need.

I think folks generally add disclaimers when what they are saying might potentially be construed as legal advice (because there are laws against dispensing legal advice if you're not a lawyer).

Having said that, there could be other reasons: I'm not a lawyer and so this should not be taken as a definitive/official answer or be taken as legal advice. :)

Perhaps you saw my disclaimer in an answer.

I am a lawyer (in CA). I need to be careful about (a) complying with the CA Rules of Professional Conduct and (b) not leading anyone to mistakenly believe that we have established an attorney-client relationship via an online post, or that a post constitutes legal advice to anyone.

As a result, I include the following disclaimer (which applies to this answer):

"Disclaimer: This post does not constitute legal advice and does not establish an attorney-client relationship."

Regarding non-lawyers commenting on legal issues: I think it is a courtesy and appropriate to explain that they are not lawyers, but I see little risk of being prosecuted for unauthorized practice of law. The far greater problem is non-lawyers who make statements about the law that are simply incorrect.

I have been through that discussion with the Founder Institute.

Here's the bottom line: lawyers are required to put disclaimers. That's why you'll see disclaimers once in a while. Then you start wondering: should I have a disclaimer too?

The answer is no: you are not a lawyer, so your advice is not legal advice. You won't get disbarred if your online advice is bad :-)

The Stack Exchange engine uses Gravatar for everyone's profile image. If you don't sign up with Gravatar to upload an image, then it will use an Identicon image, which is generated based on your IP address.

Using this information, it's pretty clear that a large number of users on the other question/answer site originate from the same IP address. These users ask and answer a large number of questions on the site.

This is one way to generate content, and it certainly works provided someone is willing to maintain the separate accounts. Does this make sense for Answers.OnStartups? Would this help the site grow and attract more users? Or, is this technique too obvious to the average user and thereby a turn-off?
row.Title: Should Answers.OnStartups have "dummy" questions and users?

row.Body:
No.

You can tell just by the similar phrasing that lot's of the questions on the 'other' site are fillers from the staff, I can understand why they do it (it's better than an empty site), but I do find it a bit of a turn-off.

I'd much rather be helping 'proper' users, than answering a fairly self/site serving question to pad things out.

There's enough here to be getting on with ;)

I think if a site has to resort to having people with multiple accounts ask/answer questions then that leads me to wonder what their motivation for the site it.

I would hope that the idea is to first be able to help others, and 2, not lose money.

If the motivation is, make many, regardless, then I would be concerned as I don't know to what extent they will do that.

So, the best approach is to start with some well-known people that may attract others, and see if you can determine how to bring in the users, how to keep them here and develop a vibrant community.

I tend toward no, as my answer, as a strong user community is vital, and if you have people with multiple accounts, how can there truly be a strong community.

Good find! I didn't realize how many puppets were in the top users list on {Blank}Ups.com

However, if I were trying to get a site like this off the ground I might resort to seeding the site with some Q & A. It is not the worst thing in the world and this question is a little gossipy.

Hmmm, wow... didn't even notice that, but now that you point it out, it's pretty darn obvious. Maybe they'll learn to start avoiding the [first name][space][last name] pattern when naming the dummy users. :-)

I concur with Jon and James that having/using dummy users comes across as disingenuous. I would actually prefer that such 'produced' questions be contributed in a manner that makes it clear where they came from. I certainly wouldn't think less of the organizers/heavy hitters on this site putting a number of questions out there... just not so much to dominate the site and not done surreptitiously... just my two cents.

That being said, if a large number of questions and responses aren't really coming from the community, it will never be the same as the value and spirit being produced by a healthy community (regardless of size). Yes, they are able to show 'growth,' but you can't force great content. The good news is that social media is really hard to fake (and it often goes horribly wrong when people try).

Excellent meta question. Thanks.

This particular behavior was relatively common in discussion forum sites. The idea was to "seed" the early platform and create the illusion of activity (thereby getting more people to participate).

Though I understand the motivation for this, I don't agree with it. I don't think it's a good idea for answers.onstartups.com.

One of the things I most like about http://answers.onstartups.com (and granted I have a biased opinion) is that the discussions have been genuine and useful.

Sometimes it's the questions we get wrong. I think the creators of a site should 'seed' with multiple questions under their name. They make good examples for other questions and give new users an opportunity to test their ideals and opinions on certain subjects.

A quick note to let you know that the Founder Conference 2010 will take place on August 17 in Mountain View. Members of the OnStartups community receive a 15% discount at http://founderconference.eventbrite.com/?discount=onstartups

This conference is for anyone planning to start a startup in 2010. We have an amazing lineup of speakers: Aaron Patzer (Mint.com), Guy Kawasaki ("The Art of the Start"), Adeo Ressi (TheFunded) and more.

Topics cover finding a co-founder, refining your pitch, how to launch and get buzz on a budget and more topics critical to entrepreneurs.

Please pass the word around!
row.Title: The Founder Conference is in 2 Months (Tell OnStartups community)

row.Body: Any discount codes for your fellow Onstartup members?
I think it would be great to have a rate my startup system with up and down votes.

I'm the one who originally flagged this question for moderator attention. I flagged it because it has nothing to do with start ups. If you need info on finding living space in Japan, try a travel web site. This site is supposed to concentrate of questions about starting and running businesses.

I've asked a few questions on the site thus far and have gotten some tremendous responses (thanks all!). But I'm a bit bothered by the fact that there really can't be one right answer to most of the questions I've asked.

This seems to go against the spirit of the site as, according to the faq:

Avoid asking questions that are subjective, argumentative, or require extended discussion. This is not a discussion board, this is a place for questions that can be answered!

I feel compelled to accept answers to the questions, but I'm not sure what critieria to use, since none of them are "correct" answers. They're all subjective because the question is subjective.

Are my questions too subjective? And if not, what criteria should be used to accept answers?
row.Title: Are my questions too subjective?

row.Body:
It's a good point.

On StackOverflow they were anal about getting very specific, which works for coding questions because you can be specific.

I think with business problems it's sometimes hard to be specific or objective; in fact opposing opinions are valuable and interesting!

So although in general it's better to be more specific, I think it's best to let the community decide what is interesting to talk about.

Perhaps you should mark the answer that was most helpful in your situation as the correct answer, it's not totally in the spirit of how SO was built but it would be helpful to see which one was the best received by the author (and not just the community which the up votes will handle)

I recently posted a question containing a link to a survey which was considered by a few users as Spam, is there any guidelines as to what constitutes spam so that I can avoid similair mistakes in the future

Thanks for any advice

Nigel
row.Title: What is considered Spam

row.Body:
Nigel,

For what I can tell, the OnStartups community considers SPAM anything that isn't a real question about a startup, but instead someone looking for self-advertisement. That is my opinion.

Probably, everything that is not concrete start-up question and trying to steal attention away from this site is considered as SPAM. But this is user and context dependent.

Can you just put the survey questions here as a question?
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I_know_it_when_I_see_it

I don't think we as a community have a clear guideline on this right now. At least, I haven't seen anything clear in the FAQ or in past [meta] discussions.

For me, it comes down to an assessment of:

  • who benefits.
  • the topic.

If the question almost exclusively benefits the person asking it, then it is spam. A few hypothetical examples:

  • "Please go fill out my market survey hosted on another site." It is spam because only the questionnaire owner benefits.
  • "I have this HTML on my webpage, and it fails in this way. Please fix it for me.". It is spam because it is off topic (it is about webdesign, not startups) and because the question is basically about doing consulting work for free (fixing the very specific problem that the person asking has, not a general problem that many people have).

The question is not spam if it:

  • benefits the person asking and current and future readers of this site

  • and it is closer to the startup itself and the day-to-day operation of and strategy for the startup and less related to a technology that the startup happens to make use of

  • and it can reasonably be answered on this site (say in ~1 page of text), and the answer is in fact posted here.

I can not upload a picture, i can not understand why. I can not actually upload it from gravatar. I am just not very fond of being a faceless user. I prefer people see my face when answering and asking questions. Thanks for your help and answers.
row.Title: How to upload a profile picture?

row.Body:
Alena - you say "I can not actually upload it from gravatar" - does that mean you can't/won't use gravatar.com to store your profile picture? My understanding is that that is the only way to put your picture on the site - it is very easy to do - there is an excellent overview video at http://en.gravatar.com/ so you shouldn't have too much trouble getting it working. (It was so trivial for me that I had to go back and look up this stuff as I had forgotten it no sooner than I had done it).

Also, be aware that Answers.Onstartups.com uses the same engine as StackOverflow, and that there is a great deal of helpful information over there on the system - see http://meta.stackoverflow.com. Specific to your question, there is this answer.

Hope this helps.

Hi Alena,

Best thing to do is go over to http://gravatar.com and create an account. Enter in your email address and upload a picture of yourself.

Then, come back to a gravatar-enabled site like this, and enter in the same email address that you signed up with at gravatar.com. Then, your image should change from the identicon symbol to your chosen picture.

to confirm gravatar is working, you can directly call your account the following way.

1) get your gravatar email address: (test@test.com) 2) create a md5 of it. (go here to create it online) test@test.com = b642b4217b34b1e8d3bd915fc65c4452 3) take the hash and append it to the following url: http://www.gravatar.com/avatar/{md5 goes here}

http://www.gravatar.com/avatar/b642b4217b34b1e8d3bd915fc65c4452 is the call made to gravatar.com for the image associated with test@test.com

Each system refreshes its gravatar calls differently - if you made the change and the image did not update, you can force a change by associating another email with your account and then change your profile email address. it will probably change then.

Good luck!

I think that new users need to be told/warned that the answers they receive will vary based on their registration efforts. I know when I see a question that needs a complicated answer I often click on the user's profile before answering. If there is nothing there I am much less likely to spend the time and effort answering their question.

The best sites I have participated in do not allow anonymous participants. There is something reassuring about talking with real people.

All that being said, OpenID is horrible. It is much more complicated than it needs to be and does not explain what is expected of you.

In with reading many posts it seems to our group that a "question" alone cannot always sum up an individuals request. We say this as yesterday we posted some thoughts mixed in with questions. Some dismiss confusion and possible frustration as a "rant" but in reality we face issues like most start ups.

Why post this? Well we noticed many start ups in many different stages of their development on this board. At times the questions are one in the same, Is my business viable? or How do I attack this business opportunity? How do I find a business partner? These are all complex questions and can hope by providing our experiences it serves as a guideline. Heck, maybe we can even save some people time AND money.

By us painting a picture of our travels we hoped to give insight as to some basic trappings most underfunded start ups face. We seek to offer up our experience and can only hope if one person reads it and says to themselves, "wow, this is what we are dealing with also". Nothing more. In doing so we have gotten feedback, important feedback that we can utilize in our advancements, we say thank you. And we say if anyone needs guidance, a few words of direction to help avoid pitfalls we have seen then reach out as all information is pertinent. We believe this is this websites purpose.

Sometimes the question is not within the title, it lies within the context of the story. Be well and thank you contributors.
row.Title: Closing thought on VC/Angel "game"

row.Body:
From an entry on the Stack Exchange blog, "Stack Exchange 2.0", posted today:

Existing Stack Exchange sites will be kept open, under existing rules, for at least three months, and at least one year if you have an active site (defined as ten or more visitors or more on April 8th)."

We’ll give you at least 3 months notice before shutting down any site."

How do I know how long my Stack Exchange site will remain open?"
row.Title: Will we survive ?

row.Body:
Absolutely!

I've been following several Stack Exchange sites, and OnStartups is one of the more popular ones, with good traffic and excellent participation.

These are factors that Joel and the other Stack Exchange people will be using as criteria on which exchanges to keep and which not to keep. The more than 2000 members here will not let it die.

Here's what happens:

Q: What happens with existing Stack Exchange sites?

We don’t want to harm any communities that have already successfully gotten off the ground. This harks back to our corporate goal:

Make the Internet a better place to get expert answers to your questions.

Community is hard to build, and we want to work with you to preserve it if you’ve already done that with Stack Exchange. If we closed down or competed with the existing, successful Stack Exchange sites, that would conflict with our goals.

1.Existing Stack Exchange sites will be kept open, under existing rules, for at least three months, and at least one year if you have an active site (defined as ten or more visitors or more on April 8th). 2.You will not have to pay for these sites, ever. 3.We’ll give you at least 3 months notice before shutting down any site. 4.We’ll always make your data available for download. 5.If your site remains very active, we’d love to work with you to migrate it to the new, community-owned Stack Exchange platform. That would be the best thing that could happen to a Stack Exchange 1.0 site, in our opinion: that way your site can take advantage of our existing resources and expansive community.

See Stack Exchange's complete rules at: http://blog.stackexchange.com/post/518474918/stack-exchange-2-0

I've been talking to the folks at FogCreek.

We are one of the most popular sites, so we won't be shut down quickly, certainly not in the next 3 months, possibly not ever.

Mostly this is a backlash against a large amount of sites that weren't building community. But also it's true that they don't want to make money from us $150/mo at a time, so it remains to be seen exactly how that pans out.

I can tell you this: We'll keep this forum going. Even if that means we end up having to export/import into one of the several open-source platforms which exist (and I'm guessing will now receive renewed attention).

Update: StackExchange is guaranteeing the site will remain up and untouched at least until April 2011. Obviously we'll be talking with them over the next few months and if that date cannot be extended we'll start looking for alternatives where we can move all the content and all the user reputation etc..

Interesting perspectives from 'Anonymous Regular Men' and lkessler - but I'm not sure it's quite as polarised or as simple as that. I think stackexchange.com has created a problem for itself here - for sites that are as popular as this one (I'm guessing Answers is not too many down the list after the obvious suspects, StackOverflow, ServerFault, etc), the message seems to be they don't want to destroy the current community. However, as noted, there are sites out there in the big wide world with more users and more questions, so who's to say they (one of the other sites) can't argue to be the startup questions site on stackexchange?

For me, stackexchange seem to be (unintentionally?) setting themselves up as some sort of governance authority on the internet. I can't help thinking this is unwise, given how the internet works. Of course, there is only one Wikipedia, and that works fine, but people respect that because it is explicitly not-for-profit and it has established itself as the place to go for information. Nobody minds contributing because (amongst other things) they don't feel they are helping someone else build their business. I think the rules of the game are very different for commercial operations on the web.

One approach would be for the the founders of the different communities to get together and see whether a single community makes more sense. This is certainly a possibility, but it has the potential of watering down each community's unique personality, so I'm not convinced that would be such a good thing.

Having invested quite a lot of time into Answers, I for one would be sorry to see it disappear - I think we have a great community here and the quality of answers is very high. That's something that should be considered when looking at the stats - 5x the questions and 2x the users is meaningless if the quality is nothing like what we have here (I must confess I didn't even know about startups.com until today).

I guess meanwhile we carry on as we are, but it would be good to get some clarity about the future before too long as uncertainty will eventually be harmful to the community.

You guys already found the relevant parts of our announcements, and correctly interpreted them, but just to clarify:

  1. We don't want to hurt the Internet. This site is good for the Internet. So we don't want to hurt it.
  2. Looking at our future plans we're confident that we can promise to continue to host this site as-is for 12 months.
  3. In 12 months, we won't want to hurt the Internet, either, but things can change, so our promise can only be for 12 months.

As far as startups.com vs. answers.onstartups.com - honestly, I would be happier if there had only been one site, and honestly, I think it would be cool if they would merge somehow (I'm not even sure technically how that would work), but that's not up to me to decide, since they're not my sites. We have no plans to "pick one winner."

There are a few people whose comments I've found particularly insightful. Is there any way I can "favorite" those users so their posts stand out in the future. Perhaps in a different colour or something?

That would be pretty useful when skimming a list of answers.

(Yes, I know people upvote the good stuff... even so, I'd like to notice when one of these people speak, even if they didn't get voted up)

I could do it in greasemonkey or something... but why reinvent the wheel if I don't have to?

[edit] Looks like ya can't get there from here. The closest thing I could find was a suggestion to pull each user's answer rss feed into my favorite reader: http://meta.stackoverflow.com/questions/4064/is-there-any-way-to-mark-a-user-as-favorite
row.Title: Can I "favorite" certain commentators here?

row.Body:
You can set up an RSS feed for a particular user. I do that on Stack Overflow for some people.

Using your user number (1133) as an example, the link would be:

http://answers.onstartups.com/feeds/user/1133

This link is on the bottom right of each user page.

Tags are an important part of this site yet I sometimes struggle to think of an appropriate tag for a question. I am sure some of you have the same problem I have.
