Tags are also important for searching and collecting information so that redundant questions won’t be asked and the community can start to build useful how to guides. To this end, I wanted to propose some “standard” question tags that will help organization things. Along with “standard” tags, there are some additional tags that, in conjunction with “standard” tags, help define what a question is. The list I propose is below:

  • Sales: Advertising, Payments, Negotiation, Subscription, Metrics, CRM, Partners, Business-Development, Conversion, Channel
  • Marketing: Product, Pricing, Promotion, Place, Launch, Product-Definition, Analysis, Branding, Inbound, Outbound, Research, Product-Management, Identity, Public-Relations, Conferences, Benefits
  • Finance: Funding, Equity, Investment, Investors, Angel, VC, Seed-Funding, Evaluations, Loan, Stock-Options, Warrants, Bootstrapped
  • Accounting: Tax, Cash-Basis, Accural-Basis, Bookkeeping, Banks, Payroll
  • Operations: Office-Space, Hosting, Phone, Location, Real-Estate, Process, Payments
  • Human-Resources: Hiring, Motivation, Employees, Resources, Inspiration, Salary, Review, Recruiting, Benefits, Incentives, Productivity, Interviews, Compensation, Stock-Options, ISO, NSO, Consultants, Intern, Career
  • Development: Project-Planning, Beta, Minimum-Viable-Product, Metrics, Open-Source, Platforms, Demo, Team, Virtual-Workforce, Bug-Tracking, User-Interface, Launch, Research, Outsourcing, Graphic-Design, Technology, Software, Website
  • Legal: Business-Structures, C-Corporation, LLC, S-Corporation, Sole-Proprietor, Partnerships, Non-Profit, License, Corporate-Structure, Insurance, NDA, Contracts, Terms-and-Conditions,Patents, Trademarks, Copyright, Trade-Secrets, License, Intellectual-Property
  • Customer: Support, Trial, User-Interface, Social-Network, Service, Metrics
  • Management: Board-of-Directors, Exit-Strategy, Pitch, Co-Founder, Leadership, Advisors, Incubators, Risk, Business-Plan, Founders, Planning
  • Business-Model: SaaS, PaaS, B2B, B2C, Desktop, Channel, Direct, eCommerce, Enterprise, Consumer, Service, Subscription, Partner
  • Meta: Advice, Recommendations, Ideas, Startup, Startups, Software, Hardware, Mentor, Tags

The idea would be to have less than 15 “standard” tags or categories and the rest would be additional details for a question. For example, a question about how to price for the SaaS market might have the tags: Marketing, Pricing, Business-Model SaaS. Of course, you can still put any old tag you may want as well.

What do you think? I community wikied this so feel free to hack away or leave a comment.
row.Title: Answers.OnStartups Standard Tag List

row.Body: I read there was was a delay due to importing questions from this site to another.
row.Title: Is this site moving to an Area 51 site?

row.Body: Am I allowed to set a dollar bounty on a question asked on OnStartups?
row.Title: Am I allowed to set a dollar bounty on a question asked on OnStartups?

row.Body: No, bounty system works with reputation.

If you offer a dollar bounty, how would the responders know that they will get paid, and, what is to prevent you from putting up an answer under a different IP address and account, and then selecting that one as the winner?

My point is that there are so many unknowns, that it would be risky for people to expect to get rewarded with money.

But, if you want some ideas on how to get the information you need, then you can ask that for free, and people will try their best to answer their questions.

If you want to give a dollar bounty your best bet is to work with some third party that would hold the money, and have an independent judge determine the best response, but, by the time you get that into place it is costing you a lot more than just asking here.

Besides, you should be either doing your own research or knowing where the information is coming from and how the statistics were calculated, so that you can know what was excluded, otherwise you are perhaps looking at very biased information, that is skewed to certain major companies.

It's against the general spirit of the site to start throwing around cash, however it's very much in the spirit of the site to locate people whose opinions you value, and compensate them accordingly.

So maybe there's a middle ground: Instead of offering a bounty on the answer alone, offer to pay $X for $Y hours of consulting on a particular problem, and use the answers as a way to decide who to hire, or perhaps to get the information you want without having to spend money at all.

Even so, no it's not "illegal," although there might be difficulties as mentioned above.
Just something to think about.
row.Title: Is tagging a question as "startup" redundant?

row.Body: I'd say it's pretty redundant.

I took it to mean that the questions tagged with startup relate to a company in the planning early initial stages before it is formed and right after being formed as opposed to a new company in existence that is operating but not yet fully established.

I found someone on Stack Overflow who seemed knowledgeable about a somewhat esoteric library and offered him to do a small amount of work for payment. He accepted and I paid. Twice.

There really is no mechanism built into the website framework, but just contact those people offline.
Yep! Here it is!
Does Stackoverflow.com license their architecture? What is a good way to approach them about using it?
row.Title: How did OnStartups get the stackoverflow architecture?

row.Body: Yes, they do license their software through StackExchange.com. It`s currently in beta so anyone can signup and start their own site for free (until they get out of beta).
There's also shapado which is open source and it does hosting too (for free).

Hi all! Long time reader, first time caller.

I'm starting up a company to help professionals make the most of their online community activity, and I'd greatly appreciate a minute of your time for some quick anonymous feedback. Please, share this with your friends too!

  • The survey:

If you'd like to get a summary of the anonymous results collected, please provide your email at the bottom of the survey, or reach out to me via . Or, if folks like, I can post the summary here too.

Thanks again!

-pete
row.Title: Ask OnStartups: quick survey of people like us

row.Body: I think it would be great if you could post the survey results here. That way you'd be giving something back to the community. Thanks
Definitely will be interesting to see the results. I just filled it out.

Hi Pete

Well thought out survey and yes I'd love the results too as it ties in a little to mine - I'd appreciate you completing this and sending it out too - it's just two multi choice questions so super simple

Entrepreneurs 2 Q survey
What benefits can you get by answering questions here?
row.Title: Why do you answer questions on onstartups.com? What is your motivation?

row.Body:
Answering questions forces you to constantly challenge what you think you know and put some order in your thoughts. It's one thing to know something intuitively, but "teaching" it to someone requires a greater understanding of the problem: by answering, you learn at the same time.

For instance, answering this question forced me to retrospect and ask myself why I actually do it. I think I came up with a somewhat rational explanation.

For me it's about giving back. I read many answers to many questions that are very helpful to me. I take that information. So when I believe I may have information that could be beneficial to others I want to give back. Just that simple.

I actually come to this site to ask on occasion, and to read answers to other people's questions. Then when I see a question that I know the answer to, or can provide value, I do so because that will encourage others to contribute as well (thereby benefiting me). So it's all about giving so that I can receive. Very selfish.

It's an excuse to organize my thoughts on a variety of topics. It is also less commitment than writing a blog. Lastly, since I usually have more questions than answers, it is in my best interest to see the community flourish.

Basically, I enjoy helping people.

Answering these questions also hones my thinking, writing and organizational skills. Distilling a complex concept or situation into a couple of 100 words forces you to really understand what you are talking about.

The feedback is also valuable. Where else do you get direct feedback on how well you have helped people. That part is tremendously rewarding.

Because I like to keep my business "karma" balance in the positive. I mentor 1st-timers, I am active in community, I write a blog sharing best practices (LeanStartups.com), and recently started answering questions here. I strongly believe one should spend at least 10% of their time giving back.
I think it is a way to add back to the community. I ask questions, and get help, and the least I can do is to see if some of my thoughts may help others out.
The more you giveth, the more you taketh!

I joined answers.onstartups.com because I liked that I found answers to questions I had but did know where/who to ask. (Friends and family would not be interested in this stuff!) The answers are of great quality, many from experienced entrepreneurs. Most posts are encouraging and supportive which I believe is so important for someone starting up. I like that our hosts restrict spam. I started asking my own questions and I answered where I felt I could contribute.

THEN I got addicted to this site! (The creators of this platform are ingenious!) After posting questions or answers, I wanted to find out if I got votes. After I got a few votes, I wanted more votes. I also got badges. Then I wanted to collect badges…

I have no clue about the many IT questions but I answer what I can. I answer questions because I want to belong to this entrepreneurial community and it also feels great to help others out. I also remember what it’s like not knowing what to do and not having any one to bounce off ideas with.

It was my new years resolution to try to increase my signal to noise ratio of what I read online.

I realised I'd be spending whole days on Twitter and reading blog articles on business, and not really take much away from any of them, let alone apply any of it.

This site is the great antidote to that. Everything is distilled down to a question and answer, and I don't need to parse the whole article to work out what it is important.

There are some great posters on here and I'm taking a ton away from it. For that reason, I want to share my opinion and hopefully help the community grow and give back.

I have to admit, seeing that rep number go up is appealing as well. It shows that someone, somewhere, thought I had something useful to say!

Feel more connected when I read and answer to questions.
I am the single person in my startup and
I like to be part of bigger team.
Being a one man mISV is a lonely business. Social conversation with other mISV and sharing the problems and solutions helps. Asking and answering questions clears the ideas.
Somehow it's fun, I don't know why :)

Ego stroking. When people vote up my answers it makes me feel better about myself.

Oh yeah - something about helping people too ;)

Well, since you asked...

Enlightened self interest:

  1. I run a startup for startups, http://startuptodo.com (a training/productivity community for startups and microISVs) - helping my current and prospective customers makes good sense.
  2. I do a podcast for startups, the Startup Success Podcast (http://startuppodcast.wordpress.com/) - helping my current and prospective listeners makes good sense.
  3. I write books for startups, the latest of which came out in July: The Web Startup Success Guide (http://www.amazon.com/Web-Startup-Success-Guide/dp/1430219858) - helping my current and prospective listeners makes good sense.
  4. I'm also an [unpaid] Microsoft BizSpark Network Partner - getting startups signed up so they can use all of Microsoft's goodies and so that .NET developers can escape their cubicles and breath the air of freedom.
  5. Finally, it's a value choice - I prefer to help, hang out with, support startup founders. I've done the corporate thing - writing software for big companies for 25 years. Meant far less to me than giving one startup a helping hand.

This site is proving to be a great resource for the start up on which I am working. I am a firm believer in "as ye sow, so shall ye reap". It's the members who keep the community strong by contributing thoughtful answers. I want to make sure the community stays vibrant and valuable so it's in my self interest to contribute.

I enjoy leveraging my business experience to help others with their start up efforts and I am finding that I enjoy the positive reinforcement of the "up" votes for good answers.

Last, our country and our economy need jobs to be created now. Supporting start ups by answering questions to help other start up efforts strikes me a terrific way to help drive job growth.

Well I am new to the forum and the reason I joined is because I have the experience regarding the issues faced by entrepreneurs, small businesses and home based businesses when it comes to setting up your business. I want to share my experience and knowledge so that they don't commit the mistakes that people have committed earlier.

All of the above are true for me too, except the one about being a Microsoft BizSpark Network Partner. But the main thing is that expertise is like muscle, the way to grow it is actually to use it. These kinds of forums help me pull my thoughts and experiences together, and find important insights to share. It's something I hope to become better at. Doing this in a re-active way (in comments) requires a less effort that composing original blog posts.

My hope is that I help someone out. We've all had different experiences - maybe I can bring in an angle on a topic that someone will find helpful. But the reason I keep doing it is more because my own mind becomes clearer the more I engage in this type of dialogue.

The fun, status-markers, procrastination value on my other tasks and all the rest factor into it all too, of course.

I have been advised that questions about specific startup issues belong on the main startup site, whereas questions about the policies of the board belong on the meta site.

However, we are confused on how to use this. On the main site, we registered and ask and answer questions. However, on the meta site to vote up or down we are asked to log in, and even with this attempt we receive the following message:

Oops! Your question couldn't be submitted because:

* Anonymous participation isn't allowed here; please log in before posting.

How, and with what creds, do we access these other features? Also is it possible to message another member for private chat?

We thank you for any assistance as it is confusing, but a very nice resource to work with and we hope to help and contribute both in a effective manner and in proper format.
row.Title: How to log into meta, and why does one need to register if already registered with OnStartups?

row.Body:
That is really strange. If you already have an account you shouldn't have to re-register. Your browser should be storing a cookie, unless you have it configured differently. How do you interact with the main site? Do you have to login every time you come to the site?

  1. Are you saying that even on the main site you can't vote? (i.e. are having the same problem)
  2. Have you tried logging out of the main site, and logging back in?
  3. If you try to log in to the meta site, what happens? Are you able to successfully log in, or do you get some type of error, and can't log in at all? If you can log in, although it may be annoying to have to do it every time, at least you can use the site (until we can figure out what's going on).
  4. Can you walk us through it? You click on the meta link at the top of the main site, and then what happens? You should either see XS Direct at the top and a log out link next to it, or a log in link.

I've got a lot of questions here. It might be best if you edit your question to address them instead of in the comments.

I thought all SE 2.0 sites are owned and operated by Stack Overflow / Exchange.

How come OnStartups is heavily linked to onstartups.com, which I presume is not owned by them?
row.Title: How come answers.onstartups is simultaneously part of Stack Exchange 2.0 and OnStartups.com?

row.Body:
This question has a "big" total of 4 up votes for 6 answers and 1 question. More specifically, there is 2 up votes on the question and 2 up votes on 2 answers.

It means that at least 4 people took the time of answering the question but didn't think it was an interesting question (since the question has only 2 up votes). It is also very likely that answerers didn't bother looking up other people's answer since only 2 of them were up voted (or that all the other answers were crap but I doubt it).

This is not an isolated case. The up vote ratio is incredibly low here compared to other SE sites.

I'm tempted to draw the conclusion that contributors here are too self-absorbed to consider up voting anything.

  • Do you agree with my observation?
  • Is there an alternative conclusion to draw?
  • How can we fix this tendency?
row.Title: 1 question, 6 answers and a total of 4 up votes... what is wrong with here?

row.Body:
I am no prude, but I find it odd and annoying that people feel inclined to use what most would consider inappropriate language.

Can this be the result of all these DHH and Jason Fired wannabees who think they can duplicate 37 signals' success by using the same colorful and racy language as those two guys?

In any case - what is the policy from the moderators?

Should we flag the posts or just tolerate it?

It is a small minority, but a number of posts lately just didn't seem appropriate.
row.Title: What's with the recent spate of potty-language on the site?

row.Body:
I'm new to answers.OnStartups, but I think I've seen a pattern where people down vote their answer competition. Since a -1 answer is less likely to get upvoted again, this strategy may become successful. Which is very unfortunate. Since this site isn't as active as, say, Stack Overflow, and voting also seems less common, that may impact willingness to answer.

Am I right? Is there any other way than a more active community to stop it?
row.Title: Effects of down voting your competition?

row.Body:
More active participation in the voting would certainly help. The occasional author who may down-votes others where they participate are still only one vote. So it should balance out across the site… if enough people are voting.

I don't imagine there is a problem specific to this site. But typically an undeserved down-vote creates an indignation that causes what can be termed as "pity up-votes." Down-voting is often met with an accompanying up-vote, unless the down-vote is truly deserved.

I understand that the occasional random (even undeserved) down-vote can sting a bit. But, as you use the system and gain a bit of reputation, accounting for each and every point becomes less of a concern and you can better enjoy the use of the site. Consider for a moment that, for every undeserved down-vote, you've probably also received the occasional up-vote you didn't deserve either. Remember:

  • Up-vote = +10 points
  • Down-vote = -2 points

At the moment, there is no policy, because it's never been an issue until now.

I think that the users that are consistently doing this, are doing so on purpose, because there really isn't a need for it. It's always possible to make your point without having to resort to using foul language.

I don't think we should have a blanket ban on profanity. Personally, I'm not offended by that type of language, but I do find it immature and unprofessional. And I understand that others may be offended by it. I think this is something we should handle on a case by case basis. If it's a one time offense, maybe we should let it slide (assuming the general statement isn't offensive). However, if we start seeing this pattern from certain users, then I think something should be done. What that "something" is, I don't know. Maybe a moderator should email the individual privately about the matter. Any suggestions?

That said, I think there is a difference between using foul language and being offensive. We should never have to tolerate or accept offensive behavior. The problem then becomes how do we define offensive, because we all have varying levels of acceptance.

answers.onstartups.com is owned and operated by SE. My understanding from reading this question is that the current design of the site is only temporary.

As a side note, I'm not bothered with the linkage to OnStartups. Dharmesh and Jason put a lot of time and effort into growing this community before it became a 2.0 site. I think we owe the success of this site to them. Without them this would have been another startups.com.

I've been with the community for a long time (relatively speaking), and I have to say that I have not seen the behavior you are describing. About a month ago, I saw what seemed like that type of behavior with two questions that had bounties on them, but I haven't seen it since. And I don't know for sure if the downvotes were from the "answerers" or from other users.

I have seen a lot more downvotes recently, than in the past. That does concern me somewhat. I'm not sure why, but I'm guessing it's new users.

Since a -1 answer is less likely to get upvoted again

I think if the downvote was undeserving, the opposite is actually true. People tend to be more likely to upvote something they normally wouldn't have, if it has been downvoted for no reason. I've done that myself. If that happens, in the end you end up netting more rep.

I can see why: I rarely upvote questions, because I don't see a benefit in doing that. As far as I can tell, the home page is mostly chronological, so I'm not sure what upvoting questions achieves.

It's much clearer for answers: the most upvoted ones rise to the top, which is very important.

I think upvoting questions is just as important as upvoting answers, especially for new users. By upvoting (or downvoting) a new user's question:

  1. You are helping them get the most out if the site, and as a result they will be more likely to become more active. If you upvote a good question, you are showing them that these are the types of questions that are beneficial to the community as a whole. You are also telling them that the level of detail provided in the question is good. In the same way, by downvoting a question, you are helping the new user understand that either the way the question was asked needs improvement, or that the question is simply off-topic for this site. Of course this can only occur if the downvoter leaves a comment. Basically, it encourages the asking of good questions.
  2. You help increase their rep to the point that they can get more out of the site, and as a result will be more likely to become active. Simply asking and answering questions may not be as exciting to some people. For example, if a new user asks a good question, and gets upvoted enough times to reach 15 rep, they can then upvote those answers that were helpful to him/her. Which in turn encourages the answerers.

Also, there are a few badges you can earn from upvoted questions, which again can stimulate more participation on the site.

I agree that this site tends to have a low vote count when compared to other SE sites. I'm not sure why that is though. It could be that we get a lot of one time visitors. It's hard to change the behavior if we don't really know what is causing it. Any suggestions would be helpful.

For my part, I can tell you that I try to vote as much as I can. I will usually upvote a question I've answered, unless I think it is an extremely basic question. For example something like "What is an LLC?", but those types of questions are not very common here. Also, sometimes I get so carried away answering a question that I forget to upvote it. In those cases, I will end up upvoting it later on when I realize that I forgot to upvote it.

Do you agree with my observation?

No. It's one of many possibilities, but I don't think the likeliest. It also ascribes a big negative to a lot of helpful people.

Is there an alternative conclusion to draw?

Sure. Plenty. Maybe many questions don't merit upvoting? Maybe the purpose of upvoting isn't clear or similarly understood by everyone? Maybe there are bigger implications with upvoting the wrong answer here than, say, the hombrew site, and so people shy from dropping it like it was candy?

How can we fix this tendency?

I come here to answer questions or seek advice. It's one of the better places I've come across because it emphasizes a Q&A mindset, rather than subjective discussion. To me, the points are incidental, not the main thing. Plus, the more active you are, the more you give and gather over time. What's the rush?

I downvote things that I know are incorrect. I upvote questions that are novel, unique, remarkable. Like Zuly, I also get carried away and forget to upvote.

However, IMO upvoting is not the equivalent of FB's "Like". It's not something to throw about like a popularity contest. People base their startup decisions on some of what is written here.

I would ask the reverse question: Why does it matter who asked a question?

I answer questions on the merits of the question, not the questioner.

To add to John's post, which is correct, I think it's important to not close questions because one is tired of seeing them. This site should be interesting, not interesting to me.

I have admin'ed forums of a few types. Every domain has a few "evergreen" topics. We need to see those questions as one way that many people enter this site, as an opener to more interaction. They don't know that people here are tired of them.

I don't understand how this site is sorting answers to a question, if it is at all.

Other StackExchange sites sort answers by up-votes, including this meta site... but this doesn't seem to be the case for answers.onstartups.com.

Here are some examples:

  • http://answers.onstartups.com/questions/18148/while-working-on-my-startup-should-i-keep-track-of-my-time
  • http://answers.onstartups.com/questions/18114/possible-dangers-in-specific-startup-percentage-scheme
  • http://answers.onstartups.com/questions/17868/im-exhausted-with-my-consulting-business-how-can-i-find-the-energy

Is this a bug or was this done intentionally?
row.Title: Why are answers not sorted by up-votes?

row.Body:
I can't reproduce this.

Answers are sorted by score, by default -- have you clicked another answer sort order?

If so then that answer sort tab is the new default and will be "sticky" for you.

Hi,

When i open OnStartups Answers page, it logs in automatically. How does it happen? I use Opera Browser & Clear my Private data on Shutdown. I signed up to OnStartups using Facebook login details.

Thanks.
row.Title: How does the site Auto-Login.

row.Body:
Hi, what is Area 51 site?

Thanks.
Let's call it the Dave McClure effect.

For now, I'm willing to moderate language that is uncalled for. I don't mind strong language that conveys an emotion. But I would remove foul language that doesn't add to a sentence.

I understand that every person has a different threshold. I think mine is flexible enough that if people truly are shocked if I ever censor something, they can raise an issue and we can discuss it then.

For instance, if Dave McClure was to answer questions here, I would normally cut some words :-)

We'll have to see how it goes.

Explained here:

http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/09/global-network-auto-login/

More detail in the links in that blog entry, if you are interested.

OnStartups is a fantastic resource and I have spent a lot of time here in the last couple of months. I have learned a ton of stuff and I would like to contribute just a tiny bit - even if it is just by up-voting. But I don't seem to have enough reputation to do ANYTHING.

I don't feel qualified to answer any questions yet, so I can't get reputation that way. All the questions I might want to ask have already been asked.

If I could just get 15 points, I could become a contributor - but I don't know how to get them!! I haven't had this problem on any other stack exchange site.

Yes. I realize that this should be a meta question - but asking a meta question requires points :-(
row.Title: How do I get started with OnStartups?

row.Body:
Dear all,

I have a few times been unable to connect to our beloved answers.onstartups.com. Right now, as I'm writing this, I have this problem. (Meta works for me, as you can see.)

This time, I traced the problem down, and I cannot connect because the DNS name does not resolve. I'm using both Google's Public DNS and UltraDNS as my upstream DNS caches, and they're usually highly reliable...

The symptoms right now are simply the browser fails to connect to Answers.Onstartups, but other Stack Exchange sites work for me.

Is anyone else seeing the same kind of periodic issue, where connecting to Answer.Onstartups fails, but other Stack Exchange sites work? Or is it just a random fluke?

Thanks,
row.Title: Anyone else seeing periodic DNS issues for answers.onstartups.com ?

row.Body:
link

(Sorry. This is not really a question.)
row.Title: Congratulations, Dharmesh!

row.Body:
Hey,

I had this too, about 1h ago. Exactly the same symptoms: http://answers.onstartups.com down, the rest of the Stack Exchange network working perfectly. I use Google DNS servers.

Cheers,
We are aware of this issue, and are working to get it resolved as soon as we can.

also have had problems over the last month - using opendns

I've seen a few users that have this at the end of every answer they write, in order to prevent being sued(which could actually happen if they are a lawyer)

Note: This is not legal advice, nor does this create an attorney-client relationship.

I say we should somehow incorporate this into profiles, or this site specifically(because there is a lot of legal talk shared on this site) Maybe it could be appended at the bottom of every answer and question(in a small font) by checking a box in a profile, or possibly just for everyone just to be safe.

What do you think?
row.Title: Protecting users on the legal-advice front

row.Body:
I like the sentiment behind the idea; that's a nice thought of you.

The kind of disclaimer you mention is required if the person giving advice is an accredited lawyer in the United States. For a layman, it is not required. I don't think we help the legal professionals in our community by adding this to a site-wide disclaimer. I believe lawyers would still add this to their posts, either because of professional requirements or just out of old habit.

Another question is perhaps whether we would benefit from having a site-wide general disclaimer in place. I mean, to protect those who provide answers, and for all answers given, regardless of whether the answer is about legal issues or not. Something like "All answers are WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY, EXPRESSED OR IMPLIED; AND ANSWERS.ONSTARTUPS.COM AND CONTENT CONTRIBUTORS ASSUME NO RESPONSIBILITY FOR DIRECT OR INDIRECT CONSEQUENCES FROM FOLLOWING ADVICE GIVEN ..." etc. (Obviously, using a real legal text written by a lawyer.)

I'm a Danish citizen, and I'm not worried about getting sued over advice given here in my country. But perhaps some of the US contributors, especially those with some money in the bank, would like it. I did a quick read through on the legal disclaimer on this site, and it does have a warranty disclaimer in section 5. But this disclaimer seems to me to only protect Stack Overflow Inc, and not the people who write answers?

Summary: A special disclaimer for lawyers is IMHO not required. A disclaimer for all contributors might be a good idea; I'll leave it for the US users to decide.

According to the SE Site Directory Answers.Onstartups is:

Q&A for entrepreneurs looking to start or run a new business

Many questions, including quite a few recent ones, seem that they are less about entrepreneurship and starting/running a business and more about being a Webmaster.

Here are a few examples:

how to deal with a slanderous website that is using a trademarked domain name

Good Host in US and UK

Getting visitors and earning money through directory based websites

What makes a Successful Web Site Launch?

I realize that being a Webmaster can include topics relevant to running a new business, but I think this could use a bit more clarification so that the community members can know how to flag and/or respond to questions more accurately.
row.Title: Can we further clarify the purpose of Answers.Onstartups?

row.Body:
The good host question is suspect as it's so generic.

But in general, I think it's fair to say a lot of entrepreneurship these days is on the web. That's where those Facebook size (yeah, we can all dream) opportunities are and the costs of getting started are tiny relative to classic brick n' mortar businesses.

So it is not unreasonable to see a large amount of interest in web startup information.

Where I would draw the line, personally, is if the question is so generic that it could apply to anyone, not just an avid entrepreneur who is specifically running a startup. Which is why I brought up the "good host" question.

Any progress on this?

I'm getting frequent outages on a daily basis.
Heartiest congrats Dharmesh :)
For example - a query to see how many edits I have or votes on only questions, etc.
row.Title: How does a user see the progress for getting certain badges?

row.Body:
I don't think there is a way. Even with mod priviledges I haven't found a way to get that information for my own account.

The best I could find is going to the activity tab in my profile, and then clicking on revisions. It should show all of your revisions, but I'm not sure how accurate it is. In my case it shows a total of 210 revisions, but I haven't received the badge for 100 edits yet. My guess is that tag edits don't count towards that badge.
If you click the Unanswered button, you do not see a list of unanswered questions. They all have answers. Am I missing something here?
row.Title: Why does the list of unanswered questions not only show questions with answers but exclusively so?

row.Body: A question is not considered "answered" until one of the answers is predominantly up-voted (i.e. +1 or greater).
You can also see zero answer questions by selecting the appropriate tab:

Sorry for the issues folks. The problem was with our DNS provider (eNOM), as far as I can tell.

Things seem to have settled down now.

I'll keep an eye on it.

Yeah, I'm kind of surprised at the lack of voting, especially when the author will comment saying "thanks for the advice" or something like that. We seem to have a lot of question askers with pretty low acceptance rates too - at least from a quick glance at some random questions - so please, also accept an answer.
A lot of business questions relate to a certain country rather than apply to all countries. Wondering if it makes sense to start to add some type of geographic tag to the questions?
row.Title: geographic tagging for questions

row.Body: Does this refer to the percentage of time that a questioner marks his questions as answered or is it something else?
row.Title: What is "X% accept rate"?

row.Body:
The short answer is "yes", the accept rate is the percentage of answers that a user accepts. But there are stipulations:

The following rules are used in the calculation:

  • Questions must not be community wiki.
  • Questions must not be closed.
  • Questions must be more than 3 days old.
  • Questions must have at least 1 answer.
  • There must be at least four eligible questions as determined by the above rules, otherwise the statistic will not appear.

You can read the complete details of the feature in this blog post: New Question Asker Features.

This site has a lot of issues with people not voting in general. Questions across many SE sites get less votes than answers. I think part of the problem is people ask questions and don't come back if it doesn't get answered right away - or if it does they take the answer and still don't come back - or up vote the answerer or even accept the answer.

the issue to me seems that we have alot of people that come, ask a handful of questions, then never come back. they aren't vested so votes aren't a big deal to them as long as they get an answer. There is just a lack of community somewhat I think.

+1, I think it's a good idea. It will probably take some time to gain acceptance, but I think it's useful.

What is a little harder is to determine how big/small the geographic zones should be. Both for the US and for EU, the situation is often that there are some considerations regarding federal / EU harmonized laws, but the also other considerations that apply locally / nationally.

That said, maybe we could start off with something like:

  • United-States
  • Canada
  • European-Union
  • India
  • China

What do others think?

I would avoid locale specific tags except when the nature of the question makes it fundamentally locale-specific.

The goal is for questions and answers to apply to a wide as audience as possible. Obviously this isn't always possible, but it's definitely the overarching goal:

http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2011/01/the-wikipedia-of-long-tail-programming-questions/

It is OK to edit a question to make it more general. With the power of editing comes the power to take someone’s selfish, very specific question, and edit it a little bit until they’re asking the more general question that hundreds of people encounter. For example, if someone asks, “I set up a web server at home but I can’t access it from work,” it’s OK to rewrite the question as, “What things should I check when a web server running at home is not visible on the Internet?” In fact, sometimes selfish, stupid questions of the “do my homework” variety can be easily edited into a form where the answer will provide an extremely valuable resource for the internet at large

Also, I would note that "teach me how to fish" is sort of the point here, e.g. don't tell me how to find cheap office space in New York City, but teach me what I need to know to make a smart deal on office space (almost) anywhere in the world.

If a question really is specific to a geography or jurisdiction, I think it should be tagged. For example, questions about taxes, licenses, business registration, etc., are likely to be specific to a single legal jurisdiction, and even though they are not universal, they're still very valuable to have here.

If a question is sufficiently universal (or if the answers are likely to be universal), there is no need to tag it.

Unless the location is essential to the understanding of that particular question (taxes, legal issues, etc), there's no need for a location tag. Users are free to edit and suggest tags that make the question clearer, but I don't think most questions are that location-specific. If the author's locations is important, you can tag it as such… but the body of the questions should include any pertinent information needed to add context.

Tags help searching and are used to draw interest (or exclude) certain types of questions. On a site about start-ups, I can't see how a location tag makes viewing or finding questions any easier. Who's going to say "I don't want to see any questions tagged 'India'?" The vast majority of questions are location neutral so such preferences or exclusions would only be counter-productive.

I wouldn't be in favor of any site-wide convention or policy about location tags for questions across the board. The majority of questions are not location specific. And I don't really like the idea of a required tag or somehow dividing or labeling all the questions in that manner. Tagging is inherently ad hoc; users should be free to use any sort of "categorization" that is appropriate for their specific question.
On the message list there is a column for the number of views. Occasionally I see one that replaces views with kviews. What is that?
row.Title: What are "kviews"?

row.Body: k is short form for a thousand. So its saying one thousand views.

There are certainly some forces on the site, that are quite destructive. Consider the upvoting vs. downvoting ratio of this user for example. Before getting removed the same user had an answer, which had a total of four downvotes on a question where the user tried to take away the motivation of a 15 year old asking a good question. I believe that some negative forces needs to be corrected in a very clear manner, or else the community might be heading off down the same road as Wikipedia where the initial positive spirit of the community has to a large degree vanished. The users answer, which was removed, did not have any noticable impact on the reputation of the user.

How about that we created a list of the users with the worst negative to positive voting ratio?

At the same time, I have to say that I believe the whole topic of startups is a very difficult topic, with lots of different ways to see things and advices that might be good in some situations (juristictions, cultures, niches, etc.). This compares to forums about physics or specific programming questions.

A similar question was asked before: Why aren't there country tags?

There are already some country tags in use. The ones I am aware of are:

  • usa
  • uk
  • canada
  • india
  • foreign (My guess is this tag was created in the very beginning when most users were from the US.)

As others have said, I don't think we need to include a country tag with every question. I think it's only useful when the country information is necessary to give good advice, such as with legal and tax questions. And I think if the country information is important to the question, it should be included in the text. I wouldn't rely solely on a tag.

Also, I think we should draw the line at some point. For example, I'm not sure we would need a tag for every state in the US.
When I have unread messages in my inbox a red numeral appears. However all the messages look alike. Is it as simple as the top X messages are unread?
row.Title: How to recognize unread messages in my inbox

row.Body: Correct. The number is the number of unread messages. The inbox will show you more than just the unread ones.

I would suggest for the moderators (or anyone with sufficient privileges) to clean up and remove that tag as soon as possible, before it gathers even more questions. 750 questions and counting.... and IMO it really adds ZERO value.

+1 for losing it, as it's going to sit there at the head of the tag list confusing people. Sometimes it seems to be used where 'starting' would be better, so some careful re-tagging would be helpful where it wasn't a redundant tag, just a poorly-chosen one.

Is your question about startups?

We prefer questions that can be answered, not just discussed.
row.Title: Is your question about startups?

row.Body:
Is there not room for all? Some questions have specific answers, others have a range of answers that the original poster will have to filter and determine what best suits them and finally there are a set of questions which are really best suited to a 'round table' discussion with like minded people.

One of the big benefits of this site, in my view at least, is that the latter can be accomplished without being physically close to one of the 'startup hub' areas (not everyone can afford to or has the capability of moving). The whole idea of a startup is based on individualism yet in recent years seems to have accumulated the behaviours of a 'group' or 'movement' that requires physical access to certain areas where 'experts' or 'gurus' happen to be. Given that many startups involve distributed communication over the internet this seems a little strange to me.

If questions on this site are filtered because they are too general or because there is no specific answer available I would find that very disappointing.

Regards, ShaneG

What is your perception of using the down/negative option vote on this site?

Sometimes, I'll see an answer, which though carefully worded, detailed, and thought out, I strongly disagree with.

Is voting them down the wrong thing to do in this case?

I feel as though the site needs something more subtle to distinguish between 'this is a bad answer' and 'this is a good answer I disagree with'.
row.Title: What is your perception of voting down?

row.Body:
I'm not even sure we're supposed to discuss how answers.onstartup.com is working on the site itself? The original sites (Stack Overflow, Server Fault) use a separate site for these discussions.

Regarding the "answer is concise but in my opinion incorrect", what I would suggest is:

  • Down-vote the answer (which will cost you a little bit of reputation)
  • Add a comment to the answer which briefly mentions what you disagree with.
  • Add your own answer, where you discuss at length what the proper answer is, provide pros and cons, etc.

The community will then cast votes on the original 'possibly wrong' answer and your new answer, and over time one of them will emerge as the community choice.

Edit: To clarify, I'm thinking about answers which are "incorrect" in the sense of factually wrong or badly wrong; not wrong as in "it's a matter of taste" or slightly different priorities.

Can people who down-vote also leave a comment? This site is all about collaboration and feedback where all criticism should be constructive. An anonymous down-vote hardly helps the learning process for the person asking the question.

I believe that adding a comment why you disagree is much more productive then a down vote...

The votes are anonymous... A comment promotes a discussion on the subject, which is productive to all those concerned. We are here to help each other make better decisions, and voting down does not help that.

At first I voted down spam, but I stopped doing that since it costs me reputation points, and spam is handled well in this site.

There are a lot of different questions. If the question falls in the category the FAQ describes as subjective or argumentative I dont think any answer that is "carefully worded, detailed, and thought out" serves a down vote. Use comments for these questions.

Can I ask questions that are subjective, argumentative, or require extended discussion?

Yes! In fact, lots of questions about startups fall exactly into this category, because there's often not just one right answer.

If you're used to StackOverflow, this will be different for you.

If the question falls in the category that has a right and a wrong answer the down vote is appropriate.

I have found the discussions in the comments on this site to be really good. If you disagree start the discussion so we all can learn.

PS. I still don't have the reputation to leave comments, nor to down vote

I'll never down-vote someone because I disagree. In fact, the very existence of differing, strong points of view are what I love about this site.

I've down-voted very rarely. Usually it's because something is off-topic or irrelevant.

Certainly down-vote if something is abusive, spammy, etc.. That's part of what helps me notice those things and actually delete them from the system. Fortunately this is rare in this community (for now!).
Only time I down vote is when someone is spamming the board...acting like they're asking a question but their only intention is promoting their company / product.

I tend to down vote questions that are off-topic, spam, etc. I would down vote an answer if it is harmful (And I would put a comment as well.) or if it is not an answer at all depending on how negative the response.

Like most I'd like to think I differentiate answers I may disagree with to those that are just wrong. Unlike SO, I think this site is more about being informative by promoting discussion and giving feedback instead of being "right" and getting points. The reason I have more points than some other users is probably because I read and respond to a lot of questions and answers and not because I am any type of expert. This site has been a great learning experience for me and would like to thank everyone who contributes.

I have been the victim of downvotes that end up being helpful. If someone downvotes me, but gives a comment, then, if I respond appropriately to the comment, they will undo the downvote.

It is a bit harsh, but, if the answer is seen as being completely off-base, or, your answer has nothing to do with the question, then a downvote does make sense.

A user is more likely to edit their answer, or delete it, based on a downvote, if there is a comment as to what is wrong with the answer, to undo the reputation loss.

If I see a comment, but it doesn't negatively impact me, then why go through the effort of changing my answer?

I'm using stackoverflow since the beta and the performance is pretty good in there. Since the these systems are based on stackexchange I'm not quite sure why the performance is quite bad in here. I assume stackoverflow is running on its own server. That's why it's fast.

Is there anyway to make stackexchange aware that the website is really slow and also it was totally down (was giving out ASP.NET errors) about 4-5 hours ago.

This is the beginning and I assume/hoping that this website will be quite popular soon, so it'd be a nice idea to sort out these performance issues now, instead of waiting for a bigger disaster.
row.Title: Why is this website so slow?

row.Body:
My understanding is that although this is similar code, it's not identical code. Same with the hardware.

However we're confident that as time passes they'll make the performance optimizations that they did with StackOverflow and we'll be back to good.
You must be on top of the world... congratulations !!

Hi Kevin - sorry, this is a question not an answer really. I have the same issue. I'd like to get more active on here but am short on reputation since I recently got started. You seem to have built a reputation of 198 in a month even though you've just got 1 question... did I miss something ? Can you share the secret sauce as to how you managed to did this ? Thx!

You can edit questions and answers. As a new user, your edits will not appear immediately... they will be held for a high reputation user to approve. When two high-rep users (or one moderator) approve your edit, you'll receive +2 reputation (up to a maximum of 1000).

Your edits will have to be pretty good to get approved, of course, but some things which are explicitly encouraged:

  • improve spelling and grammar
  • get rid of "Hi!" and "Thank you!" and "My question is..." all the flotsam that clutters questions
  • help rewrite questions written by non-native English speakers to be clearer and easier to understand

As far as I recall up until now I have not up-voted questions (I just broke my record with this particular question) because I don't believe there is such a thing as a bad question. There may be questions that I'm surprised are asked but the person asking is at least reaching out for more advice. All questions are equal so up-voting or down-voting makes no sense (and, as pointed out by a previous poster, doesn't seem to affect the display order).

Similar with answers - an exceptional answer (or a particularly succinct one) deserves an up-vote, a good (but not necessarily great) or obvious answer gets nothing and a particularly bad, misleading or spammy answer would get a down-vote.

I'm surprised that some of my answers have been up-voted when they are really not out of the ordinary. I appreciate it (I get more points and site access) but I don't understand it.

I guess different people have different ways of interpreting the up/down vote on things - my own interpretation may change after reading this as I know have a bit more understanding of what my peers expect.

TL;DR - From my perspective a non-vote is not negative feedback, a down-vote is. Up-votes are reserved for above ordinary questions or answers. It's how I roll :)

Regards, ShaneG

@Ryan:

This may be true (people ask questions and don't come back if it doesn't get answered right away) but I don't think it's a blanket explanation.

I have asked a single question on this site (and didn't get any answers - apart from supporting comments) but I still come back on a semi-regular basis (usually if I see an interesting question pop-up on my RSS reader or if I think of this site and decide to see what's new).

Given the nature of startups most people involved in them don't (or probably shouldn't) have a lot of time to browse this site. Right now I'm watching old X-Files episodes and browsing the questions rather than working on preparing applications for release - I'm avoiding what I consider the 'boring bits' in order to do something fun.

Perhaps that's what many other posters are doing - getting the answer they need and getting on with business. In that case I envy them being able to do that.

Regards, ShaneG

PS: I was going to post this as a comment but it grew too large.

(edit) PPS: This was posted as a response to an answer that was posted after my other one. The ordering of posts that I am seeing is now completely out of whack with the actual timeline.

To cite a specific example I spent some time composing an answer to 'What are the books or other sources that gave you the knowledge that contributed to the success of your business?' only to find once I posted my answer it had been closed by a 'Michael Pryor' as an 'exact duplicate'. The post itself registered a possible duplicate originally posted in 2009 that was asking for feedback on a very specific book (The Entrepreneur's Guide to Business Law) and requesting information on others like it.

Apart from the fact that the new question was far more generic (What are the must-read books/sites/blogs/articles for the people who start their small IT business?) is it not at all possible that new books have been published and new blogs created that would be relevant in the 12 to 18 months between the previous post and this one?

How is it that a single user can arbitrarily close an entire discussion? This whole [Closed] concept only seems to have started sometime within the last 6 months - is this a new feature that has suddenly become available to people?

Regards, ShaneG
row.Title: What is with all the 'Closed' questions recently?

row.Body:
A few times now when I've answered a question I wanted to make a document available to the person asking a question (an NDA template for example) or provide a way for them to contact me so they could follow up if they needed additional info.

The problem is that I'm reluctant to post my email address or phone number here due to spam.

What's the right way to handle this?
row.Title: What is the recommended way to connect with users

row.Body:
Twitter works good. Post your twitter account and have that person direct message you. You can exchange emails then if needed.

Plus any people that liked your answers here can follow you on twitter.

Post your email in a non-obvious way. Spam bots look for patterns and add them to a list.

Email me at apapadimoulis at inedo dot com

No one is going to spam your phone. If you're that concerend, get a Google Voice number that forwards to your real phone.
I've had a web address and an email address of the form like Alex suggest on Stackoverflow for a year and have not had a problem at all.

The way I do it is breaking up the email like this: montana "@" complimedia.com. By wrapping the @ symbol most spam bots will not recognize it as an email address but some might so it is not 100% safe.

If you have a website with a proper contact form you could share that URL and not have to worry about spam as long as your form has proper safe-guards. If you need a website and/or contact form contact me at the email address above.

Twitter will work, but I would rather someone send me an @reply then send a Direct Message because I never check those due to the high amount of spam I get. It also isn't very professional and lots of people don't use twitter (gasp).

I think it is a good idea to put your spam-proofed email address into your profile - that way anyone can continue an out-of-band discussion with you if they feel so inclined, but because they have to make the effort to look it up from your profile, it's a little less in-your-face.

<gripe>On that subject, I wish people would take the trouble to fill in their profiles - on more than one occasion by knowing a little more about the questioner would help in providing a more targeted answer.</gripe>

I am surprised how many questions have been open for more than a couple of weeks and no answer has been marked as accepted.

It would be beneficial if people would realize the importance of accepting.

Is there any way, besides just starting to put comments on some of the questions, that they should consider doing this?
row.Title: How can people be persuaded to check which answer they feel was most correct or helpful?

row.Body:
I don't know if this is what you want, but from the faq it seems that once some users get to 3K reputation they will be able to vote to close questions.

Personally speaking, I would like questions with more than one answer and positive score to automatically close within say 1 week.

On Stack Overflow specific technical questions are asked with solutions being posted. It is much easier to pick a "correct" answer there than on this forum. Here, the answers are much more subjective and often there is no such thing as a correct answer. Is it really that big a deal if answers are left unaccepted?
I like this site but there is no email option that I can find. RSS might be great but it is one more thing to check. I never get to it. Why not share this wonderful asset via email summaries?
row.Title: Why no email option?

row.Body:
Though I personally use Google Reader, here is a guide to getting RSS Feeds via Email.

I do agree that there should be some sort of Email option, but this type of discussion belongs on Meta StackExchange.

You're right! But unfortunately we don't control the platform. Part of the trade-off between getting this site going quickly and having it work and making it do exactly what we want.

+1 to the above that you can convert RSS to email.
You can! Click on your username above, then go to 'prefs'. There, you'll be able to check an option to receive e-mail responses to your activity on the site.

The duplicate post is actually "What books do you recommend?" not feedback on a specific book. There's only so many times that question can be asked, and it gets asked over and over again on all of the stack exchange sites.

  • (note the closed ones here) http://quant.stackexchange.com/search?tab=relevance&q=books
  • http://homebrew.stackexchange.com/questions/89/book-for-beginners
  • (note the difference in the questions here) http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/books

It's a poll type question where there really isn't an 'answer' just a list of books that you can vote on. It's not really the type of question that would attract great people to the site while it is still in beta.

Joel writes about it here:

It's tempting to start with easy questions, like "what are some good finance books" or "what are the best finance blogs."

Those are not good questions for the private beta, because ultimately, they don't reflect the actual content that we want this site to contain, and are not representative of it.

This site is in public beta, so I guess you could argue that this question was different than the other books question and so it should be allowed. If so, just vote to reopen. I won't close it twice. My opinion is there has been a gradual decline in the quality of this site since Jason and Dharmesh don't actively participate as much and I'm trying to head that off. The newer questions tend to be poorly worded, hard to understand, focused on discussion rather than objective answers or advice, and I don't want those broken windows to define the future of this site.

Regarding your questions on the 'close' feature: The reason a single user can close a question is because moderators can close questions with one vote. The question can be reopened but either a mod would have to reopen it or five users from the community with enough rep would have to vote to have it reopen. It's not a new feature.

For the third time in a row for a few days, I get "Portal not found" instead of the Q&A site when I try and visit answers.onstartups; here's what dig says:

$ dig answers.onstartups.com

; <<>> DiG 9.7.1-P2 <<>> answers.onstartups.com
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 816
;; flags: qr rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 1, AUTHORITY: 0, ADDITIONAL: 0

;; QUESTION SECTION:
;answers.onstartups.com.                IN      A

;; ANSWER SECTION:
answers.onstartups.com. 3572    IN      A       74.205.116.34

;; Query time: 83 msec
;; SERVER: 208.67.222.222#53(208.67.222.222)
;; WHEN: Mon Feb 14 05:35:47 2011
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 56

...where 74.205.116.34 is the IP of onstartups.com itself.

In all cases, trying after a few minutes fixes the issue. Running dig again gives:

$ dig answers.onstartups.com

; <<>> DiG 9.7.1-P2 <<>> answers.onstartups.com
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 24054
;; flags: qr rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 2, AUTHORITY: 0, ADDITIONAL: 0

;; QUESTION SECTION:
;answers.onstartups.com.                IN      A

;; ANSWER SECTION:
answers.onstartups.com. 3600    IN      CNAME   onstartups.stackexchange.com.
onstartups.stackexchange.com. 21600 IN  A       64.34.119.12

;; Query time: 209 msec
;; SERVER: 208.67.222.222#53(208.67.222.222)
;; WHEN: Mon Feb 14 05:38:35 2011
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 95

Waiwai933 also uses OpenDNS and can experience this issue.
row.Title: Intermittent "portal not found" errors when attempting to visit this Q&A

row.Body: If the post really is spam, it'll be deleted. If that happens, you can trigger a reputation recalculation to get your reputation back.

Badges are meant to be a bit mysterious. Some of the badges you can keep track of, but the ones you mention you cannot track.

Please see this post for more information.

We're switching the DNS provider for this site this weekend, so you should see improved perf next week. This site isn't currently using the same DNS as the rest of the SE network.

EDIT: This change was made 2/23. If you have any further issues, please post it as a separate question. Happy surfing! (:

Somehow I created two accounts for this site- user 8009 and user 7547. Can they be merged somehow?

Also, how did that happen? They are both linked to my other SE accounts.
row.Title: I somehow have two accounts

row.Body: You probably used different account (email) for authentication. It happened to me before on SE. I abandoned one account.

Noticed Joel's post in the blog about the stackexchange career 2.0 launch.

I also noticed that it's slanted towards stackoverflow - and that their rep / participation seems to be the deciding factor if one gets an invite.

I would think that onstartups would also benefit from having a careers area. Sure, if you're looking for a coder, go to stackoverflow - but what about other startup positions?
row.Title: Careers.onstartups.com ?

row.Body:
Possibly, but this site topic is so "soft" compared to programming, system administration, etc.

We think careers sites will work best on sites where the topic is technical and has verifiably "correct"(ish) answers to a lot of the questions.

You can however, list any Stack Exchange site on your Stack Overflow careers profile as you see fit, so there is some cross-pollination.
I asked a question that had more than one great answer. Can I check more than one answer as accepted?
row.Title: Can I accept more than one answer to a question?

row.Body:
Sorry, but no.

You can mark a question as "Community Wiki". But doing so is not semantically the same as saying "this has multiple good answers", it changes several aspects of how the post is handled and reputation is earned.

You could add a comment, in which you explain why you selected a specific post as the accepted answer, and also praise the other contributors. That's often a good way to go; as it both gives you an opportunity to explain which part of the answer turned out most important for you, as well as giving credit to the other people contributing answers.

Note that it's perfectly normal that the original posters opinion and the community opinion of which answer is "best" differs. That is what you see whenever there is an accepted answer with less upvotes than the highest non-accepted answer has.
Now I can't see the badges we all have. I was used to a particular view format (like SO) and now it is completely gone.
row.Title: Why was the users tab/screen changed?

row.Body:
SO decided to change the /user page design for all SE sites. See this post from their blog. The new format now shows most rep for the week by default, but there are other tabs. I'm not sure how they are calculating this information, but it looks to be wrong (at least on our site). For example, right now Jesper is the number one user in the weekly view with 110 rep, but if you click on the monthly view, the number one user only has 105 rep for the month, and Jesper is not on the first page at all. How can that be?

Personally, I don't like the new user page design. I find it harder to read that the old design. I think some of the changes they made only make sense for SO because they have a ton of users and questions. For example, displaying the tags each user has been most active for. I can't imagine this will be of much use to any SE site, other than SO.

As a side note, your rep might have changed recently as well. They recently recalculated everyone's rep in preparation for the new /user pages. They claim the rep re-calc was necessary to even everyone out, but I have yet to find any logic in their argument for this.

When I click the little envelope next to my name on the top bar of the screen, I move to a page partially displayed below:

My question is, what is the stuff in the green boxes? What is the top number? The bottom number? What is "acc"? Why are some characters white and some yellow?
row.Title: What are the funny green boxes all about?

row.Body: The top number is the number of votes you've received on that post. Upvotes are green, downvotes are red. The bottom number is the amount of rep you received from those votes.

I've noticed on a few occasions that decent and neutral answers are being down voted for no reason whatsoever. A couple of my answers and even a question I asked which was a valid question has been downvoted into a score of negative one.

What is the reasoning for this? Can anyone see an issue with any of my answers or one of my questions I've asked which have been down voted?

I would really appreciate some feedback and insight into this situation. All of the downvotes do not have any comments explaining so, so I am slightly confused.

I'm not trying to peddle erectile dysfunction pills, Acai berry diet supplements or ebooks on dodgy affiliate sites, I legitimately want to help answer peoples questions and this slightly deters me considering every answer I give or question I post is well thought out and checked aggressively for spelling and readability mistakes.

I know it's not only myself it's happening too, but others as well.
row.Title: What Is With The Unwarranted Downvoting On Answers

row.Body:
We certainly encourage people to leave comments when they downvote. Below 2k rep, every time you downvote you'll get a <div> reminding you to do so, in fact.

But remember that the voting rule, both up or down, is:

This question is useful and clear (click again to undo)

This answer is useful (click again to undo)

And this is visible as a tooltip on each voting arrow. However, it is not required to justify downvotes -- though it is always fair to ask in comments and here on meta as you have.

I don't see any serial downvoting statistics on your account, and I agree that your posts are certainly quality -- but I also don't see a big pattern of downvoting on your recent posts, either. So while I agree with the general concern, I'm not sure 2 posts is enough to define a pattern or trend.

Is anyone else experiencing problems with their profile ?? For one, my avatar has stopped showing up. Also my points and badges show different numbers when I log in at different times.I had 6 badges the last time I logged in and now I only have 1. Any ideas ?
row.Title: Profile Problems

row.Body:
There is one user on this site (with plenty of reputation) who's heavy on the down-vote trigger.

It's very discouraging for newer users, considering how hard it is to earn enough rep to do much of anything on this site.

When I tell people about OnStartups, one of the key aspects is the community approach to governance. Members help evovle the conent in a community that is controlled by contribution-based (or reputation-based) authoirty levels.

I'd like to start using industry-accepted buzzwords for what the reputation-based governance is called rather than having to spend time explaining it.

So, what's it called (officially or best-guess suggestions)?

Also, if there are other sites, such as ones that address site community governance, where you found your answer (or I might read more about it), consider including that source in your answer.

C. Scott
row.Title: What's the common term for referring to the reputation-based governance that's used on StackExchange?

row.Body:
Are you still having problems with your profile?

I looked at your profile and saw all 6 badges. Your main page user profile has 6 badges, while your meta page user profile has only 1 badge. Could that be the confusion?

Did you ever have a custom avatar? Right now I see you have the default identicon avatar. Your custom avatar is pulled from Gravatar.com. If you had a custom avatar, and now you have an identicon avatar, my guess is that you might have removed this particular email address from your Gravatar account, or deleted the image associted with this email address.

The identicon avatar is based on your IP address. So if you never had a custom avatar, and you were just using the default identicon avatar, the new avatar means that your IP address changed.

The folks at SO have been generous enough to offer 1 member from each SE community sponsorship to a community related conference. In exchange, all they ask is that you promote the community at the conference. As they put it:

spend a little bit of time speaking / networking / blogging / sharing during your time there, and of course mention our fine ... community here.

So, which startup related conference should we select for our lucky community member to attend?

Edit: (In response to Michael's comment.)

This is what Jeff says in his announcement of this initiative (linked above):

Sending community members to conferences is something we are very serious about, because we believe so deeply in learning. Going to a conference to speak or participate — and bringing that experience back to our community — is a great way to share what you’ve learned. That’s the very principle our communities are founded on, this idea that we’re all there to learn from each other.

And that’s all that we ask in return — that these community members share their experiences with their respective communities, and the greater internet, in some way...
row.Title: Community Conference Sponsorships

row.Body:
I’ll start off by suggesting the Business of Software Conference. It’s an awesome event that has one of the best speaker line-ups around. Previous year speakers include Joel Spolsky, Dharmesh Shah, and Jason Cohen. It will be held Oct 23-26, 2011 in Boston.

I’ll also volunteer myself as the guinea pig for this first round :-)
These two types of questions seem to come up over and over again. Any thoughts?
row.Title: What questions are left after 'how do I market my business' and 'how do I split up equity'?

row.Body:
For questions that come up over and over (and over and over and over), we definitely recommend writing the "canonical" question and answer, and closing all of them as dupes of that one.

http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2011/01/the-wikipedia-of-long-tail-programming-questions/

Help us build a great library of canonical answers. If you keep seeing the same form of questions, whether it’s mod_rewrite rules on Server Fault, freezing computers on Super User, or how to use regular expressions to parse HTML, write a great, canonical answer, once and for all. Make it community wiki so that as many other people as possible can make it great. Work really hard on writing something that is clear, concise, and understandable by as wide an audience as possible.
We moved this a bit to the new user greeting sidebar -- to see it, use Google Chrome Incognito mode.

GeeknRolla - March 30 - UK

Annual conference to bring together Europe’s technology startups to network with investors and talk about how they create and build themselves.

The Founder Conference - May 3 - Silicon Valley

The Founder Conference 2011 will take place at the Center for Performing Arts of Mountain View on May 3rd, 2011. Topics range from finding co-founders, how to pitch to investors, the new trends with super-angels, create buzz when you launch, and more.

Speakers include Naval Ravikant (AngelList), Adeo Ressi (TheFunded), Guy Kawasaki, Robert Scoble, Tim Young (About.me), George Zachary (Charles River Ventures).

Lean Startup Conference - May 5 - Vancouver

Who should attend?

Anyone who is: either working for or planning to work for a start-up losing sleep because of having a brilliant idea and wanting to see it implemented tasked with designing new features and wants to know how to validate ideas and business assumptions with customers wanting to reduce waste and amplify learning curious to know what all the excitement is about

TechCrunch Disrupt - May 23 - New York

This past September, over 2,000 people assembled in San Francisco to watch as 24 companies launched their innovative new businesses at TechCrunch Disrupt. In addition, nearly 70 speakers and panelists graced the stage, including IAC’s Barry Diller, Digg’s Kevin Rose, Google’s Marissa Mayer and Bradley Horowitz, Ron Conway, Peter Thiel and surprise visits by Google CEO Eric Schmidt and San Francisco Mayor Gavin Newsom.

This has been discussed before, but this site has had some serious 'broken windows' problems with poor questions, badly worded questions, repeat questions about marketing, etc. Just last July we had Rand Fish on here as well as Dharmesh and Jason and other business celebrities. Their activity has essentially dried up.

Now we still get the CEO of stack exchange, but hardly anyone else noteworthy stops by because the quality of the stuff being discussed is too beginner and entry level. We've had a rash of new user questions that are poorly worded but hold the stub of a possibly good question and instead of just closing them I've been trying to breathe some life into them.

One was "how do company close funding round". I changed it to "How do I raise a second round of VC when our first round VC passes". Related, but not the intent of the original asker. The problem is the original asker's question stunk, horribly. The question I turned it into, could actually be interesting. I don't really know how the original asker feels, but I hope that

  • he/she understands that the new question is a better question than the original one
  • he/she understands that if they don't want their question edited, they don't grok the point of SE
  • I don't give a hoot what their question actually turned into, just that it was a good relevant question for this site that makes people want to come back

For one of these questions, the user got upset with me for 'hijacking their words'.

The original question looked like so:

Million Dollar Homepage success reason

What do you think about the success of http://www.milliondollarhomepage.com/?

Why did it became a quick hit? I would love to have your thoughts on its success story.

Here's what I saw wrong with this question:

  1. The title was not actually a question
  2. The url link should be actual url markdown and have the name of the site (not the url)
  3. Most importantly: What do you think about is not a type of question for stack exchange

Based on #3, I would have normally closed questions like this, but instead I've been trying to salvage them into something better; otherwise there's not really much left on the newest tab.

How can I achieve the goal of elevating this site without making new users upset?
row.Title: How to respond to users who are offended when you edit their questions?

row.Body: I have always thought this site was not aggressive enough about closing bad questions. If the question is not salvageable with some approximation to the OP's intent, then I believe they should simply be closed. If it is salvageable, then I say one should add a comment to provide direction or edit away. If the OP doesn't see the value in the edits and/or can't engage via the comments to get to a quality question, then we as a community, are probably not losing a whole lot if they never come back.

Whenever possible, this community should edit, clean up, and improve those question to live up to the quality that should be on this site. For every user who complains about fixing (or closing) their posts, there are hundreds of others who are privately applauding your efforts. I hear from them all the time.

Try and make your efforts a learning experience for others to follow. Leave thoughtful comments about why the question needed to be improved... and link to meta posts like this one for support. If your reason for editing can benefit from further explanation, create a meta post to help others and link to that one. Users need to understand why a rigorous adherence to quality-above-all is so vitally important to this type of Q&A… otherwise we're just asking the same uninspiring question you find on any other phpBB forum.

Hopefully, the time and effort you put into fixing the posts will make them worthy of imitation.

The end goal is that others should follow your example. Having just a small number dedicated editors will not scale. If other do not follow your lead, the site will ultimately succumb to poor quality and fail.

The front page is so important to the design of this site. To attract experts, you need a site where people are asking very interesting and challenging questions. Those questions are the first thing potential experts see when they visit your site for the first time. They'll either love what they see, or they wont. That's why quality participation is so vitally important.

You want to make those questions worthy of imitation.

FWIW this is covered in the http://answers.onstartups.com/faq#editing, not that anyone reads that...

Other people can edit my stuff?!

Like Wikipedia, this site is collaboratively edited, and all edits are tracked. If you are not comfortable with the idea of your questions and answers being edited by other trusted users, this may not be the site for you.
