This question seems like it should be a dup of something that already exists:

steps/tips to create an online company

but I can't find the canonical question this should be a dup of. Does it exist already?
row.Title: Can someone help me find the already existing 'how do I create a company' question?

row.Body:
(A friend who knows I'm interested in startups forwarded me the link below. Sharing here.)

2011 MicroConf - The Conference for Self-Funded Startups - June 6 & 7 - Las Vegas

What is MicroConf 2011? MicroConf is a two-day conference focused on self-funded startups and single founder software companies. A limited supply of discounted pre-launch tickets will be available soon; sign up for pre-launch below.

Who Should Attend? Anyone launching a startup with no outside funding who wants to learn from, and hang out with, 225 of today's leading founders and entrepreneurs.

Who's Behind MicroConf? MicroConf is hosted by Rob Walling and Mike Taber of the Startups for the Rest of Us podcast and Micropreneur.com.

Possible Duplicate:
What to do with feedback on my site type questions

Is someone asking "What do you think of my startup?" an on topic question for this site?
row.Title: Are 'review my startup' questions on topic?

row.Body: No - because essentially there are no real answers to this question.

You are mostly right, but do not make up new questions that are not what the original poster intended. In your example, you are asking about raising a second round. Was that in the original question? If not, I can see why the original poster would not be happy.

Are there any (non-empty) tag wikis on this site? Is there a way to find them?

I tried to open a dozen tag wikis, but they were all empty.
row.Title: Non-empty tag wikis?

row.Body:
http://answers.onstartups.com/tags/tag-wikis lists some (currently only 4), but if there is text above the tag then it is not empty.

I don't know if I believe it, but according to this there are currently only two non-empty tag wikis:

  • Tax
  • SaaS

I noticed that when a question is modified, it is displayed 2 times in my RSS feed reader. I noticed that it was displayed three times today.

I don't know if it's a problem related to my reader or a problem related to the RSS feed, so I post it here just in case it could be a valuable information.

In the screenshot, you can see three questions. They are all the same. If you click on each of them, you arrive on the exact same page. The only difference is the title.
row.Title: Possible issue with RSS feed when question text is changed?

row.Body:
Startup 2011 - New York - May 10

http://www.businessinsider.com/startup2011

From what I can see, this site is doing quite OK. But I don't understand why it hasn't graduate yet.

Any plans for graduation?
row.Title: When OnStartups will graduate?

row.Body:
A few stats:

  • http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/6243/startup-business

  • http://stackexchange.com/sites?expand=true

Also refer to Robert's post here:

http://meta.writers.stackexchange.com/questions/221/what-happens-now

But if that's TL;DR, in general ...

  1. Share great questions and answers
    http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/09/announcer-booster-and-publicist-badges/

  2. Vote, vote, vote
    http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/10/vote-early-vote-often/

  3. Love and reward your new users for being awesome!
    http://answers.onstartups.com/review

Actually, I'm a bit concerned about the quality of the questions. We seem to get a lot of weird questions from people with a reputation of 1. It's all over the map with tax, incorporation, self-promotion... It's not spam, but it's not very high quality either. Am I being elitist?

Regarding the prior post, I'll admit that I'm new here, but I think a lot of incorporation/taxation questions are critical questions which I wish I'd had a forum to post questions about when I was trying to figure them out. When I look back at some of the times when tasks were eating me alive, it was incorporation/tax stuff. Granted, the answer is almost always "ask your lawyer" and "ask your accountant," - but in startups, those lawyers and CPAs could be doing you a favor or working for nothing; you're not always able to pay retail for them. If the questions are intelligent and genuine, why not?

My sense is that the only domain in which Quora is doing a better job than Stack Exchange is startups.

In my opinion, the thoughtfulness and relevance of questions and answers, the profile and level of experience of the participants and the pace of discussions on this site is lower than other Stack Exchange sites and inferior to Quora for the time being.

Others have also commented on the abundance of questions on incorporation, taxation and sharing equity that lack any nuance or sophistication and ultimately are not compelling for the experts on the site.

What can be done to raise the level of the conversation on OnStartups to make it a real alternative for folks on Quora?
row.Title: How can we raise the quality of questions on OnStartups?

row.Body:
I think it's a matter of slowly grinding away. Answering questions, promoting links when logical, but not in excess.

Basically, just doing all the things you do to build a community. At some point there will hopefully be unexpected big break with a key mention someplace at a pivotal time.

Well, consider the history: Quora started with silicon valley insiders and that was always their seed audience.

Despite the huge home field advantage, I'd try to exploit one key area in which we clobber Quora -- we're so much lower friction to participate in.

That is:

  • no sign up whatsoever is necessary to answer or ask
  • the home page contains a clear list of questions defining the topic and "what's hot"

So sharing a link to onstartups with someone is a much clearer invitation to participate than on Quora, where you have to let Quora have unfettered access to your Facebook and/or Twitter logins and friends lists to even begin participating.

So, two suggestions:

  1. Start with a kernel of generously sharing high quality questions and answers. The more we share, the more visitors we attract, and some percentage of those will be stickier here due to our radically lower barrier to participation. In the long run that is our biggest competitive advantage on someone else's topic home field.

    http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/09/announcer-booster-and-publicist-badges/

  2. Great new users are more precious than gold. Shower posts by great new users with tender love, care, and lots and lots of upvotes:

    http://answers.onstartups.com/users
    http://answers.onstartups.com/review

The same question has been asked on META.SO and is getting more attention there. So I will follow it there.

http://meta.stackoverflow.com/questions/18051/prevent-title-edits-to-spawn-a-new-rss-post

One of the lessons from the 7 essential meta questions of every beta: to identify (and recruit) the jeff- and joel-like bloggers, pundits, podcasters, publishers and celebrities of our industry.

So how do we recruit and retain contributors to the community...it sounds like 'a leaky bucket' from subscription businesses to me, hope you dont mind me playing out the analogy...

  • Grow thy funnel. I think Jeff & Brian's point is the best marketing channel is to broadcast & share great content. I think using twitter and facebook (and linkedin) is passive marketing. Are we organized on identifying which specific pundits we should recruit?

  • Convert and Engage. I think Brian nailed this - slowly build great questions and answers to convert folks to active contributors.

  • Retain. I don't have enough history to know (and will try to dig up the answer myself), but if have we had experiences of great contributors dropping out of the community, would be great to learn lessons on how other stack exchanges have recaptured the good guys.
We can all spend more time reviewing answers, questions, voting and answering. Attracting some notable experts to answer can help to.

One thing that Quora does better than StackExchange is that it explicitly asks you in the flow to post on Facebook or Twitter. Yes, you can suggest here in meta to a very finite audience that we ought to broadcast in general but at Quora it is built right in.

I am enjoying reading the thoughtful responses in this -- my first -- meta site conversation. I am new to the site. I have been around for -- about a day.

I like the structure. the format. And I have enjoyed the opportunity to answer some questions with some expertise that I have built up over the years. I am sure there are lots of conversations on here about how to build the site, but I would like to address this specific question --

Quality of Questions.

Some are good. Some suck. Some are inviting. Some not so much. What is the most important is are there filters that allow me to find the good ones fast? There might be -- I haven't figured out how to use them yet. Are they the ones with the most votes? Most active?

Are there featured questions which be reflect and model the type of questions that seem to spark the best conversation? The only featured one I have seen on the list is one that "bought" its way there with reputation points -- and I am having a hard time seeing it as a great example of the type of question the community would want to feature.

I haven't posted a question yet. I know I should. I know it would help. I started writing one. I left the screen before it was completed. Why? I didn't feel like I knew enough to write a good question for this site. I haven't seen enough good ones yet.

I see that badges are given for the people who post outstanding questions -- perhaps there would be an easy way I could go and see the people who have earned those badges and the questions that was so exemplary?

Perhaps after I have been on the site with a certain level of activity a "community leader" will reach out and say hello, we enjoyed your answers -- how can I help you ask a question?"

Back when I did community development -- a couple professions ago -- we had a game to teach community called "Shake your assets." It was about how a complex system like a community needs people to ask as much as give. The act of giving is often seen as a gift to someone in need. But asking is a gift to some one who has a talent or resource to give. For a community to be healthy there must be a balance for those who ask and those who give.

So, in summary:

  • Make it easier for us to find good questions
  • Profile and Feature great questions
  • Allow me to learn from best
  • Make it a goal of the community to solicit questions from all community members.

I look forward to learning more from all of you! practices on good questions

There is a question at the moment which I think is a legit startup question. Ok he doesn't know what he is asking ... but thats the point of the site isn't it?

Instead of people politely answering his question they give him a bunch of down votes and are downright rude to him in their answers.

What is the protocol and is there a write up or "how to play nicely" page that we can direct these guys to? ... maybe they have to write an apology before they are allowed back on or something.
row.Title: How to deal with nasty answers

row.Body:
I love this question. I was just thinking this very issue looking at same responses a first time asker was getting related to raising capital.

I think that there is a strong correlation between this question and the previous one about improving the quality of the questions on the site. We should be nurturing and encouraging participation. Not stiffing it. A nasty answer is a way to stifle participation.

I think the answer is that you, me -- and all of us that do care -- take a little extra time to ensure that we write answers that affirm and support while we answer. As a consultant I strive to make my answer palatable -- by making them a sandwich. The meat is between two pieces of praise bread. I don't do it to be cheesy -- but as a reminder to myself to see the positive. And to acknowledge it. Can't say I always do it -- but I will try.

And we can out post the nasty with the affirming. Which is something that I see in almost all of your responses Rob!
When I look at the list of questions here in meta, some of them are gold and some are dark gray. How come?
row.Title: A meta meta question (ouch)

row.Body:
I have earned the right to launch a tag! Yeah. It is a right and privileged that I am looking forward to exercising.

Based on the experience of past users I am curious if there is a right way or a wrong way to launch a new tag. Is there methods that have drawn the most new people into the community? Others methods that have not been so successful?

Thank you for your answers/feedback and wisdom.
row.Title: How do you effectively launch a new tag?

row.Body: The gold questions are the ones that you've already browsed. Similar to how a blue hyperlink turns purple after you've already browsed it.

Not only do I think this fails to respect the OP, but I think the site is in real trouble if questions need to be edited to the point where they take on new meaning.

Yes, a lot of people write poorly, especially where English is a second language. And I'm sure you could write many questions to be "better". But I would question what type of site you end up with if that becomes common.

With apologies to Michael A. Jackson --

Step One: Don't do it!

Step Two (for experts only): Don't do it yet!

But seriously, think carefully about why a tag should exist before creating a new tag, and strongly favor using existing, broader tags before creating a new, more specialized tag.

Some things to think about:

  • Who would find this tag useful?
  • What binds together questions with this tag?
  • How would I guide others in using this tag on future questions?

On a mature site, many of the tags have already been created -- so the important work is around curating and organizing the tags that already exist, so that questions are easier to find.
It sure would be nice if while at any meta forum there would be a link back to the non-meta forum, e.g. a link back to http://answers.onstartups.com would be nice here at the meta forum.
row.Title: Getting back to the non-meta forum

row.Body:
LOL. I couldn't find it forever (well three days) since I joined either.

It is already there. Go up to the top navigation bar in black. Next to your name After the number (impressive!) After the badges you have earned See chat? Don't click that. See main? That's it -- that will take you back to the main forum.

:)

I don't necessarily disagree with voting a question down if it's poorly written b/c people don't want to waste their time on a nonsensical question. The negative comments are totally unproductive and immature.

As far as a solution, they should have a mechanism to hide an answer or comment if enough people mark it as off topic, mean or inappropriate. The writer's comments will be visible to him, but no one else. He doesn't even know it's been cloaked. I'm not on this site a lot, but I thought they had some way of dealing w/ this already?

I have seen this same copy paste answer in a few posts recently and while I'm not against people linking back to their own site for relevant reference material (hand up, I do that myself) but this seems a bit out of bounds.

Can we flag it? Block it? soemthing?
row.Title: What is the policy with straight advertising in answers like this?

row.Body:
It is completely and totally unacceptable -- flag it for moderator attention and we'll destroy the account, removing all posts.

I've seen more borderline "is this promotion?" cases before but this one is egregious:

http://answers.onstartups.com/faq#promotion

May I promote products or websites I am affiliated with here?

Be careful, because the community frowns on overt self-promotion and tends to vote it down and flag it as spam. Post good, relevant answers, and if they happen to be about your product or website, so be it. However, you must disclose your affiliation in your answers. Also, if a huge percentage of your posts include a mention of your product or website, you're probably here for the wrong reasons. Our advertising rates are quite reasonable; contact our ad sales team for details. We also offer free vote-based advertising for open source projects.

I hate spam, so feel free to email via the address at the bottom of the page if it's not getting handled quickly enough through regular moderator flags.
I have seen on SO a lot of "mixed" kind of spam: "Good answer" + "look for more info on my web site". I always flag them.

This question (new link) was asked when the site was new.

Most of the answers said -- let's give the site some time and identified the "newbie" variable that kept people from being able to vote.

Now the site is older. It is still in beta-- and there are now a significant number of users, many with extraordinarily well earned reputations -- yet it seems as the "conversion rate" from views to answers/votes is fairly low.

I have had a lot of fun upvoting. I up-vote anyone who answers a question I ask in what I consider to be a legitimate answer. I be sure to upvote every question I answer -- if it was good enough to garner an answer from the likes of me, why wouldn't I vote it up?

Clearly I am using the upvote differently from others on the community. Why? What am I missing? Is there some secret desire to become the top ranked person and the strategy is never to vote for any potential "competitor" questions/answers?

I notice on the badges that there are only 26 (!) people who have voted 300 times, only 26 (!) people have ever used all 30 votes in the same day or more -- and only 3 (!!!) people have earned the sportsmanship badge for consistent upvoting competing answers. (Really, none of the other answers to the questions you answered added significant value?)

I am confused. Please, tell me what I am missing. Thanks!!
row.Title: What is the secret lost art of voting?

row.Body:
What you might be missing is that this site started life as a Stack Exchange 1.0 site

http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/04/changes-to-stack-exchange/

Much of its content and userbase was imported from that older community.

We find that imported Stack Exchange 1.0 communities are much, much 'sicker' than the ones we launched through Area 51, which started in summer of 2010:

http://area51.stackexchange.com/faq

They are 'sicker' because:

  • they did not have a meta to handle governance and organization of their communities
  • they did not have chat to coordinate real time activities
  • they were not a part of our larger Q&A network and could not "import" experienced users who understand how our flavor of Q&A works

In short, these imported Stack Exchange 1.0 communities are not galvanized or as effective as the newer, more democratically created communities that emerged from the Area 51 process.

It will take time to overcome these obstacles, but your very post is evidence that it is happening...
The Unanswered tab is full of old answered questions. Is this thing working?
row.Title: Unanswered tab has answered questions

row.Body:
[Edited - removed incorrect information]

The correct answer can be found in this post from the stackexchange board.

A question is considered "answered" if either of the following happen:

  • an answer gets an up vote, or
  • an answer is accepted.

So either condition will cause the message to be removed from the Unanswered queue.

I don't think this is a shortcoming of the board software - its indicative of the type of questions posted here. Many have no true "answer" only good advice.

Perhaps there should be some suggestions that the question poster should select the one they feel best represents their view of the answer.
I have 2 user profiles on this website - one from when I answered questions before I registered. Can someone please tell me how to amalgamate them?
row.Title: Two User Profiles

row.Body: I have this issue as well. I don't like the OpenID system, seems buggy and it's a bit unintuitive.

Try asking on the Meta site.

http://meta.stackexchange.com/

I've looked on the meta site. What we really need is for an administrator to merge our accounts with those that were created for us when we weren't logged in. I'm not sure why it doesn't do this automatically.

How do we get in touch with an administrator?
Why are the other user competitors? Isn't the goal a healthy community nurturing and supporting healthy sustainable start-ups? How percisly does someone win?

How does being a lone downvote on a question without comment helpful?

It provides no feedback to the user on how to improve or get better. I have been on the site less than a week. I am still learning the communities' expectations and norms. I find it hard to understand how- especially in an environment with such limited voting- how being the lone downvote on a question is in any way helpful to guiding a user to ask a better question.

Let me know- thanks.
row.Title: How do anoymous downvotes build community?

row.Body:
I really value the idea of the reputation points on Onstartups. They make sense to me. I have been impacted by the correlation between an answer to my questions and the perceived competition in "securing points"

What is the value of this competition? How does this work on the other stacks? What does the drive to get more points that someone else add to the community experience?

Thanks!
row.Title: What is the value of competition on onstartups?

row.Body:
Broadly speaking, this is covered by the faq:

http://answers.onstartups.com/faq#reputation

If you’d like to help us run OnStartups - Stack Exchange, you’ll need to earn some reputation first. Reputation is a rough measurement of how much the community trusts you. Reputation is never given, it is earned by convincing fellow users that you know what you’re talking about.

Reputation is peers vouching for other peers.
It probably happened by using two different openid's for logging in. Just send an email to team@stackexchange.com and they will fix it very soon. (Happened to me recently on another site).

Is there a "usage cycle" for OnStartups? By week, month, time of year? Are there standard lulls -- like the end of a quarter?

Is there a chart where unique visitor rates over time can be considered?

Thanks!
row.Title: What is the OnStartups Calendar?

row.Body:
I'd expect the question distribution, by hour of day, to be similar to this:

http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2009/01/the-best-time-to-ask-a-stack-overflow-question/

As for weekday, as a business oriented site I'd also expect the traffic graph to be strong on M, T, W, Th, and ramp down on F to the weekend -- traffic is usually about 1/3 its normal levels on Sa and Su.

On How to plan exit the accepted answer has been flying around considerably. It's now on an answer that the poster has commented doesn't answer his question.

Shouldn't it be up to the poster to assign which question he feels answers his question? What traceability is there as to who is assigning the accepted answer and what priviledges are required to view this?
row.Title: Transparency of accepted answers

row.Body:
Shouldn't it be up to the poster to assign which question he feels answers his question?

The only way for the accepted answer to be set, is if the owner of the question sets it.

What traceability is there as to who is assigning the accepted answer and what priviledges are required to view this?

Only the question owner can set the accepted answer.

It's obscure, but you can see the history of accepts in the timeline (experimental feature, not really linked from anywhere..)

http://answers.onstartups.com/posts/22580/timeline
Another thing to consider is the way we dismiss the "sketchiness" of the site as stated in the FAQ. A lack of elegance of design will definitely keep some folks away.

OnStartups is:

for entrepreneurs looking to start or run a new business

Why are questions about shutting down a business excluded? Don't most startups fail?
row.Title: Why are questions about shutting down a business excluded?

row.Body:
If you are an entrepreneur and need to shut down your business, I am sure that is on topic.

I'm always glad when people read the /faq but in this case I think you might be reading it a bit too literally. :)

@Joseph Barisonzi: Downvotes without comments are not helpful. In general, if a post is downvoted then it's good form to add a comment as to why, and/or then remove the downvote if the post is edited and improved.

That said, a single downvote shouldn't do significant damage. A singe downvote can happen for lots of reasons; fx someone speed-reads and misunderstands the post, or the post genuinely isn't a good fit for this site but the downvoter doesn't have time to add a more helpful comment, etc. A single upvote brings +10 reputation points, so upvotes are much stronger than downvotes.

Zuly Gonzales notes that undeserving downvotes are often countered by one or many "sympathy upvotes", so the net effect ends up being positive for the poster.

Jeff Atwood blogged about the rationale for the design decision to have downvotes here: http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2009/03/the-value-of-downvoting-or-how-hacker-news-gets-it-wrong/

What are the rules around a down vote?

This answer is from a new guy with 6 rep, it was a link to a commercial site but it did go some way to answering the question and didn't "feel" like a deliberate sales pitch.

For reference ... Am I being touchy or was the person down voting being a little rough?
row.Title: Rules on voting down answers

row.Body:
As I understand it, there are two classes of off-topic questions:

  1. Really off-topic: Spam, subjective, etc.
  2. Slightly off-topic: Good question, but this is not quite the right forum for it.

If the slightly off-topic questions are deleted with no explanation (rather than closed with an explanation), how will the poster (and others) learn what this site's topic boundaries are?
row.Title: If slightly off-topic questions are deleted, how will posters learn what this site's topic boundaries are?

row.Body:
I agree James. I think that anonymous off-topic closes would not be helpful to new members of the community.

It takes multiple votes to close a question. Hopefully each of those who do so will provide a comment or explanation in the comment section. That way they-- and all of us -- can learn.

There is also an edit function where other community members can edit a question to bring it back onto topic. I believe that there are many community members that strive to edit before they click to close.

Welcome to the site -- and I hope that we see a question of yours on the main board soon!

Is it an either/or question -- is "you are being touchy" AND "the person down voting could have been being a little rough" both options?

If it can be a both/and -- that is what I am going with. :)

I think down voting without an attempt to edit or comment in a fledging community that should be encouraging and embracing new members is unhelpful at best and off putting at worst.

Fortunately there are members of the community who often use their "up-votes" to offset errant down voting.

I see a post back on Oct 22 '10 announcing a slate of moderators. It references an impending elections.

What I don't see is: 1. Announcement of the election 2. Results of the elections 3. Posting of who the moderators are today and their term.

Could someone point me in the direction where the community's leadership information is shared? Thanks!
row.Title: Who are the moderators?

row.Body:
You should generally look at the user's profile to see if there is a pattern of spamming, or gamely attempting to mask spamming by providing weak, barely topical answers "in addition to" spam.

http://answers.onstartups.com/users/9214/frank

This user seems provisionally Ok to me so far.

Our site hasn't had an election yet. Election dates are determined by SE when they feel the site is ready for it. Since our site didn't go through the usual Area 51 process, we tend to lack some of the qualities SE likes to see in their communities.

When we are ready for elections, it will be posted here on the meta.

Is there some secret desire to become the top ranked person and the strategy is never to vote for any potential "competitor" questions/answers?

No, I don't think this is the case. The lack of voting has been an issue with this site for a while. I have yet to figure out why people don't upvote. I don't think it has anything to do with being #1, but I could be wrong.

In fact, I think it's a lot more important to upvote new users than it is to upvote us oldtimers with high rep. Upvoting new users will hopefully encourage them to stick around. It will also let them reach important rep milestones that will allow them to help keep the community organized (e.g. editing, retagging, voting to close/open questions). So I would hope, and encourage, people to upvote the newbies more than those on the first page.

I think it boils down to different people having different philosophies on voting. Why our site tends to have a lower rate of voting than other SE sites, I don't know.

The best thing you can do is lead by example. Upvote as you see fit, and hopefully others will follow. Also leave comments when appropriate.

and only 3 (!!!) people have earned the sportsmanship badge for consistent upvoting competing answers. (Really, none of the other answers to the questions you answered added significant value?)

Something to keep in mind about the sportsmanship badge is that it is awarded when you upvote 100 competing answers. I would imagine that a lot of people have upvoted competing answers, but upvoting 100 competing answers is not necessarily an easy task. I, myself, have upvoted several competing answers, but I haven't been able to reach the 100 mark yet. At one point I even went back to some of my old answers looking for competing answers I could upvote just so I could get the badge ;-)

Here's what makes getting this badge a challenge: When I see a question I am able to answer, if the question already has answers, I read the answers first before posting an answer of my own. If I find that the posted answers address the question, then I upvote the answers, and move on. There's no point in answering the question if there is nothing for me to add. If however, I find that the already posted answers don't address the question adequately, or if I think there is something else I can add to the discussion, then I post an answer of my own. In this case, if the current answers don't address the question adequately it makes it harder for me to upvote them. It's not to say that it's impossible, but the opportunities for this are limited.

Another aspect of this is that there are times that people get so carried away answering a question that they forget to upvote altogether (including the question itself). This has happened to me on several occasions.

There seems to be a new StackExchange site with similar objectives as this site. They have a killer domain name. But I'm not sure how worthy/credible the discussion which are taking place there are. I have not registered on their site yet, I am sceptical.

There seems to be lot of communities rising for discussing startups. In this kind of scenarios how does a new entrant gain community and trust?
row.Title: One more StackExchange site www.startups.com

row.Body: Startups.com is owned by the same group that does KillerStartups.com I believe, which has been around for a while. So it's going to get some great exposure right off the bat, as well as the great domain name. I don't think this one will have any trouble gaining traction.

I've been looking at questions on both sites and it seems that onstartups has more questions relating to venture capital based startups and fewer lifestyle/partnership startup questions. Maybe that is one way for Dharmesh and Jason to distinguish this site from the other.

I noticed that this site seems to attract more people that are earlier into the startup process, which is important, as there are so many issues just getting started.

So, the two are not really competing for the same people, yet, but, eventually it may come down to only one getting the majority, and the one that best figures out how to go beyond what StackExchange gives them will probably win.

There's always been a lot of communities and forums for startup founders -- or anything else you can think of!

The Joel On Software Business of Software forums, the Ning group by the same name by Neil Davidson, the stuff Bob Walsh does, VentureBeat..... there will always be a lot.

It's a good thing to have many communities, unless by fragmenting you prevent a truly fantastic group to appear.

I think the group's culture will develop itself, as noted elsewhere here. It will be interesting!

I have recently earned the privileged of accessing the "moderator tools". On the privilege description there is some basic information. It didn't tell me where I access the tools but fortunately I hit refresh and happened to notice a new menu item on the user bar that said "tools" :)

I am wondering if others that are actively using the moderator tools could provide me additional guidelines, best practices, or words of advice before I start to take the responsibility of moderation seriously.

Thank you.
row.Title: Guidelines on use of the "Moderator Tools"

row.Body:
Interesting. In the past you needed 10000 rep to get access to the moderator tools. I wonder when they changed this.

My advice is to slowly become familiar with the tools. There's no need to rush into using all the tools. Learn from the community, and use your best judgement. Some actions will be no brainers, like deleting deliberate spam, while others you may not be so sure about. On things that are in the gray area, let the community guide you. If you are unsure about something, pose it to the community here on meta, and let them decide.

You won't make everyone happy, and that's OK, but as long as a majority of the people are happy you have succeeded.

Congrats, and thanks for helping out!

In @Zuly's response to my question about moderator tools, she expressed suprise about a change to the Stackexchange platform.

Is there docuementation of the changes made to the answers.onstartups.com platform, specifically the reputation points needed to access specific privileges.

This made me want to find the list of upgrades, changes, or new features that have been deployed to StackExchange and the OnStartups.com platform. Where can I find the documentation of versions or changed?

How are community members notified of such changes? Thanks!
row.Title: Where is the list of updates, changes or features to the StackExchange platform?

row.Body:
(Note: You have access to the "10K Rep tools" at +2,000 because the reputation requirements are relaxed during the beta. The reputation requirements return to normal when the site graduates.)

If you've been an active participant in the community self-moderation up to this point, the "10K moderator tools" make it a lot easier to find activities that need community attention. The 10K tools are really important help the high-rep community see where intervention might be needed: where edit wars are going on, where new tags with typos have been made, which questions are spam, etc.

10K moderators are the sentries of the site; They provide the lookout. They have a lot more oversight about what is going around key events in the site: extreme voting situations, decisive voting activities, new user posts, new tags, etc. But for the really "heavy lifting", where direct intervention is needed, users can flag the diamond ♦ moderators.

Check out Matt Haughey's Video Offering Advice to Community Moderators. This information will help you understand how these types of tools can help in everyday community moderation.

But besides all the reports and back-room insights, there are a few new active powers that 10K moderators gain. Most notably, 10K moderators can finally DELETE closed posts which the community decided no longer belong on the site. +10K users can so also see deleted posts. They can also undo much of this activity, if something goes wrong. 10K moderators provide a bit of checks-and-balances where the community and other moderators do something unexpected.

So where should I start?

Start at the top. The activities are sorted by tab. Flip through them to become familiar with the tools. When you see something suspicious on the site, you'll know how to check up on it.

… and don't forget to drop in periodically to provide a more proactive approach to see what needs to be tended.

Get in the habit or lending a hand with the routine cleanup work. Check the latest closed posts to decide what no longer belongs on the site (off topic, spam, etc).

These community moderator activities keep the site sleek and high quality.

Congratulations on your new reputation abilities!


For anyone who is not familiar with the 10K tools feature, here is a quick overview of what is to come:

Users with +10,000 reputation become what is known as a "10K moderator." It is the highest level of "community self-moderation" just short of the voted "diamond ♦ moderators" which are voted on by the community.

In the top bar where you have the 'Chat', 'Main', and 'FAQ' options, there will be another menu option called "Tools".

The menus and help text list the basic tools available there:

Congratulations!

Now that you've achieved 10000 reputation, you've earned the right to see (and undelete) deleted posts, and vote to delete questions that have been closed for 2 days.

You also have access to these moderation tools:

  • posts flagged as offensive or spam
  • recently deleted posts
  • recently closed questions
  • recently imported questions
  • see all recent edits in chronological order
  • new posts by new users
  • questions with newly created tags
  • new answers to old questions
  • recent questions with most view velocity
  • recent questions with most edit velocity
  • recent questions with most vote velocity
  • recent wiki changes
  • recent wikis created
  • suggested edit stats

[So it looks like the reduction in rep required to access the mod tools wasn't a change. The 10K rep needed to access the mod tools only applies to sites that have graduated from beta. Those sites in beta only require 2K.]

Now to answer your question - As far as I know there is no one single place that logs all the changes that have been made to SE. But two places you can get some of this information from are the StackExchange Blog and the StackOverflow Meta.

When they are considering a new feature they will usually post a question on the SO Meta asking for feedback or suggestions. And when a major feature has been rolled out they will usually announce it on the SE Blog.

How are community members notified of such changes?

Other than checking the above two sites, they are not. If you don't happen to read about an upcoming change in the blog or meta, the change will usually be rolled out without you knowing that it's coming. On more than one occasion I have come to the site and been surprised by something :-)

We're evaluating the feasibility of sponsoring a member of the startups community to speak at a conference in 2011.

Speaking is a relatively big "ask", so this needs to be planned many months in advance. Let's get started!

We'd like the community to establish where ...

What relevant startup conferences are coming up in 2011 that have open speaker slots or calls for papers?

... and then who.

Which members of the community are strongly interested in being sponsored by Stack Exchange, Inc to speak at one of the above conferences in 2011?

To be clear, the speaker is free talk about anything he or she wants so long as it would be roughly on topic for this site -- with a quick acknowledgement of support from Stack Exchange and a mention of the community here.
row.Title: Possible Conference Speaking Sponsorships -- 2011

row.Body:
Indeed this is a big ask :-) Can I ask why the speaking part of it such a big component for OnStartups, when it's not for the other SE communities? I'm using this as reference.

I started a thread on this about a month ago, and we got a few things listed, but there wasn't a whole lot of activity. See here. The conferences listed that haven't passed yet are (not sure which ones still have open speaker slots - I'll check tonight):

  • The Founder Conference - May 3 - Silicon Valley
  • TechCrunch Disrupt - May 23 - New York
  • Business of Software Conference - Oct 23-26 - Boston
  • Lean Startup Conference - May 5 - Vancouver
  • Startup 2011 - New York - May 10
  • 2011 MicroConf - The Conference for Self-Funded Startups - June 6 & 7 - Las Vegas

I came across this community promotion initiative, so I thought I would start a thread here to discuss what things we can do to promote OnStartups to the world.

The ideas don't have to be free, as StackExchange is willing to support these initiatives by giving us the necessary resources. But it's up to us to become involved, and come up with the idea.

Do you have any thoughts on ways to promote answers.onstartups.com?
row.Title: Community Promotion Ideas

row.Body:
Could someone who knows outline the process for requesting a new feature for OnStartups?

I am interesting in knowing the following:

  1. How is a request initiated?
  2. What are the criteria upon which the request are evaluated?
  3. Who makes the decision?
  4. How is the decision communicated to the members?

Thanks!
row.Title: Process for Requesting a new feature?

row.Body:
I think that having speakers present in a manner which promotes the OnStartup community could be an effective component of an overall marketing/promotion/community building plan.

Not seeing that plan, or knowing what it's components are makes it difficult for me to

There seems to be two distinct voices that we would want to speak to -- and correspondingly have speak on our behalf. (These are two voices in recognition that they are often embodied in the same person)

  1. Start-up entrepreneurs: Entrepreneurs who are launching companies that have found the resource of the community helpful and essential. The benefit to the entrepreneur of being able to speak is promotion of their idea, the opportunity for earned media, and great networking.

  2. Consultants: Professionals which work with start-up companies and entrepreneurs. The benefit to the consultant of being able to speak is the promotion of their skills and resources supported by the validation of a community.

From the perspective of onstartups I can think of nothing would be more powerful than the two speaking together --either in person or as two individuals sharing the platform. A start-up entrepreneur who found the advice and answers they needed from the consultant/professional on the board.

In both cases I believe that the selection process should leverage the existing infrastructure of the community. What do I mean? Use the question/answer/reputation process to "reward" community-members with the speaking opportunity in each of these categories.

What if we post a featured question which solicits stories of success on the use of the Onstartups platform-- the bounty is the invitation to represent our community at a given conference?

Being a speaker at a decent conference is pretty tough - you need to quality on your own merits. If you are high-profile enough to do so, then why do you need an endorsement from onStartups?

Now if Jeff or Joel wanted to spend 5 minutes on stage at the Founder Conference, I'd be happy to interview them, it would be relevant to the audience without being a plug for the site.

I understand that using the founders is not scalable, there are just too many conferences that StackExchange would relate to.

For sure start by reading

http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/08/a-recipe-to-promote-your-site/

Beyond "share great questions and answers" -- this is absolutely essential -- the bigger picture stuff is less clear:

  • Sponsor the right kind of conferences. For many sites, we should be able to identify the top 2-3 conferences.
  • Reach the right kind of publications and bloggers. Make sure that the key experts in every field know about the site; not just the “Martha Stewart” big names; we want to talk to the people who go to these conferences.
  • Sponsor fun things for each community… especially the kinds of things that are likely to get talked about. This may mean photo contests for the photography site, cooking classes for the food and cooking site, etc.
  • Make sure evangelists from each community have the opportunity to speak before groups of experts in their fields. We may want to organize a speaker’s bureau that arranges to get our top users bookings at conferences, user groups, etc., to talk about each site. Encourage and participate in grassroots conversations in existing discussion groups, where appropriate.
  • We can provide access to professional designers and design give-aways like t-shirts or bumper stickers for interesting contests and events.

Anything specific along those lines would be great.

I often forget to check related questions because it requires scrolling so far below the fold in the right column. I sometimes misread "Visit Meta" as the "Related" section too as my natural expectation is to find related questions. I don't care that much about the tags or the stats at the top of the right column. So why is the precious screen real estate of the top right column laid out this way? If we want more engagement, surely the most important thing to have at the top of the right column is the list of related questions.

EDIT: I have changed the tag from "discussion" to "feature-request" per the recommendation by @Joseph Barisonzi
row.Title: Why is the right column the way it is?

row.Body:
Here (in meta) is the single, best way to request a new feature. Write your request and be sure to tag it as a [feature-request].

These requests are piped through to the developers who constantly review and evaluate these requests. The meta [feature-requests] listing provides a sort-of live to-do list for our developers.

But that doesn't mean that every request get implemented. Votes do strongly influence features we develop, and we try to complete as many of the high voted items as possible. But sometimes we don't always agree how (or if) a request will be implemented.

Feature-requests are evaluated based on a combination of the merit of the feature suggestion, the voting, the resources available, and how it fits in with our vision of how this stuff should work.

A reasonably complete listing of the relevant upgrades, changes, and new features that have been deployed to StackExchange/OnStartups platform can be found here:

Recent Feature Changes to Stack Exchange

If that's too much detail, I would suggest following:

The Stack Exchange Blog

The blog provides the most sweeping, "big feature" announcements across the network.

But if excruciating detail is what you seek, become a regular visitor to our

Meta Stack Overflow Site

It's the Network sounding board where the most avid participants ask about the day-to-day feature requests, musings, and philosophical discussions about what makes this Network tick.

"Review my startup" posts shouldn't be allowed. They can be closed as "Off Topic," or, perhaps "Too Localized."

There are four main reasons:

  • They only help one person. The goal of Stack Exchange is to build up a large site full of general questions and answers that will help thousands of people who come after us. The goal of answers.onstartups.com is to build up a bunch of high quality questions and answers that will help many entrepreneurs. These critiques are so specific to one person's exact business/website/startup idea/business plan that they are not useful to anyone else.

  • The site tends to fill up with them. This happened on the Business of Software and it just became very, very irritating for the regulars.

  • They're not questions. There is no correct answer. You're asking people to do too much with one question.

  • They can be spam. Many times they are posted in good faith, but more often than not, they're simply posted as a way to get initial traffic to a site.

I say, close 'em.

DISCLAIMER: this is my personal opinion and does not reflect Stack Exchange policy.

I think a lot of community members here have startup related blogs. Is there anyone interested in hosting small OnStartups ads on their blogs linking back to specific startup related questions? Something similar to this:

I just listened to SE's latest Podcast (does that make me lame?). It sounds like they plan on getting back to releasing these more frequently. They also mentioned that they plan on having guests in the future. Maybe they would be willing to have some of our more active users on every now and then? I don't expect this will help us in getting users outside of the SE community, but it might encourage current SE users to also participate on OnStartups. Thoughts?

Something I've wanted to do for a while now is create a free eBook with the hottest questions and answers on OnStartups. It seems like it would be relatively simple to do, and I think it has the potential to spread quickly. But I don't have a PDF creator, otherwise I would have done it by now. Any thoughts on this idea?

As much as I would love to have more users visit meta and chat -- I think that for the majority of users it would be more important for the development of the community to not have to scroll to "related"

The purpose of the main site is to ask and answer questions -- so it seems that the functionality to do that should be the priority.

Ideal would be the ability of the user to configure the screen components in a way that worked for them. . .. :)

Based on my personal experience having my posts edited/flagged/voted to be close, multiple questions here on the board -- and finally prompted by the reaction to an edit I made on this question --

I would like to request the following feature:

The reason for an edit or a flag would be viewable by the user.

Description

When I edit a person's content -- I would like them to see the reason that I type in. When I flag it and make a comment or a reason why -- I want the user to be able to see why. When someone flags me -- now I am at the reputation level to see why -- but before I couldn't -- and that is when I needed to know and learn.

Reasons

These are the reasons I believe that this would be a valuable addition:

  • Direct feedback promotes learning: the more explicit and precise the feedback, the stronger it is as a learning tool. We don't want new users who have questions edited to get frustrated and leave -- we want them to say "wow, this group wants me to be successful" -- having personal feedback will promote a positive learning environment.

  • Transparency promotes accountability: If I know that I will be personally connected with the edit and the comment there will be increased diligence on "getting it right" If the person who has been flagged, or edited knows that the person is a real person there the likelihood of them having a negative experience goes down. And it can become a learning, growing moment.

  • Communication builds community: Facilitating and supporting communication between real people rather than just reputation numbers, up click and down click facilitates the development of a stronger community.

I look forward to hearing feedback on this feature request, and hopefully a positive response from the powers-at-be.
row.Title: Direct User Feedback on Edits and Flags

row.Body:
I can't seem to find the list of people who upvote my answers or questions. Is that information accessible on that site? How do I find it?

Thanks!
row.Title: In answers.onstartups - how do you tell who upvotes your answers?

row.Body: That information is not available. In fact, even the moderators have a very limited view of that, and it is only used to detect voting fraud.

I've seen more than one answer where the poster feels compelled to write a sentence or two make it explicit that:

  • they are not a lawyer
  • they are not an accountant
  • they're not entering into a contract with the poster.
  • etc.

My assumption is that most people reading the answers know this, and the boilerplate just clutters up what are otherwise pretty good answers.

Why doesn't the site automatically add some "I am not a lawyer/accountant" boilerplate to question page?

(edit: I'm asking because it seems like this feature is missing, and I assume that there is a good reason for leaving it out.)

Here's an example.
row.Title: Why doesn't the site automatically add some "I am not a lawyer/accountant" boilerplate to question page?

row.Body: It's friggen ridiculous. I see all those posts as well. It's so annoying that people feel the need to disclaimer themselves when they give subjective opinions. If it's really that big of an issue make it a T&C when you sign up (it probably already is) that answers provided here are opinion only and blah, blah blah

I'm relatively new around here, but I'm confused why OnStartups is a beta when other, apparently quieter and newer SO sites aren't.

It has questions from late '09 that aren't shown migrated, so has been in beta a very long time!

So is there some benchmark it must meet first?

(no it probably doesn't matter, I'm just interested!)
row.Title: Why's onstartups a beta? does it end?

row.Body:
I'm adding an answer to a question, and in clicking back into the edit box, I end up clicking help - the link isn't overlaying the icon correctly... Like so:

Firefox 3.6.16
row.Title: Bug: Markdown help link overlays edit box

row.Body:
From the Economist:

E-mail disclaimers are one of the minor nuisances of modern office life, along with fire drills, annual appraisals and colleagues who keep sneezing loudly. Just think of all the extra waste paper generated when messages containing such waffle are printed. They are assumed to be a wise precaution. But they are mostly, legally speaking, pointless. Lawyers and experts on internet policy say no court case has ever turned on the presence or absence of such an automatic e-mail footer in America, the most litigious of rich countries.

I can't imagine the story is too different for blog/site posts/comments.
This will be fixed in the next build; see Link to “Editing Help” is located under its image. on Meta SO.

The questions were migrated in from an existing SE 1.0 site, so technically it hasn't been in beta that long, it was a different site!

For more details on how/when this will change, see:

  • When OnStartups will graduate?
  • Will we survive ?
  • What are the current plans for site design and timing

An answer just to up the problem of low numbers of votes. I am active in another stack exchange site and the number of votes is way higher than here. In fact, it is very difficult for a newcomer as me to see who is a reference on the site and who is not because almost everybody has little rep.

Lawyers are legally prohibited from practicing law in states where they have not been licensed, so they have to do something proactively to make it clear that they're just exercising their first amendment rights, not actually practicing law. Thus the disclaimers.

Disclaimers at the bottom of emails are usually of a different form... in many cases, the disclaimer at the bottom of a lawyer's email is there to announce that there IS a an attorney-client communication taking place, because those communications are privileged and cannot be subpoenaed or discovered.

People writing "IANAL" ("I Am Not A Lawyer") type disclaimers are probably just trying to be helpful and warn any future readers that they may be botching up the answer totally, because they are, after all, not a lawyer, and the law often turns out to have funny opinions about things that do not correspond to common-sense.

I actually agree, and I've decided to make the following changes:

for questions with ...

  • 0 answers, we display only related questions
  • 1-3 answers, 40% chance of meta house ad, 40% chance of se 2.0 network ad, 20% chance of chat ad.
  • 4 answers, we display meta + house ad + chat

This should make the questions scale better and put the focus on Related Questions more clearly when the question is young. As it gets more answers, the sidebar will "grow" with the question.

This beta is going on for far longer than double the original slated time for a beta. What is going on? Will it be continued or closed? If it is continued, there is no reason to hold this back since the numbers especially for enough users with privileges seems fine.
row.Title: What is the decision, go or no-go?

row.Body:
A small correction: There is no "slated time for a beta." There are only minimum requirements before a site can be considered for graduation.

The basic OnStartup stats look excellent, so that puts you solidly in the running for graduation. But historically, OnStartups' traffic has been incredibly flat; No sustained growth for any significant period of time:

This isn't at all unusual. Sites typically experience this horizontal pattern of flat growth going horizontally for awhile until they reach a specific "tipping point" where the traffic begins to slope upward and takes off unstoppably. It's that virtual guarantee of sustained, future success that indicates when it is time to graduate.

OnStartups isn't quite there, yet.

I say "quite" because, in recent weeks, there have been some promising signs of more substantial growth. Those periodic up-ticks in traffic followed by small-but-sustained increases is promising. That means you are retaining users once they find the site. But more users and more traffic means we really should be seeing on-going, steady growth… and we're not quite seeing that, yet.

On a more subjective note, there seems to be a disproportionately small group of "prolific EXPERT users" who assure that the site continues to provide top-quality content. There are simply fewer users in that core group than we like to see. That leaves the site vulnerable to decline, should a few users decide to leave.

But the overall quality of new questions HAS gotten notably better over the past several weeks. If this move-to-quality continues and new users keep finding the site, OnStartups should graduate soon. Quality is job-one at this stage; much more important than asking lots of questions.

Rigorous community self-moderation is key to sustaining and promoting that quality. This site can use a burst of community cleanup activity to clear out the old cruft cluttering up the darker corners of this site.

When those top questions appear on your site, you can attract new users by highlighting your most intriguing questions. Use those social bookmarks!

I'm sorry if this belongs in a bug forum over at stack exchange. Thought I'd see a link in the footer here to submit a bug or something.

For the last couple days, I've been seeing a lot of duplicate posts, the same exact question, with the same exact author. And sometimes people answer one or the other, splitting up the conversation.

I also occasionally look logged off. I'll be cruising around, and then bam, I'm logged off, then I refresh or click somewhere else, and now I'm logged in again. Maybe they are doing some load balancing, but not using sticky sessions and our sessions get lost in the balance?

Have these things been raised with stack exchange yet?

Sorry if you are well aware of this. Please delete this if it's just redundant.
row.Title: Anyone else seeing duplicate posts and getting logged out?

row.Body: I've encountered the same issue before.
I already posted it on meta as Double submission problem

Wish you all happiness, luck, health and most of all, success with your projects !

What are your resolutions for the upcoming year ?
row.Title: Happy New Year Startupers !

row.Body:
I'll start with a cheesy quote :D

Employees make New Years resolutions. Entrepreneurs take action every day - Martin Thorborg
I published mine a couple weeks ago on my blog.

My resolution is to do more of what I did in 2009 -had a blast and many successes last year. Hoping to do as well this year!

Happy new year!

We've been looking at different ways to promote this website to the Internet at large, and it just occurred to me that it would be fun to involve everyone in the brainstorming!

In fact, I don't even want to taint the conversation with our own ideas.

But I would like to throw out these considerations:

  1. We do not want traffic at the expense of quality. That's a non-starter, period.
  2. We don't mind spending money, but not obscene amounts of money, and free is better all else being equal.
  3. We're not interested in bursts of traffic -- we're trying to get honest, useful questions and answers, not "hits" or "impressions." Although bursts of traffic where crappy hits just fall away and useful stuff sticks is of course a good thing.
  4. We'd like to give back and/or reward folks for contributing and/or helping us to add quality users, so long as it cannot devolve into people "gaming" the system with crap.

(If you have more constraints you'd like to add, that's interesting too!)
row.Title: How should we promote Answers to the world?

row.Body:
My first question would be defining your target audience. Who are the primary users of this site? Can you give a little more description of what you consider "quality" users?

My first gut reaction was guerrilla marketing. Go after the top similar type forums and post questions as well as answers for visibility. So for example, Linkedin Answers or Yahoo Answers. Answer startup related questions related to some of the best posts here and end with a simple signature/link at the end and little plug that "From our Answers Users" or something like that. Each forum (like Linkedin Answers) has lots of crazy active, crazy smart people who contribute and lots of people who look. Go after the big ones. Some may chop your posts but do it in a mostly neutral way and give it a go.

At the same time, post really interesting questions that start off with a lot of valuable content that you're giving to that particular community with a request for more answers from the users. Like I did with my "productivity" post - I had about 10 things I do then asked others to jump in. And again, you brand this as "Answers" driven. Soft sell.

And per your question, you could create some type of incentive to get people to check the site out. That might get you blasted off but you can test the waters and try.

That's just one idea. I know it takes a lot of time but it's cheap and I think it's going to hit a highly qualified audience.

I'll search the brain for some more ideas.

Best of luck.

I think one way to do this is to find blogs that write on topics of interest to your target audience, and get them to write a review of the site. I did this a while ago (here's my first mention of this site on my blog, and I've since mentioned the site several times when questions here have prompted articles on my site).

You could also write guest posts and publish them on various sites for startups. Perhaps offer a journal system where entrepreneurs can write about their journey in exchange for some customized advice, and a mention on this site (in exchange, they would get a mention here for their contributions, and they would provide thanks to this site on their own site).

I'm really interested in seeing what other people come up with!

One of the best possible sources of new members for a community like this is the existing members.

You have a good group of passionate and knowledgeable members. To best leverage this great group, I'd start with one simple step and use addthis.com to add "share this" buttons by each question and answer. This links to everything from basic e-mail to Facebook to Twitter to Digg to . Simple, easy, and free.

This will let OnStartups members share specific content with people they know who will be genuinely interested in that content - and then who are most likely to sign up as members. We're using this on our user generated content site and have been researching it - it turns out that even WhiteHouse.gov uses this now.

Good luck!!!!

A couple of things come to mind:

  • Promote where entrepreneurs get information: Places like the SBA, SCORE, Business Week, etc.
  • Reach out to Non-Software Entrepreneurs: Most of the people on this site are starting or running micro-ISV's. There are a ton of other businesses that can benefit from this forum. Most of the questions and answers apply to any business. Look at places like Startup Nation or the like.
  • Organize Resource Pages: Take all the great questions and answers and put together a common startup guide or something like that. This will reduce the barrier to entry for finding useful information.
  • Guest Post on Other Blogs: This is pretty effective for bloggers and can be effective for this site as well. Heck, I found this site because of a blog.
  • Contributors can Target Forums: Assign some of the community members to comment on other forums where entrepreneurs hang out like The Personal MBA, Venture Hacks, etc. That way, the word gets out and people can see the value.

As Chris suggested, guerrilla marketing could be very powerful, but I'd stay away from spammy tactics, like posting on forums or other Q&A sites. But doing something outrageous and controversial that will make an impact in the community might be just the thing we need, if executed properly.

Also a bunch of my friends share my entrepreneurial passion, so there should be "Tweet this" and "Share on FB" links to every answer and question. Could be done with some custom javascript without tampering with the inner workings of Stack Exchange. Or full Facebook Connect integration if possible. For example each time I answer or ask a question a prompt appears to let my facebook friends and twitter followers know about it, "luring" them back here to register and benefit themselves and the community.

Hi Jason, Such a great idea to ask the community for help and ideas. Here are a few of mine:

Badges/Buttons-The badges here are used internally to this site (which is fine) but you could implement a public badge creator that enables people to embed an OnStartups Answers badge/button on their blog or website that links to this site. This would be similar to the many Twitter button creators, etc.

Email Newsletter- Although many people use RSS feeds, some people prefer to subscribe to forums via email and receive a weekly or monthly round-up of top questions and answers. This is a great way for people to opt-in to receive information (even if they don't register with the Answers site), and emails are often forwarded to others. To increase email subscriptions, or just offer on its own without registration form if you want to take a more viral approach, offer a relevant, useful eBook, video, or other type of content that they immediately receive. This content should be optimized to be shared via social media, furthering its reach.

Video Campaign- Create a series (start with one video, test it, analyze results, create second video, and so on) of short videos and post to YouTube and the OnStartups blog. Include a strong call-to-action, for example the "Google inbound marketing" CTA that HubSpot used in You Oughta Know Inbound Marketing" video.

SEO Press Release-Simple, short press release announcing two successful software entrepreneurs started free community to help other startups. Do some keyword research and be sure to include keywords in release and provide link to Answers site. PRLog is my preferred free or low-cost release distribution site.

Contest- The person that submits a question that gets the most community votes during a specific month, and the person that has the top answer during that specific month, each receive a free 1 hour conference call with you and Dharmesh to receive valuable advice on their most challenging problems. Since only active community users with high enough internal badges can vote, this would prevent cheating.

I would come up with some type of reward system that encourages the existing members to refer and invite new contributing members who post thoughtful and relevant questions and answers. Maybe a badge for referring x new members who acquired x number of votes would work. That way members who are here for the long run will think about potential new referrals who will make this a bigger and better community and invite them in.
Piquing the interest of a journalist who writes for a large paper (NY Times, etc).

To use our own info:

1) Target these sites:

  • what-are-the-top-10-startup-blogs
  • what-are-the-top-10-vc-blogs

Try to get mentions on them. If applicable, place ads. joelonsoftware should be amenable to this, right?

Run an Adwords campaign

do some quick research - startup questions & startup help seem to be good ones.

target other "stackexchange" sites. IF they already bought into this type of q&a model, then they will feel familiar and come over here if they are so inclined. I'd definitely put an ad on stackoverflow - esp. for those microisvs.

[edit: added another]

Why not add twitter capability so that new questions are automatically tweeted? That works pretty good for other interest sites...

You may want to contact Jason Calacanis at his ThisWeekInstartups.com and he might mention this site in his podcast. His podcast is all about startups. Although this site might compete with his podcast segment where he answers questions from callers.
I highly recommend Dharmesh's book for ideas :)

I have seen in various forums that most of the start-ups are struggling to get financed. More often than not, they are gracefully/diplomatically shooed away by the financiers (angels/VC's/banks etc). This happens for one of many reasons which are not conveyed directly to the poor chaps.

How about getting in touch with angel networks / VC's who can guide these chaps to this forum?

These guys would be able to get tremendous help here.

The Stackexchange way of promoting desired behavior is to award badges. Since many of the Stackexchange-sites will have the same problem:

Is it possible to have the dev-team add badges for traffic?

  1. The user adds a link to answers.onstartups.com/incoming/user-id
  2. A bronze badge is awarded after 5 incoming unique visitors
  3. A silver badge is awarded after 500 incoming unique visitors
  4. A gold badge is awarded after 10000 incoming unique visitors

No reputation points are awarded (it would be too easy to game the system and the reputation should probably reflect the activity on the site).

A couple of thoughts I didn't see mentioned:

  1. Allow users to post their question on Twitter, Facebook, Google Buzz, etc. - Basically, make it easy to share your link is a great way to raise awareness. Also, what better reason to join than help out your friend by answering a question of theirs. Integrating with Facebook connect is a quick way. OpenID/Twitter/etc login is another great way.
  2. Encourage users to turn their Q&A's into blog posts. I blog regularly and these posts are great for when I have writer's block and can't think of a new topic to write about. They must add a link back of course.
  3. Finally, see if there's a way to work with Aardvark. This site reminds me a lot of it. Maybe there's a way to harness the power of the community they've already built.

I just started using this today and I'm really impressed by the caliber of the answers I've received. In fact, I posted the same question on Twitter and Aardvark too and this forum was the most helpful.

Best of luck!

-Yasmine

Have you thought about speaking at a conference that targets start ups?

The 19th annual Software Industry Conference will be held this year in Dallas, Texas at the Hyatt Regency DFW, July 15-17, 2010. It is intended for software start ups, SaaS, Micro ISVs, and internet marketers.

If you are interested in speaking at the conference to an audience of hundreds of Micro ISVs, here is your chance. Use the link below to build and submit an abstract on the topic you want to speak about. Feel free to pass the PDF on to anyone you think might be interested in speaking at the conference.

http://sic.org/files/SIC-2010-Call_for_Papers.pdf

For more information on the conference in general visit:

http://sic.org

Why not approach entrepreneur meetup groups to spread the word or create affiliations?

Most large metros have a few like the ones we have in the Bay Area: such as SF New Tech, http://sfnewtech.com/, Silicon Valley Assoc of Software Entrepreneurs, svase.org and TiE.org, http://startup2startup.com/ etc.

Everybody is doing a FB page, maybe Onstartups should have one too?

Since many users are in the IT industry, you could sponsor a tag(s) on Stackoverflow like Redgate does for SQL Server. SO has many questions about pricing, sales, licensing etc. Pool them together in a 'Business' tag. Users of both sites could help with the tagging if you just ask.

These sites have no way for current members to get credit for referrals or a referral mechanism. At least a badge for 5, 25, 50, 100 referrals.

Sorry, but Joel Spolsky was right (most recent podcast), both sites need to merge. There isn't enough to go around.

I suggest that you reach out to entrepreneurs involved with early stage seed accelerators like TechStars and YCombinator. They are prefiltered as very knowledgable/experienced people interested in giving back, and they may encourage involvement from those startup communities and their own.

The number one reason I come here and recommend others is because of the people who contribute. There's something special about being able to ask questions that get read and answered by a quality community.

I found this site because I follow Dharmesh's blog. I think Dharmesh needs to blog more often or find a couple regular bloggers for OnStartups (heck I'd do one or two guest posts if he asked). You don't see Arrington doing all the blogging on TechCrunch. Most of the community here came form his blog.

Another idea is to do what Guy Kawasaki does on Twitter and post the most relevant questions on this site on Twitter. He tweets about 10-20 of the best and most compelling aticles per day from his AllTop site on Twitter. I find some of them fascinating and as a result find myself on AllTop more often.

What about reaching out to college professors teaching courses in relevant areas (i.e. innovation, small business, technical ventures, technical management, accounting, etc)? They might be willing to share the site with their students as a resource for them. I would guess that the students would post good questions. And the professors may be willing to answer questions as well.

I know of one professor I'll ask.

I launched a new StackExchange site last Sunday and have followed many of the suggestions in the answers to this question as part of our launch efforts.

I had suggested using the "share this" button from AddThis for AnswersOnStartups. Since it worked here, I put this on our new site. It turns out that this has not only helped by making it easy for new members to share the content - it has also had an immediate impact on how we are showing up in Google. For example, we have had members share content via Digg and StumbleUpon and now Google shows this which I think has to help with our SEO ranking.

Some members have really high quality answers and I would like to be able to follow them without adding yet another RSS feed to my already overloaded Goog Reader. Like the star button next to the questions, maybe one after the names? ( I apologize if this has been answered, I checked the faq and did a quick search)
row.Title: Can I follow a member on answers.Onstartups?

row.Body: Yes, there's an RSS feed for each user. If you go to their profile, look at the bottom right of the page and you'll see a "User Feed" link. You can subscribe to the feed in Google Reader or another RSS reader, or you can use something like Feed My Inbox to turn it into a series of e-mail updates.

The answers.onstartups.com website copies the design & text in most instances of stackoverflow.com. Is this a copyright violation?

For example, compare answers.onstartups.com/badges to stackoverflow.com/badges
row.Title: Is Answers.OnStartups.com violating copyright?

row.Body: No, they licensed The Stack Overflow Knowledge Exchange Platform. See http://stackexchange.com/
No, because this is a StackExchange site. You're SUPPOSED to copy StackOverflow!

Even if this was an independent effort... It would not be copyright infringement. You cannot copyright a user interface mechanism.

Sorry for the nitpicky answer.

I wanted to give my concerns about this particular stack exchange site after a few days.

  1. The quality of questions looks on average poor : a lot of questions are somehow off-topic, or subjective, or very low level (the kind of questions that can be answered by the first link you find by googling the question).
  2. Nobody (or almost nobody) is voting. There are only a few upvotes and no downvotes. How can we converge to a high quality Q&A sites without any real long-term involvment : people are asking 1 question and never come back. It looks that people interested in the site do not vote systematically for good questions and answers... This makes difficult for newcomers to understand what is a good (or bad) question for the site.

For instance, the high number of questions without votes (or with 1 or 2 at max) is suspect to me. Also, it looks like there is no moderation : off-topic questions are still open, untagged questions are still untagged, etc.

Do not misunderstood what I am saying here : I am just giving my concerns, maybe I did not get what this Q&A site is about.
row.Title: My concerns about onstartups after 10 days

row.Body:
Welcome. Thank you for your questions and answers. Thank you for your voting. I have enjoyed watching your engagement over the last 10 days.

I am also new -- about 40-ish days or something -- I would have to go check to be exact. I thing that your analysis is spot on:

  1. Questions are of generally poor quality.
  2. There is very low engagement of voting
  3. There is poor initial engagement of new members -- and the UI is very difficult for new members
  4. There is relatively low level of engagement from moderators. (there are some exceptions, see my comments below)

Things to Consider

  • Based on my "look" at the other sites and a quick comparison -- the percentage of voting/views is about the same as on the other sites. The number of views on this site is simply significantly lower. This is not because of a lower number of registered users -- but a lower percetange of active users that are viewing the questions.
  • There are relatively few active users with moderation privileged. There are two type -- the chosen moderators, and those that have earned limited moderating privileged. Of those that are active-- I have found them to be very diligent on the issues that you mention like closing off-topic questions. (The lack of transparency around these processes do make that engagement difficult to assess) I have also found that they (we) are sensitive to not "shutting down" new members for slightly off topic questions in order to encourage them to improve and remain engaged with the site.
