(For example this one that you questioned this morning that lots of people really enjoyed.) One of the challenges is that most of the theresholds (for "closing" for example) by moderators with earned privileges have been set up system-wide and do not seem to be indexed according to the specific site activity.
  • There is very poor community member retention. While there is/was an extenuating circumstance (see below) the poor level of participation by the moderators and reputation leaders in the site, as well as the sharp drop off after a certin point of these folks seems to have had a significant negative impact on the sites ability to mature.

Extenuating Circumstances

I am sure you see lots of "answers" to questions on this "meta" site referencing both the beta nature of the site, as well as the fact that it is a transfer from another site model which was determined not to work. This answer is used as an explanation to the general poor level of development of the community.

It also seems to me to be an excuse. The site is a beta. It is migrated from another model. And all of the issues you identified are still true and still should be proactively addressed.

My Experience

I have found that -- in contrast to other online communities of which I am part -- the challenge of OnStartups (perhaps the Stack's model) are:

  • Lack of transparency by the "owners/leaders" of the site
  • Lack of delegation of responsibilities
  • Lack of direct member-member communications
  • Lack of discernible plan to build or grow the community

So what's the answer?

The general precept of the site is that it is a member driven community. (Whether or not it really is an authentically member driven site is a separate discussion I suppose) Within that context the responsibility to make it what we want or hope it could/should/would be rests with us. As individuals. Taking the baby steps needed.

The best way to improve the quality of questions -- is to ask high quality questions. i see that you have asked a great question about selling investors. It did not get any answers or votes. My experience is that folks like questions that are very specific rather than general. I bet if you were to have asked that question to be very specific to a situation you were facing right now there would have been lots of answers and votes. (Well, its for this site-- which will be between 5-7 votes!)

The best way to increase voting -- is to increase your number of votes. Go back to old questions and answers and find ones that you like. I see that you have been active voting in your first ten days (an average of 4.5 or so a day is more than the average bear) If more of us do this the positive feedback will encourage more involvement. We can increase the level of discernment on "quality" as the activity improves. If you "write off" questions with only 1-2 votes as being suspect with acknowledgement of the low voting, then you might be missing some great questions that your experience could add a great answer. Even if it is an old question, your answer will move it back into the active list and reintroduce it to people who might have missed it.

I have tried to reach out directly to lots of members. following up with their questions. Offering to review marketing decks or read executive summaries. I have become friends with several site members and am learning much from their experience. It is unfortunate that the site does not encourage or really support that level of community building. But for folks that do fill out their profile to include a site, that has a link for emailing/im-ing or the like -- it is possible to reach out.

I am still trying to figure out how to engage the site members in the development of a real plan which would include delegation of responsibilities, proactively engage new members, reach out to targeted folks that we want to join us -- and all of the other great things that should/could be done.

Any advice or recommendations would be greatly appreciated.

I addressed some of your concerns in this other post: What is the decision, go or no-go?. But they bear repeating here.

We have expressed concerns that there seems to be a disproportionately small group of "prolific EXPERT users" who assure that the site continues to provide top-quality content. There are simply fewer users in that core group than we like to see. That leaves the site vulnerable to decline, should a few users decide to leave.

But the overall quality of new questions HAS gotten notably better over the past several weeks. If this move-to-quality continues and new users keep finding the site, OnStartups should graduate soon. Quality is job-one at this stage; much more important than asking lots of questions.

With regard to the voting (and most of the extra-curricular activities involving community self-moderation, in general) — Unfortunately, this is a common problem on sites ported from SE 1.0. The users of this site don't participate in the vetting and community activities to the extent found on our "natively-grown" Stack Exchange sites. It's not the fault of the community or the previous owners. Those sites were simply created under a different premise.

We are constantly enhancing how we issue reminders and prompts and other behavioral enticements to promote voting and other meta-contribution. But users are ultimately going to emulate what they see on the site; And on this site, they see exactly what you describe — a conspicuous lack of participation in those activities that happen after questions and answers are posted: voting, comments, follow-up, improving the answers through wiki editing… anything that vets and makes the content better.

We are seeing signs of improvement, but it is slow slow going. Ultimately, it only takes a few users to take it upon themselves to lead by example to make this site successful.

Doesn't it feel great to have your answer accepted? I admit it, I love it. It makes me feel good to know that I was able to help. But I wonder how the "views" and "answers" on a question are impacted by accepting an answer.

Do I reduce the views on a question by accepting an answer too soon? Do I limit the number of answers (and wisdom) I solicit by accepting an answer too soon?

And if so- what is too soon?
row.Title: Does accepting an answer too soon hurt participation?

row.Body:
It is generally accepted that you should wait 24 to 48 hours to let more people have a chance to answer your question. A question with an accepted answer may deter people from looking at a question at all.

Unfortunately, accepting an answer can be viewed as closing the issue as "resolved," particularly by Internet folk who many not understand the nuances of what the accepted answer means. Accepting an answer too soon can certainly discourage other users from submitting more/better answers. We even have a built-in a 48-hour "waiting period" before accepting your answer on your own question.

There seems to be a knee-jerk reaction to downvote answers where the answerer dares to disclose a self-interest. Here is a perfect example: looking for Accounting solution Because of the environment I am referring to in this question, I must state that I do not know the answerer, the company she is from, or the product she refers to. If I had posted the exact same message minus the self-interest disclosure that wouldn't apply in my case, I think this post would have been upvoted. We are creating an environment where experts will not post answers because they will be punished for doing so.
row.Title: Why do we punish people for giving good answers when they have an openly disclosed self-interest?

row.Body:
I don't see what the issue is with that post -- it conforms with normal disclosure rules that you'd expect to see anywhere, and knowing that the poster is associated with it makes it more honest and more useful.

So the post you are referring to is fine.. what's the problem again? Per the FAQ:

http://answers.onstartups.com/faq#promotion

May I promote products or websites I am affiliated with here?

Be careful, because the community frowns on overt self-promotion and tends to vote it down and flag it as spam. Post good, relevant answers, and if they happen to be about your product or website, so be it. However, you must disclose your affiliation in your answers. Also, if a huge percentage of your posts include a mention of your product or website, you're probably here for the wrong reasons. Our advertising rates are quite reasonable; contact our ad sales team for details. We also offer free vote-based advertising for open source projects.

I just noticed something new on my profile. (It may not be new to answers.onstartups, it may not even be new to my profile, it may be I just noticed it.) It is "flag weight". If I click it, it sends me to a page with my flagging history. But I can't make heads or tails out of how the number after "flag weight" is calculated or what it means. Can someone enlighten me?
row.Title: How is "flag weight" calculated?

row.Body:
See

http://meta.stackoverflow.com/questions/80170/what-is-flag-weight

flag weight is a measure of how reliably you flag content. When your flags are positively reviewed (generally resulting in some sort of action), your flag weight increases by 10 points for flags on posts, and 5 points for flags on comments. Likewise, when you flag incorrectly, your flag weight decreases by an equal amount.

One thought I had was to introduce several other topics in questions. Three of them have been downvoted with no comments.

Becoming a great CEO

Becoming a great business strategist

The difference between marketing B2C and B2B

Perhaps we are punishing people for asking questions that are not 'how do I market my business' and 'how do I split up equity'?

I don't think that one down vote is not a pattern of a knee-jerk reaction -- but your core point that downvoting can have a negative impact on the comunity members experience and may result in folk prematurly leavin the community is well taken.

There is a lot of discussion about this issue here in the "meta" area. To summarize what they all say:

  • An unjustified downvote from one individual usually results in up votes which offset A pattern by an individual to downvoting is watched and "moderated"
  • Different members of the community will interpret the FAQ different. The benefit of the community is it takes more than one person to close or delete a question.
  • A growing number of community members are adding direct comments when they down vote to increase the transparency and positive feedback.
  • A downvote might feel bad. Darn. And move on . . .

I asked the community a similar question. (Which you just commented on with a question which I will go and answer there.)

Three thoughts that further address your issue:

  • The site needs more voting, to lesson the impact of an individual vote -- so go vote. Make it a goal to "use up" all your allocated votes in a single day at least once a week. If you need to lower your standard for the next couple months on what makes a great question or answer -- do it, because positive feedback will do far more to generate positive community activity then no feedback.
  • Give positive feedback and upvotes to the community members that take the time to explain downvotes -- and to those who provide constructive feedback to new members on how to improve their questions/answers.
  • Increase transparence between members. One way to do this is go vote for my feature request. Voting for a feature requests send the message to the site operators that it is something we want. Very few members have viewed my feature request -- and hardly anyone has comment or voted.

One of the reasons there may be slow adoption by new users is the environment is not very inviting. If they do something "wrong" (usually innocently), the result is they get smacked down (often with no explanation). There is spartan information up front, so doing things wrong is almost guaranteed if they get active quickly.

While the whole point of this forum is to be objective (as opposed to the more subjective environment of say Quora), the "style guide" for questions is far from complete. It is possible that a complete guide would be too cumbersome, so the suggestions above from @Joseph Barisonzi would allow people ramp into the community without feeling hazed.

This question for discussion is in the context of what we as a community need to do to "jumpstart" this Q&A board and give it a little sizzle:

I was listening to "Stump the Chumps" a couple weeks ago. It is a segment on the radio program "Car Talk." The basic set-up for those of you who don't listen is that they call back someone they gave car repair (or romantic) advice to several weeks later and find out if their advice was in any way helpful. My favorite part is the scorecard:

So why don't we? Why don't we challenge ourselves to contact entrepreneurs that accepted answers and find out if they actually took the advice of the community, and how it worked out?

There is real value

Now of course, I am assuming that there is real value to demonstrate. That we will demonstrate to new community members the incredible value of the collective wisdom of the community. That we will provide added value to long-term members to stay and see the impact of their commitment of time to answering questions. That if properly presented it could add some sizzle to our community and differentiate us from other Q&A boards.

Implementation

I don't know exactly how it would be implemented -- but I know that there are creative thinkers on here and that together we can develop a way to implement within the confines of the existing software -- and once we have proven value to the operators we could request specific customizations or changes that would allow us to maximize the positive impact on the development of the community.

Help me out?

So, what do you think? Is it a good idea? How would you change it to improve it? How would you recommend that we implement it?
row.Title: What if we did follow-up? (think "Stump the Chump" -- Startup Style)

row.Body: This is a fascinating idea. It would have to be done by the system as there doesn't seem to be any mechanism for private communication within this forum. I realize we all get enough spam and that safeguarding access to users is very important.

On the homepage of the forum most questions have a white background but some have a blue background. I have been unable to figure out the connection between the blue questions. Can someone enlighten me?

Here is a screenshot:
row.Title: Why do some questions have a blue background?

row.Body:
This is highlighting questions with tags that are in your favorite tags. If you haven't manually added any favorite tags, the system will detect when you have a certain level of activity in a tag and infer one for you. If you manually add a favorite tag, the system will not infer tags for you.

You can customize your favorite (and ignored tags) in your profile. You can also customize these settings in the right sidebar of the homepage and the /questions listing.

So, if you would prefer not to have any questions highlighted, you can simply add a nonsense "tag" to your favorites. Perhaps unicorn? (:

OMG I LOVE Car Talk! Click & Clack are awesome, and once when traveling back East I swung through Cambridge MA, just because it is "Ah Fayah City"! But seriously, it would be a nice feature if they added an excitement or relevance factor. It could be a 1 - 10 scale and the system could present the average. Average "sizzle" - average "relevance" or perhaps a 1 to 10 for "This impacts my Life" scale?

Agreed, we need to be able to guide peoples behaviour better. There have been several instances where people have slammed new users ... If I had got that treatment on my first question I wouldn't have bothered coming back.

Plus there was a series of questions from @Kenneth the other that got a lot of close votes with no explaination until I started asking why ...

I like the idea, a lot of my answers have "let us know how it goes".

Maybe it could be a followup email sent out 2 months after an answer is accepted asking people to have a "followup" question

  • Did you end up applying the answer?
  • Was it useful to you?

and a comments section.

That then becomes a block between the question and the accepted answer as a "feedback" ... points awarded, badges earned etc.

On a question today on the main board about selecting software a clear and transparent vote to close was made. The well reasoned argument was that the issue was not specific to startups but was general to business.

It seems to me that most issues that have been and continue to be addressed by the board are not unique to start-ups but are addressed by all business at different stages of their development.

When do we draw the line and call something off-topic -- as too far removed from the start-up stage?
row.Title: When is it "start-up" and when is it "general business"?

row.Body:
I believe that it is important to draw a line when the questions are so remotely related to startups that they draw upon an entirely different competence, which means that they are annoying for the startups community to see. To me, it would not be annoying to see a broad range of general business questions, but I do not know where this line is for others.

EDIT

I would especially be interested to hear the opinions of moderators on this, as questions are mostly closed by them.

In the case of your example the questioner stated (after being challenged) that the topic was indeed critical to his startup. The challenger could not have reasonably known that before the questioner's statement. As a result, it would seem that giving a questioner the benefit of the doubt would be sensible. At any rate, the proper thing to do when in doubt would be exactly what the challenger did - open a dialog.

The other thing that comes up often is when does a company "graduate" from being a startup? My answer to that for the purposes of this forum would be when they have different problems than a startup. It isn't about the calendar. Google stopped being a startup very quickly and Virgin seems to still be one. I hope my company is a startup forever. It is a matter of objectives.

There have been many times that I would have liked to have some follow up from someone who answered a question of mine. Other times people have asked for that follow up from me. There is no easy mechanism to facilitate this. So I propose we add a "Contact me" button to the profile section that would allow one user to email another. It would not reveal the email address and it would not be activated without the consent of the user.
row.Title: Add a contact link to the user profile

row.Body:
Oo, good stuff. I'm not quite seeing how this specific contest would work, but keep working on it. I love these contests as a way to jumpstart a community… and so much moreso if it inspires good content!

Did you notice that we are currently brainstorming ideas for such contest on Stack Exchange sites?

WANTED: Suggestions for Stack Exchange Contest “Recipes”

You should definitely post your idea over there. You'll be reaching a much wider audience. It's an opportunity to post about your community's ideas (and possibly pointing some much-needed traffic back into this site) where such site-specific talk would usually be off topic .

Keep in mind that if these contests inspires interest and participation, we have the resources to provide funds, prizes, promotions, materials, or any database/programming support you might need.

I believe that there has been an uptick in down voting.

I would not have extrapolated from my own experience if it had not been for comments on the main board by several community members I trust which strongly alluded to the same thing.

I like down voting. I think it is important part of the overall concept of the site. My comments and invitation to discussion below are not to in anyway suggest otherwise.

First: Can someone with access to the number tell me if there has been a statistically significant increase in downvoting on questions, answers and comments in the last 8-10 days?

Second: I believe that a downvote on a persons initial engagement with the site will be experiences as very off putting and correspondingly has a negative impact on the development of the community. Do others agree? And if so -- what are recommendations to limit that negative impact?

Third: I believe (and have stated before) that anonymous down voting provides no positive feedback to the person who receives it, or the larger community experiencing the site. Do others agree? And if so -- what are recommendations to limit that negative impact?
row.Title: Uptick in DownVoting?

row.Body:
If not in the actual question -- then in the Profile -- where there is a clear option in the profile for adding contact information. And during the registration process make it clear that you want people to have the option of contacting you or not.

It could even be reputation based. You need 150 pts to see the direct contact field on the profile of a user.

It is already built in that one has to have a reputation of 125 to downvote a question and 500 to downvote an answer. While those both seem rather low to me intuitively, I wonder if this is a problem in fact.

Downvoting new users will scare people away. If all they are doing is shameless self-promotion (as opposed to incidental self-promotion which should not be treated so harshly), I say go ahead and scare them away. Almost everything else though is an opportunity for teaching someone what we are looking for. I suspect most questions that get downvoted could instead be fixed with some coaching or collaborative editing. The ability to have a private conversation would really help here.

Finally, anonymous downvoting is counterproductive and cowardly. If you can't make a case for your downvote, you should not be allowed to do it. If you are afraid of getting a "reputation" for downvoting, you should not be allowed to do it. If you do not have your profile filled out, you should not be allowed to do it. This is not some kind of repressive regime where there will be deadly retribution for exercising free speech. With rights come responsibilities.

The purpose of this site is to build an expert repository of answers for the community; to maintain a focus on those questions and answers rather than individual users and "social" networking features, and to keep those questions and answers visible to everyone.

We specifically do NOT encourage off-line, private conversations which do not help the larger group of users on this site. That is by design. If something is relevant to the question, then we prefer it remain on the site out in the light of day.

That being said, if a user wishes to be contacted, they can add their email address to the 'about me' section of their profile. They may also have a blog listed in the 'website' section. Users who also wish to meet other users for conversation may also frequent the OnStartups Chat Room. Either way, if a user wishes to be contacted, they will provide a way.

I don't have specific "down-vote statistics," but what you are describing may actually be a positive sign for this site.

We have been pushing for an increase in participation on this site and trying to encourage better (i.e. more expert-level) content. An increase in down-voting (or voting of any kind) might indicate we are heading in the right direction.

It sounds a bit draconian, but a bit of "tough love" might be just what this site needs. I would NEVER encourage anyone to be mean about it, but the occasional down-vote is the only way to let people know that any old mediocre, half-assed answer is going to get pushed down the list while the better, more "expert" answers will rise to the top. That is at the very core of how the site works — and a vital-but-missing component in this communities participation.

There's been a problem on this site for a long time; Questions are getting answered, but whether that answer is right or wrong or half-baked, it is met with the same apathy; a lack of vetting of "good" content. That doesn't make this site any better than the random forum where you don't know how good the information is.

If there is more down-voting going around, I see it as a good thing. Even better if that down-voting is accompanied by a helpful comment (or, even better, a wiki-edit to the post) outlining where the post went wrong.

There are a lot of experts here. We're just not hearing enough from them, after the fact.

well as soon as OnStartups comes out of public beta you can use

-- Uptick in downvoting

-- Testing to see if there the reports about increased downvoting is true

SELECT CreationDate, VoteTypes.Name, COUNT(Votes.ID)

FROM Votes INNER JOIN VoteTypes ON Votes.VoteTypeID = VoteTypes.ID WHERE CreationDate BETWEEN '20110101' AND GETDATE() AND VoteTypes.Name = 'DownMod' GROUP BY CreationDate, VoteTypes.Name

On http://data.stackexchange.com/stackoverflow/q/100991/uptick-in-downvoting

Until then, I can't help

As for the rest of it.

I agree that downvoting should be banned on members under say 500. This is the time they are likely to receive the most downvotes for doing the wrong thing ... you wouldn't push a baby over when its trying to learn to walk.

I think a downvote should have a popup like a close flag which says "why are you awarding a downvote?" this will give much better feedback to the author of the post.
Congrats Dharmesh. Convey our regards to Mom and the new comer. -:)

The interface allows for editing questions and editing answers. So sometimes a comment made before such an edit no longer makes sense. It would be nice to be able to edit a comment with this context in mind.
row.Title: ability to edit comments

row.Body:
Well, we did remove the -1 cost to the voter of a downvote on a question -- so you may indeed see a bit more downvoting on questions.

Related discussion at http://meta.stackoverflow.com/questions/90324/should-downvotes-on-questions-be-free

This change is noted in http://answers.onstartups.com/faq#reputation as well.

I've been thinking about this, and I'm still not 100% sure how best to implement something like this, but I have a starting point, I think. I think this might work well with a promotional idea I've been toying with for some time now - starting a blog for the site.

A couple of other SE sites have blogs of their own. For example, the Gaming Blog and the Super User Blog (not sure which others have site specific blogs). So I thought maybe we could start our own blog to promote the site and increase traffic. The "Stump the Chumps" follow-up segments would make great content for our blog.

Ways we could implement this are:

  • Video: We could interview the users we helped via short video segments. This makes for a more personal touch.
  • Article: We could do a regular text interview blog post, where we would email several questions to the user we helped, and post it in a Q&A format.
  • Guest posts: Ask some of the users we've helped if they would like to write a guest post describing how the information we provided them helped them in their startup.

Some of the problems I see with this approach:

  • Dharmesh hosts his own blog on onstartups.com. We need to somehow make it clear that these are two separate blogs.
  • Finding people to write content. With the current lack of community participation I'm doubtful we will have enough people volunteering to write posts to make the blog a success. And unfortunately, I don't have enough free time to be the sole contributor (I can't even keep up with my own blog).
  • Contacting users. This doesn't solve the privacy issue, as we somehow still need to contact community members to ask if they would be willing to share their story. This is probably the biggest obstacle. One way around this is to setup a meta question asking for volunteers - people who have used the information they found on the site to positively impact their startup.

Thoughts?

I think this is a good idea. However, there may be instances where someone would like to remain anonymous. I like the idea of letting people remain anonymous if they want to, while also giving them the opportunity to speak up, if they wish to. And I think the current system gives us that flexibility.

If you'd like to remain anonymous, you can. (More on this below). No action necessary on your part.

If you'd like to leave an explanation on why you did what you did, you can. Currently, the system gives you two options to leave feedback:

  1. Leave a comment in the question or answer explaning your action (e.g. why you downvoted).
  2. Leave an explanation in the Edit Summary box when you edit someone's post. For example, this...

...looks like this:

I prefer the first method because it is more visible.

I agree that downvoting or closing a new users question without feedback is not very inviting, and as a result we will lose these folks. Because of that, I encourage our more experienced members to leave these new users feedback on what they can do to improve their question/answer - I think you've done a particularly good job of this.

The software could make it eaiser to leave a comment, maybe by popping up a box if you perform a certain action (although this can get annoying). This already happens in some cases, so it shouldn't be too difficult to expand, but I think we can work with what we currently have to improve new users' experience.

Why remain anonymous?

Well because not everyone is as mature as most of us - this is the internet afterall. Some people will actually get mad, and try to get revenge. I know that sounds silly, immature, and unprofessional, but believe it or not, it happens. To give you an example, a few weeks ago, I closed a question as off-topic. The poster got mad, and left a couple of nasty comments about me, and then downvoted two of my questions. That's extremely childish, but those people exist, so I can understand why some people may want to remain anonymous in certain situations.

Edit: I found this related thread on meta.SO discussing the pros and cons of this approach. If you'd like to spend a couple of hours reading about this, see here.

Just delete the original comment (and post a new one, if you've still something to say). Comments are rather disposable by nature; you can edit within five minutes of posting them, but after that just toss them away once they no longer serve a purpose.

If there's a conversation between multiple users that is no longer relevant to the post, simply flag the post for moderator attention and ask that it be removed entirely.

If this bothers you (perhaps because you want a conversation kept for posterity), then allowing you to go back and edit portions of it would be just as destructive as deletion (and potentially much more confusing): suddenly you've effectively re-written history, potentially invalidating any responses. So either leave it as it was written, or, if no longer useful, remove it.

The profile for this user says:

Hi, I'm not really a person.

I'm a background process that helps keep this site clean!

I do things like

  • Randomly poke old unanswered questions every hour so they get some attention
  • Own community questions and answers so nobody gets unnecessary reputation from them
  • Own downvotes on spam/evil posts that get permanently deleted

I understand the first bullet. That sounds like a useful function.

What does the second bullet mean when it says "unnecessary reputation"? And what is a "community question"?

I don't understand how creating a user named "Community" accomplishes the third bullet.

Help me understand please!
row.Title: I don't understand the user named "Community"

row.Body: Not a question but just wanted to say that the view from IE 6 is white without all the coloring and tagged really funny. Not sure if intentional but some businesses have longer technical change periods and so don't switch to a new browswer. So request the support for IE6. Thanks.
row.Title: Style sheet or related technical change IE 6 not viewing correctly

row.Body:
@John,

The official answer is that IE6 is no longer tested for, which basically means that they don't even look at it.

I understand that there are plenty of business out there who are still on IE6 due to long refresh programs.

The decision for Stack Exchange to not support IE6 is based on a few factors:

  • Traffic
  • Resources are spent better elsewhere
  • IE6 as a browser is already well passed its use by date (it has been superseded multiple times)
  • It has a high cost associated with supporting it (it requires more effort than more modern browsers and is lacking in certain features which may require more code to work around)

I had high hopes for this site. I have begun to think that it might be best to just let it go. There are some decent questions and answers every now and then, but on the whole it is nowhere near as useful as the other SE sites for their respective fields.

I understand it may take time to get there, but we really have few quality questions and very few people who making the site better/more attractive. Perhaps it is indicative of the problem domain...

I have a few theories:

  • The people who would be great contributors to the site are so busy running their small businesses that they have no time for this site - and when they do - they come by and see little that is worth their time.

  • When the people we would love to have here asking questions or posting answers do have free time - they would rather not spend it thinking about other people's business problems - they want to blow off steam, etc. The SO site does not suffer from that - people are eager to share their knowledge and help others - whereas small business problems are not served by a Q&A site like SO is

  • There are already plenty of engaging sites/places to go for the kind of people who could make this site a lot better. There is no incentive/reason for them to come here - and again, when they do land here there is not much to keep them.

Don't get me wrong - there are plenty of great people using the site - I just don't think we're anywhere near a critical mass of regularly visiting "experts".
The site(s) were not intended for heavy conversations or interaction. Comments are second-class citizens and that status is not likely to change.

Questions that become Wiki are "community question", so when you vote them, nobody gets rep. This is something like NULL pointer in some languages like C. For example when spam answer is deleted (most frequent case I see) the question's "last change" user becomes "community"

I used the openid to register and did not realize that means my email becomes public. I tried to edit, and delete the email and that did not work. I'm prepared to delete my ID if needed to achieve this.
row.Title: how can I delete my ID on this stackexchange?

row.Body: You email is not public. It is only visible by you.

I've been here not so long but I've noted as well the extremely low engagement in voting.

I believe it is for self-focused egoistic reasons.

The community is different here. Not a bunch of enthusiastic people but pragmatic and business-oriented. As such they see each other as competition just like in the real world and avoid voting each other up because it provides no reward but gives you a marketing disadvantage.

Why marketing? Because soooo many people are here for the wrong reasons. I've spotted quite a bunch of business-looking individuals spreading around links to their own sites and services disguising them as relevant answers.

So again, a different community profile.

I think moderators should more actively engage in preventing self-promotion activites otherwise the site risks getting overrun with spammers.
Jeff and Joel spoke of some funds available to spend on each site's community. I wonder if this one would be allowed to send a member or two to "Business of Software" or other suitable conference?
row.Title: Chaos request - send member(s) to conference?

row.Body: I have been here for a long time, and frankly I am tired by the low quality of questions. I think most of the problems come from that. If the questions are not very good to begin with, users don't bother to answer, upvote or come back.

I have posted a question a couple days ago but didn't get any reply. It seems as though no one is going through them because I see very little voting and answering, but maybe it's just me?

I find the stackexchange concept very, very good and I am a bit baffled.

Thank you for your time!

Andrea
row.Title: Just wondering...

row.Body:
I just looked at your question. I think the problem is that the question is too long. It's good to have details in your question, as it helps people better answer it. However, if the question gets too long, you end up losing people. Many people won't even bother to read the question if it gets too long. And to be honest, I didn't read it.

My advice to you is to edit the question, and remove the excess content - the content that doesn't help answer the question. Many more people will actually read your question, and thus increase your chances of getting an answer.

Hope that helps!

Your edit is much better!

Old revision:
http://answers.onstartups.com/revisions/25944/1

New revision:
http://answers.onstartups.com/revisions/25944/3

As with any other question, I recommend periodically updating it and editing it to improve it as you do your own research on the matter. This will naturally bump the question and cultivate interest from others.

On the Start-up America Partnership site in the specific section for companies considered to be in the "start-up" phase, they have a lot of directories of resources.

Let's see if we can get "onstartups.com" listed as one of the resources. All you need to do is join me and go and "suggest" on startup's as a resource.

This is the suggestion a resource link:
row.Title: Go Register onstartups!

row.Body:
@Tim makes a great comment on my question today about whether there is any way the question could produce one correct answer.

How are we assessing this parameter of the site? If we take it too literally there is a very small set of potential questions for the community and it will soon die-- it will become a list of FAQ's on legal, financial, and programming issues. Heck even lawyers can disagree about the "correct" answer in a case-- it is what our entire legal system is based on!

On the other hand, If we take it too liberally we end up with a lot of purely subjective questions and fluff.

It seems to me that the vast majority of the issues that entrepreneurs have with startups are "what is the best way" to do something. "Best" is inherently subjective. The resulting answers answer based on the "experts" experience and preferences. The "correct answer" is rally the "best answer" determined by what matches with the askers immediate needs, vanity, interest, or preconceived notions.

The result is a great crowd sources collection of answers that can be searched to evaluate different "best" answers and find the one that works "best" for you.

Unlike the literal world of math or science -- the art of a start-up seems to be intertwined with different takes on the same issues. How is this reconciled by the members of the community?
row.Title: Can any question onstartups produce one correct answer

row.Body:
While the question at the main site that prompted this meta question is not likely to have a single "correct" answer, it most certainly will allow for a variety of answers that the community can then upvote to determine the "best answer". That is precisely how it should work here. Startups as a topic is a lot more subjective than programming. Therefore how we apply this technology must take that fact into consideration when we moderate the content.

While we honor the Stack Overflow roots of Stack Exchange, there has got to be some flexibility here or this thing is just going to die. Even with programming questions at Stack Overflow there can be more than one correct answer. Sometimes the "best" answer is not the answer that is most helpful in a reader's particular circumstances. There are lots of questions with several highly informative answers. It is almost arbitrary which one floats to the top. Some answers, while not all-inclusive enough to be considered the definitive answer, make a very useful point that adds to the discussion. Some answers are primarily a restating of another answer, only clearer.

If we are going to smack down everyone who doesn't take a puritanical view of the "rules" we will drive away a lot of quality participants.

This is a Q&A system, not a discussion platform. The trouble with a question like yours is that the answer is too multifaceted. In other words, to be utterly literal minded, by asking what order those ten steps should be in, well, there are 10! (ten factorial) possible orders, which is 10 * 8 * ... * 1 = 3,628,800 -- so essentially you've created a discussion with infinite permutations and it's hard to "rate" good answers and the model here doesn't work so well. So you'll get one person answering "What does having a life plan matter"? And another person talking about whether you need a business plan--that's just conversation, it's not Q&A.

Far more useful and appropriate to this particular site might be to break it down into individual questions, where, even though the answer might be subjective, at least has some focus. For example:

  • Do you need a life plan to start a business?
  • How soon should you create a business plan?

Etc. There the answers can really be judged as "helpful" or "unhelpful."

One more important guideline - Stack Exchange works really well when people are asking questions about problems that they are actually having. Otherwise it's just an exercise in creative chit-chat. There are a million places on the Internet for awesome chitchat and I don't want to detract from them, but this community and this software are specifically built to get people awesome answers to actual questions they're having, and things like voting, reputation, editing, and the community's own norms of what questions are on-topic are all designed for that.

points are irrelevant, mostly - except to track who uses the system, and how much. so that they get access to more tools without needing supervision (editing others' posts, closing questions, etc...)

if one is here for the points, one is wasting one's time here :)

at least that is how it should be :) that is why questions and answers are both editable - because we are all trying to learn something here not get to level 99 over the corpses of our enemies :P

What is an example of the this Q&A board working and why?

Are the best questions the ones with the most views? The most up votes? Are these the ones that are a model that should be emulated?

Are the best answers the ones with the most views? The most up votes? Are these the ones that are a model that should be emulated?
row.Title: What are examples of the StackExchange "OnStartups" Q&A structure working?

row.Body:
There is a relatively "canonical" blog post answering this here:

http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/09/good-subjective-bad-subjective/

Is "works well" in the eyes of the owners, the moderators -- or the person who asked the question?

  • If the question is allowed on the site
  • If the question gets an answer
  • The answer gets an upvote

Then from our perspective, the site is working. Now, let's take a look at the faq and see what is allowed:

http://answers.onstartups.com/faq

More specifically I think your question ran afoul of these guidelines:

Please avoid wide open questions. Don't write a sentence and expect to get a page back. A question like "How can I sell more of my product" deserves an encyclopedia article. Try to scale back to something more specific.

Avoid asking subjective questions where there is no actual problem to be solved: “I’m curious if other people feel like I do.”

Avoid asking subjective questions where every answer is equally valid: “What’s your favorite ______?”

Without adequate community moderation, it is possible for some of these "too chatty" questions to slip through, and indeed they are WILDLY popular in the same way that "what's your favorite cartoon about entrepreneurs?" or "What color should our startup's homepage be?" are popular. There's no wrong answer and no right answer, just endless entertaining discussion because no skill or expertise is required, just an opinion. Crucially, such questions do not teach anything meaningful about startups or entrepreneurship.

In a broader sense, the information on this site should be educational; you should be here to learn from others and teach others. Any questions where people are being entertained, but not learning anything, detract from that mission and should either be removed or strongly refocused on learning first. In other words, less "let's all discuss cool stuff about the 18th century", and more "what effects did the French Revolution have on contemporary governments?"

This distinction can be subtle and it is all too easy for people to fall into the "but random discussion of things that sound entrepreneury and startuppy are fun!" trap.

As part of moving the site closer to graduation, we think it would be beneficial to "clean-up" the site a bit. By clean-up I mean remove the low quality, and maybe even some outdated content, in order to improve the quality of our site. This is being modeled after the Ask Ubuntu Clean-Up Week.

The implementation details have not been completely defined yet, but the idea is to get as many people as possible involved in the process. The first step is for us to come up with a list of items we want the Stack Exchange team to query from the database. This will produce a list of threads we can go through. We'll want to evaluate each one of these threads, and decide what action we should take, if any.

Actions

Actions will include:

  • Voting up questions and answers that are good
  • Answering unanswered questions
  • Voting to close questions that are off-topic, outdated, not real questions, duplicates, etc.
  • Voting to delete spam, answers that aren't real answers, old closed questions with no useful content, etc
  • Editing poorly written questions/answers to bring them back to life
  • Flagging anything that requires attention
  • Setting a bounty on unanswered questions you find interesting
  • Removing signatures from posts

What To Query

So, as I said, the first step is to come up with a list of things that would potentially identify threads that need our attention. Here's some of the things I've come up with:

  • Questions with close votes
  • Questions and answers with a score of -2 or less
  • Questions tagged feedback
  • Questions tagged ask-onstartups
  • Questions that have earned the Tumbleweed badge
  • Unanswered questions (including those with 0 answers)
  • Questions that have been closed
  • Users who have not visited the site in over 8 months (or some other timeframe), and have only posted once

My Questions For You

  • What else should we query?
  • Any suggestions on the best way to implement this?
  • Any questions on the idea or process?
  • Any other suggestions for possible actions we can take?
  • What should we do with off-topic questions that were asked during the 1.0 days of the site? I started a separate meta thread for this.

I also created a cleanup chat room where we can discuss things in more detail.
row.Title: OnStartups Clean-Up - Getting Started

row.Body:
As part of the OnStartups Clean-Up effort, one of the things we have to address is what we want to do with questions that were asked during the 1.0 days of the site, that are now considered off-topic. Particularly, Review my... questions and Looking for co-founders questions.

My initial thought was to close them as off-topic. However, SE recently implemented a change that automatically gives a -1 to questions that are closed as "off-topic" or "not a real question". I'm hesitant to punish our older community members in this way since these guidelines did not exist at the time.

Instead of closing them as off-topic, I'm leaning towards either closing them as "too localized" or locking them.

The description for "too localized" is:

This question would only be relevant to a small geographic area, a specific moment in time, or an extraordinarily narrow situation that is not generally applicable to the worldwide audience of the internet.

The description for locking a post is:

Posts should only be locked when something seriously bad is happening. A locked post cannot be changed in any way or voted on, and if the locked post is a question, no new answers can be added.

What are your thoughts? What should we do?

  • Ignore those questions, and let them be
  • Close them as "off-topic"
  • Close them as "too localized"
  • Lock them
row.Title: What to do with old off-topic questions?

row.Body: A feature that I'd like is to be able to keep an answer that I'm writing up in a draft status where it isn't yet published for viewing. I think this would help with more complex answers where you are writing it while you are at work on break and cannot finish it in 15 mins or so. I would think this type of feature would be nice across the StackExchanges.
row.Title: Request to add a draft status to answering questions.

row.Body:
Close them as "Off Topic" as that's the correct answer going forward. Think someone who finds a old question via fx Google, because he's thinking about asking a very related question. He will then see the correct reason why the answer was closed, and hence will get correct guidance on what's considered on- & off-topic for this site.

You are completely correct, in this situation the -1 rep is un-deserved. Perhaps the Stack Exchange team can correct this directly in the database. If not, well, if a person gets terribly upset about a few minus one rep's ... that's not really a problem, it's a minimal amount of reputation that is lost.

In the process of cleaning up the board, there is a review of past questions that may or may not fit the evolved intended purpose of the board. One of the ways to do this is to review questions by tag --

One tag that seems to have and attract questions which are not congruent with the purpose of the board is "feedback"

There is currently no wiki definition of the "feedback" tag.

Is there any potential legitimate use of the "feedback" tag on the main board?

This is similar to this question, and I ask it here uniquely to generate specific responses:

yes | no and if yes -- what?

I think we need an approved and agreed upon Wiki definition of this tag -- and clean up the questions that use it.
row.Title: Is there a legitimate use of the "feedback" tag on the main board?

row.Body:
I am looking for an example of a great onStartups question and why.

I am not looking for theory, or principles, or links to blogs.

I am looking for examples of specific questions of what is a great onStartups question and why.
row.Title: What is an example of a great onStartups question?

row.Body:
I think my original OnStartups Community Clean-Up effort post may have been a little overwhelming, and unclear.

The idea behind the OnStartups clean-up effort is to clean up the site by removing some of the low quality questions and answers. Stack Exchange has the ability to pull the low quality threads from the database for us, so we won't have to manually find these low quality posts. We will, however, have to manually go through the threads we get back from Stack Exchange to decide what we want to do with each thread.

Step 1

The first step in this process is to come up with a list of criteria we believe are indicators of a thread that needs attention. Once we have this list, we can pass it along to the Stack Exchange team and they will query the database for us. This will result in a list of threads that meet the criteria we have identified. We will then go through those threads to remove the off-topic and low quality content.

I'd like to have the list of criteria finalized by the end of this week, if possible. My question is, what are indicators of a post that may need our attention? What criteria do we want to pass along to the Stack Exchange team?

Here is what I've come up with so far:

  • Questions with close votes
  • Questions and answers with a score of -2 or less
  • Questions tagged ask-onstartups
  • Questions that have earned the Tumbleweed badge
  • Unanswered questions (including those with 0 answers)
  • Questions that have been closed
  • Users who have not visited the site in over 8 months (or some other timeframe), and have only posted once

What else should we add to this list?

Also, please take a look at @Joseph's related question, on what to do with the feedback tag.

Lastly, I created a cleanup chat room to discuss this effort in more detail.
row.Title: What are indicators of a thread that needs attention?

row.Body:
My immediate thoughts are:

  1. Focus on the questions. A bunch of really bad questions hurt the find-ability of good questions by spamming the Search function etc. A bad answer, which will typically be at the bottom of the answers list, doesn't really hurt the site.

  2. Chop this up into "phases", to make it appear manageable and raise awareness. Deciding how to do this is non-trivial. Maybe first the week of "closing bad questions", then the week of "answering all un-answered questions", etc?

  3. When deleting / closing questions, don't go for 100%. Some questions will be on the edge, could be good or not. Let those live. Getting rid of all "bad" questions won't really improve the site that much, but it will raise confusion and disagreement levels over what's on- or off-topic. Just go for removing the stuff most people can agree on as clearly bad.

  4. For the close questions phase, I would search for:

    • Questions that have one or more "Vote to Close"
    • Questions that have 2 or more downvotes cast (even if the question ends up in plus due to other votes)
    • And lastly questions with no answers. (I think these 3 should be enough to find all the really bad questions, as per my sentiments above.)

  5. For the "answer un-answered questions" phase, I would look for:

    • Questions with no answers (duh).
    • Questions where the sum of upvotes for all answers combined is less than ... maybe 3 votes?
    • Questions that have been closed and have 3 or more upvotes -- maybe some should be re-opened.

1. Questions and answers with multiple links in them.
  2. Depending on how fancy these queries can get, you could cross-reference the links in a user profile against the links found in the user's postings. This pretty well defines self-promotion.
  3. Questions and answers from rep 1 users that are older than a month or so.

IMHO delete the "Feedback" tag.

  • All questions here are asked for the purpose of getting answers. So if somebody is using the Feedback tag in the sense "I'd like an answer, please", then that is fine, but it doesn't communicate anything new.

  • "Feedback" sends the signal that pure "please review my website" questions are welcomed, and IMHO they are not.

  • "Feedback" sends the signal that pure 'Poll questions', wide open questions that are fishing expeditions, are welcomed. I don't remember if we have debated precisely this on Meta, but I don't see these questions as on topic either.

  • I can't think of anything that is accurately described by "Feedback" and isn't better served by another word. At best "Feedback" is a by-tag to better tags, fx "customer-support" or "market-research".

OK, I'm seeing this question too late, and my answer will probably live a quiet life at the bottom here.

IMHO, this is a variation of something that we have kind of discussed before. What throws us off course here is that "general business" is brought up, so it looks like a distinction done on startup versus general business. IMHO that isn't really the thing to focus on.

The critical part is a distinction between topics which are:

  • uniquely related to startups -- business plans, VC financing, product/market fit for example
  • versus
  • topics which concern a common technology or business process which just happens to be used by a startup.

The problem is that if you consider anything a startup happens to make use of on-topic, then in extremity everything is on-topic for this site. How to write HTML (for your startup website), which car to buy (for your first company car) and so forth. And thus the site will become unfocused and meaningless, a kind of discuss-everything-free-for-all like Slashdot or (shudder) Yahoo! Answers.

The above distinction is rarely a clear-cut one or the other decision, it's a judgement call.

I can remember how I first thought of this, but not find the conversation from back then (I think it was before we got a separate Meta site). The question was which hotel he should choose. My comment was that this was off-topic, he should go to Hotels.com or similar. He replied that he needed the hotel because he was in town to pitch investors; and so the question was clearly startup related. IMHO this is a good illustration of the slippery slope this line of thinking can lead to, and that some moderation is required.

One more thing I would add--this site has an unusual number of really old questions that never got an answer. If a question has been languishing for 6 months without a single answer, I'd say just delete it mercilessly. If it's important, someone will ask again....

This has already been implemented.

Allow questions to be saved as drafts prior to posting

The system automatically saves drafts when you start a new answer (or a new question) once every 45 seconds.

There are a few stipulations:

  • You only get one draft for an answer and one for a question. If you start a new post, old draft is overwritten.
  • Drafts are only saved for one week.
  • Drafts are not supported on self-answered questions.
  • Drafts do work for the anonymous users as well.
Removed! Be careful as there are now some untagged questions, however.

"If I'm working at a company, do they have intellectual property rights to the stuff I do in my spare time?"

It is great because:

  1. It is something almost every startup deals with. It appeals to a wide audience (in the startup world).
  2. The answer is not well known or easily available in other places on the internet.
  3. It got great answers.

Some queries and links that might help you get a sense of what criteria fit "great":

Questions with 2,500+ views:
http://answers.onstartups.com/search?q=views%3A2500

Posts with 25+ votes:
http://answers.onstartups.com/search?q=votes%3A25

Questions favorited by 25+ users:
http://answers.onstartups.com/badges/38/favorite-question

Questions successfully shared by users:
http://answers.onstartups.com/badges/54/announcer

I also think a lot of the questions on the homepage right now -- the ones that aren't closed anyway -- are quite good and getting excellent answers.
Just looking for clarity on the badge. Thanks
row.Title: What does the badge first flagged post mean?

row.Body: I assume you get it the first time one of your posts is flagged by a user.
When you flag post ("flag" link after post) as inappropriate.

Noticed something got edited, perhaps the tags on a question and wanted to know what it was. I saw that I could roll it back but suspected it was a good edit but wanted to see what it was so I can learn from that as feedback. Is there a way?

Thank you.
row.Title: A way to see what got edited?

row.Body: Yeah, next to the edited label you will see how long ago it was edited. Click this and you will see the different edits that were applied, with visual differences to easily see what was edited.
is it going to be based on AD placements or there is going to be paid premimum accounts for users? or a combination of both or is it something else.
row.Title: How will Answers.Onstartups.com make money?

row.Body:
Certainly not "premium accounts."

It's possible that there will be ads in future but none are planned as yet.

In general, this is part of the OnStartups.com mission of helping as many startups as possible. Asking "How will Answers make money" is like asking "How will Dharmesh's OnStartups blog make him money?"

The way blogs -- and sites like this -- make the most money is not in ads but in the attention it generates. The attention can then be turned to something that does make money.

Proof? Look at how many questions on this site are "I have a product but how do I get anyone to notice me?" All startups have that problem. If Dharmesh has 20,000 RSS subscribers, he doesn't have that problem. :-D You can see how that's more valuable than a little ad revenue.

Will there be ads someday? It's possible just to cover the operational cost of the site ($129/mo now, more as we get more traffic), but it won't be a big money-maker, and therefore we're super-incentivized to not allow ads to get in the way of content or usability.

Jason's right. No plans for external monetization. What I'm likely to do is have some ads for other projects that I work on (like the blog, my book or other varying and sundry things).

OnStartups.com (the blog) is now almost 4 years old. It was started for the same reason many bloggers start blogs -- I had something I wanted to share with the world that might be useful.

The motivation for answers.onstartups.com is not financial (not directly anyways). I just thought it'd be a good thing to do and it helps feed my voracious appetite for attention (I'm insecure that way).

Give a man a fish, feed him for a day, teach a man to fish, you feed him for life. Give a man a website where he can learn what it takes to be an entrepreneur, ask questions and get help from the community and you will see the benefit.

People remember good deeds, and they know who help them in the past. Its a very small world, and anyone that helps the community will be rewarded by the community.

If some money is generated by the site, more power to them.

Is it appropriate or on-topic to recommend services of a specific vendor on this particular stack exchange? I often see threads like: Anyone recommend a startup-friendly PR firm?

Where it may be appropriate to look for vendors or SE members who have provided good advice and you're looking for more in depth help. This could foster, reward and enhance the quality of answers.

Where i don't see it appropriate is having it become a review site on specific vendors. I.E: Advertising with buysellads.com

Your take?
row.Title: Vendor Recommendations?

row.Body:
From FAQ:

  • every answer is equally valid: “What’s your favorite __?”

  • your answer is provided along with the question, and you expect more answers: “I use _ for _, what do you use?”

Generally suggesting vendors attract spammers and 1 time visitors that just post a link and never return back.

As we all know, in startups presentations are so important. Whether a pitch to a VC, prospective customer, media, potential employees, engineering team, marketing team, whole company, whomever. We use them all the time. And it's important that they do a great job of communicating what we want to get across.

A long time ago somebody sent me an excellent PowerPoint deck with master slides and visuals to convey a huge range of information. Over 300 master charts and visuals in all. It includes bar charts (deviation, sliding, paired...just as an example of the variations in each grouping), line charts, pie charts, balance charts, barrier and obstacles, factors and components, circles, flow, action/reaction, influence, feedback, flow, process, geographic, process/phases, pyramids and a lot, lot more.

The deck had a person's name in the properties section so I contacted them via Linkedin to make sure it was okay to use / give to others and they said it was fine.

If you're interested, it's up on slideshare: http://www.slideshare.net/pagemage/master-charts-for-presentations

Or post your email and I can send it to you directly.

If you do get a copy, please share your feedback to this thread. I'd like to hear what others think.

Cheers,
row.Title: Who wants a master charts presentation in PowerPoint? Over 300 examples.

row.Body:
I'm interested.

Regarding sharing, you can easily share the file using google docs.

here's a quick how to link: http://hublog.hubmed.org/archives/001899.html

and some directions from google:

  • upload: http://docs.google.com/support/bin/answer.py?answer=50092
  • share: http://docs.google.com/support/bin/answer.py?hl=en&answer=158074

if you need some help, let me know and I'll be happy to assist.
I'm interested: adam.b.long1103@gmail.com

I'm interested too.

Slideshare seems to be the best way, as you can upload presentations up to 100 MB. And in Google docs presentations can not be over 200 slides or 10 MB.

I enjoy checking out the profiles of the users who have good answers - I keep being surprised at how many of you are in the area (call it Toronto +/- 90 min drive). I also enjoy meetups, so call this a research question before a potential OnStartups meetup...

So, if you're in the area, I hope you'll answer. If you're not in this area, sorry for the question spam.
row.Title: Who is in Toronto + Area?

row.Body: I live in the heart of Toronto, and would be interested in hearing about an "OnStartups Meet-up".
I have not been as active on this website as late but am halfway through a student exchange at McMaster University....not too far away!
I'm in the GTA.

I'm in the downtown core and interested in meeting others in the startup space. Cheers,

Jordy
I live in downtown Toronto, too.

Additional thoughts:

  • Questions tagged untagged
  • Questions tagged ideas
  • Questions tagged review
  • Questions by this user: http://answers.onstartups.com/users/2233/steven
  • Questions by this user: http://answers.onstartups.com/users/3751/jack
  • Questions that have been migrated (I'm not sure if these show up under closed as well)
  • Check if all posts by a user contain a link to the same domain
I used to live to the east of Oshawa a while back, am usually back a few times a year. Good excuse for a visit I'd say.

I noted that some of the links to Amazon Books are not properly formatted and some of them contain affiliate codes. SO engine replaces links to Amazon (if properly formatted) with special links of the form: http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/006124189X so the site can get affiliate credit and earn some money. It might be a good as part of clean up to check old links so all of them can get proper parsing.
row.Title: Amazon links parsing

row.Body:
I filled out the form so we'll see what becomes of it.

But the form says "Do you know of a great entrepreneur resource?" while the form itself seems to assume some affiliation from the person suggesting it. So, I'm not entirely certain if they'll act on the one official contact or if they're looking for more of a groundswell of support from a group of users to indicate interest. Perhaps someone here more familiar with the organization can answer that one.

Over on Writers we got a question that doesn't really fit within our scope, but I believe may be on-topic for Answers.OnStartups. It is How to write a sales letter that works. The author is asking about how to sell his or her skills as a developer, not really about the writing aspect of a sales letter. I know the question is a bit broad and vague, but would it be welcome here? If so, would you all take it if I migrate it?
row.Title: Would Answers.OnStartups accept this question from Writers?

row.Body:
I see that number of "Review my application/startup" type of questions are recently being closed.

If this is against onstartups policy then I would request you to re-consider this policy.

What is the most important thing for a startup?

It is their product/website or web application, right?

And if they have difficulty with their number one thing that makes their startup a startup then why should they not be allowed to post questions and ask for reviews?

After a while most of the startup related general questions would be answered and the only remaining ones would be left out like

'why am i not able to generate revenue for myapp.com'

'where should i market my newbeautiful desktop app'

'which bloggers cover thistype of app'

and so on.

So all of these questions are still very specific to individuals product and I believe there is always something to be learnt from someone else's problems.

Don't you think we should allow 'Review my app' kind of questions?

PS: I was actually about to ask a question to review/feedback on my new app so was researching on examples on onstartups but found that recently they are not being allowed.
row.Title: Review my application/startup type question

row.Body:
OnStartups is answering general questions to Startups, not to specific ones.

So, if you are asking about shares or marketing strategies - very good.

If you ask: have I created a nice looking design? - well, this is not startup specific, you must ask at Q&A for designers

If you ask: Check my app out, isn't it cool? - many people may think this is a kind of spam. Not everybody has the time to really review the coolness of a startup.

I think, finding the right questions is pretty difficult. It is more questions to tooling, taxes, employees, money and such stuff rather than rating design or if a startup is useful.

I am open to corrections or other views

Cheers, Christian

yeah I have faced this problem only a couple of days ago myself here on onstartups and ever since its been bugging me but you are right. Onstartups says that they are here to help cover the start-ups but the key help to start-ups (review and feedback) isn't allowed. Whats the point then?

Onstartups platform now seems more like a chat room or another general discussion forum.

I think it fits to both parties, does it?

On the one hand, this is a startup related question, without doubt.

But who could answer it better than writers? Not sure if I understand the point in writers Q&A well, but I thought it is covering professional letter writing, right?

Well, the title of that question has nothing to do with the body of the question. It is also a poorly written question, and is a good fit for closing under "not constructive". That said, we've allowed worse questions on this site before.

I wouldn't be opposed to you migrating it over. The topic itself is a better fit for our site than yours, and it could be a fixable question.

I ask that you give it an hour or so before migrating it though. I'd like to see what other community members think (I may be in the monirity on this). If no one else responds then I say migrate it over.

This topic was previously discussed here.

As I see it, there are several problems with those type of questions:

  1. This is a Q&A site, and those questions do not fit this site's format. Those questions are designed to elicit opinions and discussions, not to find the right answer. I know we have a lot of subjective questions on this site, and that's fine with me, because that's the nature of the startups topic. However, I feel like the "review my ..." questions go way beyond simply being subjective, and can only be strictly discussion questions.
  2. These questions lead to lots of spam. I'm sure there are plenty of folks out there that are truly interested in getting feedback on how to improve their product/website/etc (I'm one of them). The problem is that there are probably way more people out there that are simply interested in posting a link to their site to get traffic, and never plan on contributing to the site. I consider this to be spam, and it is very annoying to those of us that put so much effort into building this site.
  3. If we ignore the above two points, and decide to allow these questions, my feeling is that we'll end up getting overrun with them. That's all we'll end up seeing on the main page, and as a result we'll end up pushing away the few experts left on this site. These types of questions are generally not interesting, and for the most part only benefit the person asking the question. Plus very few of us actually have the time it takes to review someone's website, or product, or whatever.

I do see this as a genuine need for a lot of folks, but unfortunately I don't think we're the site to meet that need. I suggest we keep the question Where can I get feedback or have my site reviewed? in mind, and update it any time we discover a new review site. There is also this question: Suggestions on sites for critiquing websites.

My vote is that these questions remain as off-topic.

The issue is that it ONLY helps the one person. It is also time-intensive for the other folks who answer and there is no "right" answer.

Joel On Software might be the better place to go, or if you think there is a need for this kind of thing then start your own site/forum.

It has always been off topic and should remain so.

Based on the responses from this question, and this other question, I propose that as part of the OnStartups site clean-up effort we eliminate the startups and startup tags from the site.

We can destroy those tags now, and then any questions that end up untagged as a result can be added to our list of untagged questions that we plan on addressing during our cleanup effort.

What do you all think?
row.Title: Eliminating the Startups and Startup tags

row.Body:
What should be our policy on questions that can easily be answered by doing a quick Google search? For example, this question, and this other question.

Should we allow these questions, or close them? I'm a bit worried that keeping them around will hurt the quality of the site.
row.Title: Policy on "Google-able" questions

row.Body:
First off, massive props for actually engaging with this difficult topic, Zuly! You're a gem, really.

About what to do ... honestly, I don't know, and I despair at it.

Personally, I feel that Answers.Onstartups (AO) is drowning in low-quality questions. And my motivation to contribute answers is falling, hard.

Part of the problem is easily Google-able questions, but that's not the only problem. There is at least one important problem more: The Stack Exchange (SE) engine was built to avoid duplicates of the same question. But it was built on programming questions, which often have a narrow vocabulary; a specific set of words are set by the professional vernacular.

AO deals with 'business' issues and 'human' issues, and the list of more-or-less synonym words that can be used is huge. We're seeing lots of fairly similar questions being asked again and again, and the SE engine isn't successfully stopping this. (To be fair, 'reading the users mind' is the very hardest problem there is in computer science!) (And before someone reminds me of the Close -> Exact Duplicate function, I just used it a few seconds ago.)

Back to easily Google-able questions: Actually my first instinct is to go easy on them. They can work as Google-fodder, providing link bait which lures in other prospective entrepreneurs and helps grow this site.

But, this should be handled in context of how the site is currently doing. My personal view is that while many things are steadily improving, we are currently loosing a vital battle over the signal-to-noise ratio. Maybe I'm just a grumpy old-timer, but that's how I feel.

So, while I think that easily Google-able questions are essentially an asset, I would be all in favor of going hash on them until the community moderation is stronger. My main focus is that I'd like a stronger community moderation here.

For me it is a "depends" question. I think the threshold is different for everyone. Some obviously have no merit and should be closed or moved, but some, even though answers can be found via goolge, might be useful on this site for collecting good information.

I agree with Jesper - there is a real signal to noise ratio issue here.

I don't know the answer, but I think it should be considered with other relevant considerations.

Simple -- refer to this handy chart!

http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2011/02/are-some-questions-too-simple/

Long overdue IMO. This is a healthy and necessary change!

  1. destroyed startup
  2. destroyed startups
  3. added both to the tag blacklist

Beware, there are now 153 untagged questions needing cleanup. :/

[This is not a question but I want to share my story and want to send an encouraging message to hopeful entrepreneurs. Sorry for the long post.]

If you want to keep your job and work on a side online business, go for it. I did it and I am planning to do it again.. and again (note: this will not be a marketing pitch!)

I follow and read a lot about startups. I listen to thisweekninstartups.com & and read Hacker News plus others. I read books like "Founders at Work". I am web a developer and have a full time job. Always have been. After listening to all the stories about startups, I get the sense that if you want to launch a successful startup, you MUST dedicate all your time and energy to it.

I started a web hosting company over 10 years ago and it was very successful. I paid for everything from my own pocket. No funding of any kind, not even borrowing or taking a loan. I started with a single server and kept adding more hardware with more traffic, organically. I have no employees and I didn't pay myself. I had a day job. The web hosting was a one man shop and I did EVERYTHING; hardware and software support, billing and marketing. ALL THIS WHILE KEEPING MY DAY JOB! Yes it was hard work and nerve wrecking when a server would go down. I was nervous and tense whenever I traveled because I was in a "what will I do if a server goes down or I need to be there to replace some hardware" mode. I built the systems myself. My ISP has no idea and all they can do is push the reset or power buttons.

However I gave great customer support. I would answer business calls during work, secretly.. oops! Business mail would forward to my phone. That's the only way to juggle between a day job and have a side business AND offer fast customer support. But it worked for YEARS and minus the hosting fee I paid my ISP, almost all my revenue was pure profit. It was nice, minus some stress.

Then, I got married and had kids and got very busy. It affected my business. I was giving it less time and my customers felt it and they started moving to other hosting companies and I neglected all kinds of marketing so eventually I was bleeding customers. Customers left with no new customers signing up. I decided my family came first. The only time I could do any work was when everyone went to bed and I would stay up, coding and coding.

The beauty of the web is that if you go to a web site offering a service, you have no idea if one person is behind it or a group of people. I used that to my advantage. As long as your web site looks professional and you offer a reliable affordable useful service, you are in business!.

I understand that a lot of people are afraid to start a startup and to quit their day job. They don't want to lose the security of a dependable salary and the benefits like health insurance. If you have kids and a mortgage, it would be frightening to lose all that. Some take the leap and some people don't. I didn't. BUT what if you can just make both happen?
