A secure day job AND and a profitable online business.

My web hosting is dying now. That's OK and I understand. The business became a commodity and there are tons of companies offering free hosting, 59 cents hosting and other crazy figures. I can probably do the same and still be profitable but I think I had enough and I need a change.

Guess what? I am still planning to keep my day job and I have THREE ideas for startups. I am very excited about them and each one can keep me busy for YEARS. I am on fire and I am full of energy to work on the first one. Because I am a web developer, I can build them myself. I can host them myself because I already have hosting experience. I know developing them myself might be too much for me so maybe I will outsource some work using services like rentacoder.com or eLance.com and be in charge because they are my ideas, I know how they should be built and I have the specs.

If an idea fails as a business, that's OK too. Because it will be a great learning experience from a technical side for me. I am a Windows developer. I want to learn WPF, Silverlight, MVC, .NET 4.0, WCF, JQuery.. and the rest of the latest coming out from the technical firehose. What's better than learning these cutting edge technologies, be proficient in them and build a concrete application that the whole world will use. You can put these in your resume and be more marketable. Remember.. I have a day job and want to be more marketable and earn more because I have practical modern skills.

So here's my final word, which I mentioned in the beginning, if you want to keep your job and work on a side online business, go for it. I did it and I am planning to do it again.. and again. If you are going to do it yourself, it will take A LOT of work. To make it happen faster, you will need to focus, have a cutting sharp concentration, adaptable, resourceful, flexible, manage your time with a determination, be able to cut the noise from the web (tweets, facebook, blogs, emails.. etc). Learn.. learn.. learn. I read a lot every day just trying to keep up with all the new technologies. When I code and I need help, I Google. If it looks like it will take me more than 5-10 minutes (I do my homework) to find an answer, I post a question on stackoverflow.com. SO is a great resource. Ask for help, don't spin your wheels.

Good luck!

[I know people will ask. Sorry I can't name my company nor mention my new ideas]
row.Title: YES... you can build a profitable startup while keeping your day job

row.Body:
As a counter point: There is a lot of danger in working on a separate venture while you're engaged in a full-time job. This is especially true if you're inventing something that will eventually be patentable.

A great discussion of this can be found at ip law for startups. NOTE: I am not affiliated with this site in any way, I just find the content interesting.

LeCroy vs Serialtek litigation is an example of what happens when a company feels threatened by the actions of its employee or ex-employee.

I happen to be very familiar with this case and learned my lessons: don't engage in activities that might constitute a conflict of interest, or worse.

Aside from the legal issues, I wonder how people muster the energy for a startup on the side if their day job is already a high demanding job. If I am in a interesting software engineering job with all that entails (coding, inventing stuff, crunch time before releases, ...), then I don't see how I can work in the evening & weekends on top of that.

I'd like to offer a counterpoint too. I tend to agree with Cassandre about the energy issue (I'm now 46, so it's harder for me to imagine being able to do two jobs simultaneously) and I think Rich & OutputLogic make very good points about the dangers regarding IP and inventions.

However, I'd like to offer a more fundamental question. Is it right? For some the answer may be yes, but I suggest it's something people should give some serious thought to before embarking in a "spare time" business. If I work for a company in a full-time job, I believe it is right to give my all. During work time, that means I need to be 100% focused on the task in hand, so that calls into question whether it is right to be taking support calls from your side business. Also, as an employer, I take on smart people because of what they can as a whole person can contribute (for example, some of my best ideas have been in the shower), so I would feel slightly cheated if I found out their primary energy and intellect was going into somebody else's business. (Please note I am not saying staff should work 24/7).

My point is not that what Tony is saying is wrong, but rather that it isn't universally true, and that people should be careful before jumping on the "business in my spare time" bandwagon. As a transition strategy, I'm sure it has been useful for many start-ups, but I disagree it's a long-term proposition for too many people.

Interesting post. I am wondering - how do you plan to do customer development when you have a day job? Do you completely depend on the search engines to discover your service/ product? Do you plan to do other promotions for your service/ product?

I wonder if it's time to have a curated set of Frequency Asked Questions & Answers. That way, Answers can be the Google-able answer to the question.

I do agree with Jesper (Please, don't leave) and Tim that there is an awful lot of poor quality questions.

A curated set of FAQA's may be a way to point people to their answer. You could close the question and just point to the already completed answer.

I know that would be more work but it certainly would provide a tremendous amount of value to the site and the community.

I know when I Google programming questions, I always choose the Stack Overflow result since I know it can be trusted and the quality is generally pretty good. I don't often Google business questions but when I do, Answers rarely comes up.

I am pondering whether it is worth publishing my app in a Chinese-specific market.
Would this question be on-topic or off-topic here?

Details if needed: Porting an Android app to Lenovo's "LePhone" OS is not trivial, so beforehand I would like to know how popular LePhone really is. My Android app is translated to Chinese, about 100K users, 30% in Asia.
row.Title: Are market research questions on-topic?

row.Body:
I just discovered that SO has a “It does not meet our quality standards” filter that is triggered if a low quality question is submitted. I'm almost positive OnStartups Answers doesn't have this protection. My guess is that this is a trilogy thing.

I think something like this could help us fight some of the low quality questions we've been seeing lately. Assuming this is a general algorithm that would work on non-programming questions, I propose we add this feature to our site. I'm curious to see if it would help.

What do you all think?
row.Title: Using the “It does not meet our quality standards” filter

row.Body:
I just tried asking a terrible question on this site, and I got

Oops! Your question couldn't be submitted because:

  • It does not meet our quality standards.

(except that it was bigger and redder)

Looks to me like it's working!

I think they can be, so long as they are in the "teach a man to fish" format.

That is, rather than being calls for specific research data, the question is generalized a bit and invites us to learn how to ...

  • determine what kind of marketing data we need for our startup

  • source it online

  • price it (if necessary)

  • and once we have it, analyze it

The risk is that a question like this could be a bit too localized to your specific situation and unlikely to help any other future visitors learn about the process of utilizing market research to further their startup, too.

There is a great thread here related to Google-able Answers by @Zuly.

Most of us have observed that the questions on Answers have a lot of noise with not much signal. It also appears that there are a lot of redundant questions that get answered over and over again.

I'm not saying that it's necessarily bad to answer questions in a different way but how many times do we have to answer How does one judge the merits of an idea? or maybe Equity distribution among Co-Founders Pre-Money

To help solve this problem, I suggested a curated FAQA (Frequency Asked Questions on Answers) that us, as moderators, would edit and craft over time. Over time, this would turn into our Answers canon.

@Zuly gave an example of @Joel's canonical answer about how to split up equity which is an example of a great answer that should not be buried in a title like: Forming a new software startup, how do I allocate ownership fairly?, rather it should be under a question like or section like:

  • How to Divide Up Founders Equity

because his answer applies to all startups or maybe a higher level question like:

  • Startup Equity Demystified.

I think this would help reduce the noise and actually make Answers the google-able answer to these questions.

This is similar to a question I posted on answers related to a standard tag list which got migrated here. That was more to make it easier for people to select a tag. Maybe we could use that list as a starting point for our canonical questions and answers.

EDIT: I just posted an example question and answer to the question How to Divide Up Your Companies Equity

EDIT: Two additional questions are now up: How to Raise Funds For your Company and How Should I Deal with Intellectual Property

I'm sure the format needs a little work but I think it captures the idea.
row.Title: Let's come up with a list of canonical Q&As

row.Body:
We get a lot of questions about dividing equity and for good reason. Dividing up your startups equity creates a lot of heart burn for all of us. It's a tremendously stressful affair if you have never done it before.

Joel Spolsky has a wonderful mantra on equity:

Fairness, and the perception of fairness, is much more valuable than owning a large stake.

Joel's equity dividing answer to this question offers what we feel is a comprehensive answer to this nagging equity question.

If you find yourself wanting to ask an equity dividing question, please read Joel's answer first before posing the question. It's chalked full of useful information and has a wonderful example to guide you through the process.

Additional Equity Questions and Answers

If Joel's answer does not answer your equity dividing questions, then take a look at a couple more questions that dive into different aspects of equity, founders and working for stock.

  • Amount of Equity to Retain as a Key Founder: Is a discussion about different levels of work effort and how they should be rewarded with equity
  • Redistribution of Equity At Each Stage of Growth: Discusses dilution and how that happens with investment and growth
  • Equity For Specific Performance Metrics: This was a lively discussion about how to award equity when certain performance metrics were met.
  • Fair Equity Splitting Between Two Founders: This one deals with a common dilemma on how to split equity between two founders when they perform different roles.
  • Changing Your Equity Structure: Explores what happens when your equity distribution needs to change or be revamped completely. It investigates vesting plans and the sticky problems with "when one founder works harder than the others."

Lastly, looking through the questions tagged 'Equity' is often very helpful.

Feel free to add any additional links to questions or answers that expand on the topic of equity.
row.Title: How to Divide Up Your Company's Equity

row.Body: I noted recently that at least two users are continuously posting links to SalesKB site. This seems to me like organized SPAM campaign. Can somebody with access to moderation tools conform this. I feel uncomfortable removing parts of posts for each of them.
row.Title: SalesKB spam links.

row.Body: All taken care of. Let us know if you see this behavior in the future.

Funding your company is an important part of your startup and expansion strategy. It's a broad topic that has a lot of aspects including: keeping your idea secret, seed funding, angels, venture capitalists or boot-strapping.

Each company is unique and so is the funding strategy. The common thread among all startups is they do need capital and obtaining that capital takes a lot of effort and focus -- something most technical founders hate to spend time on.

There are several great questions and answers on funding which are presented below:

  • Funding: Where to Start?: We get this question a lot and this thread has several great answers. The main take-a-way is to answer the question Do you really need funding?
  • Bootstrapping Your Startup: This whole thread is chalked full of great advice. The one take-a-way is that managing your cash flow is vital.
  • What to Disclose to Investors: Shares an experience with giving some investor pitches and how much information is too much.
  • Angel Investors and Debt: Quite a good post on the difference between debt and equity for an angel round.

Along with how to raise money, we often get the question When to Raise Money. This can be tricky and obviously highly dependent on what business you are in and your burn rate.

Several questions deal with this topic that are worth looking at. They include:

  • I don't Think I Need Funding, Should I Look Anyway: Raises a great question and the answers reflect some hard choices startups need to make.

  • Can a Startup With Little Expenses Benefit From Investors?: Explores why an investor may be good for you even if you are breaking even or have a low burn rate.

  • Savings, Bootstrapping, Startup: Discusses the savings required for a bootstrapped startup. A good rule of thumb was a year's salary but it was also discussed when to go get funding.

  • Surviving Without a Paycheck: Startups typically don't make money on day one. That's the primary reason to raise money -- so you can survive and not have to dip into savings.

Also see the posts tagged 'Funding', 'Seed-Funding', 'Investors' and 'Bootstrapped' for more discussions of this.

If your questions fall out of these answers, then feel free to post a question. If you do pose a question, please link to this answer so we can build a better canon for the site.
row.Title: How to Raise Funds For Your Company

row.Body:
Intellectual property is a subject that has far reaching implications for your business. There are several different types of intellectual property that every business deals with. They include: patents, trademarks, copyrights and trade secrets.

Intellectual Property (IP) laws vary country to country with some countries having strong IP laws while others have little to none. When asking a question about IP, it's important to include the country that you are concerned with.

One of the most popular and relevant questions and answer to budding entrepreneurs has to deal with Ownership of works created on your own time. This is actually a complex question because the answer has a lot to do with where you live and your employment contract.

As with anything of a legal nature, make sure to contact a lawyer for specific advice.

Some Other Intellectual Property Questions Worth Reviewing

  • What to do if some steals your idea: Explains an idea someone had that he things google stole and what he should do about it.
  • A discussion about Trademarks: Asks a good question about registering trademarks in different countries
  • Patenting of Software: A discussion about algorithms and if they are patentable.
  • Joint Development and IP: How to setup ownership of IP when software is jointly developed.
  • Copyrighting A Marketing Idea: It's a specific question but the answers point to a great summary of the different types of IP.
  • What to do if Someone Violates Your Copyright: A real world example of someone getting a blog post ripped off and what to do about it.
  • User Interface Protection: Are user interfaces copyrighted material and can you copy them.
  • How to File a Patent: Gives advice on filing patents and what's patentable.

Additional Tags: Take a look at intellectual-property, patent,trademark or copyright to find other useful questions and answers.
row.Title: How Should I Deal With Intellectual Property

row.Body:
I have now added three of these questions to meta and wanted to get feedback from the group. Should we pursue these types of questions and answers on the Answers?

Clearly, they should be community wiki type answers so that they can get expanded upon as new questions and answers come along.

Any other thoughts on this?

DISCLAIMER: I've been fairly sparse with my involvement on this site, so this suggestion may not be as applicable to someone whose well versed in the communities doings and may be heavily self serving. I apologize if it reads in bad taste. Thanks for a wonderful site!

So, currently the site's purpose reads:

Answers.onstartups.com is a site for entrepreneurs starting and running new businesses.

Topics include financing, hiring employees, renting an office, legal, marketing, sales, compensation plans, banking, payroll, benefits, and more. This is the place to come with specific questions or to seek specific advice from your peers.

I realize the site is called OnStartups, but I've heard from a large number of individuals that the challenges that intrapeneurs face within Fortune 500 (and definitely Fortune 10 companies) are quite similar to entrepreneurs: financing, getting the right industry mentors, marketing new initiatives, proposal drafting and pitching - analogous to business case writing and pitching to VCs, and getting the right team together.

Of course intrapreneurship comes with its own caveats in each of these dimensions and also has some of its own challenges in being more tightly entrenched in local politics. Recently, as an intern at a Fortune 10 company, I've been proposing a new position for myself and have been learning of numerous new initiatives that are looking for support and growth within the company. So, this may detract from the initial intentions of the creators, which I would completely understand.

This site might gain a large segment of the population that may be deterred by a definition fit for a glorified group of individuals willing to risk any form of stability to be entrepreneurs when many are truly "starting and running new businesses" within larger organizations all over the world. Also, I think intrapreneurship is a great gateway for entrepreneurship for many and vice-versa, as can be seen in a post by someone, who felt unable to contribute as openly for the reason that they're not an entrepreneur in the traditional sense.

Whether or not the ideas bears any weight, thanks again for the great site, and I hope to continue being a part of the community!
row.Title: Discussing Intrapreneurship on the site?

row.Body:
I'd personally advocate for opening up the purpose to include another "class of entrepreneurship", intrapreneurship!

See my suggestion for more of my thoughts: Discussing Intrapreneurship on the site?
It seems to be broken today. Or am I hell-banned?
row.Title: What is wrong with the editing functionality?

row.Body: We aren't aware of any issues with it at this time. Have you tried clearing your browser cache?

I think the issues of intrapreneurs are so different from entrepreneurs, it wouldn't be helpful to merge them. It would only confuse everyone.

Entrepreneurs have full freedom to build anything they want, so they do, and then tend to need help focus on stuff that makes more business sense.

TL;DR: Regarding canon questions, I think question and answer should be posted separately to allow for more answers and stay in the Q&A format.

Hello all,

I've seen canon questions are now being posted on the main site (and think it's great). I'd like to question the format in which they are: wouldn't it be better to have the question/intro posted and then the answer (with links, etc) as a separate, accepted answer?

This would, imho:

  • keep the expected Q&A format around here
  • by posting the answer (and accepting it) I think we are encouraging other members to add to that answer, as happens on the other questions since it's still an open question.
  • right now, these questions feel like "Admin Posts" which are so common in other kind of forums and which are not meant to have replies. I don't think that's the reasoning behind them, am I right or wrong?

Cheers,

Tomé Duarte
row.Title: Format of canon questions

row.Body:
I tend to agree; questions with no answers are an odd duck.

So unless there is some amazingly compelling reason to have "just a question", I support breaking it into the traditional question and answer pair.

In answering a questionable question (which I voted to close) I went to review the FAQ and notes that no where does it address questions that explicitly or implicitly refer to illegal activity.

Did I miss that somewhere or is that not in the FAQ?

If someone asks about setting up a company to sell drugs? Engage in prohibited business activity? Violate a Visa?

Are these questions that are voted "close"? Which reason? And where in the FAQ do I link an explanation to the ask-er of why?

Thank you.
row.Title: Policy/FAQ on Questions which allude to illegal activity

row.Body: I'd use intent to decide. If someone asks genuinely "can I stay longer on my visa?", that's a valid question. If the person asks "I am trying to avoid being caught by the authorities while overstaying my visa, what are good tricks", I'd close the question.

I think the canonical "questions" would be better off as tag wikis.

(BTW, the [canon] topic name title can't be used any more. You'll get a posting error like "title contains a [tag] prefix; please use the tag field to enter tags instead.")

Has this happened, or is it theoretical?

If it has happened... we should decide on a case-by-case basis!

If it's theoretical, I believe that free speech is an important principle, and it's not our job to censor your questions merely because some jurisdictions may or may not currently consider what you're doing to be illegal.

That said, there are certainly things which everyone in the community might consider odious, so we can use our discretion to close them on those grounds.

So for example... if someone asks about marketing, where they happen to be marketing marijuana, I think we could safely say that marijuana is not universally condemned, so we don't have to close that question just because it happens to be illegal in many jurisdictions. Whereas, if someone asks about how to best trade in child sex slaves, we can pretty much agree that that is universally abhorrent, at least by the standards of this community, and close or delete the question.

For the specific examples you gave (selling drugs, prohibited business activity, violating a visa), I don't think there is a strong reason to close the question. Why not just answer with a comment along the lines of "That would be illegal and almost no sane startup owner would take the risk of their entire business jeopardized for something like this".

Do, however, be aware that these questions are often trolls. "Should I give free samples of my hallucinogenic product to everyone or only high school kids?" That question is "not a real question" and should be closed as such, not because the activity discussed is illegal, but because it's imaginary.

Even though I have an affinity for grids personally. This background grid graphic is really uninspiring. Make it be a paper napkin, like - write your ideas on a paper napkin. Maybe add a corner coffee stain for flair.
row.Title: Change the background image for OnStartups

row.Body:
The current theme is called "Sketchy," and it's used for all SE sites still in beta1. When sites launch, they get a design of their own.

Some statistics on how this site is doing:

  • Compared to sites that started around the same time period
  • Compared to a standard set of goals

Previous discussions here about graduation:

  • When OnStartups will graduate?
  • Why's onstartups a beta? does it end?
  • Will we survive?
  • What are the current plans for site design and timing
  • What is the decision, go or no-go?

1 Minus one exception, but it's not relevant here.

What is it with people on this site?

It feels like we are losing a lot of people early on in the cycle and I think its because they don't feel welcome.

Its supposed to be a question and answer site, not a if you don't know the question I'm going get nasty about it site.

We are losing a lot of users by being snarky and closed minded ... epecially when they are new to the site and they have people jump on them from a great height.

I have spoken to a few senior users about this in the past.

  • Given the influence of stackoverflow, most of the people answering have a techie world view ... I hadn't realised but this is isolating others and keeping them out. How do we encourage people to see things from different perspectives?
  • We see the same questions again and again, what are shares etc. Linking them to the previous answers is fine but I have seen people get nasty about doing so ... placing myself in the new persons shoes I would be put off.

To counter these

  • Could we have a ban on down votes for people with less than 500 rep.
  • Could we have a must comment on downvotes as to why.
  • Could we have a "pull your head in" option on the flagging of at post. Under the "not welcome on this site" marker. A lesser version which is a warning to go easy and rephrase your answer to be in a friender tone.
row.Title: Are we losing users by being snarky and closed minded?

row.Body:
I'm ambivalent. On one hand, I find a lot of questions are really low quality. So we close a lot of questions, or answer them with an attitude.

On the other hand, it doesn't give a welcoming feeling, I can see that. I have tried to be open-minded. For instance, I didn't close the question about having a better slogan for Coca-Cola, even though I found it naive.

One of my concerns is which community we want to build. I have a preference for solid, high-tech startups, not small businesses like the ones that seem to hang out on startups.com. There are a lot more of the latter by the way.

I believe it is correct to say that we are loosing users because this site is relatively hard to define. I believe this is the root cause for many issues.

I, for example, often find myself spending time considering whether a question would be on or off-topic, and end up not asking the question because I am not up for the potentially lengthy discussion.

I believe we could solve the problem that this site is hard to define in the following general ways:

  • Communicating the topic clearer. This also means creating technology, which would communicate this while one tries to submit a question, so off-topic questions are never asked.
  • Segmenting the site using new rules/technologies for tagging. The reason for this is to make it easier for experts to exclude questions they are tired of seeing. One way is to say that we demand that the submitter of a question either tags it as an "advanced" or "newbee" question. I am not saying this is a good idea, but it is an example of such an idea.
  • Changing the topic of this forum. This is a lot more drastic, but one could for example broaden or narrow the topic, to make it easier to communicate.
I would vote, but I'm not allowed, not until I arbitrarily post some probably-duplicative answers in order to be able to vote...
I'm going to duplicate others' answers in the hope that it'll get me more rep, so that I can vote instead of polluting the site with answers posted only to get rep...

Such as:

Can more than one U.K. company be registered at the same U.K. address?

Or are such legally-specific questions off-topic anyway?
row.Title: Are country-specific questions acceptable?

row.Body:
If I'm asking a question on "mvp" and I want to link the word 'mvp' to a page for those who might not be knowing about it and might find it helpful, then should I try to

  1. link to the best possible match for what mvp is about on this community itself, or
  2. link to wiki page, or
  3. link to a (popular) blog post, or
  4. tag 'mvp' takes care of that (I'm not sure about this though), or
  5. no need to give the link as a question discussing something about mvp is generally not meant for someone who doesn't know what mvp is.
row.Title: Best way to link to content in/outside this community in a question?

row.Body:
It's probably sufficient to link to the Wikipedia entry in the post itself, and/or the blog entry.

There are a few questions already tagged mvp and that seems to be using the same definition, so I updated the tag wiki to reflect an excerpt of the Wikipedia information, too.

I like what David says. Personally, I think some people don't come back because their reputation doesn't move up. There are many good comments out there, or at least comments that's obvious the person took her time to put them together, that don't get any upvotes.

As for the relevance of the questions, perhaps there should be another vote system to signal whether the community thinks the question is relevant or not.

I'm a member of the CHAOS team over at the Stack Exchange headquarters in NY. We're working on ways of growing the membership of the site while maintaining the high quality participation and integrity of posts. Engagement seems to be greatest in a regular group with a drastic drop-off of activity in most of the membership- a fair bulk of the users registered here are passers by. To increase both membership and engagement a sustained interest in startups and our community should be present.

To that end, what are your views on advertising or partnering on startup job boards/networks such as startuphire.com, ventureloop.com etc? The rationale is that users are presumably already working at startups or have a serious interest in them and would stand to learn/contribute much over longer periods of time to our community.

Are there other networks or sites that you would like to see OnStartups partner with and have a usership that you would want to join our community?
row.Title: Networks/sites that you want to see OnStartups partner with?

row.Body:
A couple come to mind:

  • Lateral Action: Which has a lot of creative entrepreneurs that are from all sorts of industries
  • Copyblogger: Caters to more of the social media/blogger crowd but a lot of startups look to them for advice and guidance.
  • Venturehacks: They also have Angel List that is a great community of angels and startups.
  • SCORE: counsels entrepreneurs for free but their resources are a little thin on the high-tech side. It's run by the Small Business Administration.

I am a relatively light user of this site so I suppose my observations could be considered "fresh", or maybe not.

For what it's worth, some of the questions seem to provoke legitimately snarky responses. In other words the poster is kind of asking for it.

I have noticed slews of questions in this general pattern: "we want to hire X, but we don't really want additional partners, and we really don't want to pay a person anything unless profit results from our business. How can we attract droves of talent on our terms alone?"

Another is variations on "we want free content/programs/etc. and no commitments on our part".

I personally find this kind of question somewhat annoying. I have had to work for everything I have... including business assets... and it seems self absorbed to presume that someone will just donate valuables to someone's startup. If I feel that way, then I assume others do, too.

I'm saying there is a definite "something for nothing" mindset to a lot of questions posed on this site, and those attract scornful responses.

In real life a mentoring figure would give the student a non gentle "reality check" on many such questions.

The strict Q&A format of exchange sites already makes the interaction somewhat robotic. I think a mild dose of reality is often called for to humanize things.

Just like to drop a note on who I am and what my team does. I'm Seth, a member of the CHAOS team at SE headquarters in New York. We're lurking in the SE sites learning about the communities and helping out in raising the bar on quality posts. Much of our efforts are directed towards promoting the site and growing the community in a high quality and organic way. Personally, I have a background in psychology and have a passion for tech startups, food, progress and history.

I will post in the meta with ideas we have for promoting OnStartups and engaging new users. Feel free to send me a note any time with ideas for community events, promotions, problems or lunch. Also, I will pop in to chat for a couple hours each day.
row.Title: Who is this person with a Ψ character and what is the CHAOS team?

row.Body:
I see quite a few questions posted to OnStartups to be edited. What triggers this?

Is it poor writing, or rambling, or misspellings?

Sometimes I can tell much about the intent of the question from the typos and the original writer's style.
row.Title: What causes posts on the regular OnStartups forum to be edited?

row.Body: I sometimes correct minor spelling mistakes. When a post is really poorly worded, I may try to restructure it, or add line breaks.

I'm trying to review the 6 oustanding items at the moment in: http://answers.onstartups.com/tools/flagged

There are is one post that I would like ot say "this question shouldn't be closed", it appears as though you can only make negative statements rather than reverse something where flaggers have been a little over zealous or misunderstood the intent of the "target".
row.Title: How do I say "this is fine" using the moderator tools?

row.Body:
I pay relatively close attention to the Weekly questions RSS feed, and I've been noticing a lot of questions related to laws - after reading the FAQ, I didn't see a section that addresses the issue of legal advice.

There should be a policy on that sort of questions, because as far as I know, OnStartups isn't for legal advice - you should consult a lawyer.
row.Title: Update FAQ to address legal questions

row.Body:
You can always see what exactly is eddied in each question. The reason are mostly:

  • Bad spelling.
  • Questions with intention to market some site, e.g. mention of site that do not make the question better.
  • Editing that improves general applicability to question.

To disagree with a flag:

  1. Click on the "flag or disagree" button.

  1. Select "it needs ♦ moderator attention" > "invalid flag"

Many thanks for helping out with the flags! That is much needed in our community right now. Also, if you see a flag you do agree with, please add your own flag or vote to close. It helps us mods out in determining how to handle flags. Leaving public comments is also helpful.

Another section to check out is the close section. If you see a question with close votes that you agree with, please add your vote to close.

There are many reasons why a post may be edited. Ross and Alain mentioned the main ones - formatting, grammar, spam - but there may be other reasons. Please review our FAQ to get an idea of what is acceptable (and what is not) on this site. For example, we don't allow signatures, so someone may edit a post to remove a signature.

To add to Ross's point, you can always view the edit history of a post by clicking on the edit date of that post. That is demonstrated in our FAQ here.

I think it's perfectly acceptable to ask a legal question on this site, as long as it is related to startups. I would deem these within the scope of our site.

I do agree with you that any legal question should be followed up with a real lawyer in your jurisdiction, and I believe most folks on this site realize that.

Most startups have very limited funds, so they may use this site to get an initial feeler. Some valid reasons to ask a legal question on this site may include:

  • Doing initial research on a topic to get a better understanding of it.
  • Learn what questions to ask a lawyer on a specific topic when you meet with him/her.
  • Find other online resources that may help you in your research.
  • Get a better idea if this particular legal issue is something you should worry about now, or maybe put off for a later date.

Again, I agree, this site should never be used as a substitute for a lawyer, but I do think startup legal questions are within the scope of the site, and if used responsibly, this site can be a valid resource.

So many questions refer to their business and/or website without listing them. Are they afraid it looks like they are spamming or that others might steal their ideas? I think the quality of answers would improve if everyone had more information.

I didn't see anything in the FAQ's that discourages this.
row.Title: FAQ - Encourage listing company name/website in questions

row.Body:
Fear of looking too self-promotional, I'm sure. Also, in comments at least, for new users there's a limit to how many links you can have; it may be the same for questions.

Most users have their site listed in their profile; if their question doesn't reference their business, I check there.

Spamming.

If you write the name of your company, people will think you are trying to promote it, and will vote you down without readying the question.

If you are asking a question since you need advice regarding your company, you should state in which field the company is, and give an idea of what it does so that the answers are more relevant, but keep the name to your self.

It isn't in the FAQ, but it is how this community works.

I agree with the responses above.

Though mentioning company names would likely establish some context, the risk of being seen as too self-promotional likely outweighs the benefit.

Also, though there could indeed be a lot of contextual information by mentioning the company name/website, the odds of a community member actually taking the time to do the required background reading are pretty low. I'm already pleasantly surprised with the level of contribution the community is making.

I would suggest that when people mention "my company" in a question, they should link to their company URL. That way, it is neither obtrusive nor too self-promotional, but at the same time, interested people can click the actual link.

Stackoverflow is starting a job site. Is this site looking into offering some type of market where people could look for business partners?

Not really interested in other sites, but curious if this is something the makers of OnStarups.com are considering.

There seems to be a lot of users that ask a similar question about either learning to code or finding a tech. partner. There is an obvious need.
row.Title: OnStartups.com offering a site for finding business partners?

row.Body: I would suggest getting involved in local tech and entrepreneur groups and using your connections, but if you're looking for an online community, PartnerUp is supposed to be all about that.
I think it would be an interesting idea as well. OnStartups could add value to such a marketplace by leveraging the "karma" points from answers.onstartups.com.

Well that question is simple to answer :)

http://spreadsheets.google.com/ccc?key=t1_0CjyeF5QqMwgh6AFGtqA

yCombinators co-founder match list

It's a great place.

How to make optimum utilization of closed questions?

I am sure, this would get closed. I see that there are 1,480 closed question on answers.onstartups.com
row.Title: How to make optimum utilization of closed questions?

row.Body:
I'm not sure what you are asking here.

If you're asking about how to prevent questions from getting closed, here's my advice. The most important thing is to make sure your questions are inline with the guidelines in our FAQ. The most important sections related to this topic are:

  • What kind of questions can I ask here?
  • What kind of questions should I not ask here?
  • Why are some questions closed?

Also read How to Ask.

If you want to know what you can do once a question has been closed, see the Why are some questions closed? section of our FAQ. If a question is closed you can edit it to try to make it more inline with our guidelines. If the community is happy with the changes they can vote to reopen the question.

So I see an old question of Joel's pop back on the top of the active list, and it raises a question: should pricing questions be considered too localized?

I'm pretty sure the cost of office space has changed a lot since the question was first asked, so it's unlikely to be useful years from when it was first asked, making in localized in a time sense. And in terms of space localization, each of the variations of this question are localized to a specific metro area.

We've made them off-topic on the DIY site for this very reason. But then again, it is Joel asking the question.
row.Title: Should pricing questions be considered too localized?

row.Body:
I agree with you. I also think they should be closed as too localized, but I have been hesitant to do it. First, as a moderator it's tough for me to use my super vote to close a question with no close votes, unless it's a clear cut case. Second, it's Joel, and you'd think he'd know a thing or two about asking a question on Stack Exchange. The thing to note, however, is that those questions were asked in the very beginning of the site - during its 1.0 days, before we merged with SE. I could be wrong, but I'm almost positive that "too localized" didn't even exist as a close reason back then.

I think this is perfect timing to have this discussion because we are finally at the point where we can start our OnStartups Clean-up (more to come on that soon). I'd love to roll this into the clean-up if others agree.

A closed question has one foot in the grave.

Many closed questions will eventually be deleted; I wrote about this in

http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2009/04/the-stack-overflow-question-lifecycle/

But subsitute "entreprenur/startups community" with "programming community" as necessary...

Is there a way to search the user base by the tag's answered? For example if I would like to see the list of people who answer the "marketing" tag -- how would I do that?

Thanks!
row.Title: Search Users by Tag's Answered?

row.Body:
Okay-- I found it.

  1. I click: tags
  2. then the specific tag and
  3. then the "users"

Here is my theory.

Short summary: Startups as subject matter is quite popular. So OnStartups attracts the bad as well as the good.

tl;dr version:

OnStartups exists primarily because there is high current interest in the tech startup phenomenon, driven by publicity about social networking, "4 hour work weeks", VCs, and technology IPOs.

The startup scene today resembles the dot com bubble of 1997-2000 but much smaller and with less free cash floating around.

And, there is a high unemployment rate, and many younger technology people, especially those just graduated, may be having difficulty finding traditional employment.

The point I am making is that there is a great amount of "effervescence" of the startup scene - lots of people dabbling in it. You have people today who believe that they are attempting to create a new business who do not have the first clue about the landscape of self employment or business creation.

In a different period in history with more affluence, say 5 years ago, a startup is the last thing that many startup "founders" would have considered. They would be working in an entry level job.

So they come to OnStartups -drawn by the board's subject matter - and their questions tend to reflect an extreme "newbie" sensibility.

It's all about them and their needs, and they don't tend to be terribly appreciative of truly realistic advice that is provided.

That's my theory, anyway. I have had what I consider decent (and realistic) answers to fundamental questions blown off as "too critical" or too harsh. After a few of these I won't even participate in subjects that have a whiff of naivete'. It's not worth my time.

Hopefully the relatively few who do have meaty questions can buoy up the quality here.

Here's my input, and it matters a lot.

People who want to start businesses have questions and reading an article you found through google is so incredibly different than getting actual advice from somebody who has done it or is in the same process! So different. And it's so important that you get that.

We, as start-up entrepreneurs, are clueless until we learn about something. And, as a general rule, we enjoy learning something from people, instead of books. Even better would be hands-on, with guidance. Shit, if I could get a 1 on 1 with Seth Godin, I would do anything within my power (no joke, anything).

Want to test this theory? Remember yourself in the beginning, lost in the business book section at B&N. Weren't you thinking: "How the hell am I going to figure out what to do with all this noise?" or "Man, which book should I choose?"

The 'low quality' of questions reflects the necessity of our collective advice. The amount of repeat questions is a fantastic problem. It means we're still needed. The young entrepeneurs who ask 'stupid' questions are willing to listen to you. That's a big deal.

The big miss is that a lot of what we teach entrepreneurs, especially in traditional business school, is totally irrelevant to actually starting a business and being your own boss. Not only do you need technical knowledge, you also need to learn a lot about yourself. You need to develop personality traits like persistence, focus, and responsibility, that somebody who is just starting out simply will not have.

Celebrate these 'bad questions'. Answering them is the only thing that will move our industry forward.

I'm new to meta, sorry if this was raised earlier, couldn't find a duplicate but I'd be surprised if this was never discussed before.

What I see is lots of people asking low quality questions with 1 reputation score. I suppose the reason for allowing this is the assumption that it needs more knowledge to answer questions than to ask, so why not allow beginners to ask, rather than force them to answer questions to reach a reputation limit first.

However, I think this is a mistaken approach. Asking good questions needs a lot of knowledge, maybe even more than answering some easier ones. This knowledge can be easily collected even by browsing the web and reading about entrepreneurship. I'm definitely not an experienced entrepreneur, but could raise my reputation to 71 in 3 days by answering questions based on my readings.

So I don't see a reason why there shouldn't be at least a minimal reputation limit to reach before people can start asking questions. At least they should have the badge for reading the faq, and posting at least one answer. I would also limit the number of questions one can ask before reaching a higher reputation, as many newcomers start by flooding us with 6-8 pointless questions in a row. These limits could raise the quality of questions significantly.

What do you think?
row.Title: Why not raise the reputation limit for asking questions?

row.Body:
This is tricky because

  1. historically we do not block any user from asking a question.

  2. The types of users with much reputation tend to be those that answer questions not necessarily ask them

  3. It would radically reduce question volume. I am estimating it would cut questions per day in half, if not more. This could kill the site, as if there are no questions to answer, what is there left to do on a Q&A site?

I am certainly sympathetic to the idea that we need to maintain quality of incoming questions, but this might be a "boil the sea" solution... it's better to try to:

  1. edit new questions to improve them

  2. leave comments on new questions guiding users on how to improve their questions

  3. if necessary, downvoting and voting to close questions that cannot be saved through editing or comment guidance

This question on how to hire people effectively has been flagged for migration to OnStartups. It's quite old (March 2010) so we'll understand if you don't want it.

There's also Whats the best term to describe a measure of value of a product based on its monetary value vs. the initial & post-release costs associated with it?

Do you want both, either or neither?
row.Title: A question on Programmers has been flagged for migration here. Do you want it?

row.Body:
I see Mark already closed the question, but yes, I would say it's fine to migrate over to OnStartups. It's on-topic and well written.

For the second question, I don't know. It's kinda borderline I think. I'd rather not have it migrated over, but I wouldn't close it if it were. BTW, the answer to that question is scalable.

I think we decided that meta was ok for conference announcements... Anyways, I'm organizing the Startup Conference. It was very well received in Silicon Valley, and it's now coming to Los Angeles this November.

More info at http://thestartupconference.com.

Let me know if the OnStartups community wants to get involved in any way.
row.Title: Startup Conference is coming to LA

row.Body:
It is of my opinion that answering a question "Contact your lawyer" or "Contact your accountant" is not in fact an answer. It is at best a comment.

There are several reasons that I have come to this opinion:

  • It is within the scope of the site to ask questions of a legal or accounting nature related to start-ups.
  • It devalues the participants of the site who do have the capacity to answer the question.
  • It started with lawyers, and then became with accountants -- and could be used on any topic "Ask your programmer. . . Ask your CMO. . . Ask your. . . "
  • It "dumbs down" the site by having low quality "answers".

So what am I asking?

  1. I am asking that when you see an answer of this kind -- please flag it for attention by the moderators.
  2. I am asking that the moderators move these non-answers to the comment section.

Why do I think this would improve the site?

It leaves more "space" to attract the lawyers, accountants and others professionals who work with start-ups to answer these questions.

Note: I appreciate that often the "non-answer" is started with or ended with the phrase "Go ask your. . . " and then is pro- or pre-ceeded with a lot of content which may or may not be helpful. In these cases the migration of the "non-answer" to comment would not work. Perhaps we could have a community agreement to edit out the "throw away phrase" when it is not integral to the content of the answer.

Thank you for your consideration!
row.Title: Should we migrate non-answers to comments?

row.Body:
Real time visitor tracking

This was my answer to the question and got deleted by a moderator. But I have absolutely no clue as to why it was deleted. Shouldn't deleted answers include a note as to why they were deleted so the person who posted the answer can learn & improve future answers?
row.Title: Reason for deleted answers

row.Body:
There should be a link on your deleted answer showing you why:

Click the "see the faq" link:

http://answers.onstartups.com/faq#deletion

That particular answer was deleted because it looked just like drive-by spam.

It is an answer by a 1 rep user (at that time) that is two sentences long, and contains a link to a random site. In the 46 days that your account has been active, it is the only action you have taken (i.e. 0 question, 1 answer, 0 votes - the votes thing is understandable since you don't have enough rep to vote). So it leads one to believe that the only purpose for creating the account was to answer that one question to spam the site.

We tend to get a lot of spam on this site, and that answer fit right in with the trend we've seen in the past. There are other answers with links in that thread, but note that those users have more rep than you and have been a lot more active on the site in the past. That gives some legitimacy to their answers.

As moderators we use our best judgement, but sometimes we make mistakes.

The fact that you are asking means that you want to become a contributing member to the community, which is great! We look forward to your participation.

I hope that answers your question.

I am making a website and want to integrate a forum into the site. I really like the layout of onstartups, and also other sites like reddit where you can rate comments and posts up or down. Is there a free forum template that allows this rating system, or how would I get a system like this in my website's forum?
row.Title: What type of forum is OnStartups

row.Body: Its a biz startup knowledge sharing and interactive forum, built with a good algorithm targeted to bring factual questions and solution.
its built on stack exchange you can use their technology stack but need to go through their process of being approved

OnStartups is not a forum.

It is explicitly designed to allow answering questions, but discourage ramblings and off-topic discussions.
Should one up-vote a "meh" question that has a great answer (so the answer gets attention). Or, can an ace answer get attention without the question being upvoted?
row.Title: OK Question Great Answer

row.Body:
It's been my experience that the answer can get the attention even if the question is so so.

So, just up vote the answer. We should reward people that contribute great content and that's the best way to do it.

It really depends...in order to provide exceptional answer question needs to be that heavy or involved, or frequent use case and increase the curiosity of someone to go and read answer...again one can always categorize this as chicken egg problem.
Questions are editable. If there is a great answer, chances are the question can be fixed up to be worthy of an up vote.

The "influence of stackoverflow" is the thing that has bugged me the most. It's not just that it drives away newcomers, it drives away engaged, qualified members. In the techie world it is acceptable that people are direct, often curt. The general business world does not have this "brevity at the cost of civility" bias. Before anyone goes off about my lack of tech credentials, I have a degree in Computer Science and have spent my entire 30 year career in programming, development, and development management and I am quite capable of taking it (and dishing it out). However this is not the appropriate place for such a communication style. I have been well ranked here at onstartups but I stopped my involvement a few months ago because of this problem -- it seemed like the darkness was dominating the light. However such questions in meta give me hope.

When I click “flag”, the number of my remaining flags shows as a black number on a dark red background, which is almost unreadable on my display:

I think this should be changed to something more readable, like black on yellow or white on red.
row.Title: Some text is barely readable due to background

row.Body:
Two things really bug me about OnStartups sometimes, and I hope you don't mind if I gripe a bit...

  1. People who downvote quality answers without comment. I spent a fair amount of time on this answer. As of now, the Q has 16 views so my A has fewer views and a downvote (balancing out an upvote). I'm a patent atty so I know this is a good answer and the original poster liked it. Perhaps the downvoter found the answer confusing or misleading or something but I will never know.

  2. People who post strongly worded answers when they have no idea what they are talking about. I notice this mostly in questions that have legal aspect to them. I won't name names, but there are some very frequent posters who fall into this category.

These two things don't seem to happen nearly as often at StackOverflow. What can we do to improve behavior here?
row.Title: Preventing annoying behavior

row.Body:
1. Sorry, but learn to live with it. While we encourage users to take the time to comment on content they downvote to indicate how it may be improved, it's not required. Nobody has time to do it every time they see a bad question/answer, and some people don't like calling attention to their downvote or feeling like they are reprimanding the poster in public.

    Don't take downvotes personally -- they're about the content, not about the person posting it. See if you can figure out what could have been better -- if not, move on with life until someone posts an explanatory comment. Uncommented downvotes are more common on SO than on our other sites -- there are simply so many people voting that chances are higher someone will comment.

  2. Downvote and provide your own, better answer. SO does get a ridiculous amount of garbage, but the community there is much more active in downvoting the garbage to oblivion than Onstartups is. Content quality means producing quality content, but it also means constantly cleaning house.

    • If you see good content poorly written, edit it.
    • If you see content that just needs a tweak or two, edit or comment.
    • If you see a bad answer, downvote it. If you feel it can be saved and have time to do so, leave a comment.
    • If you see a bad question, edit/downvote as you would with an answer.

    • If you see a question that doesn't fit the format, either edit it to usefulness or vote to close.

      Note that closing a question is not permanent -- it's perfectly reasonable to leave a comment about what should be fixed, then vote to close the question. If the OP fixes it (for example, with more specific info to make the question answerable) either the close votes will expire, or the already-closed question can receive votes to re-open.

I'd love to see more active housekeeping being done by the OnStartups community.

I agree with HedgeMage -

I am an active down voter. And I generally do not give reasons. No reasons need to be given. If I have to give a reason every time I downvote I will just not participate.

Do you require people to give reasons to upvote? No? Why not?

Don't take votes personally.

The site is struggling to survive - and all the poor content is one of the reasons it is not working well.

I have spent too much time on this site. The quality of the questions is abysmal. Many of the answers are poor. It's a struggling site.

Per this question we should raise a new meta question if we see the "Portal not found" error, and I'm seeing it now. Here's my DNS record for the site, if that helps:

$ dig answers.onstartups.com

; <<>> DiG 9.7.0-P1 <<>> answers.onstartups.com
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 4899
;; flags: qr rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 1, AUTHORITY: 0, ADDITIONAL: 0

;; QUESTION SECTION:
;answers.onstartups.com.        IN  A

;; ANSWER SECTION:
answers.onstartups.com. 248 IN  A   74.205.116.34

Edit: I've narrowed this down to a bad DNS record out there. Switching to another DNS server, I get the expected:

$ dig answers.onstartups.com

; <<>> DiG 9.7.0-P1 <<>> answers.onstartups.com
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 30476
;; flags: qr rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 2, AUTHORITY: 3, ADDITIONAL: 0

;; QUESTION SECTION:
;answers.onstartups.com.        IN  A

;; ANSWER SECTION:
answers.onstartups.com. 3596    IN  CNAME   onstartups.stackexchange.com.
onstartups.stackexchange.com. 3596 IN   A   64.34.119.12

;; AUTHORITY SECTION:
stackexchange.com.  3212    IN  NS  ns3.serverfault.com.
stackexchange.com.  3212    IN  NS  ns1.serverfault.com.
stackexchange.com.  3212    IN  NS  ns2.serverfault.com.

;; Query time: 17 msec
;; SERVER: 68.105.28.13#53(68.105.28.13)
;; WHEN: Thu Nov 17 09:55:49 2011
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 161
row.Title: Portal not found error is back

row.Body:
I have no particular axe to grind with downvoters - I don't think I have been downvoted often here.

In my opinion, reasoning and explanation are worth infinitely more than a trivial downvote. To be clear, I think downvotes are trivial. I will only downvote an answer or question without comment if I actually think either is self evidently stupid. I normally prefer to show more respect for the thought process by actively commenting.

Why I use the word trivial: a downvote offers no information nor added clarity.

And I've found that there is a popularity contest aspect on OnStartups: some feelgood answers that amount to "this is unfair becuz XXXX" receive great upvotes while deeper and non trivial responses that don't have an emotional note will receive few if any votes.

I have also seen some really poor or outright advice, from a legal viewpoint, upvoted substantially. It is actually scary to think that there are some who are using this site for legal Q&A.

In the final analysis, votes appear to be a "collectible currency", a bragging right for a user badge, that often don't indicate the real quality of the post or answer. Usually they do, but there are enough exceptions to this that I really want to read commentary on why something is good or bad. That's worth more to me than four digit personal merit scores and bronze/silver badges.

A take on the topic of poorly constructed or silly questions:

Sometimes I answer a question in a way where I try to "elevate" the question to reasonable quality. In other words, I reframe a somewhat limited question so that I am answering a more universal or deeper concern that others would probably have about the subject.

Many questions here suffer from ignorant n00bness - as I complained before, the posters who want free work by calling it "crowdsourcing" and want the community to advise them how to do this legally and attractively. And questions in a similar spirit.

Some questions are just lame and reflect bad assumptions. But many poorly phrased questions have a core of a reasonable concern. That's what I am talking about.
It looks like the bad DNS record worked it way out of the original DNS server that I was using, and my "Portal not found" error is gone now.

I understand that the website software that OnStartup (and StackOverflow) uses can be downloaded. Can someone point me to where I can obtain it?

Thanks, Marcus
row.Title: Where can I get the software OnStartups uses?

row.Body: The software that this site is based on is StackExchange by Joel Spoksly and Jeff Atwood. It's not free nor downloadable, unless if you go for the self-hosted plan.

This site (and many others) runs on the StackExchange software platform that was originally developed to power StackOverflow by Jeff Atwood and Joel Spoelsky.

There is no free version of the software and they host the site. This is part of their pricing structure, and allows them to control bandwidth/pageviews as well as maintaining codebase versions and pushing updates.

It's a fantastic piece of software, but it's also a hefty investment, so make sure you're willing to put a lot of work into growing your site before you go for it.
There is a free, open-source Stack Exchange clone called OSQA (Open Source Q&A). It's powered by Python and works quite well. Our company uses it for customer support.

I think it is because there is no "right" answer. In contrast to Stack Overflow where you often have at least one "right" answer, or at least a clear distinction between good and bad answers. One person can do something and succeed in their start-up, and someone else can do the same exact thing and not succeed. There are many complex and uncontrollable factors involved.

Also, maybe it's because most people are voting with knowledge that they have gained through reading books or blogs or posts. To have true first-hand start-up success you would have to build a reasonably profitable company, and perhaps most of the would-be voters are not there yet (including myself). Without first-hand experience, you don't really know what works.

Hi guys I am unable to connect to answers.onstartups, it just says "portal not found"

I read other questions and it said this was resolved but apparently not?

how does this happen? last night it was working fine then suddenly this morning I cannot access it!
row.Title: Portal not found error

row.Body:
Yes, definitely!

We made arrangements to sponsor Zuly Gonzalez for the Business of Software Conference. It was a small gesture of 'thanks' for all the hard work she's done with this site.

The conference is over now, and she did a great job representing and getting the word out about this site. Zuly published her first blog post about the conference, and is planning on posting a few more.

Business of Software 2011

We even got some blog coverage from the Business of Software website:

Business of Software 2011 Business of Software Blog

Zuly really went above an beyond and did a great job representing this site at the conference. Thanks, Zuly!

I have already something similar (without the scorecard) on some of my questions elsewhere on SE. e.g. I was planning some major server changes, asked a question, got answers, made the changes and later posted a comment back on my own questions to let readers know what I did and what happened.

Why not try a special Follow-up box for questions? You get five (or pick another number) points for every follow up response, and your profile shows a follow-up rate (like the acceptance rate).

It might not be as direct as emailing people but it could help start a culture of closing the loop on questions and finding out what people did with the answers. Once you start collecting the responses you could generate more metrics/badges/scorecards

SO has moved towards the view, over the past 6 months certainly, that poll style questions (what is the best x that does y) aren't appropriate. Rather than a brief flurry of activity, this threads turn into endless numbers of "this one" type answers.

In addition, virtually all of the questions just end up as poor cousins to the equivalent answers on SO:

Any opinions on the latest wireframing tool contenders to Balsamiq?

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/408202/what-collaborative-wireframing-ui-mockup-tools-are-out-there
row.Title: Should we declare poll type questions as off-topic?

row.Body:
We follow SO's guidelines and consider poll style questions to be off-topic. Our FAQ indirectly states that:

To prevent your question from being flagged and possibly removed, avoid asking subjective questions where … every answer is equally valid: “What’s your favorite __?”

Also, one of our close reasons is "not constructive". The definition for "not constructive" specifically calls out polling:

not constructive

This question is not a good fit to our Q&A format. We expect answers to generally involve facts, references, or specific expertise; this question will likely solicit opinion, debate, arguments, polling, or extended discussion.

I have one very strong objection to the implementation of "question editing" of Exchange sites.

Here it is. The editor's profile is shown alongside the original author of the question's. And the editor's name is shown in the list of questions as the last participant in the thread.

Essentially, it creates confusion (even for someone experienced with the site) because it elevates the editor to parity with the author - as though the editor co-wrote the question in cooperation with the original author.

I know that is not the case. It still creates a cognitive "thud" of slight confusion whenever I see an edited question. I have trouble keeping the original questioner in mind.

I see it as a bit of cognitive clutter. It makes, for instance, Zuly Gonzalez (just as an example) look like she "co-wrote" several dozen questions (at least) on this site.

The identity of the editor should be subordinated visually compared to how it is displayed now, IMO.

I consider startups to be tech or software related businesses. The OnStartups site has a few questions about other types of businesses (ie. coffee shop, sushi shop). I checked the FAQ, and it just says:

Answers.onstartups.com is a site for entrepreneurs starting and running new businesses.

What is the intent for this site? If it is for tech/software businesses, can the FAQ be updated.

It would help me to know so that I don't erroneously downvote/vote to close off topic questions.
row.Title: Is OnStartups for tech/software businesses only?

row.Body:
My definition of a startup would include any new or starting business...but we're subjective to opinion here. so I pulled in some of the experts:

  • Wikipedia: Startup Companies
  • Free Dictionary: startup
  • Merriam Webster: startup

Wikipedia says it can come in any form...but most commonly a technology oriented company. Free dictionary just specifies it as a company, as does Merriam Webster.

So I guess the official answer, from a technical point of view, would be any company.

I would like to know your thoughts about two different websites that have same task.

I would say for say Quora has more focused people, and when I compare the topics and the user numbers between here and quora I would say Quora is leading. However, I really like that site which has some better functionality over quora.

What do you think quora and onstartups have disadvantages/advanteges on each other?
row.Title: Comparing with Onstartups vs Quora in terms of effectiveness?

row.Body:
The confusion is natural for these reasons:

  • Techies tend to use Q&A forums extensively and are more comfortable with online discussion than those from other areas of work and life - so technology startups are overrepresented on sites like this. (Otherwise, you'd probably have questions here about marketing of lawn care businesses or food trucks, et al.)

  • The word "startup" has been conflated through media attention to imply technology-specific new businesses

I could see a question about a non technology business being asked here and I would not vote it down for that reason - that would just be wrong. But, such a question would probably get very little traction here, unless it were couched in social media or technology terms.

I believe that effectively, this site is almost exclusively technology specific, even though that's not the official charter.

Joel brings up a great point, though. I'd say that if the site is almost useless to the non-tech startup, perhaps the FAQ should be changed to reflect its predominant use.

There seem to be a lot of questions like:

What is my software worth?

There are two of us, how much should each person get?

What is my idea worth?

etc.

All these questions seem to me to be questions that do not contribute in a meaningful way to this site. It's sort of like asking "What is an apple worth?"; the short answer is something is worth whatever you can sell it for, and clearly some people are better salespersons than others.

Are questions like these considered on-topic for this forum or should they be flagged?

To me, a question like "What is the general range of prices that .... goes for?" would be appropriate. Of course the range might be very large!
row.Title: The "what is X worth" questions seem inappropriate

row.Body:
Splitting equity sounds like a valid topic to me (but I may be biased, it's a personal interest of mine).

What my idea is worth is probably not on-topic.

Been lurking around here recently and I reached a question marked great-developers. The tag has no wiki. What is the purpose of tag?

The earliest use of this tag is at: To be a great software company, you hire the best developers... how?

Anyone care to enlighten me?
row.Title: What is the purpose of the great-developers tag?

row.Body:
Good question. I don't know what the purpose of that tag is. I never even noticed its existence.

We should probably get rid of that tag. I don't think it has much meaning on this site. I think a generic "developers" tag is probably good enough.
I have a quite a few flags (almost 10) tied up in spam & offensive for a while now. Some of those posts have already been edited for the spam links. Can someone please review & release the flags?
row.Title: Flag reviews backlog

row.Body:
Thanks for helping out. Action has been taken on those spam flags. But from what I saw, the flags weren't sitting in the queue for long - it looks like between 4 to 9 hours.

Ideally the community should be self-moderating, but that is something this site has been struggling with, so most actions end up requiring moderator intervention. I usually remove spam as soon as I see it, but I'm not on the site 24/7, so there will be gaps in coverage.

Keep in mind that there are only a handful of moderators, and a limited number of active users over 2K. 2K users have access to a subset of the moderation tools, but are still limited in what they can do. For example, they would not be able to clear any of your flags. They could, however, view your spam flags and add their own flag to the post in question to bring more attention to it.

I've seen several posts that were off-topic that could've been migrated to another StackExchange board. Those questions dealt not with business operations but using specific tools (software suites). Since I have enough rep to vote on closing and the only option for off-topic migration is Meta, I had to raise moderator flags with the explanation where to move the question.

Thus, can we get some other migration destinations, such as at least SuperUser, Webmasters, and WebApps?
row.Title: Additional migration options for off-topic questions

row.Body:
This is because we are still in beta. By design, beta sites are not allowed migration paths, other than the site's meta. Per Jeff:

Migration paths won't be defined until sites are out of public beta.

Once the site graduates we will have 5 migration paths available to us. With the exception that moderators can migrate questions to any site on the network.

We are finally ready to get the OnStartups clean-up effort going. I apologize it took us this long to get to this point. I’m excited because I think it will be a great exercise for us, and we will be giving away some prizes!

For those that may not know, a while back we started a discussion about cleaning up the site to remove low quality content, and we put together a list of items we thought would be indicators of low quality posts.

Contest Rules

We will break up the contest into phases. (Thank you Jesper for the suggestion.) Each phase will involve performing a different task. I’ll post a new thread for each phase once the previous phase has been completed.

At the end of the contest four winners will be randomly chosen from those that have actively participated in the cleanup effort.

Contest Prizes

One winner will be selected to receive a $100 Amazon gift certificate. This is the person we think did the most good for the community. (Thank you Dharmesh for sponsoring this prize.)

The other three winners will each get to choose two books from the following list:

  • The Web Startup Success Guide

  • Founders at Work

  • The E-Myth Revisited

  • Good to Great

  • Start Small, Stay Small

Contest Phase 1

The first phase will be to go through questions tagged ask-onstartups and review to close off-topic questions. See here for details.

Contest Phase 2

The second phase will be to go through the unanswered questions to reduce the number of them. See here for details.

Contest Phase 3

The third phase will be to continue working on phase 2, as well as to go through an additional list of questions. See here for details.

Contest Phase 4

The fourth phase involves retagging those questions that are currently untagged. See here for details.

Contest Phase 5

The fifth phase will be to go through questions tagged ideas to close off-topic questions. See here for details.

Long-term Goals

The goal of this contest is twofold:

  1. Improve the quality of the site

  2. Increase community involvement on meta and with site moderation

Hopefully after the contest is over we will be at a better place to attract more experts to the site, and finally graduate!
row.Title: Clean-up contest is getting underway

row.Body:
The first phase of our clean-up contest is to go through questions tagged ask-onstartups and review to close off-topic questions.

Background

Feedback on my idea/startup/website/name questions have been deemed off-topic for this site. New questions related to these topics are closed, but we still have some old questions lingering on the site that should be closed. We should close them to avoid confusion among our new users that may take these open questions as an indicaton that they are on-topic.

Most of these feedback questions have been tagged with either ask-onstartups or review.

Procedure

We need to go through these tags and vote to close the off-topic questions. To make it easier and minimize the need to revisit valid questions, this is how it will work:

I posted an answer to this thread that contains links to the questions tagged ask-onstartups and review. Pick a question from the list, and perform one of the following actions.

  • If the question has already been closed, delete the link from the list. (We will deal with these in a later phase.)
  • If it is a valid on-topic question, delete the link from the list.
  • If the question is off-topic, vote to close and leave the link in the list for others to find.

This first phase will last 1 week, starting today and ending on January 22. On January 23 we will move on to phase 2.

At the end of phase 1 all the links should have been deleted from the answer.

Bonus

If you happen to find a feedback on my idea/startup/website/name question that is not in our list, add a link to it under the Misc category. This is not necessary, but feel free to do it if you’d like.

Please don’t add random off-topic questions to this list. We will deal with those in later phases.

Requirements

You need a minimum of 500 rep to have the ability to vote to close questions. For those that have less than 500 rep you can still participate by leaving comments if you feel a question should be closed as off-topic.
row.Title: Clean-up contest - Phase 1

row.Body: Phase 1 completed.

I'd like to request the SE devs destroy the following tags:

  1. ask-onstartups - per discussion here.
  2. great-developers - per discussion here.

I'm also requesting that ask-onstartups be blacklisted.

There will be a few untagged questions, but that's fine because we will deal with them during the clean-up contest.
row.Title: Destroying superfluous tags

row.Body:
Depending on whether the answers bring anything to the table, I'm inclined to mostly kill them.

This trivial question triggered me to come look on meta for policy after I'd answered it. I really should check meta more, but it's usually full of tumbleweed :)

It's a terrible question, and my answer is found on the first page of google with the obvious search term. Beyond that there's no way to really salvage it either in expanding the question, or my answer. So the whole exchange is probably line noise.

This question on reviews is a fairly poor question, but brings two interesting answers - I'm more inclined to leave that as it does bring something (despite the 4 close votes). Even if it's expanded to become the canonical exchange on why onstartups isn't a venue for reviews, or why they;re inappropriate here. But it does, to me, seem orders of magnitude better than the endless one or two liners we get with a few 1 line answers, like:
