Oh dear, what's this a link bait thread? The question is so vague that it's just show and tell for answers - and brings nothing to the site. If it had a little more focus, perhaps.

I don't have all the answers, but I am inclined to think we get much harsher with quality of questions. It seems to work on programmers - sometimes they're way too harsh (imo), but the overall quality of the site is good. Here is endlessly struggling with junk, and I think that's why especially the good people give up after a while. It gets too tedious after a while to open yet another daft question that google can answer on the first search.

Is it the internet marketing effect? ie Too many people coming here in hope of finding the magic answer to be an internet "sensation" without the work.

Or is it simply that business and startups are just harder to pin down than programming and grammar questions?

IMHO, junk is junk and it hurts the community. If we let low quality questions stay open/visible/answered we're creating a sort of a broken window that lets others think that we welcome such behavior in the community.

When a new user asks a trivial question they show that they're a poor business manager because they can't solve questions on their and don't have reliable advisors (granted, advisors aren't always available). It also shows that the person doesn't respect our time - others might be happy to get easy reputation points but telling people to find a local lawyer or accountant to deal with their local issues or pointing them to equity calculators for umpteenth time isn't productive.

It's also astonishing to see experienced users answer such questions knowing that there are plenty similar questions and that they could vote to close the new instance.

It's interesting to see how many great ideas and discussions happen around this community.

I've seen a lot of discussions around startup products that are mainly websites and software.

My question is: - are they just new software products that are intended to address an unsolved need or - are they a completely new way (with a new and disruptive business model) to address an issue that no-one has ever thought before?
row.Title: What type of product is your startup creating?

row.Body:
I think that most discussions here are about software startups because building software is way easier and cheaper than building, say, aircrafts or even lawn mowers.

I strongly believe that in the field of software there is very little left to invent, but there are tons of things that could be done better than now. If you look closely, the vast majority of software products have a large range of competitors. You "just" have to make your way through them and gain some market share.

Entering an existing market is very hard, but entering an empty or totally new market is even harder as people will not even know there is a product that does this new cool thing. In an existing market they just search for the variant that best suits their needs.

We're building something that we consider pretty innovative, especially for the long-term view we have, but that surely has alternatives. What company can say they have no competitors at all?

My startup addresses an old need (building and maintaining a website), but tries to improve on the process. It is targeted at small businesses without in house tech staff that don't want to outsource their web development. There is a lot of competition in the area, but my product has some unique features that I haven't seen anywhere else. So I guess the answer is solving an old problem in a new way.

Thanks to the vibrant ecosystem that is the Internet, new issues that need addressing are appearing as quickly as old issues disappear. Every well-designed product is disruptive. Nobody can afford to sit still.

For instance, a project I'm working on builds on top of web sites where you can post jobs for free. We're trying to make these free job sites work better for hiring managers. A few years ago, these sites didn't even exist, so this problem didn't exist. As (say) the Semantic Web gains market share, this problem will go away and hundreds of other problems will appear in its place.

Even giant companies like Google can't afford to sit still for long. Google has stayed ahead only by attracting and motivating phenomenal talent and making good strategic acquisitions.

We don't exactly control the DNS for this site as it's not our parent domain, e.g. we don't own

http://onstartups.com

If this keeps happening, let us know, but hopefully it's resolved by now.

edit: also asked here on main http://meta.stackoverflow.com/questions/119909/portal-not-found-for-onstartups-stackexchange but I think this question is best answered here, since it is truly site-specific.
What happened to flag weight? Mine dropped from ~550 to 174 (now called "helpful flags").
row.Title: What happened to flag weight?

row.Body:
They are acceptable, provided the area in question is large enough to be of interest to a substantial number of people.

e.g. "What are the tax rates for hog processing plants in Guymon, Oklahoma, USA?" would not be great.
Per your request, these tags are now burninated, and the blacklist entry was created.

Flag weight is gone.

Instead of flag weight, the system now shows the number of helpful flags vs the number of declined flags. Your profile should look something like this:

helpful flags X (Y)

Where X is the number of helpful flags and Y is the number of declined flags.

If you don't have any declined flags, then you will just see X.

If you go to your your flagging history page and add up all the flags that were deemed helpful, it should add up to X (in your case 174 as of your post). Note, this is not a public number - it is only visible to you and the mods.

The second stage of our clean-up contest is to go through the unanswered questions.

Background

Questions are considered unanswered if there is no accepted answer or if there are no upvoted answers. Our goal is to reduce the number of unanswered questions by taking several actions.

Currently there are a total of 384 unanswered questions, with 198 of those having no answers. Some of these unanswered questions will be off-topic or low quality questions that should be closed. Others will be good questions that have been missed somehow. And others will be good questions that require an expertise we’re currently lacking on the site.

Procedure

You do not have to act on all 384 unanswered questions; only what you feel comfortable with.

Go through the list of unanswered questions at your leisure, and perform any of the following actions:

  • Answer the questions you can answer.
  • Upvote good answers. Please don’t go crazy upvoting stuff you normally wouldn’t. Stick to only upvoting good posts.
  • If it’s a good question, and you know someone outside of the community that has the expertise to answer the question, share it. For example, Twitter, LinkedIn, etc.
  • Edit those questions that can be improved.
  • If a question is unclear, leave a comment asking for clarification.
  • If the question is off-topic or otherwise not a good fit for the site, vote to close and/or downvote. And leave a comment if you feel inclined to do so.
  • Vote to delete some questions.*

*Questions that have been around for a while with no answers are candidates for deletion, even if it’s not a terrible question. And obviously really bad threads should also be deleted.

For those questions you feel should be closed or deleted, leave a link to them in the answer below under the appropriate category. The reason for doing so is that we have 384 unanswered questions, and the odds of everyone going through all 384 questions is close to zero. By leaving the links below it makes it easier for people to find these questions.

Doing it this way also opens up the contest to more people. Note that you need 4000 rep to have the ability to vote to delete. If you have less than 4000 rep and spot a question that you think should be deleted, leave a note in the answer below next to the question’s link.

Final Points

We are not looking to end phase 2 with 0 unanswered questions; we simply want to reduce the number of unanswered questions. The most important aspect is to answer good questions that have been missed, and close and delete the really bad questions.

This phase will last 1 week, starting today and ending on January 29. On January 30 we will move on to phase 3.

Let me know if you have any questions.
row.Title: Clean-up contest - Phase 2

row.Body:
Close Candidates

  • Recognizing When to Use Previously Mentioned Advice (too broad and off topic)
  • Are there any "decision based" survey tools out there?
  • Name some innovative Social Media Campaigns that garner a lot of attention
  • Start up primary focus in the initial phase (4 votes left)
  • Any online performance review sites?
  • How to sell through ClickBank via a GoDaddy Quick Shopping Cart website

Delete Candidates

Zuly: Thanks for taking the initiative. It's a noble cause (much like a public park-cleaning effort).

To make it even more enticing and interesting, I'll throw in a $100 Amazon gift certificate as the "moderator's favorite award". The one person we think, in our opinion, did the most good for the community.

Since we don't control the registration or the name server for onstartups.com we don't have direct control over the quality of DNS (which is causing this issue).

This was solved by the owner of the domain by moving to another DNS provider, but then there was an issue with that provider and the owner moved back.

After contacting the owner he is going to move the domain to another provider again which hopefully will resolve this issue for good.

We're trying to clean up low-quality questions here. Yet, some people who can vote to close (let alone flag questions for moderation) answer them. Why is this happening? Do they not understand what off-topic is? Or are they chasing reputation points?

Some examples of bad questions that have been around for a few days:

Difference between H1 vs H2 tags
EB-2 Visa Amendment: How to apply for the visa for my new startup to be based out of the valley
What shall I do at a business lunch?
row.Title: Why do so many users with closing vote privileges entertain off-topic and not constructive questions?

row.Body:
Update: For those that are not aware, a $100 Amazon gift certificate has been added to the prizes.

The third phase of our clean-up contest is to continue working on cleaning up the unanswered questions (phase 2), as well as go through this set of questions.

Unanswered Questions

During phase 2 we went through the unanswered questions to reduce the number of them. We are extending this portion one more week. You guys have done a good job with this, but it's a fairly time consuming exercise, so we are giving it one more week.

We started phase 2 with 384 unanswered questions. We are now at 286. Let's see if we can improve on this even more.

Steven's Questions

Additionally, go through this user's questions to identify and close any low quality questions. This user has asked some good questions, but he also has a history of asking low quality questions.

If you spot a question that should be closed, add a link to it in the answer below, as well as vote to close it if you have enough reputation.

Schedule

This phase will last 1 week, starting today and ending on February 5. On February 6 we will move on to the next phase.
row.Title: Clean-up contest - Phase 3

row.Body:
Close Candidates

What big lessons did you learn from your business practice?

From an investor's perspective, what is the true significance of an investment?

Are there other novel classifieds websites besides craigslist?

Why do recruitment websites charge companies(recruiters)? Is it feasible if a recruitment website provides free service for both recruiters and job-seekers?

What is your motivation to start a business, especially a novel business

Is there a good TV series or movie that can enlighten me how to do business or investment?

What do you think of Crowdsourcing? What is its market size?

How much does TV marketing cost? Which type of advertising is the cheapest?

Steven's: Mostly not constructive questions or opinion seeking. (Ross)

"What does your website do?" My answer is

What's the best book about investment you have ever read?

Do you feel anxious when you don't receive any inquiry from prospective clients for consecutive days?

What industry/field are going to change the world during next decade?

How to estimate how many questions have been asked over the web each day?

What can I do with my website start-up? I need insightful suggestions?

Will my relocation greatly affect my business? My business fields are language interpretation, real estate market, travel market, internationanl trade market

• Who owns the copy of an answer I post on here?
  • Do I?
  • Can I copy it and use it in a different format?
  • If I use the answer as a base -- and then edit and polish it -- can it be marketed as a standalone resource?
  • What reference back to the source here at OnStartups.com is recommended, requested or required?
  • What if someone other than me copies what I wrote, slightly changes it, and publishes it without reference in their own name?

Thank you.
row.Title: Who owns the copy?

row.Body:
The user content on all SE sites are licensed under Creative Commons (see the footer on every page). Anyone is free to republish the content as long as attribution is given to the original post.

This blog post explains it in more detail.

What if someone other than me copies what I wrote, slightly changes it, and publishes it without reference in their own name?

This is definitely not allowed.

This portion of the clean-up contest involves tagging those questions that are currently untagged.

There are currently 31 untagged questions. Please go through the list and retag them with appropriate tags.

There are a few closed questions in the list. Go ahead and retag those as well.

This phase will last 1 week, starting today and ending on February 12.
row.Title: Clean-up contest - Phase 4

row.Body:
Remove anonymity in return for accountability.

Getting a down-vote from someone with 141 rep is different to getting a down-vote from someone with 1410 rep!

A different way of doing without removing anonymity is to show just the rep of the people up-voting and down-voting your comments, answers and questions in a graph.

Red for down-vote, green for up-vote.

This graph could be on a separate page, or as a psuedo-popup in javascript on mouse rollover.
row.Title: Show who up-voted and down-voted

row.Body:
The short answer: no.

The long answer: We have a long history of keeping voting anonymous. You're not the first to ask for this feature, and we've seen it requested in various forms over the years.

Voting is anonymous because it shouldn't matter who downvoted you. When one receives downvotes, it's a signal from the community that one's post is insufficient: it needs more research, it's too broad and needs to be refined, it's poor quality and needs to be edited, something. All these measures together make better users, overall.

Furthermore, who's to say that the 1410 rep user is better than the 141 rep user? Maybe the 141 rep user flags, downvotes, and participates frequently in meta -- while the 1410 user writes a few good answers but isn't really engaged in the workings of the community. I'm not saying that's gospel truth (it's not) but it's also not unheard of.

Basically: no, we're not going to de-anonymize voting. It's an integral part of our engine.

Can we have chat casts with startups, VCs and the like?

For example we pick a certain strategy in business or a certain element in investment and we pick the brain of the entrepreneur for an hour (or a play by play of how that entrepreneur would go about it)?

Similar to Ask HN or MBA Mondays by AVC?

Would for example, the Trello Team (in/excluding Joel) be up for volunteering?

It could be a

  • Good reason to use chat
  • A way to get startups who want extra coverage on their business in the loop

What do you think? Critique is welcomed.
row.Title: Can we have a chat cast around an Entrepreneur or a Startup Team?

row.Body:
There are various tags website, internet and web. What's the correct usage for each tag?

  • Is the website tag for anything dealing with a website?
  • Is the internet tag anything dealing with data communications and the architecture?
  • Is the web tag dealing with wait, I actually not sure this tag deals with anything, it looks meta to me.
row.Title: Website, Internet, Web Tags; Do they all relate and are they needed?

row.Body: The more well known (if not the proper) way to creative processes using graphics and tools is Graphic Design not graphics-design
row.Title: Change graphics-design to graphic-design

row.Body: It's a good idea in theory. In practice, it may turn out very bad because of real-time communication and a large number of participants. Currently, there's no "crowd control" in chat that could assist in facilitating a meaningful discussion: people can and will interrupt each other. Also, given the quality of questions we have been seeing here, the chat may turn out to be very low-value with participants asking easily-researchable questions.

I have seen a strange behaviour here (for the the short time I have been here). There are many questions that contain non-trivial spelling and grammatical errors. It's actually impossible to read the question without realizing it. Yet, there are 4-5 answers on these questions.

Why are users not editing these questions?

Recent Example

  • How works the "invite friends and earn cash" in a website?
row.Title: Why are users not editing low quality questions yet answering?

row.Body:
I've been going through setting up the favorite tag list and came across tags:

incorporating and incorporation.

Both in my mind are the same so the can become synonyms but I think that there are more that might be the same for example dba

I don't know about making it into a contest with prizes format but wouldn't a cleanup effort be advantageous?

Additional Tags:

strategy to strategic-planning

contract to contracts

partnership to partnerships
row.Title: Is Tag Cleanup necessary?

row.Body:
I would partly agree with dnbrv on this. But it is not a problem just on this stack although the problem is more here. There are people who actually do answer a lot of questions to be able to get reputation quickly and advance to the highest level of privileges possible and then rest upon the laurels similar to the MUDs.

However there are people who look past the grammatical and even semantic errors and understand what the question is actually about and answer them without editing the question for the rest of the population to be able to read.

IMHO.

I would expect an answer like that from members that don't have rep high enough to put it into the comments. The privilege of Commenting Everywhere already implies some level of experience and participation so I don't expect to see someone capable of leaving a comment "punting" the question back in this manner.

I would say that the better action would be a downvote with explanation.

I agree. I made graphics-design a synonym of graphic-design.

Thanks for pointing that out. We need to cleanup our tags. Let us know if you find any other tags that need fixing.

Yes, a tag cleanup effort would most definitely be advantageous.

I initially thought about making that part of the current cleanup effort, but decided against it because I thought it might be too much for one contest. But you're right, we could use a tag cleanup effort.

Our tags are not very organized at the moment. I think the main reason is that we started as a 1.0 site, and not going through the normal Area 51 process resulted in us not putting too much thought into some of these things. I've slowly been trying to organize the tags as I find them, but there's still a lot that need to be cleaned up. Here's the current list of tag synonyms.

If you find any other tags that you feel should be deleted, explained further, or are synonyms of each other, please post it on meta, as you've done here. Alternatively,

Users with more than 1250 reputation and a total answer score of 5 or more on the tag, can suggest tag synonyms. Users with a total answer score (total upvotes minus total downvotes) of 5 or more on the tag, can vote for tag synonyms. Suggestions will be automatically approved when they reach a score of 4, and automatically deleted when they reach a score of -2.

After we finish the current cleanup contest we'll think about how we can implement something similar to clean up the tags. Feel free to post any ideas you have on how we can implement this.

As for your tag synonym suggestion, I agree. I think incorporating and incorporation are essentially the same thing. Even if they're intended to have different meanings, I think the two are so similar that it would just cause confusion to keep both of them. I'll give it a few days to see if anyone disagrees. At the end of the week I'll create a synonym pair for these.

I think the dba tag is sufficiently different from the other two that we can keep it. Doing Business As is normally used by sole-proprietors which are not incorporated.

Thanks for pitching in to help the site :-)

Phase 5 of our cleanup contest is to go through questions tagged ideas to close off-topic questions. This will be very similar to phase 1.

Background

Feedback on my idea/startup/website/name questions have been deemed off-topic for this site. New questions related to these topics are closed, but we still have some old questions lingering on the site that should be closed. We should close them to avoid confusion among our new users that may take these open questions as an indicaton that they are on-topic.

Most of these feedback questions were tagged with ask-onstartups, review, or ideas. In phase 1 we looked at the ask-onstartups and review tags. In phase 5 we will finish this off by looking at questions tagged ideas.

Procedure

We need to go through these tags and vote to close the off-topic questions. To make it easier and minimize the need to revisit valid questions, this is how it will work:

I posted an answer to this thread that contains links to the questions tagged with ideas. Pick a question from the list, and perform one of the following actions.

  • If the question has already been closed or deleted, delete the link from the list.
  • If it is a valid on-topic question, delete the link from the list.
  • If the question is off-topic, vote to close and leave the link in the list for others to find.

This phase will last 1 week, starting today and ending on February 26. At the end of this phase all the links should have been deleted from the answer.

Requirements

You need a minimum of 500 rep to have the ability to vote to close questions. For those that have less than 500 rep, you can still participate by leaving comments if you feel a question should be closed as off-topic, and by removing the already closed and deleted threads from the list in the answer below. Removing the closed/deleted threads from the list is actually quite helpful because it helps the higher rep users concentrate on the open questions.
row.Title: Clean-up contest - Phase 5

This question Using brand logos for polls on my website?

has generated several comments concerning the appropriateness of the question for this site.

I went ahead and answered the question, but perhaps meta is a better place to discuss the best way to handle the question.

While I felt the question was extremely naive, and something which virtually any experienced website operator in the US would already know, none the less I took it to be a sincere question. If I had to guess, it is perhaps from a non-native English speaker in a foreign country. Further since he has a reputation of one, presumably this is his first question.

Clearly he could have done a much better job of asking the question, particularly by breaking it down into multiple questions, each of which involved a single topic calling for a simple answer. He really had 3 different questions rolled into 1 which is not good.

What is the best way to handle a question like this?
row.Title: Best way to handle question - http://answers.onstartups.com/questions/36388/using-brand-logos-for-polls-on-my-website

row.Body: The best way to handle such questions is to reply in a brief comment suggesting the OP to seek professional help locally because assuming location & experience of the asker is the road to misinformation.
Where are the exceptional entrepreneurs that were going to participate in this board?
row.Title: Where are the exceptional entrepreneurs?

row.Body: Probably working on their businesses. They can't be here all the time and most of them chime in regularly. Plus there are plenty of people here that are not on that list but are exceptional nonetheless.
Exceptional entrepreneurs need exceptional problems to solve. Let us see if we can ask those challenging perplexing questions which can engage them. I am sure they are around watching us. :).

I have a biased opinion, but it seems that the quality of the discussion here has been great.

We shouldn't necessarily be seeking exceptional entrepreneurs (which I think we have in this community now), but exceptional answers and dialog.

Let's keep asking great questions and I promise I'll do my best to draw in a rich set of responses.

Not exactly a constructive question in my mind. I would vote your question down, but I just joined and don't have the reputation level required yet to do so. To @Dharmesh's response, the answers and dialog are looking pretty good so far and ultimately for this site to be successful the list will have to go well beyond the names of contributors you are referring to anyway.

I would suggest you to look optimistically at the fact that so many questions are already getting answered by anyone with a constructive thought no matter who they are. In fact, isn't that one of the beautiful things about entrepreneurship is that the new guy without much experience can come to a market and (hopefully!) successfully challenge the incumbent "experts" with their product, service, or ideas!?

And, for the record, while I'm not likely someone you've ever heard of, I'm a high tech entrepreneur that has done two businesses, has one mid-ranged seven figure exit under my belt so far, AND I am also looking to try and contribute to this community.
They are slowly making their way here.

IMHO there are plenty of excellent questions and excellent responses. I've been in the start up world for a long time (from IPO at one to closing the doors at another to other situations in between) and am finding a lot of good information here.
wow.. so many people offended with my question..
Here you go; great entreprenuers

I made a product, now how can I find customers?

After realizing that there are many, many questions that boil down to this question, I thought I'd make a canonical answer. The only issue is, I'm wondering if this defeats the purpose of this site? (i.e. is the purpose so that everyone can ask, "I made a website for salons. How do I get customers?" and "I made a website for dentists. How do I get customers?" and we give individual answers?)

Looking for feedback on whether this is a worthwhile canonical type question.
row.Title: Is this a valid "resolved as duplicate?" type question?

row.Body: One thing about your answer is that it contains mostly links rather than putting the lists in the answer. Links are transitory and can disappear, much better to include the content in the answer.

As an additional way of enforcing the intent of the site, is it acceptable to down-vote answers to off-topic questions regardless of the answer comments?

It seems to me that we need to take more clear action to have any hope of making a useful site.

the quality still isn't there and if people continue to spend time answering useless questions or off-topic questions then we will not make progress.

the person asking the question is only half the problem - the other significant part is the people who seem to answer anything, regardless of content.

I have been haphazardly downvoting some answer sets like this. I suppose it might be anti-social or something of that nature, but I don't know what else to do when I see people spending time answering really really bad questions.
row.Title: Is it acceptable to down-vote answers to questions that are clearly off-topic?

row.Body:
For example - one moderator was sponsored to go to BoS this past year.

Can we get a few more sponsorships in the coming years assuming that the recipients sufficiently review, provide feedback, discuss, etc?
row.Title: Can this site provide more sponsorships for events/products?

row.Body:
If I post a request for feedback on a startup idea on my blog, can I also post it as a question here or is that rude? If it's not rude, should I post a link or repost the whole question?

(Related: http://answers.onstartups.com/questions/2999/is-there-a-place-i-can-go-to-float-my-ideas-and-get-feedback)
row.Title: Etiquette: cross-posting requests for feedback for a startup idea?

row.Body:
I think it is okay if you're genuine with your request. I personally would try to help if it's within my knowledge.

I find it more annoying if people are posting for the sake of posting without any real purposes on their side.

If you can sum your question in few paragraph, it's better to post the whole question here.

Hope that helps.

I agree with Hendro that it would be helpful if you could just phrase your question in a summary form here, and if people are interested they will go to your blog to get more details, as the concern would be to follow comments, you have to keep going here and to your blog, and that would get really annoying, really fast.

I think it would be easier to just keep the comments here, as then you are adding to the community, rather than using the site to drive more traffic to your blog.

I agree that we need to start taking stronger action if we want this site to survive.

I think most of the off-topic questions are asked by low rep users that don't have a good understanding of the site. Ideally, they should read the FAQ before asking their first question, but we can't enforce that. It's our job to kindly guide them into becoming productive members of the site. We should do this by leaving them comments explaining the site guidelines, not by answering their off-topic/low quality questions.

I think there is a much smaller subset of folks who are aware of the site guidelines, yet ask off-topic questions anyways in hopes of getting some good answers before the question is closed.

There's also a small group of people that will answer any question, regardless of question quality, simply to earn as much reputation as possible (i.e. Rep Whores). Related question: Why do so many users with closing vote privileges entertain off-topic and not constructive questions?

Out of the three groups I mentioned, the last two are the most dangerous to the site. There's really not a whole lot we can do about the first group, other than help them understand how the site works. And in most cases these seem to be one off.

To answer your question, I don't see anything wrong with downvoting answers to off-topic questions, even if it is a good answer. I've thought about doing the same thing myself several times before (though I've never done it). I think it can help fight the last two groups I mentioned.

Some guidelines I would use:

  • Only do it in cases of obvious off-topic and low quality junk. There are different opinions on what is on-topic. Maybe the person answering thinks the question is valid. I would leave answers to boderline questions alone. Maybe take the approach of not voting at all, but I wouldn't downvote these answers.
  • Only do it for high rep users. I've noticed most answers to obvious off-topic questions come from low to mid rep users. These users may still be learning our site guidelines. There's no sense in possibly alienating them when they are only trying to be helpful. For low rep users, I would say leaving them a comment (or leaving a comment on the question itself) is the better approach. If after repeated comments, they continue answering junk, then downvoting is appropriate. High rep users, on the other hand, should really know better. I think downvoting in these cases is fine. The question is, where do we draw the line between low rep and high rep? I think anyone under 200 rep definitely gets a pass, and anyone over 1000 rep should definitely know better.
  • Only do it for new answers. During the early days of this site we allowed certain types of questions that we no longer allow. We've been working on removing these old off-topic questions from the site, but I'm sure there are some we haven't gotten to yet. If a question was answered in 2009 or 2010, when it was on-topic, I don't think it's fair to downvote someone who answered the question in good faith. In this case, it's better to vote to close the question, and flag it, if appropriate.
  • Leave a comment, if you feel inclined to do so. Voting is anonymous, so leaving a comment is not required. That said, leaving comments can be useful in helping people understand site rules. Especially in cases where the answer isn't bad and may cause some confusion.

SE has stated that they are willing to sponsor community members to community related events, so your request is totally doable. However, they're not going to randomly pick a community user to attend a yet-to-be-named event. SE wants us, as a community, to decide which events are important, and which community members should represent us at those events.

If there's a particular event you think would be beneficial for OnStartups community members to attend, start a discussion on meta. If there is sufficient interest from the community (via votes and comments), SE will likely sponsor it.

As a moderator it's my job to bridge the gap between the community and the SE staff. If you can get sufficient interest from the community for a particular sponsorship proposal, I'll be happy to ping the SE staff to get it going.

I think it's worth a shot to do something like this. This community isn't so large to where there would be a noise problem. First, this is a beta site, not StackOverflow, and second, I think that would be a very innovative way to drive interest in the site.

I would personally be interested in attending one of those events as I feel like I'm somewhat of an entrepreneur and would love to learn from real ones :)

I might even have some ideas. We have several products that we're working on and some very talented entrepreneurial-type people who might be interested in using this as an opportunity to promote out products.

Another possibility is to focus on a group of small developers like the author of the question on How to Promote a Translation Android App.

I see people downvoted me without mentioning why, or without even reading what the article I linked to said. I have used the methods of those articles myself and they also have been proved by the author (Derek Halpern), hence he was interviewed here http://mixergy.com/derek-halpern-social-triggers-interview/

And of course as you guys know I am talking about the topic here How can I increase the perceived price value of the products?

I don't care about the fact that I got downvoted. I was wondering if it is possible to require commenting if one downvotes someone? I feel like it is fair to let someone know why they got downvoted.
row.Title: Downvote is a trend now or what?

row.Body: There's a message suggesting a comment being shown when someone downvotes. In your situation, the downvotes were likely as a result of the low quality of the answer: just giving a link and providing an outlandish claim (increase value by 71%) isn't the best way of answering. You should at least summarize the advice and, even better, explain how you've used it & succeeded yourself.
It seems that deleting some old questions (and all answers) that are now considered off-topic decreases the reputation points on people that give the answers above the question. Am I right?
row.Title: Do you lose reputation on answers when the question is deleted?

row.Body:
Yes, you are correct. When a post is deleted any reputation you may have accrued on that post is reversed. See this thread. It may not seem fair, but that's the way the Stack Exchange engine works.

Note that this applies to both upvotes and downvotes. So if at the time a post is deleted it has downvotes, those downvotes will be removed from the OP's reputation, and the OP will actually gain rep.

This change in rep due to deleted posts happens right away, however, up until now, your displayed rep would not be updated to reflect this. As a result, displayed reputation tended to be "inflated" (i.e. it did not reflect your "true" reputation, according to SE's rules). Therefore, anytime SE performed a global reputation recalc most users would see a sharp drop in their reputation.

SE just performed a network wide reputation recalculation, which is why a lot of us saw a drop in our reputation. I lost about 100 rep. The last time SE performed a global recalc my rep dropped by several hundred.

Moving forward reputation changes due to deleted posts will be reflected in your displayed reputation, so we should no longer see these huge drops in rep. Instead we'll see smaller sized changes more frequently. These new changes are explained here.

Update: SE changed the way reputation is calculated on deleted posts. The new rules are:

If you’ve contributed something worthwhile to the site, you should keep the reputation for that even if it eventually gets deleted. “Worthwhile” here is defined as,

  • A score of 3 or greater
  • Visible on the site for at least 60 days

Are you unsure about how the close vote system works?

Ninefingers posted on the Cryptography Meta site a great guide on how the close voting system works. It turned out so nice that it has subsequently been reused by other SE sites.

I'm posting it here for reference.

If you find something that's missing, or still need further clarification on something, feel free to ask.
row.Title: A guide to moderation - voting to close a question

row.Body:
Rationale: why do we close questions?

There are really two ways to do moderation. If you've been on any of the .moderated newsgroups you'll be well aware that to get a post on there, it needs to undergo a review process first and be accepted. The aim is to keep problem discussions from arising.

SE is slightly different - it works the other way. Anyone can ask a question on SE and closing a question is the equivalent of putting that question back into review/improve mode. It's a feedback mechanism designed to react to problem cases only, so the usual business of asking and answering good questions can just... happen.

Why do we close a question?

The philosophy of SE is that each site handles questions on problems you face or things you are trying to understand. The don't ask section of the FAQ gives you a good overview of things that don't work - to summarise:

  • Some questions invite arguments or extended debate that suck up time when members could be helping other people.
  • Some questions are too broad, too narrow or have other content problems.
  • Some questions belong elsewhere.

These have been worked out over time and with a lot of experience from Stack Overflow and are, broadly speaking true. Sometimes, exceptions are made - it is always a case-by-case thing.

Is closing like deletion?

No. Actually, deletion is a different concept on SE. Closed questions are put "into improve mode" if you like, and are still visible for anyone to improve. That's the idea. Deleted questions are different - they have a red background and are invisible to all but high reputation users. So deletion is different and solves a slightly different problem.

What are the requirements for closing a question?

If you have 500 reputation on the site currently, or 3000 reputation on a graduated site, you can vote to close any question for the reasons above. More on that in a moment.

If you do not have this level of reputation, you will find that under the flag menu, you have an option "this question does not belong here". That will raise a flag for users who can vote to close.

Why can anyone vote to close/reopen?

Firstly, anyone can vote to close or reopen (or flag as such) because it is your site. This is really important - it's about expressing what you feel works and doesn't.

How are moderators different?

Moderator close votes complete the required vote count immediately, no matter how many people have voted. This applies for both close/reopen votes.

Initially, as the reputation requirement rules out many users, you will see moderators doing most of the closing to guide the site and look after the content. As you gain in reputation, you get to join in.

Ok, so how does it work?

Ok, the important piece. Voting to close works like this:

  • Underneath the question, there will be a close link. When you click on this, you will be presented with a list of options from which you can pick a close reason most appropriate to the situation.

  • If other people have voted, you will see blue numbers against the reason they chose.

  • The exact duplicate page takes you to a page that allows you to specify a question to close as an exact duplicate against.
  • The "off topic" page will present you with two options - one to migrate here, to meta, and one just off topic. On SE betas, only moderators can send questions elsewhere, so feel free to cast a vote here and flag if you have a target in mind.
  • The other options are straight out closes.
  • Once you pick your option and click "close", your vote is registered. You cannot retract it at this stage, but nobody else, including moderators, will know it was you who voted.
  • If five people agree, the question will be closed. You've seen the effect of these before.
  • Your name, and the name of other closers, will appear on the bottom of the question.

How does vote to re-open work?

A closed question has a "reopen" link underneath it. If you click this, a dialog box will ask you if you are sure - click yes and your vote will be registered to re-open the question.

Below, you can see an example of the re-open link with two votes registered for re-opening (out of five).

What happens if I make a mistake?

Don't worry! Unless five people agree, or a moderator agrees, the question won't be closed.

I've seen a closed question and I disagree. What can I do?

Well, one option is to use your re-open vote! You can also always raise a discussion here on meta to seek clarification on why a question is closed and hopefully either a resolution will be reached, or you will get an explanation for the closure.

My name appears on the bottom - isn't this going to cause problems with other users?

Actually, surprisingly few closed questions generate any response at all.

However, if you experience difficulties as a result of closing a question, you can and should contact a moderator via the flag mechanism (which is anonymous). We can then take any necessary action.

How do I find questions I might need to close? What about re-opens?

Actually there are two tools for this.

  • Review. Here, there are a number of options for seeing things that might need say editing. One of these is a tab for all questions with close votes. You are then free to look at the question and decide if you agree.
  • Tools. Commonly referred to as the "10k tools", this page let's you see even more information - certain anonymous flags, re-open votes, delete votes etc. The important one for this is the re-open page. Here, you can see questions that might have been closed incorrectly.

The OnStartups clean-up contest has ended.

Who were the winners?
row.Title: Who are the winners of the clean-up contest?

row.Body:
We want to thank everyone that participated. You've made a big difference in improving the quality of the site, and your commitment to the OnStartups community is greatly appreciated. I hope we can continue to work together to improve the quality of our site.

The winners of the contest are as follows:

The winner of the $100 Amazon gift certificate is

The book winners are

Please join me in congratulating your fellow community members.

I agree that "Ask your..." posts are not answers. At the very best they are comments, and even the value of such statements as comments is debatable, as it is understood that the OP will follow-up with a lawyer, accountant, etc.

If the post is nothing more than a statement telling the OP to consult a lawyer, accountant, etc

Your proposal to convert these non-answers to comments is a fine approach. Alternatively, I think that deleting them altogether is equally as valid of an option, as these statements don't normally add much value to the discussion.

As you suggested, flagging these non-answers for moderator attention is the correct action. Additionally, it would be very helpful if the person flagging also leaves a comment stating that they do not believe the post is an answer to the question. Adding a link in the comment to the Why are some posts removed? section of our FAQ, and even this question, should be sufficient.

If the post contains a "throw away phrase"

I appreciate that often the "non-answer" is started with or ended with the phrase "Go ask your. . . " and then is pro- or pre-ceeded with a lot of content which may or may not be helpful. In these cases the migration of the "non-answer" to comment would not work. Perhaps we could have a community agreement to edit out the "throw away phrase" when it is not integral to the content of the answer.

If you see a "throw away phrase" you think needs to be edited out of an answer, feel free to do it. There is no need to flag a moderator for an edit. The site is designed to put trust in the actions taken by the higher rep members.

However, I think it's fine to make a note that you are not a lawyer or an accountant when answering a legal or accounting question. It's a courtesy to the OP to remind him that your advice could be wrong, and that he should follow-up with a qualified professional. I don't see a reason to remove these statements as long as there is some substance in the rest of the answer.

In the case where an actual lawyer (or accountant) answers a question, they may be required to state that their answer does not constitute an attorney-client relationship - CYA. I would not edit these statements out of their answers.

On a slightly related note, link-only posts are also considered non-answers. This is stated in our FAQ for reference. Also see this.

As part of organizing the site, Karlson has suggested we make the following tag synonyms:

incorporating --> incorporation

contracts --> contract

competitors --> competition

legal-issues, law --> legal

What do you all think? I agree with Karlson's suggestions, but I would like to hear what the community thinks before making the changes.

Please chime in with your thoughts.

In a related question, phwd has asked for some clarification on the website, internet and web tags. Please take a look at that question as well.
row.Title: Do you agree with these tag synonym suggestions?

row.Body:
I think you have nailed the first 2 tags.

The last tag would probably be just a generic tag for all things related to web participation such as participation in Social Networks such as Facebook, or Twitter, Distribution of files and actually having a website.

It is possible that web might actually be redundant in favor of more specific tags, but the questions in this category will have to be looked at carefully.

I agree with all but the competitors -> competition tags. Those two words can have much different meanings.

As in, my competitors are copying my software vs should I enter a market with lots of competition.

Another thought- We have a lot of non-native English speakers here. Anything we do needs to keep this part of our audience in mind. Multiple tags that are very similar will confuse many (not all) non-native English speakers, and then the tags become meaningless because they were used incorrectly. So my approach would be the simpler the better. I see a big difference between competitors and competition, but I'm betting a large part of our audience does not.

The best I can figure Reputation-based governance is actually a buzzword in itself.

Speaking of there is a paper published by the same author wrt the subject

I know that I may have created a monster that @ZulyGonzalez has taken up(Thank you), but I think this one deserves a discussion of its own.

Going through some question I've found a couple tagged ein.

This has got me thinking. There are identifiers for businesses in every country around the world. UK has "Tax Identification Number", Canada Has "Business Number", etc, etc, etc. I could be wrong on the terms but the idea is the same.

And though I have not seen any questions regarding same from UK, Canada, or other countries (may be I just wasn't looking hard enough) they boil down to whether separate tax ID is needed, necessary, or how to obtain one.

So with that in mind would it be more advantageous to have one all encompassing corporate-tax-id or should these be kept separate?

P.S. This one probably even in the US might have some of the larger number of aliases:

ein -> tin, fein, federal-tax-id
row.Title: Since we are on the subject of Tag Synonyms: EIN

row.Body:
Given the discussions regarding tags and various synonyms that need to be created now and some tags removed: Would it be worthwhile upping the level required for the privilege of creating tags?

Right now it's sitting at level 150 and that is fairly easy to get if you already have 200 on any other SE site.
row.Title: Should we increase the rep required to create tags?

row.Body:
Update 3/14/2012: I was doing some research on this topic in order to properly word this request on meta.stackoverflow.com (MSO). In doing so, I realized that I was acting based on incorrect assumptions. It turns out that it only takes 300 rep to create tags on graduated SE sites. The only exceptions that I found were Stack Overflow (requires 1500 rep) and MSO (requires 500 rep). (I thought it was 1500 for all graduated sites.)

Based on this, my original idea of requesting that the rep required to create tags be increased on all beta sites isn't going to fly (I was going to propose 500 rep). The privileges on beta sites need to be earned at lower reputation levels than on graduated sites, for obvious reasons.

So, the best we can hope for is that SE will agree to make this change just for our site. And even then, the best we're likely to get is that they will match the current level of graduated sites - 300 rep.

It is going to be almost impossible to convince SE that it makes sense to make this change for us. Plus, I don't think it is worth the effort for an increase of only 150 rep. However, I am willing to make the case if the community believes this is of benefit.

If you believe this is a worthwhile exercise, upvote Karlson's question. Sharing your thoughts, both in favor and against this proposal, in answers and/or comments would also be very helpful. If there is a strong desire for this change from the community I will contact SE.

Original Answer:

I completely agree with you.

I think 150 is way too low. However, there is nothing we can do about that. The 150 rep needed to create tags is a network-wide rule applied by Stack Exchange to all beta sites. Only SE can change this, and if they do change it, it will likely be a network-wide change.

This is something that would need to be brought up on meta.stackoverflow.com to get any attention. I'll bring it up to the SE team to get an initial feeler, and we'll see where it takes us.

The problem isn't in the rep needed to create tags but in the reputation needed to create tag synonyms and activity levels of the users who have enough reputation. Currently, it's 1250 but many of the 79 people of that level haven't been to the site in months. In addition, there's the requirement of having 5 points in a tag to suggest a synonym. Though people with 2000+ rep have access to moderator tools, which override all those requirements. Yet again, many are inactive in the community.

As for tag creation, 150 is high enough for a "beta" site without a large group of regulars because it requires 15 upvotes for newbies and 5 upvotes for 200+ transfers. If we were to be made a "grown-up" section, people would lose many privileges, such as editing and voting to close (they require 2k & 3k instead of 1k & 500 respectively).

Currently, there are just 810 of 9836 users who have the privilege of creating new tags. However, many of tags have been created over the 2 years the site has been around so the only way to fix the problem is doing these clean-up contests.

To my way of thinking the internet is far broader than website. So for a startup an "internet marketing strategy" might include having a website but it could also include social media like Facebook, Twitter etc.

SO I think we need at least two tags. I don't like web and website as the only two tags, too similar and confusing. It would be better to use website and internet.

I agree that there are a lot of questions related to "the number assigned to a business by a taxing authority". This is much more specific than general tax questions, and I think deserves a tag of it's own.

What I don't know is what the tag should be. EIN is specific to the USA and I don't believe that even most Americans know the term, much less people in foreign countries. EIN is short for Employer Identification Number which suggests employees which may confuse people with no employees. To make matters more confusing in the US a EIN is only one kind of possible Taxpayer Identification Numbers (TIN).

Is there a general tag that is not specific to the USA that would be understood by people from all countries that we could use?

I haven't thought through this in detail, but I dont' see why we would downvote the answers. Close the questions if they are off-topic. Why would we penalize users who made an effort to answer? Reputation whores aren't that hurtful, compared to properly closing bad questions.

If I write a good answer to a question that is unclear, and I get penalized, I wouldn't be happy, that's for sure.

At the moment we have four tags related to license:

  • license
  • licensing
  • software-licensing
  • licence

How do you suggest we better organize these tags?
row.Title: How should we organize the 'license' tags?

row.Body:
I see three types of licenses relevant to our site: business licenses (e.g. county permits; not certifications), software licenses and license fees (i.e. royalties).

Based on that, I suggest we maintain three tags on the site:

  • software-license: Questions related to software license choices for startups. Some examples are:
    • Help me with software licensing models?
    • How do I price my expensive software and charge $100,000 in a presentable way?
    • Creating non-profit startup from open-source software project
    • How do I decide on licensing terms for my popular app?

  • business-permit: Questions related to permits required by your jurisdiction to legally run your business. I don't anticipate this tag will get used much, if at all, since most questions in this category will likely fall under "too localized", and end up getting closed. I went with "business-permit" instead of "business-license", because I don't want the tag to get confused with business or professional certifications (e.g. CISSP). Some examples are:

    • Would you need an online gambling license that uses virtual money that can be exchanged to products/services?
    • Do you need a license to operate a bus/minibus in California? (should probably be closed as "too localized")
    • What permits and insurances do I need to open a taxi company? (should probably be closed as "too localized")
    • looking to start a CPA practice (should probably be closed as "too localized")
    • Starting travel business in Massachusetts? (should probably be closed as "too localized")

  • royalties: Questions related to earning royalties from a product. It can be an intangible product (e.g. a brand, patent, etc) or a physical product. Some not so great examples are:

    • Computing Valuation of Custom Software
    • Can anyone share experiences in licensing content?

Now, what to do with the four tags we currently have?

I suggest we do the following:

  1. Make software-licensing a synonym of software-license. This is really just a personal preference. We can just as easily keep software-licensing, but I think software-license is a better choice.
  2. Make licence and licensing synonyms of license. This is just an intermediate step to reduce the duplicate tags, and make step three less painful.
  3. Retag the questions tagged license with our new, more descriptive tags. Questions tagged license can fall into any of the three categories I described above, so I don't think we should make license a synonym of any of the more descriptive tags. We'll need to manually go through all the questions and retag them with the appropriate tag (i.e. software-license, business-permit, or royalties). At the end of this we shouldn't have any questions tagged license.

People may still recreate the tag license, so we'll need to keep an eye on that.

Your solution(s) sound great. The biggest problem will be policing the recreation of the same wrong "license" tags.

Maybe some type of routine maintenance needs to be established to look for specific tags that need to be removed or renamed if they keep popping up.

What should be our policy regarding very specific market research questions?

I think general questions on how to conduct market research are fine, and on-topic. However, I have a hard time justifying specific market research questions for a particular startup.

Some examples:

  • How to estimate the value of a person going from being obese to non-obese?

  • How many women purchase an item online every month by age group?

  • How do I find the number of internet users who post comments? Or post videos expressing a point of view?

  • How many users use Google, Yahoo, MSN and Outlook Calendars?

  • Researching my market size?

I would consider these questions to be off-topic. At best, I see them as "too localized". Do you agree? Disagree? I'd like to get community consensus on how we should handle these questions.
row.Title: Should we allow market research questions?

row.Body:
First let me say that while one of the questions you list is mine, that's not a big deal to me, though after reading your questions, I thought I'd share my take on the concept of being too local.

Questions that are too local based on my experience are based on the estimated number of people the question is likely to help. By help, that might mean directly, indirectly, or the viewer simply enjoyed the question and related answers. While I've never seen firm numbers, I'd guess given the long-tail approach of SE take too local would mean the question only helps the person asking the question. Normally, questions that are too local are also almost impossible to answer, or could easily be rephrase to ask the question in a way that covers the first question, but opens the question up.

After reviewing the questions you linked to, I thought they were both interesting and I would have a hard time believing they only helped the person asking the question.

That said, it's very possible I've misunderstood the concept of being too local, but thought I'd attempt to post a reply, since you went to the effort to ask about the topic of market research questions.

UPDATE: Thought more about your question/comment -- and have more feedback. First, just to be clear, in my opinion any user that upvotes a question is saying the question was of value to them. The questions you linked to in all but the case of one question had at least 2+ upvotes; which means that including the person asking the question that at least 3 users found the question of value. To me, three of more users saying the question is of value means the question is not too local. If the questions are off=topic is another matter, but unrelated to if a question is too local in my opinion.

I think they have a place as long as they aren't too localized. Sometimes you hit the wall in research because you just don't know of the correct terms. So even if answers will have outdated info, they still are valuable because of the terms they will mention.

In this case, a "too localized" would be a question asking for statistics on the number of people who use Google Calendar to plan their meals for the week.

Right now I vote to close market research questions (that are not about how to conduct market research). I do this because the current policy is that they are off-topic.

If we do change the policy that is fine.

I don't think it is worthwhile to allow them.

Generally speaking there is such a wide variety of possible market research and so few users of this site that the usefulness for the poster will be marginal. It will likely lead to to discussions and likely will lead to more people posting yet more questions for requests of market research.

I think we can agree that a single forum like this is NOT the best place to do unrestricted market research - we should be encouraging people to get out and talk to customers or potential customers - not pretend that this site is suitable for data for deciding whether to pursue a product or business. Given that, market research on startups might be considered ON-TOPIC - or at least have a meta-site of its own. Perhaps it is for this site or a new area 51?

I am open to arguments to keep them - as they seem to be popular subjects here.

I looked at the list of questions/links Zuly posted (again) and only the last one seems to be useful to me.

All the others are just "do my homework for me" or similar nature of - "I am in this domain space but know so little about it that I have no idea about the market size" - or the market size is so ridiculous as to be useless.

The last one is phrased better and useful.

Perhaps this indicates that it is a case-by-case basis as to allow these types of questions.

Again - some of the questions are so open and have nothing to do with startups - it is just an attempt to offload work to others.

In your question you state:

I think general questions on how to conduct market research are fine, and on-topic.

and I would like to understand why you feel this way?

To my way of thinking, a question should be startup appropriate and not at a level for a large established company.

There is already a site, stats.stackexchange.com where someone can ask about the vast majority of statistical and practical aspects of survey design and interpretation. Among the specific topics they cover are:

designing experiments, collecting data & statistical analysis, applied or theoretical

Why would we want a market research question here that overlaps with (or is perhaps more appropriately on) stats.stackexchange?

expanded answer:

I undoubtedly did not make clear the first time which aspects of marketing research I was referring to.

Personally I would consider a marketing research question that is in some way unique to a startup to be on topic.

I would not consider a general marketing research question applicable to any organization to be on topic.

In this respect I believe my opinion is counter to Zuly's to the extent that she considers all "general" marketing research questions to be appropriate.

I would agree with blunders comment:

To me covers the real issue, how do you know if a question is for a startup (new type of business), a new business (the execution of existing known type of business by a new entity), or general business (the enhancement of an existing business). My understanding is the site is just for startups.

Perhaps it would be appropriate to consider an analogy to an accounting question:

I would consider on topic:

I am starting a small business, what low cost software is available to do accounting on my PC?

I am starting a business and buying a new PC, do I need to capitalize it of can I expense it?

and off topic (although) great accounting questions:

Which accounting software is best for handling inter-company eliminations and consolidation? (If you are managing a conglomerate you are not a startup)

How do I insure my accounting conforms to Sarbanes-Oxley? (SOX applies to public companies, once you've gone public you are no longer a startup)

What is the difference between single-entry and double entry bookkeeping? (nothing unique to a startup)

Marketing research in particular: The particular issue with marketing research is that to be of value it needs to be done properly and does involve a bunch of math and statistics. consider a question as simple as:

I am trying to decide whether I should sell Coke or Pepsi in my new store, how do I do market research to determine what my customers prefer?

or

I'm building a website for my new on-line business to sell widgets, how do I conduct market research to select colors and fonts for the website to optimize sales?

These type of questions on how to conduct research, while clearly startup related, do not permit simple yes/no answers. In fact a complete answer to either of these questions would probably run to several pages and include terms like "double-blind study", "confidence intervals", "sample size" etc.

Viewed from the point of view of which marketing research questions permit simple answers, they pretty much boil down to the type referenced by Zuly in her question. While the referenced question are far from examples of great questions, they definitely could be edited and improved. Personaly I like questions like:

Where can I get population data for US counties? (census bureau for free)

I want to sell coffee beans online, is there any data on which countries buy the most coffee per-capita?

In the US who spends more on books, men or women?

but that's just my opinion.

It's unclear to me why my question was closed as being "too local", since in part because the roll-over for an upvote states:

"[the question] was of use and was clear"

and two users upvoted the question; meaning three people including myself believed the question to be of use. How many visitors must a question be of use to be not labeled "too local" - and how is this determined?

For ease of reference, the default description of "too local" is:

This question is unlikely to ever help any future visitors; it is only relevant to a small geographic area, a specific moment in time, or an extraordinarily narrow situation that is not generally applicable to the worldwide audience of the internet.

UPDATE:

Since the reason for the question being closed has been changed from "too local" to "off-topic", I'm updating the question. As Zuly states, she's asked a related question:

Should we allow market research questions?

Though that question I believe assumes it's understood why "market research" questions are being closed, and her question is asking if they should now be allowed. That said, as an asker of such a question it is unclear why market research questions are being closed. At first I misunderstood her question as an attempt to address why the question was closed, though it's now clear that her question is about if the question should be allowed. I'm not attempting to be argumentative, tricky, or for that matter lazy -- I just do not follow beyond "that's just the way it is" why my question was closed.

Meaning per the OnStartups FAQs, my question is on a topic that allowed (that being marketing), and is practical, answerable questions based on actual problems faced by me. While I agree the question might not clearly be phrased as one for a startup, it is for a startup, and don't believe that there's any information in the question that would exclude the question from applying to a startup.

Why was my question closed?
row.Title: Why was my question closed?

row.Body: That question should have been closed as off-topic. I closed it as "too localized" to prevent the system from giving you an automatic -1, which happens when questions are closed as off-topic. Note, the only reason I did this was because I felt that question could also slightly fall under the "too localized" category. I want to be clear that I was not trying to circumvent the system. I was only trying to be nice. However, I see now that doing so has only caused confusion. I apologize for that. I have fixed it. The question is now closed as off-topic.

One of the most important aspects of being a Stack Exchange site is quality. Yes, there are lots of metrics that one can use to "measure" a site, but we don't really care about those as much as we care about a site providing expert answers to good questions. To that end, we're encouraging self-evaluations on our sites!

Meta sites often see people discussing specific questions that have been closed to determine whether or not they can (or should) be reopened, but it's rare that anyone looks at questions that are open and answered. Are they better than what the Internet has to offer? Are we making the Internet better?

Here's a rough guide:

  • Below, you'll find ten questions randomly selected from your site.
  • For each question, search the internet for the question as if you were the asker!
  • If our answer is good (complete, well-written, answers the question, found in search results, etc) then vote it up!
  • If our answer is bad (incomplete, poorly-written, off-topic, unfindable, etc) then vote it down!

Comment with anything you feel is worth noting, or to explain your voting choice. We have a rough guide to better/par/worse right here. If your result is par, make a choice to vote up or down.

Remember that our goal is to make the internet a better place. If you find yourself unable to decide how to vote, ask yourself: does this question and/or answer make the internet better? How you answer that question should determine your vote.

Talk to your fellow community members about how your site is doing and what you all can improve. Above all else, remember: this is a team effort!
row.Title: Evaluate Your Site -- A Check for Quality

row.Body:
Hiring a Sales Intern

Vote and optionally leave a comment according to the guide above.

Do I need to incorporate in the US to run events?

Vote and optionally leave a comment according to the guide above.

Higher pricing for Apple in-app purchases

Vote and optionally leave a comment according to the guide above.

How does the "invite friends and earn cash" functionality work?

Vote and optionally leave a comment according to the guide above.

“I need to scale up”. What does that mean?

Vote and optionally leave a comment according to the guide above.

Undisclosed equity: advantages and disadvantages

Vote and optionally leave a comment according to the guide above.

How long should you keep your idea a secret?

Vote and optionally leave a comment according to the guide above.

Negative effects of using a photo as logo

Vote and optionally leave a comment according to the guide above.

Can I manage(make money off ) a start up in the USA from another country?

Vote and optionally leave a comment according to the guide above.

My webmaster created our website and is now charging me a licensing fee

Vote and optionally leave a comment according to the guide above.

This question in particular How to evaluate a lawyer? - asks how to evaluate a lawyer. While I have seen a lot of questions relating to start-ups and the law they've been (from what I've seen) relating to starting up a business and what legal advice to seek on things like hiring employees, forming partnerships and all of that kind of stuff.

However, the above aforementioned question I've been thinking about in my head the last couple of days: is it a real question and does it belong here?

Forgo the fact my answer was down-voted, this isn't about down-votes. The question appears to ask a question that can't be answered in a way that it would be beneficial or relate to start-ups. Am I being pedantic about this, or are my concerns about the validity of this question valid?

The reason I bring it up is because I feel like the last few months the quality of this site has started to deteriorate. A lot of the questions I've seen are heavily subjective and only result in answers that are based on opinion and not fact.
row.Title: Is A Question About Evaluating A Professional Within The FAQ?

row.Body:
In reviewing the OnStartups FAQs, I'm wondering if the following text about "wide open questions" being types of questions to avoid asking is just a rephrasing of "not constructive" questions:

Wide open questions. Don't write a sentence and expect to get a page back. A question like "How can I sell more of my product" deserves an encyclopedia article. Try to scale back to something more specific.

If so, would it not make more sense given that "not constructive" is a reason to close a question to use a rephrasing of the "not constructive" with a link to the StackExchange blog explaining questions of this type?

Here's the text that's given when a question is closed as "not constructive":

Not Constructive. Question will likely solicit opinion, debate, arguments, polling, or extended discussion are not a good fit for our Q&A format. We expect answers to generally involve facts, references, or specific expertise.

For example:

Not Constructive questions. We expect answers to generally involve facts, references, or specific expertise, these questions will likely solicit opinion, debate, arguments, polling, or extended discussion. For more information on "not constructive" questions please read the "Good Subjective, Bad Subjective" StackExchange blog entry on the subject. Examples of "not constructive" questions might include: "How can I sell more of my product", "insert example", etc.
row.Title: Are "wide open questions" the same as "not constructive" questions?

row.Body:
Yes and no. Really depends on how the questions is asked, and oddly, on the answers the question gets. The question you linked to, "How to evaluate a lawyer?" should be closed in my opinion as being "Not Constructive", which if it was would give the following explanation:

Question will likely solicit opinion, debate, arguments, polling, or extended discussion are not a good fit for our Q&A format. We expect answers to generally involve facts, references, or specific expertise.

I've posted a related question, please take a look:

Are “wide open questions” the same as “non constructive” questions?

My thought is that the question as written is overly broad and poorly written. As far as this question here on meta (evaluating a professional), I would think it would be a good question if it were specific and startup related.

So for example: "How do I evaluate a tax accountant?" would be too broad.

while "There are lots of good tax accountants, how can I make sure that the one I hire knows about the particular aspects of a software startup that is a C corp with foreign investors?" would be a good question.

Lately whenever I've voted to close a question, I leave a comment on the question itself informing the askee that I've voted to close the question and then tell them to read the FAQ (in the nicest way possible). Should moderation transparency be something that we strive for on On Startups? I know once the question itself is closed, it does say who voted to close the question - is leaving a comment overkill or something that we should all be doing?

I do it out of respect mostly, to make the site a little more human and also to let people know why I've voted to close the question which to me feels a little more personal and effective than a message showing up along the lines of; User, User2, User3 and 4 others voted to close this question as off-topic"
row.Title: Close Vote Transparency

row.Body:
Question 37470 was closed rather than migrated. I was one of the people voting that it is off-topic. I do believe it is a good question, and that it should be migrated to http://programmers.stackexchange.com

What is the procedure to get something migrated?
row.Title: How to get this question migrated rather than closed?

row.Body:
ChrisF posted a comment few hours ago on the above question that it was cross posted to programmers.SE; and then closed as being a bad question, which I agree with on many levels.

As to the general question -- "What is the procedure to get something migrated?" -- just flag the question, and note the site your suggesting it be moved to in the note to the mod, and why the question would be a better fit for that site.

Believe it would be a hard to take a position that being friendly and informative would not benefit the site, though there are issues that while not directly stated come up when discussing comments on closes.

Discussion. The comments of a question should be about answering the question, not discussion of why the question might be closed (or was closed). I'd suggest if you feel the user is new, and might not understand the reason for the close by leaving a comment, and a link to the meta with a placeholder question.

Requiring comments. While I personally feel comments should be required, and that comments should be able to be downvoted, neither of these based on my understanding are the popular opinion of SE.

Debate. There's a fine line between not understanding the logic used to close a question, and debating just to debate. Some users feel that a comment is an offer to debate why a question was voted to be closed.

Anonymity. Until a question is closed, while it's possible to see how the votes to close were cast, it's not possible to see who voted to close, which I would guess is by design.

Should moderation transparency be something that we strive for on On Startups?

Yes.

I think it's a great idea to leave a comment when voting to close a question. I normally leave a comment myself when closing a question.

From the perspective of the person asking the question:

  • As you state in your question, it comes off much nicer when someone leaves a comment explaining their reason behind their close vote. The standard template that comes up when a question is closed is useful and serves a purpose, but it's not very personal, and it can sometimes leave people with more questions than it answers, especially for new users.

  • Leaving a comment gives them a chance to edit their question to address the problems/concerns before the question is closed. If the person can improve their question before the fifth vote to close is cast, they can save their question from being closed, which provides them with a better experience. Again, this is especially important for new users.

From my perspective as a moderator:

  • As I mentioned, I normally leave a comment when closing a question. If someone else has already left a comment explaining the problem with the post, it saves me from having to do it. This lets me focus my time on other areas of site moderation.
