In some cases, I will add a comment even if someone else has already left a comment, if I think it's important to mention something that hasn't already been said.

  • Sometimes people vote to close a question, and it's not immediately clear to me why. Leaving a comment helps me (and the rest of the community) determine whether we should also add our close vote. If I disagree with the close vote, it gives me an opportunity to respond with my own comment.

As @blunders mentions, we can't make comments a requirement for voting to close. However, I would encourage everyone to do so whenever they can. As people see others leaving comments, my hope is that it will also encourage them to follow along and do the same.

Migrations can be a slightly sensitive topic. Migrations should only be used when you are 100% certain that not only does the question not belong on the site where it was asked, but that it absolutely does belong on the site you are targeting with the migration. It is not our responsibility to migrate everything that kinda has something to do with another site.

Here are two examples of why we need to use some caution when migrating:

  • Please don't migrate low-quality questions to other sites
  • Please stop using Programmers.SE as your toilet bowl

I'm going to explain the background on migrations, and then I'll answer your question. You can skip down to Migration Procedure to see how to do it.

Background

The migration tool was created to help users who asked good questions on the wrong site. It is not meant to be used to offload bad questions to other sites. The golden rule of question migration is don't migrate crap.

What that means is if it's a well thought out question, but it's off-topic for our site, we can migrate it to the appropriate SE site. If the question is off-topic for us, but it also happens to be a low quality question, then we should close it as off-topic, and leave it here. We need to keep in mind the SE guidelines regarding Not a Real Question and Not Constructive before migrating a question. A poll type of question is a bad question on any SE site. An overly broad question is a bad question on any SE site. Etc.

The problem is that we don't have domain expertise in all of the SE sites. Without domain knowledge it's hard to judge whether a question is good or not. On top of that, we're not intimately familiar with the scope of all the SE sites. Not everything that has to do with programmers, for example, is on-topic for Programmers.SE.

Because of this, what some moderators have resorted to is asking each other whether a question can be migrated, or not. This is why you may have seen some of my comments referring to asking other site mods about a possible question migration. This isn't an optimal solution, but it prevents a lot of frustrations.

You can read more about migrations on the Stack Exchange blog.

Migration Procedure

With all of that in mind, here's the procedure to migrate a question.

First, please take a moment to judge the question. If it is a bad question, vote to close as off-topic and let it be. If you feel it is a good question, then flag it for moderator attention.

On beta sites, only moderators can migrate a question. The only exception to this is the site's meta, where any user with close vote privileges can vote to migrate to the site's meta.

To migrate to our meta site:

  1. Select off topic as the close reason.
  2. Select "belongs on meta.answers.onstartups.com".

To migrate to another SE site:

  1. (optional) Ask the destination site if the question is a good fit for their site. You can either post a question on their meta site, as was done here and here. Or you can pop into their chatroom and ask there, if the site has an active chatroom. Please don't do this every single time you see a marginal question. Reserve this for good questions. If the other site wants the question, move to step 2.

  2. Flag the question for moderator attention. State which site it should be migrated to, and include a link to the discussion where the other site agrees with the migration. It's important that you include the link, if the discussion took place. Otherwise there is no guarantee that the migration will actually take place. Without any information to go on, the moderator has to decide whether they know the other site well enough to make a decision, and if not, do they want to take the time to ask the other site.

Really, some of the questions are just too funny or stupid to be believable. Does anyone else find this as well?

In an effort to protect the guilty, I wouldn't reference any specific questions.

But to paraphrase:

"I met this guy with a great idea. He owns the company, does no work and I am working my ass off. There is nothing in writing, I never get paid, but he keeps telling me I'm doing a great job. What should I do?..."

or

"I cut this deal with my friends and now I don't like it. What's the best way to welch on the deal, screw my friends, keep all the assets and how can I make sure I can get away with it?..."

and of course my favorite

"I am lazy and know absolutely nothing about business but I have this complicated idea that would put Rube Goldberg to shame. It involves 57 holding companies, 27 illegal activities and bribing 35 governments. What's the best way to get lots of people to work for me for no money?"

I thing stack exchange needs some sort of humor section where once a year we could share these really silly questions.

Just saying....
row.Title: Could we have a parody day on April 1st?

row.Body:
I do think our FAQ needs some updating, but I'm not sold on your suggestion. Unfortunately, I can't come up with a way to improve on it right now.

Here are some thoughts that might help you:

  • I think the reference to wide open questions ties in better with the "not a real question" close reason than "not constructive". Particularly,

This question is ... incomplete, overly broad, or rhetorical and cannot be reasonably answered in its current form.

  • The second section in the FAQ, What kind of questions should I not ask here?, already has an expanded description of "not constructive" (subjective and argumentative), and contains a link to the Stack Exchange blog post explaining such questions.

To prevent your question from being flagged and possibly removed, avoid asking subjective questions where …

  • every answer is equally valid: “What’s your favorite __?”
  • your answer is provided along with the question, and you expect more answers: “I use _ for _, what do you use?”
  • there is no actual problem to be solved: “I’m curious if other people feel like I do.”
  • we are being asked an open-ended, hypothetical question: “What if __ happened?”
  • it is a rant disguised as a question: “__ sucks, am I right?”

(The above section was adapted from MetaFilter’s FAQ. For more detail, see six guidelines for great subjective questions.)

Note that we only have control of the first section in the FAQ, What kind of questions can I ask here?. The rest of the FAQ is a template SE uses on all sites.

There's currently a slightly related proposal on MSO to change the close reason descriptions.

Sorry I can't be of more help right now, but I'll think about this some more.

This is a follow up to this question. Karlson suggested we make partnership and partnerships tag synonyms of each other.

In general, I agree with the suggestion in order to keep things simple on the site. However, I see two different uses for the tag.

  • The legal entity of a Partnership, as opposed to an LLC, C Corp, etc.
  • The act of working together to reach some common goal (not in connection with the legal entity of a Partnership). For example, two startups may partner together to form a mutually beneficial relationship. Example question: Need to establish legal entity for business partnership or is signed agreement enough?

I'm not sure on the best way to handle these tags. We shouldn't create one tag with two meanings. At the same time, I think keeping both partnership and partnerships is too confusing, and they will be used incorrectly.

My preference would be to create two tags, one for each of the two categories I mentioned above, but pick names for those tags that will not create confusion among them. I can't think of any good names to suggest though.

What do you all think? How should we fix the confusion created by these tags?
row.Title: What to do with the "partnership" tags?

row.Body:
I believe the confusion over the word partner makes it extremely difficult to answer many questions and we should work to get people to use the proper terms.

C corporations don't have partners, partnerships have partners. Corporations have stockholders.

Often we see questions like "My buddy and I started a company. We are partners and each have half the stock. What are my rights if he wants to leave?"

This is an oxymoron.

A partnership is automatically dissolved when one of the partners dies (you can't have a dead person as a partner) but a company is unaffected if a stockholder dies.

Since partnership has a very specific legal meaning, and is often important to the nuances of a question, I don't believe it helpful to have it used as a general tag meaning "someone I do some business with".

Alternatively if it is to be used in a general, non-specific sort of way, what tag should we use when we mean a legal partnership ( as opposed to a corporation)?

I've written a comment to your question and while it is important I don't really think there are that many people being confused by the tags. People choose whichever one they think it means for their situation.

Choosing ONE tag and have that tag mean either one works just as well and makes LESS work for people trying to edit tags and explain to people what the differences are.

It is an overloaded word. there is no way around that. Just as in conversation or writing, the meaning is gleaned from the context. So it will have to be on this site.

Just my opinion.

Or we have to choose multi-word tags so that people are clear what the difference is.

Your site looks a bit different today. Yes, we are getting rid of the 'Sketchy' look and replacing it with a more-polished and finished design for sites in beta.

You can read more about the redesign of our Beta theme on our blog entry.

Please note: This will not affect your "graduation" status in any way. When your site is due for graduation, it will get its final(real) site design and branding.

If you're still seeing the old favicon, please do a hard browser refresh. (Although sometimes it may take Chrome a while to load the new image).

If you see any CSS or styling issues, please report it in this post I created on Meta Stack Overflow. It will be easier for me to track all the bug reports there.
row.Title: New Beta Theme Launched

row.Body:
The flair for this site seems to use a 32 pixel logo.

This doesn't look entirely wrong, but every other site uses a 16 pixel logo.

I guess that this is a bug, rather than a deliberate design choice.
row.Title: Oversized logo used in flair

row.Body:
Name:

Haven't figured out yet

Elevator:

Insight into startup issues by people who've been there.

Tag Line:

Startup insight of expert masses.

Motto:

Tap the collective wisdom.

• Name: Startups
  • Elevator: Real community, high-quality advice, all for free.
  • Tagline: "Living the startup life."
  • Motto: "Go big, be it."
Please leave "business" out of any core phrases, since I personally find its use limiting to the use and scope of the understanding of what it might mean to be a startup.
This has been fixed. I originally used the favicon from onstartsup.com, and didn't realize their favicon wasn't 16x16px.

As the organizer of the Startup Conference, I want the community here to know that I'm trying to build the most useful event possible for you, the entrepreneur. This year, the conference is on May 2, in downtown Mountain View, and will include an outdoor festival with a startup demo pit. We'll probably go over 1,000 people, so it should be fun!

Site: http://thestartupconference.com

Ask me anything.
row.Title: Announcement: Startup Conference Silicon Valley is May 2

row.Body: Anyone have an idea of how long StackExchange keeps a site in beta? StackExchange participates in Creative Commons Attribution ShareAlike which makes properly cited content available to others. However, beta sites like Answers are not included.
row.Title: How long will answers.onstatups be in beta?

row.Body:
How long will answers.onstatups be in beta?

This has already been answered here and here, especially Robert's answer.

Anyone have an idea of how long StackExchange keeps a site in beta?

Per Robert: "There is no "slated time for a beta." There are only minimum requirements before a site can be considered for graduation."

However, beta sites like Answers are not included.

Not true. All SE sites are covered under the same Creative Commons license. See the footer on every page.

It seems to me that in the past couple of months the level of participation seem to have dropped off. It appears to me that the questions are being answered by about a dozen people and up/down vote judging by the number of votes and the number of questions that the votes actually occurred on seem to be the same. We seem to have people who come in ask the question and leave but even those who stay and actually look at the site don't seem to be participating beyond asking original question.

Probably be one of the better examples of this would be:

  • Evaluate Your Site — A Check for Quality

Granted that we cannot force or enforce actual participation but the cleanup contests with prizes isn't the answer either.

I know that I sound like I am ranting but it would be a shame to see this site dwindle into nothing but I can't shake the feeling that we seem to be heading in that direction, or am I just being paranoid?
row.Title: Do we seem to get lower participation or just lack of care?

row.Body:
Currently we have the tag landingpage. Should we make it a synonym of landing-page?

Which one works better?
row.Title: Should "landingpage" be "landing-page"?

row.Body: Google SEO has shown to like dashes between words. It turn, it would be better for searching and much better for finding on search engines. I would say to expand it to a dash just because of the SEO point.

Do people find the tags useful? Do people really look at them at all or sort or search by them?

I know that I do not. (on any of the SE sites).

Under the covers they may be useful, but to me they are just noise - it is the content I am interested in.

I suppose I just don't bother to set my preferences or filters so I am not a good use case for this.

But, to answer your question - I prefer the readability of the hyphen
Should we make pitching a synonym of pitch?
row.Title: Tag synonym suggestion: Pitch and Pitching

row.Body: The process of delivering a speech vs the speech itself? I don't see much difference in the startup context so do make them synonymous.

Currently on the home page of answers.onstartups is this:

I am just wondering why the 3rd question that is both closed and has been downvoted appears so high on the home page. I would have thought that the ordering has some sort of relevance algorithm to it, it seems wrong that this question would rank so highly.

Is this behaving correctly?
row.Title: Why does a closed/downvoted question appear so high on the front page

row.Body: If you look closely, you'll notice the front page sorts questions by the time of the most recent activity, which includes new answers and edits of existing posts. Since the question is closed, it can resurface only if it's edited.

The basic philosophy is that a closed question is not deleted. They they are still part of the site and need to be tended to.

When something goes wrong with a question (i.e. it gets closed), you don't want the system to quietly sweep it under the rug to fester for others to find (Google Search). Maintenance and up-keep are a big part of running this site — so the argument might even be to err towards giving [closed] question EVEN MORE attention (not less) — either to fix the problem or ultimately delete the post from the site.

But we certainly don't want to DE-emphasize it from the main workflow of the site to be neglected and forgotten.

The question asked "Are there other types of corporations other than C and S I should be aware of as a startup?" and I answered, "The other type of business organization you should be aware of is the LLC." How does this meet the criteria for deletion?
row.Title: Why was my answer deleted?

row.Body: Because the question asked for more than that. The part about "other types of corporations" was a secondary questions.

I left you a comment explaining the reason for the deletion before I deleted the answer:

...it is not an answer to the posted question.

But, I'll reiterate it here - it is not an answer to the question.

The OP had two questions in the post:

  1. What is the difference between a C corp and an S corp?

  2. Are there other types of corporations other than C and S I should be aware of as a startup?

Your one-liner post did not answer either of those questions.

I'll also add that I deleted it after someone flagged it as "not an answer", so at least one other person agrees.

A previous discussion here on Meta about how to raise the quality of questions had me thinking for a while. I think I finally figured it out.

In startups, I believe the best advice is learning from example: how did successful entrepreneurs do it? I'm not a big fan of theory in entrepreneurship, which is why MBA programs are so ineffective at teaching entrepreneurs.

With that in mind, it makes sense that the most useful questions would be in the form of "How did Pinterest scale to 1M users in their first month". The answer could be factual and enlightening. Even better, it's easy to see that the best answers would be provided by people who worked at Pinterest at the time. And it's a draw for viewers to find out behind the scenes stories. Kind of like a "people" magazine for startups.

Instead, due to our current rules, we are limited to generic questions such as "How do I scale my startup to 1M users in the first month". I don't feel like spending any effort to answer that question. They feel too beginner-oriented.

Guess who is doing a great job of asking the right questions? Quora. So what do we do?
row.Title: Why our questions are bad

row.Body:
The issue you describe with our current constraints could be part of the problem, but if it is, it only accounts for a small portion of it.

Let's say we did ask the question "How did Pinterest scale to 1M users in their first month". I can pretty much guarantee that "people who worked at Pinterest" would not stop by to answer the question.

Quora has a lot of backing from Silicon Valley. The entrepreneurs participating on Quora seem to be of higher quality, and thus the discussions are of better quality. Don't get me wrong, we have some great people participating on this site, but the number of wannabe entrepreneurs here is overwhelming compared to the small number of "experts".

We get a lot of ridiculously dumb questions from 1 rep users that never come back. A lot of these questions can easily be answered by doing a simple Google search, or are so incredibly broad they're impossible to answer without writing an entire book on it. These users aren't asking these questions because of our rules, they're asking these questions because they are completely clueless and/or too lazy to figure things out on their own. (I realize that's harsh, but it's the only explanation I've been able to come up with.)

Why are we attracting people like that, instead of the YC crowd, Scoble, etc? Even Spolsky, our CEO, doesn't spend any time on this site. So, the question is how do we attract more experienced, smart entrepreneurs?

Sorry, I know this isn't much of an answer. I just don't know how to solve this problem.

I think it's fantastic that you are trying to improve the signal-to-noise ratio around here, and I heartily applaud the effort. :-)

useful questions would be in the form of "How did Pinterest scale to 1M users in their first month"

Well, on that one I don't quite agree. Yes, since lots of startup strategies are very situation-specific, it often makes good sense to discuss a topic from a case. I agree with that part.

But most of the "how did startup x achieve y" questions don't seem like well considered research to me. They seem more like "please spend lots of time answering this short question".

I'm sure people will learn from the answer to questions like that. But I don't feel they're good questions because:

  • Of the considerable amount of time they will require to answer well. Answering "How did Pinterest scale to 1M users" well could be a long, time-consuming answer to write.
  • That these questions might be less find-able on Google etc, because the hot startup names continuously change, and few people search for old startups.

Just to get a feel for the actual numbers, I used the site search to search for "how did" and looked over the first handful of questions. There were some good ones -- but also many which were asked by low-rep users who seemed to have left our site shortly after asking.

I'm not convinced that allowing "how did startup x achieve y" questions here would improve the situation. However, if others feel differently, we could always run an experiment and try to get data... And I do agree that Answers.Onstartups is struggling.

Quality usualy diminishes when the barrier to entry lowers. In the case of starting a business, it really is the situation. People get a lot of misinformation from the media and think anyone can make millions with their latest software idea without understanding the necessary work. Their next step is to open their favorite search engine and look a few things up. Once they hit the slightest barrier, their query will be "startup questions", or "startup help", or anything of that nature but not the description of their problem in proper terms because they don't know it. In the end, they get to this site and hit the "Ask a question" button posting their assinine problem without even reading the rules or trying to search the archives.

The other part of the problem is that people think that legal & accounting advice always costs money and is hard to comprehend. Most people don't even try to search for an answer to their problem because asking someone a question is always easier than finding out yourself. That's why we get so many very basic questions that are answered time & time again in one for or another.

As for community quality, part of it is how the site is being promoted. Quora is the Silicon Valley darling. It started there, attracted the local audience, and stayed there. This site started with Dharmesh (who is relatively known in SV, too) but for some reason it never gained as much traction (I wish I knew a bit more about the history here). As a result, Quora is synonymous with "Q&A" in the SV and that's where people go when they need an answer. However, it doesn't mean all the questions there are good. Some of them are as stupid as things we get here, such as "Who are the 2012 summer interns in Silicon Valley?" or "Start up help! Need ideas. Who will be my target market for these products?"

Startups isn't the only site in SE ecosystem that suffers from hit-and-run users who don't even come back to accept an answer. There're plenty of them. The cause of such behavior is in the inherent reason why people come to such sites: they come to resolve their own problem not to help others or not thinking they could receive any additional value from participation. Only the few who poke around and/or come back to check the answers stick around. For everyone else, it become "K. Thanx. Bye."

So what can we do to remedy all of this? The easiest thing is to step up moderation and close & delete all bad questions on sight without waiting for community response. We can also try to request more moderator slots to make sure there's at least one sweep of the site every hour of the day. (I know some will object but there's no way to keep a house clean without forcing everyone to clean up after themselves.) The second part of the solution is to work with SE HQ and figure out whether they want to promote the site among experienced entrepreneurs & investors to bring more quality answers as well as street buzz (one of the reasons for Quora's success was that you could answer a question and get a high-profile expert's answer to it).

there is a relevant subset of questions that are a good fir for startups/new founders and the SE rules.

There are another set of questions that are interesting, but lend themselves more to discussion and speculations.

I really don't care about pinterest or any of the other companies that won the lottery. If I want to read or hear about those i will listen to the many podcasts or go to the many blogs.

This site is suffering from significant quality issues. Most questions are uninteresting to me and a good portion are borderline of meeting the current SE rules/FAQ about suitable questions.

I don't think this format is really what people need/want.

There are other better places for content/help - like venture hacks and some of the popular "startups" blogs.

Again, there are "technical" questions that are interesting and useful IMO but for the most part it seems to me to be too much noise.

I would not find a more discussion and trivia-type site worth visiting - that is best left for things like Scott hanselman's series on startups or Bob and patrick's startup success podcast (to name 2)

I don't know the answer to the problem. It would be nice - but I think a big reason for the lack of quality is that the people who are really needed here are just busy. busy executing, busy mentoring others, busy learning. They may find this site and see that it's not worth the time...

Economics.SE is closing on 4 May and I, along with the other mods, am in the process of salvaging the best questions we have to be migrated to other parts of the SE universe where they may make a good fit.

I have migrated a small number across which I feel are appropriate to a discussion of small business, although - being asked from an Economics perspective - potentially more academic than you would normally host.

I realise I should ask in advance, but we have very little time and I feel it worthwhile having the discussion of relevance/appropriateness once we have the luxury of having actually saved them.

If you would like to review other questions on the site, please, we can use the help.

Thanks.
row.Title: Economics.SE is closing, some questions could be migrated

row.Body:
Just to clarify the details for the community here. There were 3 questions migrated here from Econ.SE.

  • I deleted one question on site because it was way off-topic for us. My deletion resulted in the migration being reversed, and the question is now back on the Econ.SE site. Here is the question: http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/40/is-greshams-law-relevant-for-modern-online-games-that-allow-the-use-of-real-mon?noredirect=1
  • The second question migrated here was mostly off-topic. I thought about it for a while, and then decided to delete it as well after it received a close vote. Again, this caused the migration to be reversed, and that question is here: http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/135/are-large-companies-more-profitable-than-small-ones?noredirect=1
  • The third migrated question is on-topic, and is here: Social Entrepreneurship vs Commercial Entrepreneurship

After the first 2 off-topic questions were migrated here I left the Econ.SE folks a comment asking if they could ask us before migrating any further questions, and I suggested that they could compile a list of the questions they think are potential candidates for OnStartups, then posting a question on our meta site listing those questions for our review.

BTW, I did take a cursory look at the Econ.SE site, but did not find anything relevant to our site.

This also came up on Money SE. My response (quoted below) might not be 100% analogous, but I feel it is equally applicable here.

Economics.SE is closing, do we want some of their questions?

No, please. This is an applied site about "personal finance" and really shouldn't be accepting questions about academic or broader economic issues. From the faq:

Please note that the following subjects are considered off-topic here:

  • ...
  • Academic questions about economics or questions about economics that have no bearing on personal finance

I strongly urge you to resist the inclination that you have to save these questions because they have no where better to go. They are off topic here. If they've already been imported, please close them as off topic. These are broken windows, and you don't need pile on more cruft that will just have to be cleaned out later.

Answers.OnStartups is still very much an applied site about real-world problems you encounter in your day-to-day work, so I don't suspect that there should be many questions from a largely academic and theoretical site that truly belong here. They should be off topic.

This was just a note caution that you shouldn't feel too much of a "Mother Teressa complex" when trying to save this content. If it's not a great question for this site, don't just take in the Econ stuff like you're adopting unwanted pets that no one else will take care of. If there's the occasional question that should have been on this site in the first place, great; otherwise, just let it go.

Alain, Wow. I find your problem statement well thought out and pretty much on-target, but I have to disagree almost 100% with your conclusion and solution statement that follows.

Stack Exchange is not "limited to generic questions." Yikes.

Answers.OnStartups is very much an applied site for entrepreneurs to come when they have very real day-to-day questions to be solved. Yes, we forgo question that are generally considered conversation starters that are the mainstay of discussion forums and support groups. But that shouldn't pigeon-hole you into accepting questions like "How did company X do Y?" Just the opposite. Yes, such questions are "answerable," but they would also completely miss the point of this site.

You said that "In startups, I believe the best advice is learning from example."

Yes, yes, 100 times yes!

But why not embrace that learn-from-those-who've-been-there mantra to encourage questions you might encounter in your very real everyday world? I agree 100% that nobody wants to answer vague, hypothetical, or academic questions unless you are in a discussion forum, a support group, or an undergraduate-level class. This site is none of those.

The bane of this site is the infinite variations of those "generic questions" you avoid. But they're everywhere; questions that can only be answered by pouring through the shelves of books on the subject. This site will continue to attract every wanna-be entrepreneur who wants to to jump right to "how are you going to make me successful?" or, worse… "make my idea work." Don't even entertain such uninspired and ill-conceived questions.

Next time someone asks, "How do I scale my startup to 1M users in the first month," tell them "I don't know, what have you tried and where exactly are you running into problems?" Politely, of course, but stick to a higher standard and close those questions as "not constructive" or "not a real question" and politely ask them to try again when you're not left guessing what specific advice would actually help them.

not constructive
This question is not a good fit to our Q&A format. We expect answers to generally involve facts, references, or SPECIFIC expertise; this question will likely solicit opinion, debate, arguments, polling, or extended discussion.

That's what we mean by answers that are factual and enlightening. But that does not mean "beginner-oriented" and it certainly does not mean "generic questions."

I'd like to shake things up a little on this site and add a couple of new moderators to our existing staff. If you're the type of high-energy person that can juice up the community and help drive the on-going improvements desperately needed on this site…

… then I'd love to hear from you.

So, I am turning to the community and issuing a call to arms. This community needs people to lead it! Moderation is about accepting edits and handling flags, yes, but it's also about serving as a role model to the community — mentoring others to be productive contributors to this site while making those tough decision to keep this site on track to becoming a lasting and valuable resource; one that makes the internet a better place!

Typically the "pro tem" program starts with a call to nominate moderator candidates. But this time around, I really want to encourage self-nominations only.

If you are interested, please post your interest in the answers below. The nomination thread linked below has some good replies to the question —

Who should the moderators be?

You can read about the appointment process in Moderator Pro Tempore, and learn what it takes to be an effective moderator in A Theory of Moderation.

Good luck!
row.Title: A Call for Moderators!

row.Body: I would like to self-nominate. I've been hanging out here for a while, and also at the Joel on Software forum for over ten years. I guess I'm "qualified" in that I'm currently working on a startup and have been founder and co-founder of startups previously. Any questions, ask away...

All right, I will bite, and self-nominate too.

Briefly about my personal experience:

  • I have been a cofounder twice
  • Have had a longer-term involvement with 4 startups in all
  • All of the above startups are from the Copenhagen, Denmark area

Moderation here would have to be a set-time activity for me. Right now I'm 'only' teaching mobile- & web application development in College, so my schedule isn't that demanding, but I hope to get busier later on. I'd commit to visiting the site 2-4 times a week, and spend up to a couple of hours on this weekly, with allowances for the occasional week off.

Regarding moderation style -- to be honest, I'm still working that out. In my past dealings here I have tried to be plain spoken, as well as friendly and encouraging to new arrivals. That said, I do have a somewhat stern view on the common '2 lines, poorly worded, not even the most basic research done before asking the question, not bothering to look at the FAQ' questions we see. I guess my current idea for those questions would be: one welcoming, friendly request to improve the question, and if that isn't heeded, then as a moderator I would close the question.

I'm open to questions. :-)

For whatever reason, people seem to come to this site and ask questions that are essentially unanswerable in the form initially posted. I don't know if this is because they don't bother to read the FAQ before posting or what.

A perfect example is all the questions where they fail to mention what country they are located in when asking about taxes, regulations, corporate structure, or local business practices etc.

If this is a first question from a new user I feel conflicted in that we don't want to drive away new users but at the same time posting a comment asking them where they are located takes time as well and can sometimes seem not worth the trouble for an otherwise inane question.

Put another way, it seems more worthwhile investing time to answer a question where the poster has obviously done his homework and taken the time to formulate a well thought out question that trying to salvage a poorly written question.

I often feel that it would be better if a new user had to get at least a couple of up votes for answers they contribute before they were allowed to ask their first question.

Anyway I don't have the answers, it is just frustrating.

I'll nominate myself as well.

When the site was run by Jason and Dharmesh, Jason asked me to help moderate. I accepted and was happily engaged in helping the site.

I am aware that some of my voting and comments are not always popular. As I did when I was a moderator in the past, I will refrain from that type of commentary and the hard-line stance of what should be allowed on the site. I am very happy to take direction from other moderators and the general will of the users in the interest of improving the site.

I'll be more active in cleaning up, editing and looking for ways to engage the users in broader external events and roles.

In the context of "shake things up" -- I will self-nominate myself as a moderator. I believe that my activity on the site can speak to my engagement with the community and the board.

I am interested in being a moderator to:

  • Establish a nurturing and supportive culture that welcomes all new entrepreneurs and those who support them.
  • Ensure an ever increasing quality of question and answer without absolutes or judgment.
  • Build among the moderators a culture of transparency and accountability to the site membership.

A quick review of my past comments and posts can provide greater insight as to the depth off my conviction on these areas.

I am not interested in being the moderator of a community where the role is defined as a rule maker or a gate keeper-- where an externally imposed standard of "right answer" is deemed to be more valuable that the meaningful engagement of members.

My attention over the past three months has been less than the first 11 -- due to the fact that I am leading a new start-up at the moment. But I do believe that I would have the time to work as a member of the moderator-team to provide effective service and support to the members of the community.

@Ninefingers posted on Crypto.SE a follow up to his wildly successful A guide to voting to close a question. I'm reposting it here for reference.

This is intended to help anyone who has had their post closed improve it so we can re-open it if possible. If you have had a question closed, this guide is for you.
row.Title: My question has been closed. What do I do now?

row.Body:
So, your question has been closed. Seems a bit harsh? Ok, well, this guide is here to help explain why your question has been closed. This has been covered briefly in the FAQ too.

Is closure permanent?

Absolutely not. Closed questions are only prevented from receiving additional answers; they're even still visible to all members of the site.

This might sound like a bad thing - it isn't. The concept of closure is that we prevent answers coming in that make guesses or assumptions based on an incomplete question, or are just plain bad, until the question has been improved. We are all about quality and question closure is out way to ensure users spend their time generating quality answers.

Does a closed question count against me?

Not in a reputation sense (unless you have also been downvoted). However, if a sufficient number of your questions are closed, the system may automatically ban you from asking additional questions. Similarly, a moderator may take action before then.

If a moderator takes action, they will likely contact you, explain the problem and what you need to do to improve. Take note and all should be fine.

If the system takes action, you will receive an orange bar notification. Moderators have no way to tell if you have been banned from asking questions via this mechanism and we cannot lift it, either. You will have to have had a sufficient quantity of questions closed to trigger this, however.

Ok, so why was my question closed?

Underneath each question, there is a banner which explains why your question was closed, giving a few short reasons. Here, I will expand on these:

  • Exact duplicate - this type of closure is exactly what it sounds. We already have a question covering that material and it would be better if the material is to be revisited for those answers to be edited and improved on, rather than creating a whole set of duplicate answers.
  • Not constructive - some questions are just not suited to the format we use here. These include lists, polling or opinion questions that eat up the time of our members, who are here to help people with their problems and learn about startups in a constructive, problem-by-problem manner.
  • Not a real question - questions closed as NARQ fit into two categories; the first is that your question simply doesn't make sense or is so poorly worded it's almost a crime people are reading it. The second is that your question, whilst valid, is just too broad to be covered over the internet and really needs to be broken into manageable chunks.
  • Too localized - questions closed with this reason refer to a very narrow scenario, or are, for example, only useful to you and in no way would be useful to other people with the same problem.

What about off topic questions?

Sometimes, a question is good, but just doesn't fit here on OnStartups. In this case two things will happen:

  • The question will be migrated to another Stack Exchange site.
  • The question will be closed as purely off topic.

Migration is a privilege, not a right. If your question has been migrated, a moderator has gone to the effort to get it moved; however, there is no onus on us to migrate questions anywhere. If your question is poorly formatted, we are unlikely to move it.

How do I get my question re-opened?

Occasionally, questions are closed by mistake. This is a rare occurrence and will usually be rectified pretty quickly when we realise this has happened.

Here is a list of steps you can take to get your question improved and increase your chances of re-opening:

  1. Read about what questions are on topic and off topic in the FAQ.
  2. Decide if your question was really a fit for SE in the first place. Not all questions are. However, you may well be able to re-word it into such a way that it does fit. Do have a ready of point 3:
  3. Work through each of the articles on the how to ask page. Specifically, I would highlight the following:
    • Is your question properly formatted?
    • Have you checked your spelling and punctuation?
    • Have you explained your problem sufficiently?

  4. Underneath your question there is an edit link:

    Use this to improve your question. Take your time and ensure you put sufficient effort in.

  5. When you are sure you have edited the question and framed it in the best possible way, you may do one of the following:

    • Contact us in chat. Users capable of re-opening are not always around, but it may help to ask for feedback and get other user's opinions.

    • A moderator should have commented on your post. You can reply to them using the following format:

      @moderator_name Hello, I've edited my question, can 
you please let me know if it is suitable for re-opening?

    • Alternatively, you can flag for moderator attention using the flag link underneath your question and filling out the custom reason box:

NDAs, non-competes, etc -- Do they expire, and if so, are there any limits to the use of knowledge?

If the agreements date/term wise are legally expired, and there's no additional IP agreements beyond them (copyright, patent, etc) - what legal/moral obligation do I have not to compete against the parties in those agreements using the knowledge gain during the course of those agreements?

Taking a step back, some might say that the party paid/owns the related information, but my understanding is the spirit of the law for IP long-term is that all IP enters the public domain, it's just a matter of when/how/why/etc.

Also, is there a legally enforceable way to test the expiration of the agreements without potentially discovering the terms of said agreement were violated by doing the test? If not, how do I define the scope of limitation related to the use of knowledge covered by the agreements?

Legal Disclaimers: Yes, I know: Seek the advice of an attorney; Your response is not legal advice; You are not an attorney, or your response does not form attorney-client relationship; etc. I know, thanks!
row.Title: Is this question ontopic, and if not, where might it be ontopic?

row.Body: If I ask a question about choosing between two marketing strategies for my startup (I have a plan for both and don't want the users to suggest the strategy, just tell me which one would be a better option), will that be inappropriate? On one hand, it could just be a poll like reply, while on the other, it can be thought of as a discussion wherein people can start to discuss about pros and cons of each strategy ?
row.Title: Will it be a good question and if I ask users to choose/suggest out of two marketing strategies?

row.Body:
This seems like a purely legal question, so my answer is it would be off-topic here.

I don't think there is a legal SE site, so I don't think it would be on topic on any SE site. Avvo.com exists for purely legal questions.

From the OnStartups "Ask Question" FAQS:

What kind of questions can I ask here?

Answers.onstartups.com is a site for entrepreneurs starting and running new businesses.

Topics include financing, hiring employees, renting an office, legal, marketing, sales, compensation plans, banking, payroll, benefits, and more. This is the place to come with specific questions or to seek specific advice from your peers.

If you look at the tags page, you'll see some of the topics that are discussed here.

This is confusing to me, since I posted a legally related question on meta to see if it was ontopic (the question was basically about NDA/NCA agreements), and was I believe told it was not; see is-this-question-ontopic-and-if-not-where-might-it-be-ontopic. To be clear, this question is not about why my questions may, or may not be ontopic/offtopic, on the main site, just citing my question to give some content/background.

Basically, my question is do the FAQS need to be updated to state that all legal questions are off-topic? If not, how does a user know: what legal questions are okay; when giving a legal answer/comment is okay; etc.?
row.Title: Why are legal questions listed as ontopic on the FAQS?

row.Body:
It seems obvious to me. This is a startups site, therefore any and all questions asked on this site must relate to "starting and running new businesses", as stated in our FAQ. That includes legal questions.

Asking a sales question related to Fortune 500 companies would be off-topic here.

Asking a banking question related to opening up a personal bank account would be off-topic here.

Asking a financing question related to paying for a hobby would be off-topic here.

Asking a legal question related to a divorce would be off-topic here.

I don't understand the non-constructive logic behind closing of some posts that ask for study resources, for example, Good books on sales for non-sales people? and Good references on sales and customer relationship?.

There is certainty no one single answer, but they are helpful for many of us to study and learn. For example, on math.SE, CS.SE, cstheory.SE, programmer.SE, etc, such questions are quite popular and welcome and well-received.

If you insist on raising the question of not being able to choose the best answer, the most common solution is to turn the thread into community Wiki as the other sites do.

This principle should not depend on what the area is. It is a matter of whether some people at this site have the insights and are willing to embrace others at different study levels and styles.
row.Title: Requests for study resources are not constructive?

row.Body:
From the FAQ:

What kind of questions should I not ask here?

...

To prevent your question from being flagged and possibly removed, avoid asking subjective questions where …

  • every answer is equally valid: “What’s your favorite __?”

This is exactly why the questions in question are not constructive, more often than not they generate extremely low quality answers. The first question, Good books on sales for non-sales people?, generated:

  • A somewhat thorough answer, that coincidentally starts with "My favorite book ..." ;),
  • An answer that looks more like a comment to the question,
  • Four "link only" answers, one of which doesn't even link to the suggested book.

The other question, fortunately, was closed before it had the chance to generate such poor answers. Don't get me wrong, when I say poor I mean in a Stack Exchange context, the suggested books may be wonderful, but right now the Stack Exchange model and format has no way of vetting such answers. How do we now which answer (or very small set of answers) is the best? Why would anyone down vote someone's favourite book? Questions that ask for lists of stuff can not be evaluated, every answer is equal, and thus are considered not constructive all across the Stack Exchange network:

I realize this is a lot of rules, a lot of guidelines, a lot of thinking. But it’s simpler than it looks. As Aarobot said in his post: real questions have answers, not items or ideas or opinions.

And yet, those questions are indeed extremely popular. Popularity alone however is not really what we aim for, it's always nice when a useful question is popular, but a completely different story when it's just popular:

Popularity is a tough thing. I’m tempted to call it a curse, but what we try to do at Stack Exchange is make sure that questions and answers are popular for the right reasons — because they are amazing resources for learning from your peers. If you want to slip a few jokes in there with the learning, that’s fine, but when the question devolves into little more than entertainment, I hope you can understand why our community moderators are obliged to step in and protect the community from, well … itself.

Every Stack Exchange community can shape those generic guidelines (to a point) depending on the unique characteristics of the community's expertise, but there's little chance that questions that have failed repeatedly on several sites will work on another. You mention that such questions are welcome and well-received on Programmers (where I'm a moderator), but that's not a very accurate statement:

  • 324 questions tagged [book],
  • 116 of which are closed.

And if you sort the 208 open ones by votes, you'll see that most of the high voted [book] questions aren't really requests for lists of books / references, or are questions on canonical books on very specific topics. In fact, we consider book recommendation questions that aren't on specialized and specific topics off topic, and close them asap.

Questions that are asking for external resources / references / books, and worst, a list of, are not questions that have much chance of building up to an amazing resource, for quite a few reasons: External resources get outdated, links rot, people tend to just post their favourite without much explanation, and they are extremely easy questions to answer, which explains their popularity. Thus, not constructive.

If you insist on raising the question of not being able to choose the best answer, the most common solution is to turn the thread into community Wiki as the other sites do.

No, Community Wiki is not a "get out of jail, free" card:

Community wiki isn’t only abused for “fun” or “getting-to-know-you” stuff, though. Many sites propose using community wiki to allow content that is on-topic and useful, but can be considered borderline or questionable in other ways. Someone notes that a certain class of question has problems, and proposes using community wiki as a quick fix.

If a question is valuable enough that you believe it belongs on the site, chances are you don’t need it to be community wiki! We welcome all contributions which improve the quality of a site and advertise its greatness to the rest of the world. If you allow a certain class of questions, but only under the stipulation that no one can earn reputation from them, you’ve strongly discouraged these sorts of questions. People aren’t going to put in nearly as much effort to ask them.

Instead, strive for quality. If you’re unsure a certain question class belongs on the site, don’t tolerate the worst examples — demand that these questions be awesome. Questions shouldn’t be swept under the rug with community wiki; they should get the same respect and treatment as the rest of your Q&A. If those questions are something you are uncomfortable showing to visitors … they probably don’t belong on your site.

If the OnStartups community decides that reference requests are valuable for the site, there's no point in marking them Community Wiki. If not, then there's no point in hosting those questions all together, Community Wiki or not. The problem here is not that these questions generate cheap rep for the participants, but that they don't add to the overall quality of the site, and Community Wiki is only meant to lower the editing threshold and not as an excuse for poor questions.

I already left comments on those questions (here and here) addressing the reason for the closures, but I'll address your other points here.

Your statement that "give me a list of books" type of questions are "welcome and well-received" on Programmers and StackOverflow is far from reality. List, poll, and recommendation questions have been banned on both sites for some time now. Just search on the respective metas, and you'll find plenty of evidence. (I left you a link to one of them in my comment, but there are plenty more.)

If you take a look at the Programmers link that you yourself provided, almost all of the questions on that first page are either closed or heavily downvoted. The questions that are open are mostly in the format of "I have a specific question about this book" or relate to books in some other way. For example, Is it worthwhile to author programming books?.

Individual Stack Exchange sites are free to interpret the standard SE rules as they see fit. We're not going to decide what's best for the OnStartups community based on what math.se does. Note that math.SE and cstheory.SE are academic/theoretical subjects. Startups is a practical discipline.

Closing list questions does not mean that we don't welcome different experience levels. We have plenty of newbie questions on this site that remain open, and are answered. Take a look at our getting-started and definitions tags. The expert level of the question does not play into the decision of closing a question. A newbie question that conforms to our guidelines will remain open. An expert level question that does not will be closed.

I recommend making the failure tag a synonym of success.

Why?

Reframing from the mindset of problem in a question to how can I overcome, learn or be successful with this challenge

Some may think this is a trivial change but if you really think about it, allowing users to tag questions with fail/failure/setback anchors negativity to the question; pushing it to the wrong intent in the answer.

Not putting a feature-request or support tag. This support is not technical nature more of a psychological rewire to think of ventures within a positive/solution frame in startups.

Just a thought.
row.Title: Make failure a synonym of success

row.Body: It can go both ways. Sometimes I want to find questions related to success and failure. In which case, having them be synonyms is great. In other cases, I just want to hear about failure, because it's a special event. And other times, I may even want to look for success without failure being included. Personally, I think the concepts are far enough that they could be kept separate, but I won't freak out if they get merged.
Wondering if questions like this ought to be closed, but I don't see anything explicit in the FAQ prohibiting this.
row.Title: Should asking "which companies solve problem X" be explicitly listed in the FAQ as off-topic?

row.Body:
You're correct. That question should be closed as Not Constructive. It's basically a give me a "List of x" question, which Stack Exchange strongly discourages. To keep it from getting closed, I have edited the question to be in the format of "What process can I use to discover x". I think rephrasing the question in that format fits better within our guidelines.

I realize that you don't have enough rep to vote to close yet, but if you see questions that are not a good fit for this site, I encourage you to suggest edits to improve the question, leave comments guiding new users on the proper usage of the site, and vote accordingly. I also realize that as a relatively new member of our community, you may be hesitant to do these things since you may still be getting a feel for how we do things. If you are unsure about something, ask on meta, as you have done here.

With respect to our FAQ, our FAQ still needs a fair amount of work. On Programmers.SE, you all have done an excellent job with your FAQ. Unfortunately, we're not quite there yet. I do think we would benefit from explicitly stating that "shopping recommendations" and lists are outside of our scope, but we should probably start a separate question focusing just on that one aspect to get some community input.

It's hard to say without actually seeing the question. You bring up a good point that a question like that could turn into a poll. However, it could be an interesting question if people put some thought into their answers and give you their reasons as to why you should choose one option over the other.

My advice would be to post the question, and explain your two options in detail. Also, make sure you state in your question that you are looking for more than just a simple option A or option B answer. State that you don't want this to turn into a poll, and that the answer must include the reason why one option is better than the other.

The key to getting good answers is that you provide details about your two options. If your question is too open ended you may end up with a poll, and that's not helpful to you, or anyone else on the site.

The past weeks I have seen an annoying trend on OnStartups. It seems to me that some people are downvoting valid answers "by random". Some of the answers I read were very good and somebody downvoted them. This is frustrating and annoying for the guys who give answers. At the moment I don't feel very comfortable to answer questions here. It feels like some kind of "weird" competition is on going.

Maybe forcing an (anonymous) comment on downvotes will help.
row.Title: Downvoting by random

row.Body:
This issue has been fixed with the introduction of the new beta theme.

Just posting this answer to remove this question from our unanswered list.

Related:

Meta Stackoverflow, Meta Ask Ubuntu, Meta Ask Ubuntu, Meta OnStartups.

Short version:

It's their choice - we can't force them to do that.

People vote their conscience, nothing more.

Requiring a comment will only open people up to ridicule - for example, I've been told that I have a very distinct writing style for comments, so I'm (supposedly) easy to identify when people know me. However, I've also noticed that there are people who have similar writing styles, so if one of the were to downvote, leave a anonymous comment, and the OP thinks it was someone else, then well, we're in trouble.

Either way, requiring comments after a downvote has been discussed, and denied for a pletora of reasons.

I would like to formally request that slogan get merged into branding.

Why? Because I think that a slogan is such a important part of your branding, it doesn't deserve its own tag.
row.Title: Tag synonym request: slogan -> branding

row.Body:
I would like to formally request that screen-recording get merged into screencast.

Why? Because I think that they more or less mean the exact same thing. I mean, screencast? Screen recording? Seems pretty obvious to me, and while I would just manually edit them, I have a feeling we'll get more questions that are going to be tagged 'incorrectly'.
row.Title: Tag synonym request: screen-recording -> screencast

row.Body: I agree. I'll make the change if no one objects to your request.

I like the thinking as far as it goes, but I don't think it's quite right.

It seems to me that to abstract from the case in point, the real thought here is that:

If synonyms are well-maintained, there is potential value in mapping antonyms

Let's for convenience call these mappings tag/anti-tag pairs.

This is then a UX challenge, and I'd be interested in the experiment! I can imagine a few possible approaches:

  1. (Closest to your logic) Treat anti-tags as synonyms so that, for instance, if 'failure' is a valid tag then this will have replaced 'success' (this seems to me to impose too much burden on people asking questions)

  2. (A restricted subset) Where a given tag has a single anti-tag, which in turn has as its only anti-tag the tag we started out with, treat these as virtual synonyms (so both exist as valid tags, but any search on one returns both)

  3. Whenever someone is searching on one or more tags, the platform should weave in questions that have the anti-tag (so there's a scoring algorithm needed, because a tag may have multiple anti-tags)

  4. Whenever someone is searching on one or more tags, after (or beside) the questions featuring the tag(s) comes a list of anti-tags, so the user can decide for themselves to explore related areas

I don't have a strong opinion whether or not these should be merged, but it seems to me marginally more natural that if merging, then to merge the other way round, screencast -> screen-recording

If I want to know how to make a screen recording, I may have other intents than screencasting. But if I'm screencasting, I'll certainly need screen recording.

It could be that my logic implies that they shouldn't be merged - but there are plenty of cases where a general tag is preferred to one that's more (and arguably too) specific.

You love your site and we love your site, but there is a whole world of people out there who might not even know it exists. When they do find it, their first impression will either scare them away or keep them around. Given this, let's take a hard look at the questions and answers here and make sure newcomers see the site at its best!

Below you'll find ten questions randomly selected from this site. What do you think about each of them and their answers? Are they the best they can be or can they be improved? Would they look interesting and inviting to an outsider or are they a little embarrassing?

Upvote the corresponding post here on meta when we're awesome. Downvote when our content just isn't quite up to par.

Oh, and do comment to let everyone know your thoughts and take part in this conversation. :)

Here's some feedback from the last evaluation:

Your Area 51 site stats look pretty good, but when we took a closer look at the last evaluation, we noticed a couple troubling behavior patterns.

First and foremost - the post received almost zero attention from the community. The response was very light. We've seen these evaluations on other sites spark discussion in comments and improvements to the questions and answers on the list. That did not happen here on Startups. This is consistent with what I usually notice when visiting the site - there are many instances of a new user asking a question or giving an answer and not returning. The site members here are having trouble coming together as a cohesive community.

The other issue we picked up on was that a good number of those sample questions on review were very difficult to find through Google. They were not necessarily bad questions or answers - such as this one - but they're not attracting users to your site because they're difficult to find.

To me, the first issue is the more important one. A healthy, engaged community can fix almost any issues with the content of questions or answers. However, when there isn't a community, the site starts hurting. I'm going to extend the length of the evaluation by a few days, since it took me longer than expected to get back to you guys with this feedback. It would be great to see if this new evaluation would boost the involvement some and get conversations going in the community about the future of this site.

Feedback on this evaluation:

The Q&A quality in this sample set looks better than the last one, but we hesitate to say this means the site is in the clear scope-wise. There is still a lack of community engagement. That looks to us like one of the biggest problems with the site right now - a bunch of users are MIA and inactive, and user retention seems to be slowing down.

Most of the issues from the previous evaluation seem to still apply. This site needs strong leadership to emerge from its users and help out those who have already stepped up. But even beyond that, every little bit of help ...well... helps. Anybody can submit edits, flag inappropriate questions, and so on. The moderators on this site are doing an admirable job keeping it going, but they can always use a hand and any help they get will make this community stronger.
row.Title: answers.OnStartups self-evaluation: let's get critical!

row.Body:
Upto what extent is MBA useful in launching and running startups?

What do you think about this question and its answers? Vote and comment to let everyone know.

Can a patent troll sue an overseas company?

What do you think about this question and its answers? Vote and comment to let everyone know.

What is the best way to prepare and e-file Form 1120

What do you think about this question and its answers? Vote and comment to let everyone know.

Should I use a separate domain name for each of my apps?

What do you think about this question and its answers? Vote and comment to let everyone know.

Selling a Startup

What do you think about this question and its answers? Vote and comment to let everyone know.

Is it safe to use a trademarked name in a domain name?

What do you think about this question and its answers? Vote and comment to let everyone know.

Accepting monies from customers

What do you think about this question and its answers? Vote and comment to let everyone know.

Acquiring a website with unclear ownership

What do you think about this question and its answers? Vote and comment to let everyone know.

Get financial information for a competitor

What do you think about this question and its answers? Vote and comment to let everyone know.

Is it worth it to create an LLC through NOLO

What do you think about this question and its answers? Vote and comment to let everyone know.

I have seen a few questions where the op is looking for a investor, a partner, workers etc.

Are they ok to ask (I can't figure that out by just reading they FAQ, I feel the answer to that sort of question benefits "the rest", but if the answer is more of you apply to see they dragons by xyz or similar they sort of do) ?

If they are not, what should I as a user do (I have flagged a few for moderation, but if they are off topic or similar, I (think) I can cast a vote to close) ?
row.Title: Are matchmaking questions ok?

row.Body:
The community and the moderators have consistently closed the match-making questions.

Note however, that questions about HOW to find matches are typically left open. (Though they are probably duplicates of ones that already exist.)

My opinion is that the general question of HOW to find matches are ON-TOPIC, but a specific request for a match is off-topic (and likely the best reason is "too localized" (in both time and other scopes)

You can certainly vote to close any time you feel the question is off topic or for other reasons. We encourage you to apply the FAQ policies as best you can. One user vote will not close a question - except if done by a moderator - so you are not hurting the site for casting your vote.

Flag when you see things that need moderator attention. It's probably not necessary to flag an off-topic question unless there is something unusual or offensive about it.

Those questions are off-topic. See Are "Co-founders wanted" posts on topic?.

You need 500 rep to cast a vote to close, so you do not have that ability at the moment. Your only options at the moment are to:

  • Leave the OP a comment in hopes that he will edit his question to be on-topic for us. You can include a link to either this meta question or the one I linked to above. Leaving a comment may also encourage those who do have vote priviledges to vote to close the question.
  • Flag the question as off-topic. You shouldn't "abuse" the flagging option. Flag in special circumstances, for example if you have less than 500 rep or if you happen to stumble upon an old question that isn't currently visible on the main site list and is likely to go unnoticed. (Those with close vote priviledges should vote to close, and not use a flag instead of casting a vote.)
  • Downvote the question. If you downvote, I highly recommend that you also leave the OP a friendly comment indicating the reason his question is off-topic for our site.
Checked the notify box after questions and just realized I never receive emails. Bug?
row.Title: Bug? Not receiving emails for answers to questions

row.Body:
Yeah, its on meta.stackexchange.com already... known issue.

They said it's because they didn't think it was necessary, since that feature wasn't on StackOverflow for the first 6 months.

Yeah fine, but then don't say it works, right?

...

Update: Unfortunately, we didn't get enough people willing to write the blog posts to make this happen. Maybe we can try again next year. I posted summaries of all the presentations on the Business of Software blog. You can get to them from here.

Update (Aug 9): This has received a lot of upvotes, but so far only two people have said they are willing to write a blog post. I need a few more people to come forward before I can take this to SE for approval.

(This is just an idea at the moment. I'm looking for community feedback.)

The Business of Software conference is a couple of months away. In the past, Stack Exchange has sponsored community members to relevant community events, and I'd like to try to get someone from the OnStartups community a sponsorship to this year's Business of Software conference.

How It Will Work

The idea behind the Stack Exchange conference sponsorships is to increase awareness of the site and recruit new members. So with that in mind, here's my idea:

We'll run a contest here on the OnStartups site to choose one winner to attend the conference. To be eligible, the OnStartups community member must write a blog post related to a question and answer thread from this site. The community member must link to the Q&A thread related to their blog post, and expand on what has already been mentioned or add a new perspective to it.

The blog post will be hosted on the Business of Software blog as a guest post.* Once a blog post has been published on the BoS blog, we'll post a link to it here on meta. Each blog post will be listed as a separate answer, then the community can vote for each blog post individually. The author of the blog post with the most votes will get the conference sponsorship.

Benefit

The idea is to get in front of a large audience of business and startup enthusiasts, and hopefully encourage some of them to become active participants of our community.

Details To Work Out

  • Since the goal is to attract experts to participate on our site, we'll want to showcase our good, quality content. Therefore, we'll want to make sure we are picking good Q&A threads from our site, and not old threads that are no longer good examples of Q&A on the site. We'll have to figure out a way to vet the threads being selected for the blog posts. I'm not sure on the best way to do this, so I'm looking for feedback from you all.

  • Since this is an OnStartups community event, we want to reward someone from the community. So, do we want to set a minimum rep required to participate? I think we should in order to prevent people who have no interest in the community from showing up, entering the contest, and never coming back. If we do set a minimum rep, what should it be? I'm thinking it should be something low, like less than 300 rep.

  • In addition, there are probably other issues I haven't thought of. I'm looking for suggestions and feedback on this idea.

I have not approached Stack Exchange about this yet. I'd like to get community involvement before I approach them with this idea. If SE sees that the OnStartups community is strongly behind this, odds are they will agree to this. That means you need to comment, answer, and vote on this thread if you want it to happen.

What do you think of this? Would you be willing to write a blog post for a chance at a conference sponsorship? Any details I'm overlooking? Please discuss.

*This won't be a problem. The BoS organizer has already approved the use of the BoS blog for this.
row.Title: Attend the Business of Software conference for free and help the community

row.Body:
Great idea! I have been part of this community since the beginning (user #42) and I would like for it to continue growing and reaching more aspiring and experienced entrepreneurs around the globe.

Having been to the Business of Software conference before I can assure everyone that this IS a conference you want (and need) to attend if you have a software/internet startup.

Regardless of SE approving this or not, I believe this is a great idea and will be writing some blog posts around a few topics I started that have been popular in this forum.

Zuly,

I think its a good idea, there are a few questions:

Sponsorship/Prizes:

  • What does the sponsorship cover? Being an Aussie, should I enter my costs to get there are higher than someone who lives there, I assume it is entry to the event?.
  • Are you taking Sponsorship donations? Does the sponsoring company get a mention, or advertising around the event/winner?
  • Would the top 10 blogs get showcased somewhere, its good exposure for the bloggers to participate.

Blog

  • Can senior (top 20 or so) participate or is this more to draw new people in?. I think it should be to raise profiles and drive newer people.
  • Can we get a list of examples for "good topics" or "too old"?

Judging

  • How is it to be judged? and by who?
  • Can judges also blog?

Each entry goes in as a specific type question and the community votes?

Sorry about the phrasing, but I don't know how to express it better.

A user asked a question, which was downvoted. He got answers. Anyway he decided to remove his question and replaced it with -----. It is of course pretty ugly.

Please look at this to understand better what I mean: http://answers.onstartups.com/posts/40984/revisions

How do we deal with that? Rollback because it is vandalism? Delete it, because this was the users intention?
row.Title: How to deal with vandalism to own questions?

row.Body:
Some guidance would be helpful here.

How should one nicely promote the fact that a person should accept an answer to a question? I'm assuming that if someone never accepts an answer people will become less interested in answering the question.

An example is this user - a two year member, asked 50 questions and never accepted an answer.

Bottom line: Is it appropriate to ask low acceptance rate users to accept an answer?

You have asked quite a few questions and yet have a zero accept rate. As a courtesy, please consider accepting one of the answers.
row.Title: Addressing accept rate

row.Body:
Stack Exchange doesn't allow vandalism of any kind, whether it be to one's own post or someone else's.

If you spot vandalism, the best course of action is to immediately roll it back to the previous version, as @jimg has done, and then flag it for moderator attention with an explanation that the post has been vandalized.

What happens to the user?

The moderators will keep an eye on the user in question and take action as necessary. We can contact the user privately to point out that vandalism is not allowed. If the behavior persists, we have the option to temporarily suspend the user.

What happens to the vandalized post?

If the post is of low quality, off-topic, offensive or is otherwise inappropriate for the site, the moderators will delete the post. If it is a good quality post, we'll keep an eye on it to make sure it doesn't get vandalized again, and if necessary, we will lock the post to prevent it from continuing to be edited.

In this particular case, this is a question that has been asked several times before on the site, so I have closed it as a duplicate.

Additional resources from MSO

  • How to deal with cases of vandalism?
  • Removing SO questions by replacing title and content with "......................."?
  • How should we treat posts that are vandalized by their original authors?
If this site is open to listening to suggestions where do I go to make them?
row.Title: Where do I post or send suggestions for improving this site?

row.Body:
If it's a suggestion specific to this site, you would post it here.

If it's a suggestion regarding the Stack Exchange platform in general, you would post it on Meta Stack Overflow.

This is a contentious subject.

Having a low accept rate isn't necessarily an indicator of a bad citizen. It could be that we as a community did not do a good job answering their questions, or that their questions are badly worded and could use some editing help. I think it's fairly obvious that the example you cite in your question is a case of a bad citizen, and not a reflection of our community's expertise. In fact, according to that user's profile he has voted 0 times! But let's put that aside for the moment.

Background

A lot of folks on Meta Stack Overflow dislike seeing comments regarding accept rates, even if it's done in a friendly manner. On Stack Overflow, accept rate comments are routinely flagged and deleted. There is even a feature request to eliminate displaying a user's accept rate. I think the disdain for accept rate comments stems from the fact that some of the comments may have come across as rude, but I can't say for sure.

That said, I think this is one of those areas where we have the freedom to come up with our own guidelines as a community.

What should be the OnStartups policy?

We should decide as a community how we want to handle these type of comments, but personally, I don't see anything wrong with leaving new users guidance on how accepting an answer works, as long as it is done in a friendly manner. We are encouraged to teach new users how our site works in every other area, so why not with accepting answers?

I can tell you that as of right now the OnStartups community does not flag these type of comments. And if I see them, I do not delete them, assuming the comments aren't rude. (I'm currently following the advice here, which says that friendly comments are fine.) To me these comments are in the same category as comments explaining what constitutes an answer and why non-answers are deleted, comments explaining why a question is off-topic for our site, or any other comment that aims to instruct a new user on how our somewhat unique rules work.

My recommendation is that it is fine to leave comments on accepting answers as long as:

  • It is a friendly comment.
  • It focuses on how accepting an answer works, and not on the individual's current accept rate.
  • [optional] It contains a link to How does accepting an answer work?.
