Maybe something along the lines of:

Welcome to OnStartups! I noticed that you have a low accept rate. You may not be aware of it, but our site gives you ability to choose which was the best answer you received. It's a nice way of saying "thank you" to those that helped you. It also serves as an indicator to others that are having a similar problem. You can learn about how accepting an answer works here.

What shouldn't we do?

What we don't want to do is badger people about their accept rates, or encourage people to accept a wrong or non-useful answer just for the sake of getting their accept rate up. The point of accepting an answer is to signal to the rest of the Internet that, that was the most helpful answer. We don't want others to base their business decisions on bad advice.

I think this is a great idea! I do have a suggestion, though. I'd be happy to write a blog post, but surely in the spirit of the site, shouldn't the community tell me which question / answer I've contributed warrants a blog post?

PS -- I've been lucky enough to attend BOS in the past, and I can confirm the event, the speakers, the audience, the atmosphere and the networking are awesome.

Is there anyway to show that the performance of a user on OnStartups.SE a good measure of their knowledge of startups? For example, I'm aware of one user works with a lot of startups that posted an answer to my question and honestly in the realm of SE standards the answer was sub-par. That said, the current top user (Jason) to me both on and off OnStartups has a very impressive amount of smart content posted online. Is the performance of a user on OnStartups.SE a good measure of their knowledge of startups, and if so, why?
row.Title: Is the performance of a user on OnStartups.SE a good measure of their knowledge of startups?

row.Body:
Heck no. I would say I have a nice rep here (top 15% overall) ... but I know nothing about startups. I have some knowledge with the internet (domains, web sites, web development and design) and with trying to start a company while working for "the man". But besides that, I know nothing about startups.

I am on here to learn, and I try to help out wherever I can ... but if you ask me anything about Corporations, or finding startup money, or another else like that, I am clueless.

As with ANY forum or QA site, you need to look at the person's other answers to see how knowledgeable they are.

Really makes no sense to me at this point why I'm not given an alert that a question was closed given the inbox notification system is now in place.

I know this question has been asked before, but to my knowledge SE has never stated why they won't deploy this alert.
row.Title: Inbox alert for closed questions

row.Body:
I'm a moderator over at Pro Webmasters, the stack exchange site for websites. I've noticed that there has been a lot of overlap between Pro Webmasters and Onstartups, and that there are a lot of questions related to websites, seo, and community on Onstartups that are also on topic over at webmasters.

Are website related questions supposed to be ontopic at Onstartups? And if they aren't, could you close or migrate some of those questions?
row.Title: Are questions related to websites on topic?

row.Body:
It depends.

Questions related to personal websites or blogs: No.

Questions related to business websites: Maybe.

We don't have any hard rules on this, and it really depends on the question.

We do close some website related questions. For example:

  • What is the most valueable ad realestate on a blog?
  • How much does it cost to get verified by EV SSL Certificate?
  • is it 15 visitors a day is sufficient enough to attract advertisers to my website?

(If you want any of those flag them for migration.)

You'll probably find a lot of old website related questions, and other offtopic questions, from our early days. Back then we allowed just about anything, and have since gotten more strict with what's allowed. However, SE staff has said that mods are not to migrate old questions (there are a couple of reasons for that). Therefore, I'm not going to migrate any of our old offtopic questions to any SE site, unless the destination site specifically says they want that question.

There's no question in your post, but I'm assuming the question is

Why don't we receive notifications when a question of ours is closed?

That's completely out of our hands.

That's an SE decision. It could be that they disagree with the request, or it could be that they agree with the request, but have more important features ahead of this one on their list. If SE has never stated why they haven't implemented this, there's no way anyone here can tell you why.

If this is a feature you would like to see implemented, the best approach is to request it on MSO. However, it has already been requested many times in the past on MSO, including this one which you posted an answer to, so it doesn't make any sense to ask again since it will just be closed as a duplicate.
I would like to advertise my site on this site. Is it possible, if yes how do I start?
row.Title: How do I advertise on this site?

row.Body:
If you take a look at the advertisement on the right it says 'Powered by influAds' which links to http://influads.com/ . That is probably your best place to start.

Otherwise check the hosts to the right and tweet them directly!

I have a question about a specific trademark situation.

Is it appropriate to ask such a question here with reference to my own product names?

I don't want my question to be perceived as advertorial, but I'm really unsure how I should react in the situation...

I run a very small ISV, so we don't have any resources to handle such legal issues. I'm therefore wondering:
1) Do I have a case?
2) What should I do to handle the situation as best as possible?

The case: (Feel free to delete if inappropriate)

Our software is named "Smart Mobile Studio" (http://www.SmartMobileStudio.com) and that name is trademarked: http://tess2.uspto.gov/bin/showfield?f=doc&state=4009:krp20j.2.1
Embarcadero (http://embarcadero.com) has revealed that they will release a product named "Mobile Studio" in their next XE3 release: http://www.felix-colibri.com/papers/delphi/delphi_xe3_info/delphi_xe3_info.html#ios
row.Title: Is it appropriate to ask about specific trademark-issues?

row.Body:
We can answer general trademark questions, but asking a trademark question about a specific name is too localized. We've closed such questions in the past as duplicates of this question, which should provide you with general guidance on the topic.

So to answer your question, no it wouldn't be appropriate to ask trademark questions about specific names.

There seems to be a lot of legal questions. I feel like these aren't great for the on startups site. Often, the answers can't and shouldn't be relied upon (most often ask a lawyer is the best response).

Is there a reason these are kept as on topic? I don't think onstartups should be a place people come for legal advice and I think it dilutes the quality of the site (a bit too much noise to signal ratio).

Do people think these are appropriate? If not, can something be changed?
row.Title: Are legal questions in the best interest of OnStartups?

row.Body:
I guess startup-ers are most concerned about legal dilemmas, then.

And that's not strange at all. As a startup-er, you have very limited resources to deal with such matters, and you know that such issues can sc**w your business - even before you've reached the point of "now we've started"-feeling.

I don't believe that the average StackExchange-user will take any StackExchange-answer as a "legal advise".

I rather believe that these users would want some startup-advice on how to deal with such legal situation. Startup-er to Startup-er.

From our FAQ:

Our advertising rates are quite reasonable; contact our ad sales team for details.

You love your site and we love your site, but there is a whole world of people out there who might not even know it exists. When they do find it, their first impression will either scare them away or keep them around. Given this, let's take a hard look at the questions and answers here and make sure newcomers see the site at its best!

Below you'll find ten questions randomly selected from this site. What do you think about each of them and their answers? Are they the best they can be or can they be improved? Would they look interesting and inviting to an outsider or are they a little embarrassing?

Upvote the corresponding post here on meta when we're awesome. Downvote when our content just isn't quite up to par.

Oh, and do comment to let everyone know your thoughts and take part in this conversation. :)

Note: This evaluation will close on 26 September 2012. Get your votes in!
row.Title: OnStartups Self-Evaluation -- Let's Get Critical!

row.Body:
Need to suggest client seek legal advice - how do I word this to them?

What do you think about this question and its answers? Vote and comment to let everyone know.

How to compare contract rates with permanent rates, in UK

What do you think about this question and its answers? Vote and comment to let everyone know.

Can a firm buy itself?

What do you think about this question and its answers? Vote and comment to let everyone know.

What are your experience on business in making windows phone7 apps vs windows8 apps?

What do you think about this question and its answers? Vote and comment to let everyone know.

Private company ownership

What do you think about this question and its answers? Vote and comment to let everyone know.

How important is market size? And how small is too small?

What do you think about this question and its answers? Vote and comment to let everyone know.

Freelance Designers "Quality"- Portfolio vs. Results

What do you think about this question and its answers? Vote and comment to let everyone know.

Can vesting schedule apply to non-founding officers?

What do you think about this question and its answers? Vote and comment to let everyone know.

How to sell services to companies? How proceed to contact?

What do you think about this question and its answers? Vote and comment to let everyone know.

Is bootstrap a startup development methodology?

What do you think about this question and its answers? Vote and comment to let everyone know.

I noticed that there tends to be some confusion on this site as to what makes an acceptable answer, even among some high rep users. I'm reposting this thread here from MSO in an effort to address some of the confusion.

I answered a question and my answer was (pick one)

  • deleted
  • converted to a comment
  • added to my question as an edit

Why was this? Why was my answer not acceptable?

What is the definition of an acceptable answer on Stack Exchange?
row.Title: What is an acceptable answer?

row.Body:
The following is an excerpt from yoda's excellent answer on MSO. It was written for Stack Overflow, so it focuses on programming related questions and answers, but it can still be applied to our site.

Consider a hypothetical question:

How can I foo the bar in X?
I'm trying to foo the bar using qux. However, I get an error message <error>. What am I doing incorrectly?

When should I post a comment and when should I post an answer?

If your response is:     then it should be: Corrective action    Flag as NaA

 1 Can you post your     comment on the     If you wrote an          Yes
   code?                  question           answer, delete it 
                                             and leave a comment 
                                             instead. If you 
                                             don't have 50 rep,
                                             please wait until 
                                             you do.

 2 Have you fooed the baz?     "                    "                Yes

 3 What version of X are       "                    "                Yes
   you using?                 

 4 I've had the same           "                    "                Yes
   problem since 
   version X.1

 5 You missed a comma,         "            Vote to close as         Yes
   which is causing                          too localized.
   the error

 6 This was discussed in       "            Vote to close as         Yes
   this question and answer                  duplicate.
   [internal link]


 7 The accepted answer   comment on the     Write a better answer    Depends
   is incorrect or no     answer             of your own or notify 
   longer accurate.                          the answerer.

 8 You cannot do that    an answer          Link to documentation    No
   in X because it                           if possible.
   doesn't support Y.

 9 This is what you're        "                    "                 No
   doing incorrectly. 
   [Explain]. Here's how it
   should be done [code]

10 Try this: [code]           "             Improve the answer.      No
                                             Explain why you think 
                                             that's the solution.  
                                             If it's a code only 
                                             answer, use comments to explain.

11 This is the problem:       "             If it's an external      No
   [Explain]. In a                           link, it helps to 
   related answer/blog                       document the key points 
   post, I/they discuss                      here so that the crux 
   blah [link] which might                   of the post is available 
   be of interest                            even if the link goes down. 
                                             Do it yourself or leave 
                                             a comment for the OP.

12 See here:            be heavily          The answer must be       Depends
   [external link]       improved            improved as described 
                                             above, else it will be deleted. 
                                             Downvote if link is tangential to
                                             the question. Write a new answer 
                                             with details and then flag as 
                                             Not an Answer. 
                                             Also flag if the link is broken.


13 I've tried these     a new question      If you have +75 rep,     Yes
   solutions and it                          consider placing a bounty
   doesn't work on                           to seek a better answer.
   [operating system].                       If not (or if it's
   How should I modify the                   different enough), 
   solution to make it work?                 ask a new question.

14 Thanks man,          deleted              Glad it worked, but     Yes
    this worked!!1!                           seriously, just 
                                              upvote it if you have 
                                              the reputation.

15 Sir, I am having a   deleted with         Do not encourage these   Yes
   similar project       extreme              users to ask new questions - 
   this is due           prejudice            they're most likely 
   tomorrow. Can you                          going to be closed.
   please send me the code 
   for your project at [email]

Why should they be that way?

The first three responses are clearly asking for more information and don't answer the question. Fourth is merely a "me too" statement – adds nothing of value. If the only problem with the code is OP's clumsiness or if it's a dupe, they should be closed as "Too localized" or "Exact duplicate" respectively. If the former, the question should also be deleted (either by a mod or by 10k+ users). While #7 is helpful, it still doesn't answer the question. It is good practice to let the OP know that things have changed. If they don't respond, downvote and either move on or write a better answer if you know.

Responses #8,9 and 11 are what we'd like to see on this site. They are to the point, precise and informative. If you're referencing an earlier answer (could also be an external link), provide a crucial summary so as to make the answer self sufficient. This is important for two reasons: having the summary helps in the case of link rot (i.e., external links are dead because their site shut down) and to not have to make people click through a whole bunch of links just to get to the answer. They can proceed if they like what they see. It always helps to link to the relevant documentation/authoritative sources (quoting the important information) in your answers. Remember, in all these cases, you should cite the source(s) that you quoted (it is a good practice to make it explicit that you're quoting yourself). Feel free to edit them in an answer (not yours) if the OP hasn't done so, for after all, this is a collaboratively edited site.

Responses #10 and #12 are curt, and perhaps the most contentious of all. These are quite tricky as they do in fact answer the question, but not in a way that is considered a good answer. Moderators and frequent users generally try to encourage these users to expand on them or quote relevant parts. True, it is tempting to just leave a link and walk off as in #12. However, remember that the answers that you're leaving are not just for the person who asked the question, but for practically anyone who visits that page. If you're not willing do that, then it probably is a good idea to not post that link in the first place. #10, while technically the solution to the question, gives no indication or explanation as to why that is the solution. Beyond this, there is nothing much that can be done other than let the votes speak for itself. However, if you flag these as "Not an answer", you better be prepared for a loss in flag-weight. The only time it's acceptable to bring these to a moderator's attention is if the link is dead and there's nothing to indicate what might've been there.

Responses #13–15 are self explanatory, but please, do not encourage users who post #15 to ask questions here.

The problem isn't that people might take it as legal advice. It's a concern, for sure, but the big problem with legal questions is that they can't be answered authoritatively.

Stack Exchange answers should strive to be the authoritative answer. When people come from Google searches, the answers they see should hopefully provide them with the answers they seek.

However, I do believe legal issues are part of the Startup space; therefore, I propose doing what some sites have done with subjective questions: Implement the "back it up" rule for any answers that have a legal component to them. If you're going to answer the question, you either need to quote a source or explain how you dealt with the same issue in your own experience.

Answers that don't comply with the "back it up" rule could, and probably should, be downvoted, and a comment could be left encouraging the answerer to make an edit and improve the post.

As an aside, at the end, it's also wise to add a disclaimer, just to let anyone know that they really do need to talk to a lawyer for maximum risk-reduction.

I was just looking for some clarification on the nature / purpose of this site, wondering if it's suitable for freelancers to ask questions, discuss topics and get help/advice?

Freelancers not, strictly speaking, being entrepreneurs and often the kind of subjects discussed by either group may differ to a greater or lesser extent. But this seemed like the most likely place of all the SE sites.

Thanks.
row.Title: Is this site a suitable place for freelancers to discuss and/or request help and advice?

row.Body:
I would say it really depends on what your question is about. The FAQ here is pretty broad:

Answers.onstartups.com is a site for entrepreneurs starting and running new businesses.

Topics include financing, hiring employees, legal, marketing, sales, compensation plans, banking, payroll, benefits, and more. This is the place to come with specific questions or to seek specific advice from your peers.

If you're a freelancer, and your question is about a problem you're facing starting your freelancing business, it's probably on-topic. With that said, I'd strongly suggest avoiding anything that leans towards discussions, unless you do it in OnStartups Chat. Also, make sure your question has plenty of detail about your particular problem. This typically means your question will need to be more than just a mere sentence or two.

Lastly, consider that the purpose of Stack Exchange sites, such as OnStartups, is to be a resource of knowledge not just for you, but for future visitors, so if your question is something that others may Google for, and the answers would help those people as well, then that would be a great question for the site!

Hope this helps!

I've asked a question regarding the business strategy of a major brand. The intent, I would think is clear, is to understand more about business by analyzing an established corporation.

Is there a problem with analyzing strategic elements of other business plans and models?

I'm not speaking about the whole plan of another company, nor discussion-oriented 'anything goes'. In my specific case I was raising a question about the demographic target for a service that was clearly of no use to certain demographics. I presumed a 'best' answer would outline several demographics and give reasoning for why they targets.

How is that against our policies? What is a better way to word this question?

Examples

Here are a list of questions that a feel are truly (or moreso than mine) open-ended and discussion-oriented, which yet that remain on the site, with upvotes, and accepted answers:

  • what-is-a-good-imap-email-program-for-biz :this is an unbounded solicitation for opinions.
  • recommendations-for-off-site-storage-back-up-service-for-our-start-up :here they specifically solicit discussion as the 'answer' of their question.
  • is-it-a-good-idea-to-virtualize-your-server-for-multiple-app-clients :this question solicits basic understanding about a tool.
  • how-do-i-specifically-start-a-business-as-a-government-defense-supplier :this is 4-5 questions in one.

(I actually respect any and all info on the obscure topic of GovBiz.)

I, like many others, also appreciate learning about other ideas of the state of a given industry, it's practices, or other conventions that drive financial decisions. This is why I raise this meta-question.
row.Title: What could be wrong with asking a question that seeks an analytical dimension of a business plan?

row.Body:
There are a few reasons I felt it inappropriate for the site. The most significant is:

  • (from the FAQ) "You should only ask practical, answerable questions based on actual problems that you face."

The question linked above does not show how it is relevant for startups and poses no actual problem. It appears to be an introduction to a discussion.

The users and moderators have been fairly consistent in closing similar questions that asked open-ended things about why a particular company has a strategy or what its market is. These types of questions are clearly subjective and discussion-oriented.

There is nothing wrong with the curiosity and subject - it is just not a fit for this site based on the goal(s) of this site.

There are probably a few ways you could re-ask the question to make it specific for a problem you have or for your startup, but as it stands now it is not a great fit.

You have pointed out other questionable questions. We appreciate users who flag questions they feel inappropriate and if you have enough reputation points you can vote to close inappropriate questions.

We encourage all users to participate in that process.

EDIT

I have closed one of the questions you added to your text above. Two of the others are very old questions that were posed when the site was a different entity and not moderated in the same way as it is now.

You ask:

Is there a problem with analyzing strategic elements of other business plans and models?

The answer to that is of course, "no, there is no problem with analyzing...". However, this site is not meant to be a discussion forum or a place to "analyze strategic elements of other business plans and models." It is a Q&A forum.

There are other places to go to discuss ideas and concepts. If this Q&A format does not fit your needs for some of the things you wish to discuss, please use those other outlets.

We appreciate you pointing out the discrepancies and inconsistencies. The site is moderated by volunteers and we do our best to make it better. Feel free to flag any questions you feel are inappropriate.

To answer your question (yet again):

  • The question is subjective.
  • The question is not about a specific problem that a startup faces.
  • The question is open ended and not answerable - it is an invitation to a discussion.

I propose a "time-based" tag, which lets people know that the question (& answer, if any) are subject to near-term exportation or staleness. The same would be applied to old questions that are dated and no longer very relevant.

Some questions are timeless.

Other questions address situations that change, such as

  1. demographic practices,
  2. uses for tools that may come & go,
  3. practices governed by laws that have changed.

Such a tag could also be a compromising ground against closing questions that are otherwise valuable.
row.Title: Create a time-based for content that will, or is now, dated?

row.Body:
A quick google of "amazon lockers" results in plenty of articles and posts about the move. (over a year old by now)

I found plenty of explanations of the goal(s) in a Wall Street Journal article. (And others)

http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10000872396390443545504577567763829784538.html

It has been said that SE Core discourages meta-tags that are status-oriented.

The Death of Meta Tags

The FAQ states:

What kind of questions can I ask here?

Answers.onstartups.com is a site for entrepreneurs starting and running new businesses.

Topics include financing, hiring employees, legal, marketing, sales, compensation plans, banking, payroll, benefits, and more. This is the place to come with specific questions or to seek specific advice from your peers.

If you look at the tags page, you'll see some of the topics that are discussed here.

Please avoid:

  • Wide open questions. Don't write a sentence and expect to get a page back. A question like "How can I sell more of my product" deserves an encyclopedia article. Try to scale back to something more specific.
  • "Rate my business", "Please review my startup", "What do you think about my web page" or "What do you think about my company name". If you have a specific question, that's fine, but if you want feedback on your business, ask your friends and colleagues, and, even better, ask some people who might be your customers.
  • "Help me come up with a business idea" or "Help me come up with a company name".

The close reason on your post states (with my own added emphasis):

As it currently stands, this question is not a good fit for our Q&A format. We expect answers to be supported by facts, references, or specific expertise, but this question will likely solicit debate, arguments, polling, or extended discussion. If you feel that this question can be improved and possibly reopened, see the FAQ for guidance.

While you aren't wrong -- analyzing the movements of major players can prove beneficial to entrepreneurs, this is not the place for those questions. Here, we are focused on the launching and running of a brand new enterprise. Your question, about an established and market-dominant company's actions, fits neither requirement.

What you're asking is something an MBA seminar might tackle. While your question is in no way invalid, it also isn't the type of question that we are built for. Stack Exchange is a platform where concrete, answerable questions can find a home. A question like yours, which is good for a forum, group discussion, web-/seminar, or podcast, is too broad for what we do here.

I hope this helps; if not, let me know and I'll do my best to clarify.

Today I found the tag "advice".

Does it really make sense? Not sure, but maybe we can close it. I mean... every question here is seeking for advice, right?
row.Title: The "advice" tag

row.Body:
I've been reviewing first time posts this morning and I've seen several answers that answer the question fairly well, but then the answerer goes on to say something like "and if you need more help my company can do this kind of work for a reasonable fee".

On the one hand they do answer the question and they do disclose that they are a company, but then they still end up posting what is an advertisement. This doesn't fall into the spam category as described on the flag dialog because there is disclosure.

Is this kind of answer acceptible?
row.Title: How to handle answers where the poster advertises his service, but discloses his affiliation?

row.Body: If you're asking my advice, I say get rid of it.

Name: Entrepreneuring

Elevator: Learn from someone else's mistakes for a change

Tagline: Startup growth e-hormone

Motto: You want to start something?

You're right. We should get rid of the advice tag. That tag has been on my radar for some time now. I just haven't had the time to take on that task.

Why should it be removed?

advice is a meta tag that does nothing to help you figure out what the question is about. As you said, in essence all questions on this site are seeking advice in some form or another.

There's a blog post that explains what meta tags are and why they're not allowed.

How can we remove it?

We have two options for eliminating the tag:

  • Manual: We would need to manually go into every question tagged advice and remove the tag from the question. Sadly, advice is the second most popular tag on this site, currently with 805 instances. Going the manual route is a huge undertaking, especially when you consider that only a handful of us will be working on this. Another downside to the manual approach is that even if we manage to remove it from all current questions, it can still be recreated in the future.
  • Automatic: Stack Exchange has the ability to blacklist tags. This would automatically remove the tag from all questions, and prevent it from being used in the future. Moderators do not have the power to blacklist tags, so we would need to ask one of the Stack Exchange developers to do this for us.

My preference is to ask Stack Exchange to blacklist the tag. However, they're not big fans of blacklisting tags, so I'm not sure if they will agree to it. I can approach them about this and see where it goes.

If they blacklist the tag, we may end up with some untagged questions, which we'll need to manually tag, but it should be a much smaller job than retagging 805 questions.

What do you think?

Burninated.

Please care for the widows and orphans.

Make "product-launch" a synonym to "launch".

I think both are the same. How can one achieve that? (assuming others here are fine with my suggestion)

In the same vein: "customer-feedback" should be a synonym to "feedback"
row.Title: Synonym suggestions

row.Body:
How can one achieve that? (assuming others here are fine with my suggestion)

The rules for suggesting and creating tag synonyms are:

Users with more than 1250 reputation and a total answer score of 5 or more on the tag, can suggest tag synonyms. Users with a total answer score (total upvotes minus total downvotes) of 5 or more on the tag, can vote for tag synonyms. Suggestions will be automatically approved when they reach a score of 4, and automatically deleted when they reach a score of -2.

Alternatively, moderators have the ability to immediately create tag synonyms. Since we currently don't have too many active users with the ability to suggest and approve tag synonyms, all tag synonyms so far have been done by moderators. We usually try to get consensus on meta before creating the synonyms, so if you get support for your suggestions here, I’ll be happy to create the synonyms.

"customer-feedback" should be a synonym to "feedback"

I’m not a fan of feedback. I think it’s too generic and ambiguous, and doesn’t really help identify the topic of the question, which is the purpose of tags. It may also give new users the false impression that it’s OK to ask for feedback on startup ideas, business names, pitches, etc. We even discussed eliminating the tag altogether during our last cleanup effort.

I would prefer to see feedback as a synonym to customer-feedback, although I’m not sure if it’s a good idea to make a broad tag a synonym of a much narrower tag. Are there other types of feedback, other than customer feedback, that would be on-topic for this site? I can’t think of any off the top of my head right now, but there might be.

My suggestion would be to leave customer-feedback as is, and manually remove feedback from the five questions that are currently tagged with it. Thoughts?

Make "product-launch" a synonym to "launch".

I’m fine with this suggestion if others agree.

Our meta site was down for two (or three?) days due to Hurricane Sandy taking down the Stack Exchange NY servers. At least one of our community members was in the process of earning the Enthusiast badge during this time. Can we give those users that visited meta on the day before the site went down a free entry in the visit log for each day that it was down?

This request is similar to this one.
row.Title: Can we get a few free days in the visit log to account for the Sandy downtime?

row.Body:
Yes we can, but not right now. Here's the deal: we don't control the DNS for the special OnStartups arrangement. Since we don't and the DNS updates on their side seem to take a while, we're going to have this issue again when we switch back to the New York datacenter.

This will (we really hope) be approximately 2-6 weeks from now. I'd love to give a better estimate but we honestly don't know yet, the building our primary datacenter was in was heavily damaged by hurricane Sandy. These was flooding and massive damage to the electrical infrastructure there - we are still on generator power at this time. There is also diesel fuel in the building causing hazardous conditions and very few people are allowed in. This combined with no grid power for the elevators means we cannot get our servers out - this is causing delays in all our plans.

Apologies for the inconvenience, it just doesn't make the time investment in fixing the missed days a priority right now, since it'll break again in a few weeks. Once we are all moved in and good to go, I'll personally fill in these days and make sure the badges are granted.
Per Zuly's comment, I'm raising a suggestion to create a united-states synonym to usa. "united-states" is used in personal finance @SE and other areas, and for consistency should also be available.
row.Title: Synonym Suggestion: [united-states] > [usa]

row.Body:
I disagree with this proposal.

First, time-based questions that are only relevant for a short period of time are explicitly disallowed on Stack Exchange. It doesn't make sense to create a special tag for a category of questions that are against the site's policy, and will be closed.

From the FAQ:

Common reasons a question may be closed include:

...

too localized: This question is unlikely to help any future visitors; it is only relevant to a small geographic area, a specific moment in time, or an extraordinarily narrow situation that is not generally applicable to the worldwide audience of the internet. For help making this question more broadly applicable, see the FAQ.

In fact, the time sensitivity of shopping recommendation questions is one of several reasons why these type of questions are not allowed on Stack Exchange.

From Q&A is Hard, Let’s Go Shopping!:

Let’s say the question asker provided all that information. Fat chance, I know, but let’s pretend for a moment they did — and we were able to provide the perfect, ideal shopping recommendation to them. Even if that was the case, technology moves so rapidly that the best shopping recommendations will be utterly obsolete within a year! What’s the point of a bunch of labor intensive questions that provide only temporary benefit to a limited (some might say Too Localized) audience? There isn’t any. That’s what we concluded, and we explicitly disallowed shopping questions in the Super User FAQ:

Second, this is the definition of a meta tag, and meta tags are not allowed on Stack Exchange.

If an answer (or part of a question) becomes outdated, the correct action is to edit it to make it current.

What jobs can I apply for after startup fails?

I think this question belongs to the community and should not be closed.

In first place, it alienates the user, which is obviously new around.
Secondly I think the mod is little bit bored at home editing almost any content and closing questions like this, without even trying to improve or encouraging an edit to the question so it would fit more into the community.
row.Title: Closure of this question

row.Body:
I agree with Zuly. The question is not startup related - if one removes the word startup or the fact that the person is considering leaving a startup it is just about looking for a job.

The the OP wants to elaborate or ask a specific question about VCs that might be more useful and more appropriate to the site, but again, that is not really startup related.

Not only is that question off-topic for this site, it is also very subjective and falls under the definition of "not constructive."

Why is it off-topic?

It has absolutely nothing to do with the topic of startups. It's a career advice question from someone looking for a job. (I didn't leave a comment when I closed this question, because this should be obvious.)

Why is it not constructive?

It is an extremely subjective question with zero details. It is a poll. It's a request for an infinite list of job positions. There is no right answer.

From our FAQ:

What kind of questions should I not ask here?

You should only ask practical, answerable questions based on actual problems that you face. Chatty, open-ended questions diminish the usefulness of our site and push other questions off the front page.

Your questions should be reasonably scoped. If you can imagine an entire book that answers your question, you’re asking too much.

If your motivation for asking the question is “I would like to participate in a discussion about _”, then you should not be asking here. However, if your motivation is “I would like others to explain _ to me”, then you are probably OK. (Discussions are of course welcome in our real time web chat.)

To prevent your question from being flagged and possibly removed, avoid asking subjective questions where …

• every answer is equally valid: “What’s your favorite __?”

The above section from our FAQ describes this question perfectly. I suggest you take some time to familiarize yourself with the FAQ.

I don't have the time to fix every single terrible question that's asked on this site. And some questions can't be fixed. This is supposed to be a community effort. You have the ability to leave comments and suggest edits, so if you want to take the time to fix something, go for it.

I agree with Zuly. This question has no place here. Change the time frame in the question to see just how silly it is.

"What jobs can I apply for now if I want to join a Startup in 25 years."

Any answer to either question is subjective and off topic. There is no way to improve this question.

This questions is similar to all the "What is the best..." questions we get here. There is no best, only subjective opinions all based on no real information in the question.

A very simple question:

Is OnStartups.com participating in the Winter Bash 2012?
row.Title: Participation in Winter Bash 2012

row.Body:
No, sorry.

We had to opt-in to participate. Based on the low interest from community members on past contests/events I figured it wouldn't have been worth it to post the question on meta for community feedback.

Would you have been interested in participating? We can do it next year.

The answer is (sadly) no.

Zuly doesn't like hats! I knew she was old, but I didn't know she didn't like fun! This is insane! I demand a moderator election recount-er, so no we don't have hats. :(

http://chat.stackexchange.com/transcript/1293?m=7069865#7069865

Stack Exchange has a new rule that questions over 60 days can't be migrated, even by moderators.

I found this old question that was asked during our 1.0 days that belongs on our meta, but I can't migrate it. So, I'd like to request that one of the SE devs migrate the question for us.

Note: I read the rules on getting old questions migrated by SE. However, the premise behind that procedure doesn't apply in our case, and it seems a little overkill for a one off question being migrated to our own meta site.

If the question isn't migrated, the alternative is to delete it. However, I think it's important to maintain a history of this site, since we have such a unique history.
row.Title: Request to migrate a question to meta

row.Body:
It depends. The section in the FAQ on self-promotion states:

May I promote products or websites I am affiliated with here?

Be careful, because the community frowns on overt self-promotion and tends to vote it down and flag it as spam. Post good, relevant answers, and if some (but not all) happen to be about your product or website, so be it. However, you must disclose your affiliation in your answers.

If a huge percentage of your posts include a mention of your product or website, you're probably here for the wrong reasons. Our advertising rates are quite reasonable; contact our ad sales team for details. We also offer free community promotion ads for open source projects and non-profit organizations.

So there are two components to this:

  • Disclosure
  • Percentage

Disclosing their affiliation with the product or service is a must. If they do that, that's great, however there is still the issue of excess:

... and if some (but not all) happen to be about your product or website, so be it.

and

If a huge percentage of your posts include a mention of your product or website, you're probably here for the wrong reasons.

So, even if they disclose their affiliation with the product or service, if a majority of their posts are designed to promote their product/service, I would consider it to be spam.

How the post is handled depends.

  • If all of their posts include a link to their website and there is very little useful content, flag as spam. We usually delete these.
  • If all, or most, of their posts include an advertisement for their product/service, but the posts contain useful information, leave the user a comment with a link back to the self-promotion section of FAQ (or this meta thread), and edit out the promotional parts of the post. You may also want to explain that the user profile is the place to advertise themselves. Alternatively, you can flag for moderator attention explaining that most of the user's posts contain self-promotion.
  • If this is a user's first post, leave them a comment and edit out the promotional part.

What I've found is that if a user's first couple of posts contain some kind of self-promotion, they are usually here for the wrong reasons. And as soon as they find out overt self-promotion is not welcomed here, they leave.

Man - I already have enough hats!

But I would have liked to participate anyway.

Almost all questions about options/tax/incorporation/etc. are going to depend on the jurisdiction.

Are we just assuming that world==USA (or even world==California) and tagging any exceptions? Or should we, in a spirit of international harmony, go back and mark each answer as [USA]?
row.Title: When to use a location tag?

row.Body:
No, we don't assume world==USA.

When asking a question whose answer will depend on the location (e.g. tax and legal issues), you should always indicate your location in the question. Otherwise it can't be answered.

It's important that in addition to using tags, the location be mentioned in the question text. Relying on just tags isn't a good idea, because the tags can be easily overlooked.

I don't think we should be creating location tags for every possible jurisdiction, because we'd end up with a bunch of useless one-time-use tags. Instead, we should only create location tags for the most common jurisdictions based on our audience. For the less common jurisdictions it is sufficient to simply mention it in the question text.

Also see these related questions:

  • Why aren't there country tags?
  • geographic tagging for questions

We didn't get feedback from the community on this request, but it's pretty straightforward, so I went ahead and created the tag synonym.

united-states is now a synonym of usa.

http://answers.onstartups.com/tags/usa/synonyms

Example: a spam account goes back 2 years and "answers" a question. Through moderation, the answer is correctly tagged and deleted as spam, yet in the "active questions" view the time, user and rep is displayed.

This resurrects old questions that have already been answered and makes for a confusing experience - esp. if regular account holders click on the question and see nothing new (since the spam answer has been deleted).
row.Title: Feature request: deleting answer removes username on recent activity

row.Body:
No, this is not a good idea in general. Something has happened to the question - regardless of whether or not you can see what happened, it's important that activity can't go completely unnoticed within the community. Users such as yourself (those with access to the moderation tools) can review the activity that bumped such a question, and potentially raise an alarm if something went wrong. This sort of community oversight is critical.

See also: Stop an edited deleted answer from bumping the question

Compare: How does copyright work when there are more than one copyright holders?

and How does manga fox deal with copyright issues?

What's the difference between the 2 that one is okay and the other is not?

I think the former is more legal issue rather than business issue.
row.Title: Why this question is not okay while other similar question is okay

row.Body:
Neither question is particularly good. The "how does copyright work" question could use some editing to make it clearer. To some extent, maybe that "does copyright work" question just got 'lucky' and nobody flagged it for removal (or improved it by editing it).

That said, the "how does copyright work" question contains a close-ended, concrete question to which there probably is a objectively correct answer. That question is "When there are multiple copyright holders, how does copyright assignment then work?"

In contrast, the "How does manga fox" question is:

  • More open-ended, it's not clear that there is a definitive answer to this.
  • More towards "I would like to participate in a discussion about ______" which is clearly mentioned as a red flag in the FAQ.

The difference in the two questions does not lie in one being a business and the other a legal question. It's in the degree to which the questions satisfy:

  • That a correct answer can be given.
  • That a answer can be given in reasonable amount of time -- i.e. not requiring hundreds of pages to answer correctly.
  • That the question itself applies to a number of people, so that other people may Google for this and discover the question and its answers.

The FAQ tries to make clear what is welcome here and what isn't. The blog post "QA is hard, let's go shopping" tries to explain the rationale for this, using a case from another Stack Exchange site.
I think our fav icon is not really attractive. Other sister sites are simple, yet elegant. This might be small thing, but it bothers me a lot. Why not take the white background?
row.Title: Who's responsible for answer.onstartup.com web design?

row.Body:
Stack Exchange is in charge of all Stack Exchange site designs. OnStartups uses the same design all other SE beta sites use. Once our site graduates we will get a more polished design.

See

  • http://answers.onstartups.com/faq#sketchy
  • New Beta Theme Launched
  • http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2012/03/the-new-stack-exchange-beta-theme-2

While I was reviewing Unanswered questions, I noticed Collecting donations to split between two charities? where the question has up vote but no answer.

In similar cases where the questions are local scope and IMO has limited reference value for future users, should reviewers mark these questions as too localized, or leave them be?
row.Title: What is the guideline for unanswered questions that have upvotes?

row.Body: I'd say that question is more off-topic than too localized since it doesn't really have anything to do with startups. It sounds like a pure tax question, and not one that many startups would encounter. So, I'd lean more towards closing it as off-topic, but I'd be interested to hear what the rest of the community thinks.

We all love OnStartups - Stack Exchange, but there is a whole world of people out there who need answers to their questions and don't even know that this site exists. When they arrive from Google, what will their first impression be? Let's try to look at this site through the eyes of someone who's never seen it before, and see how we stack up against the rest of the 'Net.

The Site Evaluation review queue is open and populated with 10 questions that were asked and answered in the last quarter. Run a few Google searches to see how easy they are to find and compare the answers we have with the information available on other sites.

Rating the questions is only a part of the puzzle, though. Do you see a pattern of questions that should have been closed but are not? Questions or answers that could use an edit? Anything that's going really well? Post an answer below to share your thoughts and discuss these questions and the site's health with your fellow users!
row.Title: Let's get critical: Mar 2013 Site Evaluation

row.Body:
I'm seeing quite a few unanswered questions seeking legal advice (for e.g. Equal partner is making demands that go back on our initial agreement in writing) which haven't attracted answers.

Are these unanswered questions too localized? And should we close them to reduce the unanswered "clutter"?
row.Title: Should we close question on legal that is too-localized (i.e. depends on state laws)?

row.Body:
I'm fairly new here so please pardon if my view is a minority.

I noticed that there are a number of

  • Unanswered questions.
  • Questions that had follow-up comments seeking additional info which the original poster didn't follow-up with a response.
  • Questions which has one (or more) answer that received no up votes -- and neither are the answers up voted.

My current view is the above are candidates for closing to improve the odds of searching yielding pertinent results.

I'm still trying to decide if the above is symptomatic of the topic startups which attract points of view rather than the more clear-cut "right or wrong" of programming-related SE sites. Makes me appreciate the significantly difficult balancing task that the mods of OnStartups undertake. Thanks.

Reviewing the questions, I noticed that some questions were dismissed based on experience (example: care about the job, not the options value) vs answering the underlying question (how do I figure out how much these options possibly could be worth?)

While the first answer is opinion (and likely based on experience) it invokes the "trust me, I know" model vs allowing someone to make an informed decision based on facts they have / need to have.

I would vote that some more common questions be put into a canonical answers section so we can refer to them. Those who answer "how much shares between" questions point to Joels answer, but there are others that may also be relevant or topical (like variable shares) that also should be under consideration. Perhaps these best practices could be referenced / explained in evergreen articles and kept current.

Open to suggestions, but I also see a ton of questions like - I/s(he) wanted / was told x equity, time has passed / things happen, now things changed and I/s(he) wants/deserves/demands Y equity.

Common thread is that nothing is written down.

My 2cents: Need either a facepalm / canoncal answer that we should refer to and close them as a duplicate.

Final Results

  • Workers of a subsidary purely work on products of the parent company

    Net Score: -1 (Excellent: 1, Satisfactory: 6, Needs Improvement: 2)

  • Beautiful front-end web design now or later?

    Net Score: 5 (Excellent: 6, Satisfactory: 2, Needs Improvement: 1)

  • Legal implications on being a middle man?

    Net Score: -2 (Excellent: 1, Satisfactory: 5, Needs Improvement: 3)

  • Advice on an offer from a start-up

    Net Score: 4 (Excellent: 5, Satisfactory: 2, Needs Improvement: 1)

  • Outsourcing editing / proofreading and design work

    Net Score: 0 (Excellent: 2, Satisfactory: 4, Needs Improvement: 2)

  • Tax implications of an overseas business running a Kickstarter campaign via a US or UK person's account

    Net Score: 1 (Excellent: 2, Satisfactory: 5, Needs Improvement: 1)

  • Advice on the need for a foreign subsidiary

    Net Score: 0 (Excellent: 1, Satisfactory: 6, Needs Improvement: 1)

  • How do I manage my business money vs personal money?

    Net Score: 2 (Excellent: 3, Satisfactory: 3, Needs Improvement: 1)

  • Single-member LLC and filling out tax forms for advertisers who pay me

    Net Score: 3 (Excellent: 4, Satisfactory: 2, Needs Improvement: 1)

  • Choosing between complex or simple business ideas

    Net Score: 3 (Excellent: 3, Satisfactory: 4, Needs Improvement: 0)

A year ago I answered a question related to taxes in which based upon my understanding of tax codes i stated that companies such as google would be required to pay taxes for free meals.

How much can you give employees in benefits (without tax effects)?

I have since learned from this news article that was just published

http://www.mercurynews.com/business/ci_22982220/irs-is-looking-into-whether-free-meals-at

that google does not pay the taxes for free meals but the IRS is now examining if that is wrong and should be taxed.

Since it appears my interpretation at the time was not accurate but it might be in the future, how or should I even updating the question to reflect this new information?
row.Title: How to update an old question if the information is not 100% correct?

row.Body:
By reading the FAQ I do not see any point that my question falls in. A 'book answer' could be given to every answer as most topics can be extended in different scopes and directions by everyones point of view. By asking a open end question the idea is not to make it too localized, but to make it useful to other that might search similar answer (at least give them a point). By not doing that you are making the question too localized, which could as well be answered with a book. I am participating actively in other SE sites, so I am kinda familiar with the regulations in such sites.

I am referring to this question. If I am wrong please point me my mistakes.

Thank you!
row.Title: Why should my question be considered as off-topic

row.Body: Your question, "What is the best way to do X", has no difinitive answer. Your question is as opened ended as "What is the best way to get to Los Vegas". How can anyone answer that question without knowing where you are, what modes of transportation are available to you, how fast you need to get there, and how much money you have to spend?

As someone who is a paralegal, I'd say that either the question is too vague (details matter) or else people who do know the answer (ie lawyers) are too busy to browse StackExchange. However, in the situation where I can identify the legitimate concern (and not the distracting emotional response), often the issues of fact are more important that the questions of law. The US works on the Uniform Commercial Code where state attorney generals butt heads on the substantive portions, then leave minor tinkering to individual states. What IMHO should definitely be knocked on head are tax/accounting issues as there are so many (and changing) policies that a full answer wouldn't be coherent or so lengthly to deserve a book.

I'm fortunate in that my specialty of Intellectual property and to a large extent IT is global (thanks to WIPO) but for other questions (eg labor laws) there are broad distinctions between US, European, Anglo-saxon (the commonwealth countries) and civil jurisdictions like India/China. Usually people are obliging enough to state which jurisdiction but here I tend to fall back of option A, B, C rather than specific legal steps. So far I haven't noticed any objections on fuzzy-mindedness.

I can only note that as in Bible, societies change, tech come & go, but human nature (greed, ego, pride) remain the same.

Hmmm ... I think the distinguishing factor is when does an opinion become a legal opinion. I'm inclined to leave legal-related concerns in for the simple fact that formal law is usually codified social behaviour and we all have opinions (strong or otherwise) on what is appropriate social behaviour (the lubrication of life). Whilst I am conversant with legal matters, I also make it plain that I'm not licensed to practice in a particular jurisdiction but I can help people frame the question in a form that a paid legal professional can recognise. Since they charge by the 6 minute increment, coming to a rapid understanding of the core issue save times/money during Raman noodle funding stage. But if you are absolutely reliant on my answer ... well a portion of my fees go towards professional indemnity insurance.

Objoke ... if you pay peanuts, expect to get monkeys.

Let's reframe the question ... is experience equivalent to knowledge? It's easy for peers to recall what they did, but a different matter for if something went wrong, what should be valid (or if really fortunate the absolute right) action to take? Here are were experts or specialist come into play since not only they know the answers, they can gently ask the appropriate questions. People generally learn from different sources

  • repetition (aka ingrained biases or at worst the Big Lie)
  • authority (anything from God downwards)
  • experience (school of hard knocks)

I would humbly suggest that reputation is not necessarily the same as authority, reputation is a mix of community participation, credibility and critical thinking (often sorting out the real question). Someone can be 100% confident in an answer that is totally wrong but the feedback and comments allow self-correction over time. Because authority is so domain specific (just because I know one area of IP/IT law doesn't mean I can give tax advice) I think people should treat (and perhaps encourage) StackExchange as a signpost rather than end-destination, rough rules of thumb rather than absolute dogma.

ObJoke: A bit of knowledge implies a lot of ignorance

Your question is incredibly broad. There is absolutely no way to answer it.

In addition, it's hard to understand. For example, I have no idea what the following means:

... starting up like(follow, tweet, share, etc.) exchange site ...

I also don't understand your second question or see how it's related to your first question.

But to be honest, fixing that wouldn't help. The bigger problem is the magnitude of how broad and open-ended the question is. Similar questions have been asked in the past and they always end up getting closed.

If you've tried a specific marketing technique and have not had success with it, you can ask a question related to that. But simply asking "What's the best way to promote a startup?" is not something we can reasonably answer in the space allotted.

To address your comment about being active on other SE sites, your profile actually indicates that you are still a new user on all other SE sites. The most rep you have is from Stack Overflow, but it's only 420.

Your SE activity as it stands today:

Give it some time before you get acquainted with the SE guidelines.

I'm puzzled by the lack of quality Q and A for startups on the web--especially for smaller businesses which I happen to have a particular interest in supporting. There's Quora but Quora is broader and seems more targeted to scalable startups.

There are lots of people who are starting small busineses who have questions and there lots of experienced entrepreneurs. What's going on? I've visited serveral other sites and they were overrun by spammers.
row.Title: Why aren't there more questions being asked on this site?

row.Body:
I have been told recently that some of my answers are "non-answers", whatever that means?

Personally, I prefer concise answers that don't drone on for ages. However, where I answer with just a few sentences and a pertinent link or two, I've been told off, especially by "Zuly" and accused of providing "non-answers". My answers seem to be getting several up-votes, which suggests that the wider community appreciate my brevity, so I'm confused.
row.Title: What constitutes a "non-answer"?

row.Body:
The first thing I want to clarify is that I have not been telling you off. I like to leave comments explaining the actions I take, so that users can learn from it and understand why I took that particular action.

If it's a new user, I usually try to have a much "nicer" tone, because the point is to educate them and help them understand, so that they can become active contributors of the site. With "old-timers" I'm usually a lot more brief and to the point with my comments. The reasons for that are:

  • I expect people that have been participating on the site for a while to know what the rules are. I expect that they have taken the time to read the FAQ and browse our meta site. In your case you have over 3,000 rep, and have been participatng on the site for 1 year 8 months (according to your user profile). So I consider you an experienced user.

  • It takes me a lot more time to craft a "nice" (for lack of a better word) message than a brief to the point message. Going back to the point above about experienced users already knowing the rules, I don't think my time is well spent doing that. It really shouldn't come as a shock to old users when I point out an existing rule.

When I have to keep leaving an experienced user the same comment over and over again, it starts to get a little old.

Now to answer your question about what's an acceptable answer, last year I posted a very thorough question and answer here on our meta addressing exactly that: What is an acceptable answer?. Please take the time to read it.

In your case you have a tendency to post what should be comments as answers. Answers should be exactly that - answers. Anything that is not a direct answer to the question should be posted as a comment. Additionally, Stack Exchange has a long standing rule that link-only posts are not considered answers. You also tend to post link-only posts as answers when they should be comments. If the only thing in your post is "here's a link to something that answers your question", then it's not considered an answer by SE standards. You can easily turn a link-only post into an answer by taking the time to add some details explaining what's behind that link. Both of these points are clearly stated in our FAQ.

Brevity is not the problem with your "answers." It's the lack of content. Concise answers are just fine, and well accepted. In fact, getting the same points across in as little text as possible will always work to your advantage. But you need to actually answer the question in an answer.

I know, I know, the FAQ says:

Please avoid ... "Help me come up with a company name".

But would a question like "How can I make up a good business name?" be a potentially good question? That would be merely about the process, not specific to my company.
row.Title: How to ask questions about business names?

row.Body:
Welcome to this site, and thank you for asking!

You have the right idea. :) Briefly:

  • "Please come up with my company name for me" is off topic
  • "Which characteristics must a company name have to work well in social media" is fine.

Your example "How can I make up a good business name?" could be in difficulties, depending on how it's worded. The potential problem might be if nearly every answer given to the question can be equally valid.

On this site, questions should be specific enough that answers can be judged as more or less good for the question. So as an example of a question that might be problematic, think of "Please give me some tips and ideas for naming my startup". In that question, everything which is a tip or an idea is an answer.

My question got closed. Would anyone mind which parts of the FAQ it violates?

I may modify it, but I took a lot of effort phrasing it, and trying to make it a good fit for the site. So, I'm a bit puzzled now.
row.Title: Questions about types of incubators OT?

row.Body:
If you scroll down past the comments, you'll see that your question was not closed as off-topic. It was closed as "not constructive", and there is an explanation as to what that means. Additionally, I left you a comment explaining the reason why it was being closed.

... you're either asking a yes or no question, or a "give me a list of services" poll question. Neither of which are allowed on this site ...

Those type of questions are fine for a discussion forum, but this is a Q&A site, not a discussion forum, so they are not a good fit for this site.

You received two comments before I closed your question that indicated your question wasn't clear, but you didn't edit the question to clarify. You are welcome to edit the question and we can take a look at reopening it.

We'd love to see you contribute good answers. :)

IMHO there aren't' "lots" of experienced entrepreneurs -- there are a few, and many of them already have a brutal work schedule at their startup.

There are many people who desire being in a startup, and who haven't read books about the topic (or not enough books), and who ask un-researched questions. The time it takes to create a good answer is often inversely proportional to the time taken to craft the question.

Those two points are IMHO the main reasons why there aren't more good Q&A resources about entrepreneurship.

I have a long post which gives a lot of background information to my two related questions - what is the best way to deal with this?

I am concious that if I just post the question then, without the context and background, it is (a) harder to get a "good" answer and (b) people will ask for the context anyway and I will end up editing or adding comments.

Additionally, if I post a long question less people are likely to read it so how do I find the balance?

In the FAQ, it states

Your questions should be reasonably scoped. If you can imagine an entire book 
that answers your question, you’re asking too much.

I don't feel my question needs a book to answer but it feels like a little like a book to read now so how long is too long for a question?
row.Title: How long is too long

row.Body:
Thank you for asking. And that's a very good question -- one which it is hard to answer. There is no set rule, it's a judgement call.

You might get into trouble with the "too localized" criteria for closing questions -- that's when the question is so specific that it's highly unlikely that someone else will have the same question in the future.

In general, I'd say very long questions are quite often a danger sign that Original Poster (OP):

  • is too emotionally involved, and dumps a long list of grievances with others into a more or less rhetorical question;
  • hasn't thought the question through and hasn't done basic research;
  • asks multiple questions in one post;
  • has a question which is genuinely difficult, and requires consideration of finer points of the Law, and should probably be asked to a professional lawyer instead;
  • asks a question which simply does require a book answer.

I personally wouldn't close a question just because it's long. I would ask the OP to edit it down.

For me personally, something like 2-3 paragraphs is a good size for questions here .. i.e. 10-15 lines or so. That's not to say that longer questions are necessarily "too long", but it does seem to me that very long questions often attract fewer answers.

Is it just me, or do other people get online abuse from people for voting to close questions?

This keeps happening to me, which is weird as I don't get to close the question, I just flag ones that seem inappropriate for the site rules. Someone else (moderator) always closes them, but it shows me as voting to close.

Maybe it is time to leave this site behind, as it is getting ridiculous.
row.Title: Online abuse for voting to close questions

row.Body:
I'm a community manager for Stack Exchange, I'd like to take a second and address your concerns.

Flags are confidential - only the moderators know who flagged a post and they don't reveal this information. If an action is taken on something after you've flagged it, the action is attributed to the moderator that processed your flag, and perhaps a few people who had also voted to take the same action that the moderator ultimately took.

When you use your close votes, you are one of five users that decided a question isn't a good fit for the site, and for the purposes of transparency and accountability - the question will list those who voted to close it once closed. Transparency is something we really value, it is a cornerstone when it comes to trusting the resources that we provide.

I'm not sure what exactly happened away from the site that you think might have been sparked by your involvement in closing a question. It's obviously not something that we can control, other than working to make question closings more positive, which we're actively doing. A lot of people mistake 'closed' as some kind of final state when in fact it's not - many questions can be edited to be a great fit and reopened. Taking away some of the angst and sting that comes with a closing will hopefully go a long way toward not frustrating new users that aren't familiar with our system or communities. But, harassment is never okay.

What I'd love for you to do is contact us at team@stackexchange.com and provide us with a little more detail regarding the harassment you're seeing. If it's gotten to this point, I suspect it's not exactly trivial, and I'd like to discuss it with you. Feel free to point to this meta post when you contact us, which I hope you'll do.

We all love Answers OnStartups, but there is a whole world of people out there who need answers to their questions and don't even know that this site exists. When they arrive from Google, what will their first impression be? Let's try to look at this site through the eyes of someone who's never seen it before, and see how we stack up against the rest of the 'Net.

The Site Self-Evaluation review queue is open and populated with 10 questions that were asked and answered in the last quarter. Run a few Google searches to see how easy they are to find and compare the answers we have with the information available on other sites.

Rating the questions is only a part of the puzzle, though. Do you see a pattern of questions that should have been closed but are not? Questions or answers that could use an edit? Anything that's going really well? Post an answer below to share your thoughts and discuss these questions and the site's health with your fellow users!
row.Title: Let's get critical: Jun 2013 Site Self-Evaluation

row.Body:
I've just done a review of a number of questions, and many of them should fall into the "Need Improvement"/"Not Generally Useful" category because the question deals with the specific situation of one person or company.

It's great that people are putting energy into answers for these questions, but it'd be even nicer if the questions could be generalized.

For example, there seem to be many, many questions about splitting equity fairly, but each one is specific to the questioner's negotiations. See the equity tag for examples.

Final Results

  • How To Protect My Unpatentable Simple-But-Effective Product Against BigCompany

    Net Score: 2 (Excellent: 2, Satisfactory: 2, Needs Improvement: 0)

  • If all the employees are non-salaried founders, do we need to send out W2's?

    Net Score: 0 (Excellent: 1, Satisfactory: 1, Needs Improvement: 1)

  • a problem on applying for patent

    Net Score: -1 (Excellent: 1, Satisfactory: 0, Needs Improvement: 2)

  • Using my kids as models

    Net Score: 0 (Excellent: 1, Satisfactory: 1, Needs Improvement: 1)

  • Left my startup pre-launch. What percent equity is fair?

    Net Score: 0 (Excellent: 1, Satisfactory: 1, Needs Improvement: 1)

  • Sale commission for someone who brings a big fish (SaaS model)

    Net Score: 1 (Excellent: 1, Satisfactory: 2, Needs Improvement: 0)

  • Should we add "About -> The Team" when our company is only 5 people?

    Net Score: 2 (Excellent: 2, Satisfactory: 1, Needs Improvement: 0)

  • Where to set up a very small company where my name will be hidden

    Net Score: -2 (Excellent: 0, Satisfactory: 1, Needs Improvement: 2)

  • UK company expanding to US, sponsoring b visa

    Net Score: 0 (Excellent: 0, Satisfactory: 2, Needs Improvement: 0)

  • Need help to understand the pros and cons between open source vs closed source license for webapp?

    Net Score: -1 (Excellent: 0, Satisfactory: 1, Needs Improvement: 1)

I had two questions about Y Combinator closed:

  • Y Combinator Summer 2013 application form

    This question was closed as too localized, but why then is there a ycombinator tag, and some open questions are bearing it?

    Note that Y Combinator sees itself as an international seed accelerator, accepting applications world wide. They state: "Most of the YC-like organizations that have appeared in recent years have been created with the goal of enriching the startup community in some particular town. That's a significant difference, because that was never our goal with Y Combinator. When we started it, in Boston, our goal was to help founders, not to help Boston. Which is why after the first cycle we immediately branched out to Silicon Valley." And: "Y Combinator only takes 3 months—less than any school—and afterward startups can go wherever they want."

  • Organisational structure of Y Combinator?

    This question was closed as off topic. I thought that questions about company structure are on topic. No?

    If I rephrase the question to be more broad, referring to partnerships by example of Y Combinator, would it have a chance of being reopened?
row.Title: Why ycombinator tag if YC questions are too localized?

row.Body:
Earlier I asked Stack Exchange to revoke my Moderator status, as I wish to step down as a Moderator on Answers.OnStartups.

I would like to thank all people here who have taken the time to edit posts for clarity, up- & down-vote questions, flagged spam posts; and especially those who have cast vote-to-close on off-topic questions and left comments that pushed for quality in questions and answers. :)

If you're wondering who else is a Moderator here, then the three remaining Mods are Zuly Gonzalez, Gary E & TimJ.
row.Title: Quick announcement, I'm stepping down as Mod

row.Body:
With Jesper Mortensen stepping down after a term of distinguished service, a vacuum has been left in his place. We're looking for people that are passionate about this site and its eventual success with the following qualities:

  • Patience and professionalism
  • A desire to lead
  • A few hours of free time each week that can be spent moderating
  • Creative approaches to solving problems the site faces as it grows
  • A grasp of most topics asked on the site that is sufficient to allow you to judge the quality of questions and answers that it receives
  • Has participated in most aspects of community moderation (editing, closing, reopening, deleting, undeleting, commenting, etc)

Moderation is a strictly volunteer job, you will be in no way obligated to spend time that you don't have to spend on any given day, or any given week. We ask only that you let us know if you're going to be away for more than a week or two, and that you remain reasonably active in your position.

What exactly does the job entail, you ask? I'm glad you did. The time that you're able to spend on the site will ideally go into:

  • Handling flags raised by the community, with the least amount of intervention possible

  • Participating in Meta discussions and providing support to users that need it from time to time

  • Helping the community with maintenance tasks such as reorganizing tags, merging questions and occasional edits to close reasons or help center pages after a discussion

  • Working on new ways to promote the site and attract the kind of experts and questions the community wants

  • Spending some very enjoyable time with other Stack Exchange moderators from all over the network - the finest bunch of folks you'd ever want to work with. You'll have access to a special chat room where you can go to get support from them.

  • Interfacing directly with us, Stack Exchange to tell us what your community needs and what we might be able to do to help them get it, you'll have our ear.

This position is open to any user in good standing that meets the above criteria. If you're interested in stepping up to help this community grow and continue to move forward, please leave an answer to this question indicating your interest and a short overview of why you want the job.

While we're currently looking for one moderator, I'm not opposed to considering two if more than one strong candidate emerges. If you think you'd enjoy the job and do it well, I strongly encourage you to nominate!

Best of luck, and we'll be in touch with folks after most have had time to read this, and decide if they'd like to step up.
row.Title: Answers OnStartups Moderator Position Available!

row.Body:
Just wondering how the numeric badge next to the "review" link in the header is meant to work. It often says there are items to review, but when I click on it I just get a blank screen.

Is this by design? If so, it seems a little weird. Just curious really. Thanks.
row.Title: Badge next to review always blank

row.Body:
I'd happily volunteer as I've spent a lot of time lately trying to improve the quality of posts here (even when it provokes unwelcome responses).

I'm currently working on a new startup and use numerous daily "five minute breaks" here to re-energise. Also, being from the UK, I can offer a different perspective. I started my first business at age nine and have been running my own businesses ever since, so I guess I'm qualified.

No problem if you go with someone else, but I just thought I'd reach out and volunteer. Thanks.
I'd also be willing to help out if the site needs it.

There's a bit of caching at play there, as well as other places where 'work needed' indicators are shown.
