It's not as noticeable on larger sites where there's typically a sufficient number of items that small discrepancies aren't noticed very often. One instance is the moderator queue indicator (very similar to the review bat signal) will tell you that there's 15 flags awaiting action even after you've flushed them out.

This is something that we're trying to minimize, so long as we don't defeat the gain we get from caching in the first place. Grabbing all of those tallies is an expensive query that would need to happen on every page, so the small discrepancy is a reasonable trade off for the time it cuts off of the page loading.

Just by curiosity: did you ever been contacted at one of the StackExchange sites by someone who wanted become (or became) your client because of your answers/expertise?

It can be programming, consultancy, whatever...

To make my question more precise and neutral:

Is it a good idea to expect finding new clients at StackEchange (or here at answers OnStartups) by showing your expertise?

Or people come here mainly because the answers and advices are for free?
row.Title: Can StackExchange activity bring new clients?

row.Body:
On the Stack Exchange network, excessive self promotion is discouraged. It's even part of our guidance in Help:

Avoid overt self-promotion.

The community tends to vote down overt self-promotion and flag it as spam. Post good, relevant answers, and if some (but not all) happen to be about your product or website, that’s okay. However, you must disclose your affiliation in your answers.

If a large percentage of your posts include a mention of your product or website, you're probably here for the wrong reasons. Our advertising rates are quite reasonable; contact our ad sales team for details. We also offer free community promotion ads for open source projects and non-profit organizations.

The idea is that if you are posting answers that really help and your mention of your company is helpful, that's probably ok.

However, this is a bit of a different site than most of the others on the network. Since the subject of the site includes promoting a product, there's a temptation to ask a question or post an answer in order to promote your startup. In the past (and I assume this is still true), folks have been reluctant to even name their company in posts. Zuly has noted that "if a user's first couple of posts contain some kind of self-promotion, they are usually here for the wrong reasons."

Whether or not a user of Answers OnStartups has every obtained a new client through their use of the site ought to be irrelevant to how you use the site. If it happens, it should be a happy accident of how you are using the site to learn about the starting and running a new business.

I'm pleased to announce that one of our community veterans has stepped up to fill the role of your new Answers OnStartups moderator. Please give jimg a warm welcome as he assumes his post and goes to work for this community.

Jim has been an avid user since January of 2010 and many of you probably know him through his interactions with you on the site. We're happy that Jim will be lending his time and talents to help lead the Answers OnStartups community to a successful launch.

Welcome, Jim!
row.Title: Please welcome your new moderator, jimg!

row.Body: Right now you have to change at least 6 characters for an edit to be approve. I just wanted to fix a couple of typos in someones post, but couldn't because of this limit. Should we relax the editing restriction or have some other way to do this?
row.Title: fixing typos in posts

row.Body:
If you could point me to the post, I'll take a look at it.

The character limitation is a hard coded value (read: feature!) in the stack exchange network, so its not something that onstartups can modify.

Can I ask what is the intervention of the "Community" user that puts dozens of older questions on the top of the questions list?

What is the reason for that? The scope is to "push" users to answer these questions where there is - in majority of cases - only one answer, right?
row.Title: What are all the posts pushed on top of the list by "Community" user?

row.Body:
The "Community" user bumps old unanswered questions every now and then to get those questions some attention. The goal is to clean up the site. Hopefully, it's a good question that simply needs an answer. However, there are other reasons a question may be unanswered. For example:

  • It's off-topic for this site, so there are no experts here to answer it. If this is the case, please vote to close the question or flag it.
  • It's unclear and hard to understand. If this is the case, please edit it if you can make out what the OP intended, or leave the OP a comment asking him to do the same. If it's impossible to figure out and the OP hasn't fixed it, vote to close as "unclear what you're asking" or flag the question.
  • It's way too broad and would require a very long answer to be useful. In this case, try to edit it if it's possible to narrow down the scope, or leave the OP a comment asking him to do the same. If it isn't edited to narrow down the scope, vote to close as "too broad" or flag the question.

The definition of "unanswered" is no upvoted answers.

According to this post, the Community user will bump unanswered questions every hour, with the number of unanswered questions bumped per hour depending on the site. During the weekends, the Community user's activity will be more obvious because there are less people participating on the site.

Yes, The community user helps to 'churn' older content that it believes (through an algorithm) might not have received enough attention. If a post only has one answer that hasn't been up voted much - perhaps the following could be true:

  • A real expert or rare knowledge is needed to answer the question, give it more exposure
  • The question is very problematic, perhaps applicable to a very narrow situation, is difficult to understand or just off topic. May need editing or closing / flagging / down voting.
  • The question just didn't get noticed at the time it was asked
  • The answer it got is actually great, so is the question, needs up votes!

Or, perhaps absolutely nothing is really wrong or actionable. Content churning is a very good thing for the reasons above, and really helps to keep the quality of the site much higher if folks take advantage of the old stuff coming up to the surface for air.

When you see it, have a nice critical look at it .. maybe there's something to do :)

Every little once in a while, I'll stumble across a question or answer that deals with shady businesses. For the sake of this question, let's define this as businesses that may be illegal in some parts of the world, or that while perhaps not illegal, many people would consider unethical or immoral.

Some examples might include the adult entertainment world, drug dealing, or perhaps even just a startup whose business model involves highly questionable activities.

In practice, I've seen these questions/answers get punished with down votes and harsh comments, so perhaps we've already subconsciously made a decision here. So my question is, what do we do about these types of shady questions?

  • Should they just get closed?

  • If there's a question that is questionable (no pun intended) but could be edited to still ask the underlying question while removing discussion about the aforementioned shady business, should that be done?

  • If it's about a shady business tactic, should we answer it and tell them it's a bad idea?

  • Should I just relax, and let them be? (I.e., we allow these types of questions, as long as they're still startup related?)

Along a related note, and what made me think to ask the question, what if a question or answer is mostly fine, but has a point or two that goes into this territory? This answer is what got me thinking about this. It's a good answer to the question, but in the middle is that link to an adult themed website. It's not link spam or anything (at least, I really don't think it is), but my gut reaction was to edit it out and leave the rest of the question alone.

But then I started second guessing myself. I don't want to just go edit posts because something didn't completely jive with my own personal ethics, but at the same time, it still feels odd for our site to be linking to a site like that.
row.Title: Are questions/answers related to shady businesses allowed?

row.Body:
I would use your best judgement. We don't have any hard rules on this, and I think how we treat the question will depend on the intent of the OP and how far it goes into the illegal/shady territory. Some thoughts:

  • The problem we'll run into is that some activities are illegal in some jurisdictions, but not others. So it's hard to say we're going to close all questions on X, if X is legal in certain jurisdictions (e.g. gambling sites). That said, there are certain things that while legal in certain parts of the world, are repulsive to most people. I think we can go ahead and close those questions.

  • I think questions with the sole purpose of asking for advice on breaking the law should be closed. For example, "I'm located in jurisdiction X, where it is illegal to do Y. How can I do Y without getting caught?"

  • There are some questions that are a little more grey. Or where the OP is unsure about something and is looking to answer "is X legal?" In these cases we'll have to use our judgement to determine if the question is asked in good faith, or if the intent is to figure out a way to break the law. If the question seems to be in good faith, I would tend to leave it open, and if necessary, edit it so that the tone clearly reflects that.

  • Questions that are of a pure legal nature and don't apply to the general audience of people starting or running a new business should be closed, regardless of whether the activity is legal or illegal.

  • I'm not opposed to mentions of adult entertainment as long as it is done in good taste and is within the scope of this site. Off-topic, too broad, etc. questions will be closed regardless. With respect to the post you mention in your question, I think it's fine. It is included with several other examples and is used to provide context to his answer. That said, I didn't click on the link. If the destination site bombards you with images of naked people, I would consider that to be in poor taste and would edit out the link.

Sorry, I realize I probably left you just as unsure as you were. But I don't think we can come up with a hard rule on this. I think we'll have to take each question on a case by case basis, and the decisions will be less binary and more gut feeling and opinion based. I will answer one of your questions directly:

If there's a question that is questionable (no pun intended) but could be edited to still ask the underlying question while removing discussion about the aforementioned shady business, should that be done?

Yes.

The one area I struggle with is questions where the OP is obviously asking for help on how to spam people. We tend to get those type of questions every now and then. If the question doesn't cleanly fall under one of our close reasons, I always struggle with what to do. On one hand, I absolutely hate spam and don't want to encourage or help others in that pursuit. On the other hand, if it's a valid question for the site, we can't close it. I usually just downvote those questions.

See also Policy/FAQ on Questions which allude to illegal activity

Tough call, indeed. Adult themed businesses are legal, as are "paraphernalia" type businesses.

Editing based on personal moral objections is difficult, since clear and fast rules don't exist.

I would follow Zuly's advice and evaluate if the questionable reference adds any particular value / point to the conversation. In the answer you reference, the addition of the adult business job portal is in topic (adult themed business workers) and not a bait link to get traffic.

We all love Answers OnStartups, but there is a whole world of people out there who need answers to their questions and don't even know that this site exists. When they arrive from Google, what will their first impression be? Let's try to look at this site through the eyes of someone who's never seen it before, and see how we stack up against the rest of the 'Net.

The Site Self-Evaluation review queue is open and populated with 10 questions that were asked and answered in the last quarter. Run a few Google searches to see how easy they are to find and compare the answers we have with the information available on other sites.

Rating the questions is only a part of the puzzle, though. Do you see a pattern of questions that should have been closed but are not? Questions or answers that could use an edit? Anything that's going really well? Post an answer below to share your thoughts and discuss these questions and the site's health with your fellow users!
row.Title: Let's get critical: Sep 2013 Site Self-Evaluation

row.Body:
I am still quite new here but I try to help keeping this interesting and helpful website clean and sane.

In the last days, I see more and more spammers posting poor answers with links to their webs or with "some commercial propositions". I am quite surprised by their number. E.g. today, I already spent all my available flags.

It was always the case or it's recent? Perhaps a growing interest for this website?

I know the website system depends on the system os Stackexchange but I don't know how mux flexibility yuo/we have to take some anti-spammers actions.

What about, e.g., making a moderator aproval for the first user answer mandatory (ond not only posting it to review queue)? Would that represent too much work for admins/mods?

Anyway, thank you for running this website and good luck for the future!

Martin
row.Title: Recent/actual "spam storm" on answers.onstartups.com

row.Body:
Martin - thanks for your vigilance.

We seem to get a bunch of these "answers" in waves. The latest approach - answer plus commercial plug - has happened before & will likely happen again in the future. The deep linking into blogs though is a bit of a concern... esp. when the answer is acceptable.

In my profile I have a new helpful flags entry and after searching the help section I cannot find any further information on this statistic.

Does anyone know what it refers too?
row.Title: What does the profile entry "helpful flags" refer to?

row.Body:
When you flag a post for moderator attention, a moderator can dismiss the flag as either helpful or not. You can see a history of everything you've flagged in your profile, along with whether it was accepted as helpful or declined by the moderator.

For more details on this, please see What does the helpful flag mean?

Final Results

  • Doing business in one state and mailing address in another?

    Net Score: -2 (Excellent: 1, Satisfactory: 1, Needs Improvement: 3)

  • Approaching vendors- help?

    Net Score: 0 (Excellent: 1, Satisfactory: 2, Needs Improvement: 1)

  • How to overcome this business fear?

    Net Score: -4 (Excellent: 0, Satisfactory: 0, Needs Improvement: 4)

  • How to create a business?

    Net Score: -2 (Excellent: 0, Satisfactory: 2, Needs Improvement: 2)

  • Should I provide a customer support number on my site?

    Net Score: 3 (Excellent: 3, Satisfactory: 1, Needs Improvement: 0)

  • Now that I understand that no one needs the product I've been building, what can I do?

    Net Score: 2 (Excellent: 2, Satisfactory: 2, Needs Improvement: 0)

  • Conflict of interest or fair game?

    Net Score: 1 (Excellent: 2, Satisfactory: 1, Needs Improvement: 1)

  • How can I determine if I can afford a new employee?

    Net Score: 2 (Excellent: 2, Satisfactory: 1, Needs Improvement: 0)

  • How to raise funding without a prototype

    Net Score: 1 (Excellent: 1, Satisfactory: 2, Needs Improvement: 0)

  • How do I deal with taxes for foreign (outside of the company's base) on an Internet Services company?

    Net Score: 0 (Excellent: 1, Satisfactory: 1, Needs Improvement: 1)

Over the last few days, I've seen a number of questions where people ask, "What is [Some Company]'s business model?" or "How does [Some Company] make money on [Some Product]?"

We've seen this type of question in the past, here and there, too. (Example: What is Newmans Own business model)

Is this kind of question the kind of thing we want to keep open?

Some things to consider:

  1. On one hand, there's probably a definitive answer to these questions. The company itself knows it exactly. (One would hope.) So it's not necessarily subjective or opinion-based, and I don't know if I feel comfortable closing the question on those grounds.

    But on the other hand, that company isn't likely to be here to answer the question definitively, so even though it has a correct answer, the answers that are likely to come up are going to be opinion-based--a guess at what the company does.

  2. Because they're asking about a specific company, would this be "too localized"? How many other people will this question be useful to if we leave it open?

  3. To further complicate the matter, these questions usually reference an established company. The business model of an established company may not apply to a small startup. Thinking along these lines, this question could be closed on the grounds of being off-topic (not about startups).

  4. As a follow up to #3, thinking along broader lines, answers to these questions may be misleading. Just because company X does activity Y and has success, doesn't mean that company A would be successful doing Y as well. It doesn't even mean company X has success as a result of doing Y.

    It really feels like the user is unwittingly asking the wrong question. Should we simply vote to close, and help them sort through things to find what their real question is, and tell them to ask that instead?

  5. In my opinion, it feels like these are not good questions, but I'm not sure any of the existing close reasons cover it very well. Would it be meaningful to have another specialized close option for things like this? Perhaps something like, "Asking how a specific other company makes money or functions is not a good fit for this site. Please edit your question to focus on the specific problem your startup is trying to solve instead."? (I haven't thought that through very well... that's just a stab in the dark.)

TL;DR: Should we allow these questions, and if not, what reasoning should be given for closing them?
row.Title: Should questions asking how other companies' business model works be allowed?

row.Body:
In my opinion, this type of question should almost always be closed. Most of these questions fall into one of two categories:

  1. A homework question- something anyone can figure out in minutes via google. This question variation is just an attempt to get the users here to do their homework or basic company research.
  2. The answer is not known, and there is no one from the company to answer. Or there is no answer because the company is just treading water until they come up with a plan to make money.
Agree with Gary - and many times the initial business idea was nothing like what they ended up with (example: paypal)

I'd keep the questions, at least when they present interesting insights. How to make money is one of the most important questions for new startups. It makes sense that entrepreneurs want to learn and compare with successful companies.

This question just came up today, asking for users of this site to identify a particular website based on some of its features. I question the validity of this type of question.

I had thought I remembered Stack Exchange having a general rule about closing these questions because the correct answer lies only in the asker's memory, albeit temporarily forgotten. Any ideas put forth are not much more than stabs in the dark.

Besides, even if the "correct" answer didn't have to be the one the asker was trying to remember (perhaps allowing for them to discover a wide variety of similar sites or a better alternative) it starts to feel like a product recommendation question, which we know is off-topic here.

I was ready to go vote to close this question, but wanted some sort of proof to show that these types of questions weren't allowed and instead discovered the following:

  • The SciFi and Fantasy site has a tag that is designed specifically for story identification: http://scifi.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/story-identification
  • The English Language and Usage site has tags for both single word requests and phrase requests.

In other words, I discovered at least some sites are not only allowing questions like this, but have lots of people asking them.

It just feels like questions that will only produce answers in the form of, "Was it X?" is not a good question.

(Side note, didn't we use to have an option to close things as being "too localized"? It seems like that would be applicable here.)

Thoughts?
row.Title: Should identification questions be allowed?

row.Body:
Yes, that question is off-topic. It's really just a poll, which is why product recommendation questions aren't allowed. The answers will all consist of a simple link to some site that may or may not be the right answer.

A question like this would be perfectly suited for our chat room. Unfortunately, our chat doesn't get used much.

Under the old close reasons, this question would have been closed under the "not constructive" close reason. Under the new close reasons, it translates to the "primarily opinion-based" close option.

SE recently revamped their close reasons and removed "too localized" as an option altogther, because apparently it was being abused on some of the bigger SE sites. However, it makes sense for some questions, like this one. I've found myself wishing "too localized" still existed on a couple of occasions.

We are allowed some wiggle room in interpreting the general SE rules to best fit our site. There may be a handful of exceptions, but in general SE sites don't allow these type of questions. What I've found is that in the early days of a site folks tend to be more lenient, and allow questions that they probably should close. As the site matures, they become more strict. Some sites have started by allowing polls in the beginning, but later on close them. Questions that were asked early on will get lost and remain open, while new questions are closed. That's why you may find these type of questions lurking on some sites even though they are not allowed.

This is the situation we are in. We started by allowing polls, but don't anymore. If you look hard enough, I'm sure you will find some poll type questions that are still open on our site from our early days. We close them as we stumble upon them. We even have a recommendations tag that I've been trying to get rid of for forever. So just because we may find these type of questions on other SE sites, and even some tags that give the appearance they are accepted, it doesn't mean that they really are.

It seems like I've been asking a lot of questions on meta lately. Forgive me if it has been too much.

I was looking at the visa tag and the startupvisa tag. I'm not sure I understand if there's a difference between these two. I mean, I can see startupvisa being about visas in the context of startups, but... everything on this site is in the context of startups. Why do two of them exist?

I would propose a synonym (mapping startupvisa to visa) but I think I'm a few points short of that.

Can someone else please explain the difference or make the tag synonym?

Also, note that visa doesn't have a description, but startupvisa does that seems like it would be applicable.
row.Title: Startupvisa and visa tags

row.Body:
The Startup Visa is a special visa category aimed at bringing in entrepreneurs to the U.S. It is currently awaiting committee review in Congress.

From Wikipedia:

The Startup Visa is a proposed amendment to the U.S. immigration law to create a visa category for foreign entrepreneurs who have raised capital from qualified American investors. It aims at addressing the absence of a visa category for entrepreneurs raising outside funding.

The visa tag is meant for general visa questions not specifically related to the Startup Visa. The question is, should questions not specifically related to the Startup Visa be allowed? I took a real quick glance at a few of the questions tagged visa. In general they seem on-topic, although I would say that most of them require an immigration lawyer to answer properly, which we don't have on this site.

So, I wouldn't merge the two tags because they are sufficiently different. But I do think it's worth having a discussion on whether we should allow general visa questions. I could go either way on it right now.

If we do decide to keep both tags, then we need to edit their tag wikis to clearly define how they are different from one another.

Every now and then I come across a question that is asking for reviews of a specific product or service. For example:

  • Would you recommend CheddarGetter.com (subscription payment SaaS) and why?
  • Do you use Braintree Payment Solutions?

Should we close these questions? I think it's pretty obvious that these questions should be closed as "primarily opinion-based" since there is no right answer to them and they will lead to a long list of opinions. However, I think it would be helpful to have a formal off-topic reason for them. Thoughts?
row.Title: Should questions asking for product reviews be closed?

row.Body:
I agree with you that there is no right answer and all answers are basically opinions.

In addition, even if there was a "right" answer, the right answer today doesn't mean that answer would be right 6 months or a year down the road. I see this problem with ecommerce providers all the time. A new service appears and offers more features, better pricing, and better service. A year goes by and their service quality goes down, prices up, and other firms now have more features. So the previous recommendations are now wrong.

This is a bug that isn't site specific, so perhaps there's a more general place to submit this.

I ran into what feels very much like a bug, and wanted to see if anyone else has ran into this.

There was a question that I wanted to vote to close. I chose one reason (several applied) and voted to close. Then a couple of minutes later, I decided another reason was probably a little stronger or more applicable, and went to change it. I retracted my close vote then went to vote for the other reason, but I found I could not. Once you retract a close vote, you can't vote to close again.

Have others ran into this? Is this a bug? Is there any logic for why you can't vote to close a second time after you retract your close vote? (Or change the reason behind your close vote?)
row.Title: Voting to close then trying to change close reason bug

row.Body:
It's been requested on several sites that we enable this behavior for the feature, but we have not as of yet. Currently, the feature simply allows you to retract your vote if you change your mind about closing in general - and that should be a reasonably rare event. Once you undo it, the system understands 'I don't think this should be closed anymore.'

Most suggestions revolve around allowing this based on substantial edits to a post, but that presents a scenario that is somewhat easy to misuse, and can cause a user a bit of grief if folks with closing privileges are 'hovering' over a question and at odds with each other on how it should be handled.

It's not a bug, I'm not putting a status on this yet, it something we're still discussing and thinking about.

I found this discussion, but it doesn't address the specific issue I want to raise.

Is it possible to at least show an instruction for new users writing a question that they should add a location tag/information in the question?

Just today I encountered these three questions which must include the location information to be answered.

Its wasting time - both for the OPs who're waiting for an answer which may never come (or come but not be relevant to their location) and the responders who are answering making assumptions that may not be correct and thus not only wasting the time but also potentially misleading the OPs...
row.Title: Location tags... Again!

row.Body: I agree, many if not most of the questions here need a location to be answered in any meaningful way. It is a total waste of time asking these people to supply the location after they have asked the question.

Answers OnStartups has been in public beta for a little over three years, and is doing rather well when it comes to overall traffic, question volume and answer rate. What sets this site apart from the rest is something quite unique: it's changed hands, or rather changed communities over the course of the last year and a half. The site remains as it was initially defined, but has an almost completely new group of people using it.

Unfortunately, while many people continue to use the site, the actual community has become quite small.

The last community self-evaluation validated some concerns that we've had for some time now, the quality of questions that the site receives has diminished, along with the number of people taking ownership of this community and the content it serves. We suspect it is because of this that we're losing interest from established users, and not successfully engaging new users that arrive and begin to participate. To put this in context:

  • 264 out of 387 users at the 150 to 199 reputation level (68%) have been gone for 180+ days
  • 72 out of 132 users at the 500 to 1000 reputation level (55%) have been gone for 180+ days
  • 2 out of 6 10k+ users (33%) have been gone for 180+ days

These numbers continue to plummet, leaving the burden of community self-moderation on just a few. We don't track how long it's been since someone visited the site past 180 days, as experience has taught us that they're basically gone at that point.

The amount of work, care and dedication that the Answers OnStartups moderation team has put into this site can not be overstated, and we do see their efforts paying off to a degree, but we've not been able to really engage new and many existing users with the idea of joining a community in addition to asking questions.

What is going to happen now?

Given that there is still a small core of enthused users that want this community and resource to thrive, we think that the best thing to do at this point is to put the topic back through the Area 51 process in order to ensure that we have the critical mass of people needed to make this site successful.

We'll be closing answers.onstartups.com on Tuesday, November 12, 2013. This leaves ample time for this community to propose the topic again at Area 51, and link to it here so that all interested can find it easily.

Feel free to take additional advantage of this time by identifying discussions that need to take place on a new proposal. For instance…

  • ...Where should the line between questions about general or small business administration and questions about a start-up business be drawn?
  • ...When does How do I market my new web service? fall into the on or off-topic category?

… all questions that really need consensus from an interested community before the site is ready to launch.

Launching a successful Q&A site in a subset of a much larger topic can be difficult unless you’ve got a large enough community committed to making it work, and that’s what this topic needs. We encourage you to try again, and invite experts that you know into the formation of a new, better and much more focused resource.

Update (11/27/13)

We're still working with Dharmesh to make sure that a reboot of the topic is truly the best course of action to take. We're still rather certain that it is, but we want to make sure that we've explored all possibilities prior to doing so. We do sincerely apologize for the confusion that the delay has caused, we just want to make absolutely certain that we're proceeding in the best possible manner.
row.Title: Answers OnStartups Will Close On November 12, 2013

row.Body: Sad to hear. I don't think tweaking the guidelines would make a difference. I'm interested to hear if anyone has better ideas on how to make radical changes that would improve the site?

I'm going to pull a Howard Baker here and ask, what did the moderators know about this site closing, and when did they know it?

I'm extremely curious to know if this was a decision made with the support of the moderators or not. Knowing the answer to this will help me (and I think all of us) know how to proceed next.

Can some of the moderators please weigh in?
row.Title: How involved were the moderators in the closing of this site?

row.Body: I learned at the same moment you did.

Tim had asked for my opinion, and I gave it - @ the 50k level, I believe that onanswers (or its successor) should be more focused on startup businesses whose primary channel is internet. I think SE wants to go wider to encompass questions related to all new businesses.

I'm sad to see this site is going to disappear, especially as I've put a lot of effort into it.

It seems like there should be a site like this, but most questions are repeats (how to divide equity) or totally inane.

The solution is to attract interesting questions from entrepreneurs, which will yield better answers, but true entrepreneurs are probably too busy growing their business to bother with a site like this (there was a Twitter thread about this recently).

It's pretty clear to me, from a statistic that SE hasn't mentioned, what is wrong with this community. If you look at the number of questions listed for the site, and follow this number over time, you will see it has remained almost unchanged for nearly a year. Virtually every new question that is asked is eventually put on hold and then rejected, based on the site rules.

That implies to me that we aren't giving the community what they want. The community is the one that asks the questions. The community wants web site reviews, product idea reviews, and all the things our rules say we can't offer. We can either give the community what it wants, or fade away.

It's pretty clear to me, from a statistic that SE hasn't mentioned, what is wrong with this community. If you look at the number of questions listed for the site, and follow this number over time, you will see it has remained almost unchanged for nearly a year. Virtually every new question that is asked is eventually put on hold and then rejected, based on the site rules.

That implies to me that we aren't giving the community what they want. The community is the one that asks the questions. The community wants web site reviews, product idea reviews, and all the things our rules say we can't offer. We can either give the community what it wants, or fade away.

The Powers That Be™ have officially declared that this site is going to be shut down. It doesn't appear that this was done with feedback from the community, or even the moderators, which is a source of great consternation to me.

I know this question is perhaps moot, considering all of that, but I want to put the question out to the community here: Is answers.onstartups.com salvageable in its current form? Or do you feel like it would take a death and rebirth through Area 51?

(Considering that it is likely out of our control, I'm not asking for what is going to happen, but rather, what should happen.)
row.Title: Is answers.onstartups.com salvageable?

row.Body:
everyone. This is Dharmesh (the guy behind the original OnStartups.com site and the one responsible for working out a deal with Joel to launch answers.onstartups.com

Candidly, this shut-down notification is news to me. But, I've been preoccupied with other things so it's possible someone from the StackExchange team reached out to me and I missed it.

Clearly, I'd rather us fix the issues and re-energize the community instead of just shutting it down. I don't think there's any doubt that there's interest in the topic of startups.

And, my thanks do go out to all the folks that have invested the time and energy into the site.

I'll see if there's some way to keep this community going -- I candidly don't see the upside in just shutting it down.

I hope something can be done to make sure this site does not get shutdown. Some of the problems with participation from people who contribute with both quality questions and answers is to remove some of the extensive rules that have been applied to the site over the years, almost every question I tried to answer (or ask) got removed because it went against some moderation "rule" - sigh.

What happened? It's November 13th and Answers OnStartups didn't close.

Did they change their minds? Or maybe it really wasn't going to be closed in the first place.

Or maybe it's still going to happen, and they're just late in doing it.

According to this Meta post, this site will close sometime today.

I'd just like to thank everyone who has posted here, as I have learnt a lot. I'd especially like to thank the generous people who upvoted my answers and comments.

I'm sad to see this site go, but I understand the reasons (overzealous moderation). Hopefully, a new version of this site can be created, with more appropriate rules. I'd certainly be happy to help out in any way I can, including posting and moderating.

Good luck to everyone on your entrepreneurial journeys.
row.Title: Good luck everyone

row.Body: Will the existing Q&A be archived somewhere and available for reference?

I'm still relatively new to this site, and I've been the victim of "over-moderation". But you know what... it was to my benefit. Some of us appreciate the critical feedback, and we improve our subsequent questions (and answers) as a result.

This site is one of the most useful online resources on startups. It just needs time.

So let's think long-term.

Over-moderation is a hurdle, not a show-stopper; think of it as teething issues if you will. In 20 years time, however, this community will be mature, and the content will be priceless (if it isn't already).

Give it time fellas!

I'd like to ask a question about e-commerce payment gateways and such, on this site?

I want to accept credit cards on my site, without users having to create an account with 3rd parties such as a paypal account. I'd like to ask:

  1. If there are any comparison sites,
  2. What companies offer payment solutions that do not have monthly contract fees, and preferably no start-up fees (i.e. that just charge transaction fees)

Are the above two questions off topic for this site?

Thanks!
row.Title: Can I ask a question about what e-commerce payment providers there are?

row.Body:
Those two questions would be off-topic on this site. Those type of questions are what Stack Exchange calls poll, list or recommendation questions. They usually lead to a bunch of link-only answers that are hard to evaluate and hard to maintain up to date.

A couple of related links on this site are:

  • Should identification questions be allowed?

  • Requests for study resources are not constructive?

There's also a lot of discussion on Meta Stack Overflow on this topic. Some posts of interest are:

  • What exactly is a recommendation question?

  • What is the definition of a list question?

  • Why is asking for references/sources to study specific topics considered not constructive?

The topic of payment gateways is generally allowed on this site, so if you can phrase your question to focus on how to solve a specific problem you are having, that would be allowed. But asking for a list of payment gateways or a list of websites that compare them would not be allowed.

TL;DR: My opinion is that it would be far better to attempt to refactor/evolve the site into what it ought to be, instead of rebooting it through Area 51.

Seeing as how nobody else has answered this question, and seeing as how the site seems to still be plugging along, I'm going to go ahead and answer this question, and explain why I think this site could and should be salvaged in place, without pushing it through the Area 51 process.

I'm fully aware of the fact that this is beyond the control of people like me, and probably you as well. If the decision to close the site down is final, and there's no room for negotiation (and I'd say it probably is) then this question and this answer are moot. But I don't really care. Since the site is still open for the time being, I'm going to climb up on the soap box and say my piece.

Presume There Exists a Place for a Startups-Based Stack Exchange

There is a broader question here that I'm not going to directly answer. That question is, "Is there room on the Stack Exchange network and within the overall constraints of Stack Exchange for a Q&A site about startups?" I think that's a discussion worth having, but it's not what I'm trying to get at with this question. So I want to start off by simply making the presumption that there is value in a startups-related Stack Exchange.

Presume That This Isn't Quite It

This site has been incredibly helpful to me over the years. But there are some problems with the site as it stands. I think we've all felt and seen it. Definitely, the fact that the SE Admins are in the process of shutting things down should be a strong sign that this is the case. So let's also make the assumption that this site is broken in at least one meaningful way. We could make a list, but that's beyond the scope of this question.

The Three Two Paths Forward

As I see it, there are three pathways forward, given the assumption that what we're trying to do here could work, but isn't:

  1. Continue on as we have in the past. This is what we've been doing for a while. Months at least, if not years. We're not growing. We've stalled. It's been the easy choice in the past, I assume because no one actually wants to shut things down, but also because nobody was entirely willing to try to make the radical changes that are needed to fix things. Of course, this option is now off the table, because of the looming site shut down.

  2. Reboot the site through Area 51. This second option is to pull the plug on things here, and push the site back through Area 51 to allow things to be redefined, users to recommit, and then to start from scratch. (I assume we could reseed the site with some of the questions and answers from here.) This is what the SE Admins are currently aiming for.

  3. "Refactor" the current site into the site it should be. This final pathway would be to put in effort (by lots of people in the community, probably over months) to gradually make changes to the site to try to put it on a course that will get it to the desired destination.

Why I Think Refactoring is Better Than Rebooting

I'm a strong supporter of going with option #3, to refactor instead of reboot. Here are my reasons:

  1. Rebooting means losing a lot of the current community. I've seen some people express interest in continuing to support this site, even if it goes back to Area 51. But there is little doubt that we'll lose a lot of people. It's the demotivation factor. People working on startups have little time to dedicate to helping people. If you take their efforts and trash them, many people will leave and find their own ways to help others.

    As an example, the initial 3D modeling proposal on Area 51 had enough support to get to a private beta where it was declared dead, and sent back to start. The second iteration, under the name "CG Artists" was slower to gain popularity. It hit a year in the definition phase and was very close to enough users and enough questions to advance, but the year elapsed and it was closed as well. This Round #2 was actually weaker than Round #1. It lost support in the reboot. It's now on Round #3. It's three months into it, and it only has 6 followers. It's most certainly not going to make it in the end. Again, more lost support. The people who are interested in these sites lose their motivation to keep pushing it forward when it goes through a reboot.

  2. Rebooting means lost down time. We get lots of... um... how do I say this gently... less useful questions here. But we also got lots of great questions. There will be time that the proposal sits in Area 51 that we aren't going to be able to help people like we want to. Likely months, not days. They'll find other communities to get their answers instead. So we potentially lose these people forever.

  3. You can't make the assumption that what you build the second time will be better than the first. This site, problems and all, is what it is because of the growth and learning process that has happened over years of time. Some of the problems we have are there because we learned that doing it differently causes bigger problems. Going through a reboot, we're likely to make many, if not all of the same mistakes as we did this time. Especially if we've lost some of our most active members from point #1.

  4. We're in better shape to get to our destination starting from where we're at, than from scratch. If you haven't read it before, go read what Joel Spolsky, the CEO of Stack Exchange said you should never do: trash something and start over. Sure, we have a long way to go, and I can understand why it might feel nice to start from a clean slate. But despite the problems, we have a lot going for us as well. I think we'd be fools to throw that away without at least first attempting an in-place fix.

Well I'm glad to see the site is still running. No questions were close (just may be 1 or 2 spammy ones) and the number of questions seems on the rise. Yes, the quality of some questions is "low" but if someone's asking a question, it's a legitimate question to them (and others too), even if some people think it's a dumb question. With Stackoverflow, answers are binary: the code either works or it doesn't. With OnStartups, the questions and answers will necessarily be more opinion-based because of the nature of the topic: entrepreneurship. In the meantime, new users that used to get turned away with a "closed question" are starting to get involved and I think this trend will likely continue.

So my question is simple: can we now officially declare that the site will keep running as is?

Thanks.
row.Title: Glad to see the site is still running

row.Body:
So there have been a lot of posts raging about the fact that answers OnStartups is closing, even if later than advertised, with many putting the reasoning down to the fact the rules are too restrictive. I know for one that new users can be put off by the answers OnStartups rulebook since I had my first question closed...

My main question here is why the community hasn't banded together to propose new rules to the moderators?

There are many methods to collaboratively "rewrite the rulebook" from etherpad to liquidfeedback but I haven't seen anything. On the same vein I haven't seen a new submission to Area51 either.

Would the moderators look to engaging with the community in this way in order to address the issues they outlined? Also, would anyone else be willing to put the time and effort into expunging the issues the moderators feel there are?

According to the area 51 entry answers onstartups meets all the requirements to leave beta so surly working to resole these issues would be more effective than restarting the process for history to repeat itself.
row.Title: OnStartups Site Future

row.Body:
Last year Stack Exchange ran a fun event during the holidays called Winter Bash. Winter Bash is now an annual event that can run on any Stack Exchange site that chooses to participate. Users earn “hats” for their gravatars by completing certain tasks (analogous to badges). Certain actions trigger the user receiving a hat, which their gravatar can “wear”. They track everyone’s progress earning hats in a leaderboard.

This event will run from 16 December 2013 to 3 January 2014. Users will be able to see their entire hat collection on http://winterba.sh. That site will also have a landing page, explaining the rules and other details of the event.

Individual users who don’t want to participate, don’t want to see hats, and/or are generally anti-hat will have an “I hate hats” option available. At the end of the event, all hats will go back into storage.

The only visual change to the Stack Exchange sites themselves will be the presence of the hats and the “I hate hats” button in the footer.

Last year we opted out of participating in Winter Bash, but it looks like that was a mistake. So, what do you all say? Should we participate in Winter Bash this year? We need to submit our response to SE by Dec 1.

Update 11/27/13: We are now officially opted in to participate in Winter Bash.

I don't know what's happening with the site closure, but since the site is still going I'm going to assume that it won't be shutdown any time soon.
row.Title: Do we want hats?

row.Body:
I want hats!

I know, hats can be kind of a silly thing. Some people are probably not terribly excited about it. (You grumpy hat haters can disable it.)

But I actually think there is a good solid "business" reason for hats. The whole Winterfest thing that Stack Exchange does is kind of like a holiday party for the community. I think it could actually give us a stronger sense of community, and perhaps by trying to earn some hats, it will get people to participate in ways that they hadn't in the past. The way I see it, it can only serve to strengthen the community, so I hope we do it!
+1 hats - and +2 to keep the site alive.

First, thank you! Since the site closure was announced I've seen a lot of whining and complaining, but with the exception of your posts, very little action to try to fix the problem. (And I think that behavior is at the core of what's wrong with this site.) So, thanks for stepping up!

I agree with you that refactoring the site is a much better approach than shutting it down and forcing it to go through Area 51. Let's assume that we've convinced the powers that be that this is the best path forward for OnStartups, now what?

Obviously, the site can't continue to operate like it has for the last year and a half or so. It's just not working. I'm a believer that this site has to undergo a drastic change, but I think that if we try to tackle all of the issues at the same time, it's going to be too much for the handful of folks actively participating. I think we need to discuss the issues and take each one at a time.

I think the biggest problem with the site is that there is no community. Everyone wants a destination they can go to for their startup related questions, but nobody wants to put the effort into maintaining a quality site. This is a hard problem to solve and one that's not going to be solved overnight. My hope is that if we fix some of the other issues with the site, in time this issue will work itself out.

I propose that as a first step we get together as a community and define the scope of this site. One of the issues we face is that we never actually went through the exercise of defining our site, so everyone has their own opinion of what is a startup question. What is a startup for the purpose of this site? Is it strictly high-tech companies? Freelancers? Small businesses? Without a common definition it's hard for us to come together as a community. This question was asked once before, but instead of getting a discussion going, it garnered some negative and unnecessarily rude comments. I say we give it another try and clearly define our scope. Once we've got that, we can tackle some of the other problems.
Sure - hopefully it will help - hats +1

Because there isn't much of a community left that is actively interested in participating in the governance and moderation of the site. The majority of our decision to close the site is due to the fact that only very few people are taking on these aspects of the site; that's not healthy and it simply won't scale to the amount of drive-by traffic that the site is currently seeing.

The user retention here is quite frankly, for lack of a better word, abysmal. People come and ask their questions which are either closed or answered, then they go on about what they were doing, mostly coming from search engines. Right now:

  • 270 out of 393 users around the 150 rep mark are gone
  • 75 out of 133 users around the 500 rep mark are gone
  • 5 out of 17 users around the 3k rep mark are gone
  • 2 out of 6 users around the 10k rep mark are gone

This paints a very troubling picture. The established users we have are leaving in percentages greater than or equal to 1/3 of what we had, and they're not being replenished by new members that find the site and become engaged with the concept of community and more importantly community moderation. You can't put this task on the shoulders of just a few, and that's what it has boiled down to - it's simply not a tenable situation, and it's continuing to deteriorate.

Our decision to put the site back through area 51 was mostly aimed at ensuring that the topic was defined better, and had a substantial more involved community behind it. We could talk about the scope of the site, come up with better custom close reasons and tweak our help center articles but that doesn't work well when we don't have very many users interested in maintaining the site. Additionally, after 3+ years in beta, the site positively can't sustain a democratic moderator election - there just aren't enough active users to do it.

I didn't want to get too oddly-specific regarding this when I wrote the post saying that the site was going to close, because those of you that remained have been doing what you could for the site despite overwhelming evidence that it just wasn't working.

Only now, after the notice has been posted did we begin talking about what to talk about, and there aren't many people at this table. This could be a great site and a great topic, but it's going to need quite a few more people behind it to make it work.

In the absence of the community taking moderation into their hands, the moderators had to make quite a few unilateral decisions. That's not their fault - and it can't continue.
+1 for te hats. Let's have some fun after the last scary times for Answers.OnStartups

I can't speak for the community as a whole, but I can speak for myself, so that's what I'll do.

I think your question can be divided up into two different scenarios. First, six months ago, why didn't we get this all straightened out, before the site got a go-dead date? Second, why haven't we started a discussion about this since the announcement?

For the former case, I never felt like I had the power or the clout on the site to try to push through real change. It always felt like something that could have and should have been initiated by somebody with more clout, more reputation, or perhaps just more moderator-y. I couldn't be sure if I was the only one who felt like the site had problems, or if everyone else was seeing it too.

Of course, once the announcement was made, the rules suddenly changed. If the death of the side was impending, who cares how much clout or reputation you have. But on this side of that kind of revelation, it's hard to feel motivated to start the discussion going. Heck, it's even hard to want to participate in the discussion even if somebody else gets it started. It feels futile.

We need to feel like our efforts could pay off before investing in that path forward. In fact, we've tried to start this discussion, and when we do, it's not long before the Stack Exchange admins/moderators come along to reiterate that, "no, the site is still going to be shut down." (Let's not confuse the SE admins with the moderators for this specific site, who do seem interested in fixing things.)

Since the decision, I've been doing what I can to try to fight the battle to allow us some time to try to work things out. For me, that's the battle to win first, before we can start figuring out how to change.

I, for one, am more than willing to try to get this site working. I've found it fun to be a part of this community, and I feel like I've learned a lot from smart people that I have a lot of respect for. I want that to be around for myself and for other people who try to build their own startups. If we can convince them to keep the site around on life support for a while longer, I'd be more than happy to help in the rebuilding process.

While most here have blamed the problem on the guidelines and the number of closed questions, I don't feel that's where the issue is. As a past moderator who tried to answer a lot of questions, my main issue is the extremely low level of quality of the questions themselves.

We seem to get random traffic from people who are just getting started trying to run a company in their spare time. Imagine if Stack Overflow was full of questions about how to type your first program and where the enter key is... Stack Overflow works for me because it has insightful questions.
Is there a way to contact a user directly even if they have not shared their email ID? Does this portal have a private messaging capability?
row.Title: Contacting users directly

row.Body: Only moderators can send messages to members (for moderation purposes only) - The user decides whether or not to add public contact information on their profile.

I want to suggest a rebranding. The current brand focuses on start up businesses. Open up the brand and the scope to all levels of business management questions. Because of the title I know that I have been hesitant to ask general business questions at a MNC level.

At The Workplace we get quite a few business policy questions that are out of scope there. A rebranding to open up the scope here to feel more inclusive to more established and big business management questions could help there.

countering to the numbers given, I'd like to point out that:

  • 123 users around the 150 rep mark are still here
  • 58 users around the 500 rep mark are still here
  • 12 users around the 3k rep mark are still here
  • 4 users around the 10k rep mark are still here

This is not an insignificant shift of perspective.

I'm going to state what I feel is the biggest potential problem for this site, going forward. This assumes, to a degree, that the site still hangs around for us to refactor/cleanup, instead of getting shut down, but it may be relevant even then.

Trying my best to be an impartial observer, the problem I see is that there seems to be two emerging sides as to where to go next, and they don't appear to play nice together.

One one hand, you have the "Moderator Reductionists" (yes, it's just a silly name I invented, don't anybody be too offended or anything) that feel the biggest problem here is over-zealous moderation, or perhaps rules that are too restrictive. For these people, the best way to fix the problem is to relax all of the rules as far as they can reasonably be relaxed, and then tighten them again where we see problems. Their reasoning is that the biggest problem is that we're turning away too many new people by shutting down their questions.

On the other hand, you have the people who say, "Noobs always ask, 'How does I do the strat up?'" (again, don't be offended, I'm just trying to be lighthearted.) For them, the biggest issue is that there are a lot of people who are asking really simple, really basic questions (which they should have just Googled first), or are asking questions with no correct answer. The concern is that there is massive amounts of low quality questions.

In all of this, I have a few questions. Feel free to answer any or all of them in your responses.

  1. Does this seem like a fair assessment? Do other people see this happening too, or am I pulling this problem out of thin air?
  2. Are these two sides as opposite as it feels?
  3. Is there any middle ground here? Tim Post was not wrong when he brought up the instabilities in the community (high-rep users who have left, etc.). I worry about picking one path or the other and losing the other half of the community that feels like we're heading in the wrong direction. (Should I be worried about that?)

I'm less concerned right now about what steps should actually be taken next, and I'd prefer to use this question as a way for us to openly and honestly assess how things currently sit, to answer the question, do we have a battle/dilemma brewing here?
row.Title: It appears we have a stalemate with where to go from here

row.Body: +1 for hats. As far as reboot, how come? Not enough users?
